HEADLINE: Spreading the Word in the South Bronx;
In a World Stripped of Luxuries, Mormon Missionaries Help Faith Take Root

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
Soon after arriving in New York last December, Kevin Mower sidled up to a young woman on the subway and tried to engage her in conversation.
His subject: Jesus Christ.
Her response: first, stony silence, and then this piece of advice: "Don't mix and mingle too much." 
 Mr. Mower never did pay much attention to her caution. Instead, the 20-year-old Mormon missionary and his colleague, Lance Kammer, have trudged countless miles through the South Bronx, spending 12-hour days seeking converts to the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Dressed in neat suits and white shirts, the two elders look more like junior G-men, drawing wary glances as they travel along streets where idle youths laze outside bodegas, single mothers scurry into housing projects and shaky parents line up outside Family Court. Although they believe a child of God is behind every door they approach, getting that door to open is often difficult.
The church's worldwide outreach program with nearly 50,000 missionaries, 400 of them in the New York metropolitan area, is one reason why it has grown steadily, from about 900,000 in 1950 to almost nine million members. Much of that growth has come in Third World nations, especially in Africa and Latin America.
Although the church had been accused of racism in the past, when blacks were excluded from the priesthood, church officials said the growth in such areas is proof that they welcome nonwhites. Blacks were admitted to the priesthood in 1978 after the church's president, Spencer W. Kimball, said he had a revelation.
As a result, the faith has also taken root among disaffected Protestants and Catholics struggling to survive in communities like the Melrose section of the Bronx, where Mr. Kammer and Mr. Mower live and work. Church officials said that the Bronx and Manhattan produce about 50 converts a month.
At first glance, the sight of white, middle-class missionaries ministering to residents of a predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhood may seem incongruous, but scholars of the church say the appeal of the faith -- with its emphasis on self-improvement, community and family values and lay leadership -- has been consistent since it was founded in 1830 in upstate New York.
Richard Bushman, a history professor at Columbia and author of "Joseph Smith and the Beginnings of Mormonism," said that just as Mormonism flourished among English workers who migrated to America, villagers who moved to cities and laborers who aspired to the middle class, it is now finding an audience among members of minority groups seeking to become part of the larger society.
"The Mormon church is helpful in taking middle-class, modern skills in an atmosphere where there is very little judgment or criticism involved," said Mr. Bushman, who is Mormon. "It has always had a primary appeal to the marginal individual and makes them mainstream."
The young missionaries of Melrose have come to know those margins well. "New York is dying for people who have a good ear and a good heart," Mr. Mower said. "I can say a few words, listen to somebody and do miracles."
Lillian Rivera was not looking for miracles few months ago when she first spotted some missionaries on Fordham Road. She paused to talk, she said, because she thought they were cute. But a first conversation led to more visits from the missionaries and more discussions about their faith.
"They made it fun to learn, and they were my age," said Ms. Rivera, who was raised a Jehovah's Witness. "Most of the things they said made sense. In other religions, they tell you something and you ask why it is and they say that's the way God presented it to me. Here, they explain."
They must have been persuasive: last September, she was baptized. And although her friends accused her of pulling an oddball stunt when she joined the church, she has come to shrug off their teasing.
"I just want to lead a calm life," said Ms. Rivera, a single mother of two. "I'm not looking for a man or anything. I have my children already. I just want peace of mind. Doesn't everybody look for that?"
She said she still did not understand the missionaries, how they could put their lives on hold, leaving behind family and not dating for two years. (The church encourages every 19-year-old man and every 21-year-old woman to do missionary work.) She was committed, she said, but not like that.
But Mr. Kammer never doubted her commitment, noting that she attends church regularly and contributes her tithe, as is customary. Now, he wants her to give a testimony at church, coaxing her to overcome her fear of public speaking.
"She lives the gospel in a quiet way," he said. "On the inside, she has really grown up."
The missionaries live the gospel, too, in this unlikely locale, where they are jolted awake by nighttime gunplay and where they can see young men selling and smoking crack on the stoop outside their apartment on Sheridan Avenue.
Their apartment is spartanly furnished: beds, dressers, a sagging sofa and religious posters. The only new items are piles of Mormon videotapes, books and tracts. On one wall, the Wall of Honor, they have nailed worn-out shoes and the charred remnants of ties they burned to mark the six-month point in their missions.
Mr. Mower, who is from Jerome, Idaho, and Mr. Kammer, who grew up in Chattanooga, Tenn., said their time in the Bronx has given them an appreciation for the comforts they left behind and the neighbors they now embrace.
"It's a mystery to me, but the people here are wonderful," Mr. Kammer said. "There are a lot of humble people and a lot of people who have a strong belief in God."
In a world stripped of luxuries and focused on an unyielding drive to spread the word, both now say that what matters most is service.
"The poorest person in the world can find as much happiness as a rich man can," Mr. Mower said. "It's in the way you live your life and the service you give to others, not the things you get for yourself."
Trying to put people at ease, the missionaries often approach people with a smile and a quick pitch for the message of Jesus Christ and family happiness. They try, sometimes succeeding in the span of an elevator ride, to arrange an appointment to visit the person in his or her home rather than preach on the street.
"Preaching on the street, people can't feel the message in their heart," Mr. Kammer said. "Our message is conveyed by the spirit, and the spirit dwells in peaceful and comfortable situations."
He said only about 10 to 20 percent of their contacts continue after the first discussion.
One of those contacts was with Milton Bonilla, 19, who was baptized in Ecuador before his family moved to the Bronx. He and his sister, Ivonne, 17, often invite the missionaries to their family's cramped apartment for a home-cooked meal and religious discussion.
The missionaries have helped the family in turn, assisting Ivonne with her college application to Brigham Young University, the church's school in Provo, Utah. She said a glance out her window was all she needed to see that a brighter future lay elsewhere.
"The university belongs to the church and there are young people like me," she said. "Here, there are none. It's difficult here because no one shares your values."
Her brother credited the church with instilling in him a sense of service and confidence that led him to volunteer at a hospital for a year before being hired.
"I used to be the kind of person who never thought positive," he said. "In the church, I became more positive, and after a while it didn't matter if I got paid or not. I just loved helping out people. This is my payoff from God."

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: THE BUDGET;
Clinton Aide Criticizes G.O.P. Plans for Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget director said today that it was nonsense for Republicans to suggest that tax cuts would pay for themselves by stimulating economic activity. The director insisted that such cuts had to be offset by reductions in Federal spending.
The director, Alice M. Rivlin, said she feared that the Republicans taking charge of Congress would lead the nation into "a tax-cutting frenzy" that would increase the Federal budget deficit. She thus attacked an economic theory that has been an article of faith for many Republicans, including those who orchestrated the Republican takeover of the House. 
 Those Republicans contend that tax cuts would rejuvenate the economy and generate large amounts of new revenue.
Ms. Rivlin's comments, at a breakfast meeting with journalists, were the first sign of a political counterattack by the Administration, suggesting that the White House might actively resist a central element of the Republican agenda for the next Congress.
Ms. Rivlin said she worried that the Republicans would "throw fiscal discipline to the winds in the name of tax cutting, that we will have dishonest numbers and questionable budget scoring and that we will end up with a bigger budget deficit."
Reducing the deficit is one of the Administration's proudest achievements. For the year that ended on Sept. 30 the deficit was $203 billion, down $87 billion from the record set in 1992.
Ms. Rivlin expressed concern that the Republicans, having won control of Congress last week with promises to cut taxes for the middle class, would "give away the very hard-won fiscal discipline that we've had."
She expressed grave doubts about the merits of the tax cuts in 1981 that laid the foundation for the Reagan revolution and are regarded as a model by many Republicans who are taking power on Capitol Hill.
"I am not sounding the alarm on tax cuts per se," Ms. Rivlin said. "I am saying that tax cuts must be paid for. Tax cuts without spending cuts would increase the budget deficit and would be an irresponsible thing to do."
Republicans say they want to amend the Constitution to require a balanced budget by the year 2002, but they have not specified what programs they would cut to achieve that goal. By their own estimate, the package of Republican promises known as the Contract With America would cost $148 billion over five years.
Ms. Rivlin said it was a delusion to imagine that tax cuts would generate sufficient economic activity to offset the loss of Federal revenue.
"We saw attempts to do this in the 1980's," Ms. Rivlin, a former president of the American Economic Association, said. "The allegation is that tax cuts don't cost revenue, because if you cut taxes, the economy would grow so rapidly that you would get all the revenue back, and therefore tax cuts are, in a sense, free. That nonsense goes by the name of dynamic scoring, and it's a license to bust the budget."
Later today, in a speech to an ecstatic conservative audience, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who is in line to be House Speaker, defended his theory of economic and tax policy.
"There's no question that lower taxes and greater economic productivity to increase the size of the general economy do work," said Mr. Gingrich, who proudly described himself as a Reaganite. "In fact, in the Reagan years, we doubled revenue to the Federal Government while cutting taxes. We didn't lose revenue."
But Mr. Gingrich accepted Ms. Rivlin's invitation to cut Government spending along with taxes. "There's a lot of spending cuts we ought to make," he said. "We ought to make them both to be able to have tax cuts and because we want a smaller government."
To celebrate Republican control of Congress, Mr. Gingrich said, there will be "a very low-cost dinner on the night of Jan. 3 open to every middle-class working American" who can go to Washington. In addition, he said, in the first 100 days of the new Congress, Republicans will read their Contract With America at the start of each House session, and each Republican lawmaker may be given a laminated copy of the document.
Mr. Gingrich's audience, made up of people who had donated at least $1,000 to the conservative Heritage Foundation, cheered him lustily. Thomas B. MacCabe Jr., who owns a small business in Montgomeryville, Pa., said Mr. Gingrich's remarks were inspiring.
Beverly Danielson of Coral Gables, Fla., said, "It was fabulous." She particularly liked the defense of traditional middle-class values in contrast to the "liberal counterculture."
At her breakfast Ms. Rivlin focused on the arithmetic of the Republican platform. If taxes are cut without parallel cuts in Federal spending, she said, it will put "enormous upward pressure on interest rates."
"We're at full employment now or very close to it," Ms. Rivlin said, adding that this is a "singularly bad time" to cut taxes. "If you had a big tax cut right now and people were spending more, the inflationary danger would be much more real than it is now. You'd have rapid increases in interest rates and probably throw the economy into recession. In fact, something like that did happen in the 80's."
For years many Republicans have complained that the Congressional Budget Office did not take into account increases in savings, investment and productivity that might result from cuts in personal and corporate income taxes, as well as on capital gains. The Republicans have said they will revamp the estimating procedures to reflect such potential windfalls.
Ms. Rivlin said injecting such wild speculations into estimates was "a recipe for escalating the budget deficit, for busting the budget."
Mr. Gingrich said the House would probably vote on Jan. 19 on the proposed constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget. He predicted a smashing victory.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, met today with Republican leaders to discuss possible areas of cooperation. He and Ms. Rivlin said those included trade, welfare, regulation of lobbyists and limits on campaign contributions.

Gingrich Announces Preference
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (Special to The New York Times) -- Representative Newt Gingrich announced today that he would support a longtime ally, Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania, in a three-way contest for the No. 3 leadership position in the House.
Mr. Walker, who is beginning his 19th year in Congress, is running against Tom DeLay of Texas and Bill McCollum of Florida for majority whip. Representative Dick Armey of Texas faces no opposition in his pursuit of the No. 2 job, majority leader.
Mr. Gingrich's press secretary, Tony Blankley, said tonight that Mr. Gingrich, who is expected to become Speaker, would vote for Mr. Walker but not actively campaign for him.

HEADLINE: President-Elect In Brazil Aided By State Races

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15

 BODY:
In victories likely to strengthen the free-market mandate of President-elect Fernando Henrique Cardoso, the governors' seats in Brazil's three most powerful states went to his allies today, according to preliminary returns and voter surveys.
"Fernando Henrique Cardoso will emerge from today's voting as the strongest President of the republican era," Teodomiro Braga, a political columnist, predicted, referring to Brazil's century-old system of elected government. "Until today, no President elected by the people had the support of the majority in Congress and of the governors of Sao Paulo, Minas Gerais and Rio, states that represent 55 percent of the Brazilian GNP." 
 Bolstering Mr. Cardoso's ambitions to keep Latin America's largest economy on a low inflation-high growth track through the end of the 1990's, voters have elected Cardoso supporters as governors in 8 of Brazil's 10 most populous states. State governors strongly influence state delegations to Congress.
After a decade of elections that produced legislatures hostile to Brazilian presidents, today's results were anxiously awaited by American stock market investors, company executives and exporters.
Betting that Mr. Cardoso would be inaugurated President on Jan. 1 with a strong congressional base, Americans pumped $1 billion into Brazil's stock markets this year, making markets here the fastest growing in the world. Next month, Sao Paulo's stock market is expected to surpass Mexico City's to become the largest in Latin America.
Around the world, Brazil now ranks third, after China and Mexico, for planned investments by American multinational companies, according to a new survey of company executives by Ernst & Young LLP, the American accounting firm. This year, Brazil is expected to receive $2 billion in foreign investments.
With Brazil's imports jumping by 17 percent during the first 10 months of this year, Mr. Cardoso has vowed to accelerate the trade opening by abolishing import licenses and bureaucratic obstacles that swelled Brazil's trade surpluses for 25 years.

HEADLINE: Clinton Devises New Guidelines On Arms Sales

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Making explicit a policy that has existed in practice for three years, the Clinton Administration is preparing new guidelines that will consider the health of the nation's military contractors when reviewing arms sales to foreign countries.
Such sales require approval from the United States Government, which has ruled on arms sales in the past based on whether they bolstered American foreign policy goals and strengthen regional alliances. Under a plan now before the President, a sale's benefit to the nation's shrinking military industry would also be considered. 
 With Pentagon orders rapidly declining, foreign sales now account for about 20 percent of American military contractors' business. Foreign sales are single-handedly keeping alive the M1-A2 tank line of General Dynamics in Ohio and the F-15 fighter plane lines of McDonnell-Douglas in Missouri.
Beginning with the Bush Administration, the Government has played an increasingly active role in lobbying foreign capitals on the behalf of American contractors. Washington pays some costs to field American weaponry at international trade shows. Embassy officials, who once were forbidden to promote United States arms, now hawk American-made military wares as aggressively as any other product stamped "Made in the U.S.A."
The new policy of making domestic economic consideration a formal part of reviews of arms sales is awaiting the President's signature; Mr. Clinton favors the approach. The President can adopt such a policy change by executive order.
The new policy was first reported today in The Los Angeles Times. White House and Pentagon officials emphasized today that foreign policy goals will still be paramount in guiding foreign sales.
"The basic reason for selling weapons overseas has been to advance our foreign policy goals," the Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, told reporters today. "It is not to create jobs in the United States."
Arms-control advocates said the new policy would encourage global arms races and make already volatile regions like the Middle East even less stable.
"If we keep pumping out as many arms as we can, how can we go to the Russians and say, 'Don't sell to the Iranians,' " said Thomas A. Cardamone Jr. of the Council for Livable World Education Fund, a group that advocates arms control.
But Administration and industry officials dismissed such arguments. They insisted that there were adequate safeguards to prevent illegal sales or transfers to rogue nations.
"This doesn't mean we'll now start selling fighter jets to Iraq," said Joel L. Johnson, vice president for international affairs at the Aerospace Industries Association, a trade group in Washington. "At the margin, it might mean making a call in one direction or another, or releasing a system a little earlier for export than before."
Since the breakup of the former Soviet Union, the United States' share of arms sales worldwide has increased to about 55 percent, from 25 percent. But that reflects more the decline in sales by the former Soviet republics than a sharp increase in total American sales, which have risen only slightly.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Bond Yield Dips After Fed's Tightening

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The long end of the Treasury market rallied yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced its sixth and largest interest rate increase of the year, easing traders' fears of inflation.
By late in the day, the 30-year bond was up 8/32 , to a price of 9327/32 , for a yield of 8.05 percent, down from 8.07 percent on Monday. Despite the rise in the long end of the Treasury market, prices in shorter maturities were mixed. 
 The central bank raised short-term rates three-quarters of a percent, a quarter-point more than many had predicted. Expectations were running high as the Federal Open Market Committee met to determine monetary policy for the months ahead.
While investors and dealers were expecting a rise of at least 50 basis points in the discount and Federal funds rates, they were hoping for something a little more aggressive -- and got it. The Fed lifted the discount rate that it charges banks for loans to 4.75 percent and the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for money, usually overnight, to 5.5 percent.
With yesterday's increase, the Fed has now pushed short-term rates up 250 basis points since February in its quest to slow down the economy and head off inflation. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said he did not think the tightening was over yet. "The economic trends that prompted the F.O.M.C. to move today will still be quiet evident in five weeks, and as a result, I would not rule out another rate hike at the next meeting on Dec. 20," he said.
The 75-basis-point increase was the biggest since May 1981, when the Fed raised the discount rate by 100 points, to 14 percent. Inflation then was in double digits; at an annual rate, it is now less than 3 percent.
 Mr. Fine noted that yesterday's increase appeared to many in the financial markets to be a compromise between those on the committee who wanted 50 basis points and those who sought 100. "Unless the economy slows noticeably between now and the next F.O.M.C. meeting, it stands to reason that those who were willing to go 100 today would likely be just as willing to move again in December," he said.
Market analysts noted the list of options open to the Fed included increases of 50 basis points in the funds and discount rates, 75 basis points in both, 100 in both, or a split of 50 in the funds and 100 for the discount.
Alan Krol, a portfolio manager for Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., an investment management firm, said yesterday that even with the Fed's tightening process now nine months old, "We still don't have all the signs of inflation that everyone has alluded to."
Mr. Krol added, "We also think the issue has been and remains: Is the Fed in front of the curve or behind it?" His answer is that 50 basis points were already priced into the market and that the extra 25 points yesterday added to the Fed's credibility.
Before the Fed meeting, which ended around 1 P.M., traders' continuing concerns over inflation were heightened by two economic reports, higher-than-expected October retail sales and industrial production. Still, investors were reluctant to take any position before knowing where interest rates were headed and how fast, so there was little activity in the market.
Industrial production rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, after a revised decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in September, as capacity use rose to 84.9 percent in October from a revised 84.5 percent in September. Many economists had expected that industrial production on average would rise six-tenths of 1 percent, and that capacity would go up to 84.9 percent.
October retail sales rose 1.1 percent, the Commerce Department reported, or six-tenths of a percent without including autos. That was substantially ahead of economists' expectations of six-tenths of 1 percent over all and four-tenths of 1 percent excluding autos.

The Economy
 The sharpest increase in interest rates since 1981 was made by the Federal Reserve. The central bank raised the discount rate and the Federal funds rate by three-quarters of a percentage point each. Big banking companies, including Citicorp, soon followed suit, raising the minimum rates they charge for loans. [Page A1.] 
 The move to raise interest rates intensifies a debate on whether such increases are necessary. Manufacturers and labor have joined to oppose the rate increase, saying it would slow growth too much. And some question whether the data cited for the Fed policy accurately reflect the state of the economy. [A1.]
 Bumper crops, which bring low prices and increased Government supports, are likely to spell political problems for farmers. [D1.]
 United States industry surged in October. Industrial utilization posted its biggest jump since March 1980. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Guidelines For Classes On Civics Are Issued

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
National educational standards for civics and government were announced today, provoking less criticism than did the recently unveiled standards for American and world history.
Noting that only 37 percent of the electorate voted in last week's midterm election, some of the participants at today's announcement in a chamber at the United States Supreme Court saw a connection between the lack of civics teaching and the decline in what Thomas Jefferson called "enlightened people." 
 "The strength and vitality of American democracy depend on insuring that our young people develop the knowledge, skills and dispositions necessary to become informed and responsible participants in our system of self-government," said Charles N. Quigley, executive director of the Center for Civic Education, a nonprofit group that helped develop the standards.
Often it is assumed that civics is covered by history teachers, but Mr. Quigley described the subject as "one of the most neglected areas of education in the U.S."
He added, "Jefferson assumed we need an enlightened citizenry to run a democracy, but people need to have a road map in mind."
The civics and government standards were developed with financing from the Education Department and the Pew Charitable Trusts and are part of a broad national effort to set voluntary standards for what children should know in academic subjects by the time they leave 4th, 8th and 12th grades.
The standards were developed over more than a decade, with discussions among more than 3,000 scholars, teachers and others.
Under the standards, students are expected to discuss five major areas: what are civic life, politics and government; what are the foundations of the American political system; how does the government established by the Constitution embody the purposes, values and principles of American democracy; what is the relationship of the United States to other nations and to world affairs, and what are the roles of the citizen in American democracy.
The standards say that even kindergarten students should be able to provide a basic description of government.
"If citizens do not understand the political process and how to deal with it effectively, they may feel overwhelmed and alienated," the standards for grades five to eight say. Children in these grades should be able to explain what is meant by the public agenda and describe how it is set, including the role of special interest groups, the press, the courts and individual citizens, the standards say.
In grades 9 through 12, the standards say, students should know the meaning of citizenship, the rights it confers and the responsibilities it carries.
At this stage, the standards say, students should also be able to evaluate, take and defend positions on personal, political and economic rights and obligations, like obeying the law, voting, paying taxes and serving in the armed forces.
The standards announced today had a far more congenial reception than the recently unveiled voluntary standards for world and American history, which were criticized by both conservatives and liberals.
Today's standards, by contrast, were endorsed by groups as disparate as the National Association of Evangelicals and the American Federation of Teachers.
Voluntary national standards have also been established for math and the arts. The math standards were the first to be established, in 1989, and are being used in 40 percent of the nation's schools.

Chart: "FOR EXAMPLE: New Lessons in Civics"
 The importance of limited government. To achieve this standard, students should be able to:
 Explain why limited government is important for the protection of individual rights, such as:
 Personal rights to choose their own friends, believe what they wish, enjoy the privacy of their homes and practice the religion of their choice.
 Political rights to express their opinions, vote, meet or associate with others and ask government to change laws they think are unfair.
 Economic rights to choose the kind of work they please and own property.
 
5TH-8TH GRADE
 Defining civic life, politics and government. To achieve this standard, students should be able to:
 Define and distinguish between private and civic life.
 Describe politics as the ways people whose ideas may differ reach agreements that are generally regarded as binding on the group.
 Describe government as the people and institutions with authority to make, carry jout, enforce laws and manage disputes about law.
 
HIGH SCHOOL
 How does the American political system provide for choice and opportunities for participation? Students should be able to:
 Explain the meaning and importance of freedom of the press.
Evaluate the role in American politics of television, radio, the press, newsletters, data bases and emerging means of communication, e.g., the Internet, faxes, electronic mail.
 Compare and contrast various forms of political persuasion and discuss the extent to which traditional forms have been replaced by electronic media.
 Explain how Congress, the President, and state and local public officals use the media to communicate with the citizenry.

HEADLINE: A Debate on the Greater Evil: Inflation or Chill or Pink Slips

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision to increase interest rates by the largest amount in years intensified a debate that focuses not so much on the amount of the rise but whether the Federal Reserve should have acted at all.
On one side are those who applauded the Federal Reserve's action, most of them on Wall Street. They are challenged by an unlikely coalition of manufacturers and labor leaders who charged that yesterday's increase would slow the economy too much, cutting back sales and eliminating jobs. 
 The word from Wall Street is that the economy is still too strong and that the central bank will have to raise rates again by early next year to control inflation.
"This increase is entirely justified, but it is not the last one in this cycle," said Henry Kaufman, a money manager, bond trader and economist in New York. "At some point in the next three months, they will have to act again. The economy is too strong to be greatly affected or slowed by the present level of rates."
Mr. Kaufman predicted that the key short-term lending rate controlled by the Federal Reserve, which now stands at 5.5 percent, would have to reach 7 percent before the economy begins to respond. Only then will there be a slowdown in auto sales, home construction, consumer borrowing and the numerous other activities that now keep the American economy growing briskly.
But for Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday's Fed move may prove to be the straw that breaks the back of the economy. And unnecessarily so, he argued.
"The Fed is fundamentally misreading the American economy," Mr. Jasinowski said. "They ought to get out from behind their desks and see what is really happening in plants and on factory floors across the country."
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. agreed. "What they are doing," said John Zalusky, an economist at the labor federation, "is coming down on the side of the bloody bondholders who don't want inflation to undermine the value of their bonds."
Just as industry and organized labor put aside differences to oppose a rate increase, Wall Street also closed ranks behind the Fed's action. Mr. Kaufman's sentiments echoed across the financial markets, silencing an internal squabble between those who had favored a bigger rate increase -- perhaps a full percentage point -- and others who had said that half a percentage point would be enough to slow the economy. Slower growth in turn reduces the risk of sharply rising prices.
David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street bond house, was in the camp that believed a half-point increase was enough to do the job for the moment.
"Alan Greenspan is starting to fall into a pattern," Mr. Jones said, referring to the Federal Reserve chairman. "He is analyzing the data slowly between increases and recognizing the possibility that the economy might be able to grow more strongly than in the past, without more inflation."
There have been six rate increases so far, spread out over the last 10 months.
Mr. Jones touched on a theme that increasingly concerns the Clinton Administration, as well as many economists outside Wall Street. Even some officials at the Federal Reserve are starting to question whether or not the economy has changed so profoundly that it has more capacity for growth without inflation than generally believed.
None of that wondering was evident yesterday. The Federal Reserve, in a statement explaining the latest rate increase -- the biggest since 1981 -- said its action was taken against "persistent strength in economic activity and high and rising resource utilization."
That means the economy is running out of workers, as measured by the nation's low 5.8 percent unemployment rate. Moreover, companies cannot increase their output of goods and services, as measured by the so-called capacity utilization rate, because it has reached a very high 84.9 percent through October.
The Federal Reserve acted on those statistics, preferring -- at least for now -- not to challenge the message embedded in them. The fear is that all sorts of shortages might soon develop, and these shortages will drive up wages and prices, making the inflation rate spurt.
The stakes, of course, are enormous. If the Federal Reserve manages to slow the economy prematurely out of excessive concern about inflation, unemployment will rise and people with jobs will have less leverage to get raises.
Some Federal Reserve policy makers, in off-the-record interviews, are beginning to wonder if the data tell an accurate story. Those doubts, however, have not yet reached the financial markets.
"If the Fed were to bet on the notion that the data was inaccurate, and the bet was wrong, then the inflation genie would get out of the bottle," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "So we can't afford to bet on that notion."
Like the Federal Reserve, the Clinton Administration is reluctant to challenge the official data. But economists at the White House and in the Treasury are exploring the possibilities that the American economy is capable of stronger growth than the 2.5 percent annual increase in economic output that many analysts believe is the maximum sustainable rate.
"We have had a lot of investment in the past several years, and particularly in the past three years," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers. Heavy investment in computers and machinery may have made the economy much more productive. "If that is true," she said, "then maybe we are underestimating the economy's potential."
Indeed, private industry's efforts to increase production through numerous efficiencies may give the economy enough extra output to avoid the shortages that bring higher prices.
"There is no evidence of capacity pressures," said Mr. Jasinowski of the manufacturers association. "The Federal Reserve's measurements are too restrictive."

HEADLINE: City Council Offers Plans On Budget

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Opening negotiations with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over his plan to close a $1.1 billion budget gap with deep spending cuts, the City Council revealed a wish list of alternatives yesterday, including the creation of an authority to oversee recycling, an increase in taxi medallions and the consolidation of nearly a dozen of New York City's agencies.
The Council's plan also included charging more for licenses and permits, turning the Staten Island Ferry over to the state and eliminating 2 of the 12 paid holidays city employees now receive. The Council also proposed raising money by leasing the 79th Street Boat Basin, franchising Offtrack Betting parlors and selling air rights above city buildings, including City Hall, to real-estate developers to raise cash. 
 Council officials acknowledged that many of the proposals were unlikely to occur soon, if at all. The number of taxicabs, for example, has been fixed at 11,787 since 1931, and any changes in the industry would require months of probably contentious hearings.
The officials, however, said that the Council's plan would serve as a starting point for talks with the Mayor's office over its proposal to balance the city's $31.6 billion budget and offer long-term solutions to recurring deficits.
"A significant amount of this will require a commitment by the administration to reduce bureaucracy in government," said Thomas L. McMahon, director of the Council's finance division.
The Mayor's senior aide, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, said the administration would consider some of the proposals but needed realistic ways to cut costs immediately.
"In the short time we have this year, I don't know how you save money with consolidations right now," Mr. Powers said, adding that the Mayor's office would considerconsolidating agencies in future. "Right now, whatever we do, we have to come up with hard dollars."
The Council's budget plan came as its committees continued to hold public hearings this week on the Mayor's proposed cuts.
In all, the plan the Council offered yesterday identified $300 million in savings or revenues that could be used to avert some of what officials say are the most drastic elements of the Mayor's plan.
The report, however, did not list the proposed cuts the Council would resist, though officials have said it would try to reverse cuts in financing for soup kitchens, programs for the mentally retarded and civilians in the Police Department.
The Council has two more weeks to approve or reject the Mayor's modification of the budget that took effect more than four months ago, or to negotiate changes in it with the Mayor. The Council plans to take a vote on the Mayor's plan on Nov. 23.
Even though it has the power to reject the plan, the Council appears to have little room to maneuver, since its leaders agree on the size of the budget shortfall and the necessity of closing it without new taxes.
In its plan, however, the Council criticized the Mayor, saying that despite pledges to do so, his budget fails to improve the delivery of services. "In short, the across-the-board cutting method has caused services to be delivered poorly across the board," the Council said in a 35-page report outlining its proposals.
The Council proposed merging several agencies: the Mayor's Office of Operations with the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget; the Sheriff's Office with the Department of Finance; the Economic Development Corporation with the Department of Business Services, and the Landmarks Commission with the Department of City Planning.
The Council proposed creating a recycling authority to finance the city's recycling program by using the nickels from unredeemed bottle deposits. Creating the authority, like many others parts of the Council's plan, would require the approval of the State Legislature.

HEADLINE: Jackson Journal;
The Rich Are Different. They Can Afford Homes.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo.

 BODY:
In all the sweet-breathed valleys of the West, there is no designation more feared than being labeled "the next Aspen," a reference to the Colorado ski town where the rich gather like deer to a salt lick.
In mountain hamlets on the pivot between being a pleasant hideaway and a destination resort, people watch real estate prices like heart monitors. An uptick is welcomed, at first, but is soon followed by alarm, and then a full-fledged civic crisis. 
 So it is in Jackson Hole, where news that the average home is selling for $561,000 has caused a considerable amount of hand-wringing. On Halloween, a woman labeled her costume "affordable housing in Jackson." She was wearing a box.
Staring at the high ceilings inside the 51,000 square feet of the new National Wildlife Art Museum here, Ed Marston said, "If they had just added another few thousand square feet this could be a home in Jackson."
Mr. Marston, editor of "High Country News," a Western weekly, said the clutter of trophy houses in Jackson Hole gave him renewed appreciation for his home in Paonia, Colo. "It's a wonderful town," he said. "But luckily it's still rundown."
Shadowed by the hard shoulders of the Teton Mountains and carved by the Snake River, Jackson Hole can move even the most jaded of urban visitors to light-headed exuberance.
The air, at 6,200 feet on the valley floor, is perfumed with seasonal smells. Two national parks, Yellowstone and Grand Teton, are neighbors. In the town of Jackson, there are wood-planked sidewalks, a new hospital next to the largest winter elk refuge in the world, and more than two dozen art galleries. For vertical enthusiasts, the Swiss Alps can hardly match the skiing here.
But for all of that, what Jackson now lacks are homes for teachers, firefighters, waiters, police officers and assorted others who earn their living serving people who come here to play or live on a grand ranch.
Surrounded by mostly poor counties in the boom-and-bust state of Wyoming, Jackson has taken on the look of a golden ghetto. The sunsets against the Teton Range are still free, unless the view is framed by timbers and close to a bathroom. This year one house sold for $4 million; another, with 13 fireplaces, is the talk of the valley. But the sheriff's department was unable to hire two recruits because they could not afford to live here.
At the Antler Motel, Clarene Law puts her 40 employees up in trailers and small cabins. It is the only way, she said, to hold onto the bed-changers, clerks and laundry cleaners who keep the motel running.
Other workers make 80-mile daily commutes over Teton Pass to places like Driggs, Idaho. In winter, the 8,249-foot pass is treacherous, and the commute has taken its toll. Mrs. Law said she had lost three hotel workers to death from car accidents.
From 1989 to the middle part of this year, the average price of a single-family home in Jackson Hole went up 38 percent a year, according to a study done by Jonathan Schechter, a management consultant. For the first six months of this year, the average selling price was $561,485, a 46 percent jump over last year's price.
While the boom has been good for some -- there are about 250 real estate agents competing for 900 or so sales a year, said Mr. Schechter -- it has raised property assessments -- and taxes -- to the point where many longtime residents have no choice but to sell, and it has caused a bit of a political revolt at the ballot box.
Residents of Teton County, which holds about 15,000 people, just voted to end a 2 percent tax on motel visitors. Because it hits tourists and spares the locals, the tax was thought to be a sure thing. But many people said they were angry that the money from the tax was used to promote Jackson.
A larger question is what happens when a town becomes homogenized by one economic group. In some ways, for the working poor and lower middle class, it may resemble the old company town -- with employees relying on their bosses for wages, food and housing. In other ways, it sets up sharp class conflicts, with new residents pushing for bans on trailer parks because they mar the view.
Jackson has a fledgling housing trust, which buys houses for the purpose of maintaining a base of moderately priced housing. The idea is to do for average folks what the Nature Conservancy does for wildlife -- establish a refuge, of sorts, off limits to further development. But so far there are barely a dozen units of housing in the trust.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A real estate boom has brought plenty of big houses, like this 17,000-square-foot log cabin, to Jackson, Wyo. But some residents say rising prices and taxes have put homes out of reach of teachers and firefighters. (Garth Dowling for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Space Telescope Leaves Scientists Puzzled About the Mass of the Universe

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
The Hubble Space Telescope looked deep into the sky and what it did not see has left cosmologists more mystified than ever about the unseen stuff out there, called dark matter, that may account for at least 90 percent of the universe's mass.
Astronomers using the orbiting telescope reported yesterday that their observations ruled out the possibility that dim small stars, known as red dwarfs, are plentiful enough to constitute much of the invisible mass. For almost three decades, this had been the most favored explanation by astronomers for the mass they could not see but could infer from gravitational forces shaping galactic structures. 
 The new finding seems to shift more of the burden of the search for missing matter from observational astronomers to particle physicists, who seek to explain the universe in terms of concepts drawn from theory and their atom-smashing experiments in powerful accelerators. Their current speculation is that the bulk of the universe may consist of strange hypothetical particles that have never been detected.
This setback in the search for the missing mass is the second time in a month that the repaired Hubble telescope has dealt a troubling blow to cosmologists' theories of the universe. Last month the telescope gave a measure of the expansion rate of the universe that implied its age could be as young as 8 billion years, even though its oldest stars have been measured as 16 billion.
In one of the new surveys with the Hubble telescope, astronomers showed that faint red dwarfs, which were thought to be abundant, are actually quite sparse in the Milky Way, Earth's galaxy. By extension, they must account for a negligible part of the cosmic mass.
Another astronomy team, working independently, determined that nature somehow does not favor stars with masses less than one-fifth that of the Sun. Few of these red dwarfs were observed in dense clusters where stars are born in profusion.
"Our results increase the mystery of the missing mass," said Dr. John N. Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., who led one research team. "They rule out a popular but conservative interpretation of dark matter."
Such a theory appealed to scientists because it would mean that nearly all of the cosmic mass could be attributed to something they knew existed, the ordinary matter made of neutrons and protons that is found in dim stars, failed stars, giant planets and everything on Earth.
If the missing mass was not ordinary matter, then scientists were forced to consider exotic alternatives that existed only in theory. One alternative is dark matter composed mainly of hypothetical particles called WIMP's, for weakly interacting massive particles.
Dr. Bahcall said the new findings seemed to call out for some such radical solution to the mystery of dark matter. "This is a day for particle physicists to celebrate," he said at a news conference at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington.
Determining the nature and amount of dark matter is one of the fundamental issues of cosmology. Astrophysicists have recently proposed many creative recipes for dark matter being combinations of ordinary and exotic matter. Some observations have showed the presence of considerable amounts of invisible matter in ordinary form at the edge of the Milky Way and other galaxies. Experiments are under way to see if WIMP's or other exotic matter can be detected.
The validity of most cosmic theories depends on solving the mystery. The inflation theory, a modification of the big-bang theory, holds that there was a rapid expansion immediately after the initial gigantic explosion creating the universe, after which things settled down to a more sedate pace.
The inflation theory predicts that the universe should be precisely balanced between eternal expansion and eventual collapse. If dark matter exceeds a critical density, the added gravitational power would cause the universe to collapse in what is being called the "big crunch." If dark matter is more tenuous, the universe could keep expanding into nothingness.
Theorists suggested that the lowest mass stars should be the most prevalent in the universe, and so might provide a solution for dark matter. According to stellar evolution theory, stars as small as 8 percent of the mass of the Sun are capable of shining by nuclear fusion processes, though they would be too dim to be visible from Earth.
By being able to detect faint stars 100 times dimmer than those seen from the ground, the Hubble telescope's main camera was used to conduct a comprehensive census of red dwarfs in the outer region of the Milky Way, known as its halo. Dr. Bahcall's team concluded that these dim stars constituted no more than 6 percent of the mass of the galaxy's halo and no more than 15 percent of the mass of the galactic disk. Since the Milky Way should be much like most other galaxies, the scientists said, this census should be representative of the universe at large.
The other team, led by Dr. Francesco Paresce of the European Space Agency and the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, confirmed those results with its own observations of the globular cluster NGC 6397, a dense collection of several hundred thousand stars in the Milky Way.
Dr. Bahcall's results were described in detail in the Nov. 1 issue of the Astrophysical Journal. Dr. Paresce's report is to appear in a later issue of the journal.

HEADLINE: Bills to Lift 3-Casino Limit Clear Panels in Legislature

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Mayor James Whelan's protestations that enough is enough fell on deaf ears today as two legislative committees released identical bills that would enable Donald Trump to seek his fourth casino license here.
Mr. Whelan said that while Mr. Trump is the city's biggest employer and taxpayer and does an outstanding job of promoting the city and his properties, he also "has a record of attempting to limit competition from other casinos in Atlantic City." 
 "A fourth casino would not only add to Mr. Trump's dominance of the casino market," the Mayor said, "it would also strengthen his control of the rest of our town's economy."
Other objections were raised by David J. Satz, a lawyer representing six casino operators who oppose removing the present three-casino limit for any one owner. He questioned the wisdom of allowing greater concentration of the city's casino industry in the hands of an organization "that has witnessed all three of its properties go through bankruptcy in the past four years."
Senator Bill Gormley, the Margate Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said the amendment to lift the three-casino limit "does not provide anyone a license, it provides an opportunity to apply for a license."
He said it would still be up to the Casino Control Commission to decide whether a fourth casino would give a licensee "undue economic influence."
Bradford Smith, the chairman of the commission, declined to take a position on the amendment but noted that new regulations will have to be written if the bill is enacted.
Nick Ribis, the chief executive officer of the Trump Organization's three casinos, did not testify, but outside the hearing room in the Atlantic City Convention Center, he called Mayor Whelan's remarks "the height of hypocrisy."
"His statement is a good reason why there is very little development in Atlantic City," Mr. Ribis said. "Instead of attacking the organization that pays the most taxes in the city, he should be getting rid of crime on the boardwalk and prostitutes on the streets."
The hearing today by the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Assembly Policy and Rules Committee was originally expected to be a pro forma release of a 66-page overhaul of the state's 17-year-old casino law that would allow gaming casinos greater autonomy over strictly business matters while retaining safeguards intended to insure the integrity of the industry.
On Oct. 21, Assemblyman John F. Gaffney, Republican of Linwood, proposed the amendment to eliminate the three-casino limit, and it immediately became the focus of the hearing. It was added to the overall realignment of casino regulations today just before the two committees released identical bills for votes in the full Senate and Assembly.
Mayor Whelan and others said the amendment was inspired by Mr. Trump, its lone beneficiary. Only one other concern, Bally's, with two gaming halls, operates more than one casino in the city.
Mr. Whelan said Mr. Trump was to have purchased the Trump Regency, a hotel without a gaming license, from Chemical Bank over the summer but was unable to settle due to a lack of financing.
"By changing the rules now, we are providing a financial bailout for Donald Trump," the Mayor said.
Thomas P. Ballezzi, executive director of the Casino Association, which represents the city's 11 casinos, spoke in support of the original bill, which would eliminate redundant activities by the Casino Control Commission and the Division of Gaming Enforcement in the Attorney General's office, stretch out the period for relicensing casinos from two to four years and drop the requirement for background checks on people employed strictly in the hotel portion of a casino property.
But Mr. Ballezzi said he could take no position on the lifting of the three-casino limit since the member casinos are divided over the issue.
Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian, the chief sponsor of the original bill in the Assembly, said it would remove "stifling" regulations and enable Atlantic City casinos to meet the growing competition from outside the state. When the industry began in 1978, its only competition was from Las Vegas. Now, 22 states have casinos or riverboats offering gaming. He took no position on the amendment removing the limit on casino ownership.
No date has been set for a vote by either legislative house, Mr. Gormley said.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has taken no position on the legislation.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
News Staff Faces Layoffs At Journal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The Wall Street Journal told more than a dozen members of its news staff yesterday that they would be laid off as part of a cost-cutting move, the newspaper's managing editor said in an interview.
The layoffs were the first at The Journal since 1989, when the paper was being squeezed by the recession and the downturn in financial advertising that followed the 1987 stock market crash. 
 "This is a necessity that no one likes, but we move on from it," said Paul E. Steiger, the managing editor, who runs The Journal's news operations. He said 13 members of The Journal's news staff were being notified yesterday by supervisors that they would be laid off.
With recent declines in both circulation and advertising, the newspaper also said on Friday that it would close one of its 18 printing plants in December to make its printing operations more efficient.
The closing of that plant, in Oklahoma City, will mean a loss of 20 jobs for production employees, said Roger B. May, a spokesman for the paper.
Some people in the newsroom and some newspaper securities analysts said they were surprised that a drive to cut newsroom costs was so urgent that it would include layoffs, since a number of people already leave the paper every year. The Journal has a total newsroom staff of more than 470.
A memo sent out by Mr. Steiger to newsroom staff members said he regretted the need for the layoffs and noted that the 13 people being laid off included managers, editors and reporters.
Mr. Steiger's memo added, "Assuming no dramatic declines in economic conditions, I don't expect further such actions this year or next."
The Journal's circulation and advertising have fallen over the last year. Daily circulation totaled more than 1.7 million in the six-month period ended Sept. 30, down 2 percent, or 38,140 copies daily, from a year earlier.
The newspaper's advertising linage declined an average of 3.2 percent, for the first three quarters of the year from a year earlier.
People at the paper said the advertising decline affected The Journal especially sharply because costs have been rising rapidly in the newspaper industry as a whole, particularly for newsprint.
Inside Dow Jones & Company, the paper's corporate parent, some people at the company said, the newspaper is under financial pressure because, although profitable, its revenues are growing more slowly than its costs.
Dow Jones does not provide separate information on the financial performance of its publications. But revenues in its business publication group, the majority of which come from The Journal, climbed 3.7 percent for the first three quarters of the year, compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, Mr. May said. Operating income climbed 5.3 percent.
But for Dow Jones as a whole, revenues were up 7.4 percent, while operating profit grew 18.5 percent, Mr. May said.
"It's a case of aligning costs and revenues," Mr. Steiger said. "We've had to do a number of things to trim costs in all departments, including the news department."
Mr. Steiger said he felt confident The Journal's news division budget would return to modest growth soon.
But some employees were not so optimistic in light of the layoffs. "It's like a death in the family," one reporter said. "You feel bad for the people and you feel, maybe, it could be you the next time around."

HEADLINE: U.S. Industry Had a Surge In October

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
American factories, mines and utilities stepped up their operating rate to nearly 85 percent of industrial capacity in October -- a level that had not been reached since 1980 during the Carter Administration.
A strong increase in output, pushing against industry's ability to turn out additional products without raising prices, contributed to the Federal Reserve's decision today to raise short-term interest rates yet again in an attempt to restrain the robust economy. 
 Consumers, meanwhile, shoved $191.16 billion across retail counters last month, up a surprisingly strong 1.1 percent and providing another piece of evidence to those who contend that the economy needs additional braking to hold down inflation. Automotive and other goods that last a long time were in particularly strong demand.
"This is a very, very robust economy," said James E. Annable, chief economist for the First Chicago Corporation. "It's growing too fast."
All year long, the Federal Reserve has kept a close eye on the operating rate of industry. The gauge has proved a fairly reliable guide to economic overheating. At current levels, bottlenecks may begin to develop, increased costs can often be passed along to consumers, and companies may find they need to bid up wages to attract or hold workers.
The Fed, which compiles the figures on capacity use and output, said its moves today to raise short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point "were taken against the background of evidence of persistent strength in economic activity and high and rising levels of resource utilization."
Other signs also pointed to a robust economy. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, in a report today on manufacturing conditions in the Southeast, said that an index for prices paid by companies jumped to 48.4 last month from 41.2 in September while an index of prices obtained soared to 22.1 from 9.1.
Nationwide, the industrial utilization rate climbed four-tenths of a point, to 84.9 percent. That increase slightly surpassed the August pace to become the biggest jump since March 1980, when the economy had just passed a peak in the business cycle and was slipping into a brief recession.
The increase came after a decline in September, when the rate eased three-tenths of a point.
For factories alone, the step-up in operating rate was even more pronounced, rising to 84.6 from 84.1 and tending to confirm other recent data showing exceptionally high factory overtime as well as a growing number of manufacturing jobs. The October operating rate, the Fed's report pointed out, was 3.4 points above its 1967-93 average.
At the same time, pressure eased on mines and utilities, where output has been falling for months, partly because of unusually mild weather.
Output by the industrial sector, some 30 percent of the economy, surged seven-tenths of 1 percent last month after edging down one-tenth of 1 percent in September when an automobile strike curbed production. Assembly of motor vehicles held at a rate of 11.9 million last month but production of parts rose sharply.
Consumer goods other than motor vehicles and utilities rose four-tenths of 1 percent, continuing what the Fed called a sluggish pattern of recent months as output of appliances and other goods for the home slackened, probably reflecting higher interest rates. But output of business equipment, basic metals, construction supplies and other materials remained brisk.
The 1.1 percent gain in retail sales, reported by the Commerce Department, was not only larger than had been expected but also came on top of upward revisions for August and September. With last month's sales 7.5 percent above those of October 1993, John E. Silvia of Kemper Financial Services said that "retail sales have more momentum now than at this time last year, despite the rise in rates by the Fed."
Sales of durable goods, those meant to last three years or more, soared 2.3 percent over all, the department reported. Automobile dealers took in 2.9 percent more money; merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes took in 1.7 percent more and those selling furniture and other goods had a 1.5 percent gain.
"We're still seeing a pretty strong consumer sector," said Jeff Craitenberger, an analyst at CS First Boston.
In nondurables, a larger sector, sales were up 1.4 percent at clothing stores, 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores and three-tenths of 1 percent each at food stores and those selling general merchandise. On the other hand, sales at gasoline service stations fell nine-tenths of 1 percent while restaurants and bars had a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent.
From August through October, retail sales were 7.9 percent above the comparable 1993 period with no adjustment for inflation. Consumer prices rose 3 percent for the 12 months through September.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Fed Rate Increases Set Off A Strong Rally by the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against other leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the sixth time this year.
The rate increases were greater than what many currency dealers had expected and helped to assure them that the Fed was aggressively reining in inflation. Inflation erodes the value of American bonds and stocks held by foreign investors, thus discouraging the demand for dollars to buy such assets. 
 "The market is expressing the sentiment that the Fed will be ahead of the curve on inflation," Paul Farrell, trading manager at Chase Manhattan Bank, said.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose as high as 1.5575 German marks before settling at 1.5561 marks, up from 1.5438 marks on Monday. The dollar rose to 98.69 yen, from 98.29 yen on Monday.
The dollar has been under pressure in recent months -- particularly against the yen and the mark -- because of fear that the Federal Reserve had not raised rates soon enough to stamp out inflationary pressures. But currency traders said yesterday's Fed action went a long way toward reassuring investors.
The increases of three-quarters of a percentage point lifted the discount rate -- the rate the Fed charges member banks for loans -- to 4.75 percent and the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge one another for overnight lending, to 5.50 percent. The new rates put overnight American interest rates clearly above comparable German rates, which are now around 4.88 percent, for the first time in around four years. Overnight United States rates are also well above Japanese rates of about 2.22 percent.
Mr. Farrell of Chase Manhattan said that should help increase interest in dollar-based fixed-income securities. "The rate hikes create a constructive investment environment for the near term and will attract foreign investors," he said.
The Fed's move widens the gap between interest rates on the dolllar and the yen, said Scott Pardee, chairman at Yamaichi International (America) Inc. "It puts a lot of pressure on those holding the yen against the dollar," he said.
Robert Hormats, vice chairman at Goldman Sachs International, said that other problems still plagued the dollar, including the large United States current account deficit.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.3095 Swiss francs from 1.2945 francs on Monday. The British pound fell to $1.5725 from $1.5873.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber and Copper Prices Soar While Coffee Plunges

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lumber rose to its highest price in two months yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as demand from home builders stays strong even as interest rates go up.
On other commodities markets, copper rose while coffee plunged. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 0.48 point, to 233.74. 
 Wholesalers and builders, who reduced lumber inventories in preparation for the seasonal winter slowdown, have been forced to pay higher prices as the pace of new housing starts holds steady in November. Even the Federal Reserve's increase in short-term interest rates yesterday is not expected to slow demand, analysts said.
"I don't believe that housing will slow down before the beginning of 1995," said Bob Book, senior lumber analyst with Quantum Financial Services in Chicago. "There's a mad rush by people to lock in their mortgages before rates go higher."
Lumber for January delivery rose its $10 daily limit to $347 for 1,000 board feet.
Demand has been so strong that builders are willing to pay higher prices for available supply. Lumber inventories at Western lumber mills have dropped 5 percent since Oct. 1, according to the Western Wood Products Association.
"The lumberyards are working on a just-in-time basis," said Bud Merrill, an analyst with Smith Barney Inc., in Eugene, Ore. "The mills can ask a higher price when the buyers have got to have it."
Copper prices surged to a four-year high as demand from auto makers and other manufacturers continued to keep inventories low.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for December delivery rose 1.55 cents, to $1.2905 a pound, the highest since Sept. 7, 1990. Copper prices have risen 13 percent in less than a month.
Coffee prices plunged as traders speculated that the damage caused by frost and drought in Brazil might not be as extensive as crop reports indicated.
Last week, the Brazilian Government estimated next year's crop could be as low as 12.7 million bags, 28 percent below the United States Department of Agriculture's lowest estimate of 17.6 million bags.
"Everybody is trying to discredit the Brazilian crop estimate," said Oscar Schaps, a broker with the Hencorp Coffee Group in Miami.
December coffee fell 5.9 cents, to $1.7125 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, its lowest price since June 28.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
After two recent acquisitions, more software mergers are likely.

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
TWO deals do not a trend make, especially two with as little in common as Microsoft's $1.5 billion acquisition of Intuit last month and Sybase's $940 million acquisition of Powersoft this week. Still, investment bankers and analysts say they expect more software mergers, if not necessarily of this size.
Both deals filled specific gaps for the acquiring company. The Microsoft Corporation had a personal finance program, Money, but its market share was a fraction of Intuit Inc.'s Quicken. Sybase Inc. had applications development tools, but they were thought to lag behind those of its rivals in the data base management market, the Oracle Corporation and the Informix Corporation; in the Powersoft Corporation, it acquired the market's leading tool, Powerbuilder. 
 Though Quicken, which is used to balance checkbooks and perform other personal financial tasks, and Powerbuilder, which is used for creating complex custom software applications, appear unrelated, both products are about hiding technology. Quicken makes electronic banking as simple as filling in a check; Powerbuilder replaces the writing of endless lines of programming code with a visual tool based on pointing and clicking with a mouse and pull-down menus.
"Technology is being made available to a broader and broader set of consumers," including the less sophisticated, said James A. Davidson, co-head of mergers and acquisitions for Hambrecht & Quist.
The deals also reflect a market that is maturing and undergoing a natural process of consolidation, Mr. Davidson said. "Things are getting more and more volume driven," he said. "If you want to maintain revenue growth, you need to have a differentiated product, and you need to be perceived as a market leader."
The acquisition of Powersoft makes Sybase the market leader in software tools for developing client/server applications, which divide network computing tasks between large "server" computers and smaller "client" machines, typically desktop computers. They are commonly written to run on top of a relational data base management program, like Oracle or Sybase. The other major provider of client/server development tools, the Gupta Corporation of Menlo Park, Calif., discussed merger with Oracle earlier this year but was unable to come to terms.
Many others produce development tools, including Microsoft, which is hardly on anyone's list of acquisition candidates, and Borland International Inc., which probably would be but for a potentially costly copyright infringement suit brought by the Lotus Development Corporation. Many providers of older application development tools also have client/server products and could be merger or acquisition candidates.
"There are 30 strong applications development companies today, and three years from now, only 10 of them will be left," said Curt A. Monash, publisher of the Monash Software Letter. "There's a massive ongoing shakeout in application development tools, and some very good companies are going to go away," he said. "The software industry is finally large enough that there are economies of scale in development."
Several analysts reiterated buy recommendations on Sybase yesterday, saying the acquisition would strengthen it, though the deal is dilutive in the near term. Most also retained positive ratings on Oracle and Informix, citing the underlying strength of the data base management market. Several said that Gupta could be in play, but that it might also be stronger as the last independent tool provider for the client/server market.
