HEADLINE: Pastrami on Rye, Hold the West Coast

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 13

 BODY:
Seeking the solace of salami and the balm of brisket amid the aftershocks of the 1993 earthquake, a long line of people gathered outside Nate 'n Al's, the venerable show-biz delicatessen here. When some customers grew antsy at the wait, a counterman reminded them that they had a choice: they could always go down the block to the Carnegie Deli.
The Carnegie Deli. In New York, the sound of those words would have been like chicken soup to shattered nerves. But something was evidently lost in transit between Seventh Avenue and 54th Street, site of the flagship Carnegie, and the corner of North Beverly Drive and Dayton Way, its West Coast outpost. At Nate 'n Al's that morning, no one even budged. 
 Today, the Venetian blinds at the Carnegie Deli here are pulled shut, and the glass door is covered with the greasy white paper normally used to wrap sandwiches too thick to finish. After several lean years, it became increasingly clear that this Carnegie couldn't cut the mustard. Two and a half months ago, it quietly closed.
The California Carnegie was the dream of a single man with a mammoth appetite, a more mammoth ego and a billfold more mammoth still: Marvin Davis, the oil billionaire who once craved delicatessen the way Wimpy craves hamburgers. Unimpressed with what he considered California's ersatz corned beef and pastrami and tired of shipping the real thing from New York in his private jet, Mr. Davis vowed five years ago to give Los Angeles "the best deli in the world." He then put $4 million of his money where his mouth was.
At the restaurant's celebrity-studded opening in July 1989, Carol Channing plopped a giant Styrofoam matzoh ball into a gargantuan bowl of chicken soup and, in lieu of the usual ribbon-cutting, Mr. Davis and his wife, Barbara, sliced a six-foot salami. Then, egg creams held aloft, they toasted a "new era of delicatessens" in California. When the Carnegie opened to mere mortals shortly thereafter, 2,000 people quickly ate it out of house and home.
But a chaotic beginning, staff shake-ups and a schism with the New York Carnegie changed all that. The crowds stopped coming, and the Styrofoam matzoh ball proved strangely prophetic: the Los Angeles Zagat Restaurant Survey was soon faulting Mr. Davis's establishment for "flat food" and "the worst chicken soup" in Los Angeles. "Marvin Davis should stick to the oil business," one surveyor sneered.
Milton Parker, the owner of the New York Carnegie and Mr. Davis's business partner until the two men fell out, said that even when the California Carnegie was open, Mr. Davis still had his personal pastrami shipped out from Seventh Avenue (not so, Mr. Davis said.) He expressed relief that never again would customers call him to kvetch about the Left Coast Carnegie.
In an interview, the 69-year-old Mr. Davis attributed the failure to everything from the death, in 1987, of Leo Steiner -- the genius behind the New York Carnegie and the man who convinced him to back the West Coast venture -- to earthquakes, riots, the economy and the decline of carnivorousness, particularly in California. Even a lifelong deli addict like Mr. Davis has recently, so to speak, gone cold turkey. "People didn't like fatty foods out here," he said. "If I had any pastrami or corned beef in the house, my doctor and my wife would kill me."
Yet, at Nate 'n Al's -- where Lew Wasserman, the mogul of Universal Studios, takes his grandchildren every Sunday morning, where comedians and agents, actors and groupies have congregated for half a century -- business is just fine. Indeed, others insist it was not acts of God and the invisible hand that did the Carnegie in, but acts of cooks and waitresses, designers and owners.
With its wraparound picture windows, expensive fixtures and valet parking, the place was too "fancy-schmantzy" to be a real Carnegie Deli, customers said. They griped that the countermen were inexperienced, reacting blankly to requests for hand-sliced pastrami or smoked salmon, and that the waiters and waitresses were too young and yuppified. Most importantly, the food was lousy, they complained.
"The first time it was unexceptionable, but I thought, 'Give them a chance; it's new,' " said David Sternlight of Pasadena, who was first in line on opening day. "The second time it was so bad I talked to the manager, who said he knew and would fix it. The third time, it was three strikes and you're out. The Carnegie in New York is one of my favorite delis, but here the food was just abominable."
Then there was Mr. Davis. Critics say he neither knew about restaurants nor would listen to those who did. Perhaps his worst mistake was moving in only a few doors down from Nate 'n Al's. "To put yourself up against the most beloved deli in Beverly Hills was stupid," said Merrill Shindler, a food writer and editor of the Zagat Survey in Los Angeles.
Mr. Davis, who Forbes magazine says is worth nearly $2 billion, hardly lost his shirt on the enterprise, more like a thread or a button. Mr. Davis said he did not know how much went down the drain, but suggested that it was, in the words of another New Yorker, Ralph Kramden, "a mere bag of shells."
The Beverly Hills Carnegie, said its first manager, Bobby Trager, started on the wrong foot: "We were over-hyped; we weren't ready to open up; we were owned by a multi-multibillionaire people didn't want to make even richer, and we came to L.A. as usurpers. We were resented from Day One, and we got buried. You can't take the Carnegie Deli and transplant it. It just won't work."
In fact, as Mr. Davis points out, his is not the only Carnegie to fail. In the last few years Mr. Parker has closed Carnegie satellites in Chicago; Secaucus, N.J.; Atlantic City; Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Scottsdale, Ariz., leaving only the branch in Tyson's Corner, Va., still standing.
AT least until recently, the heavy-set Mr. Davis had been a world-class deli aficionado, a trait born during much-cherished childhood trips with his father to garment center delicatessens in Manhattan. An oft-told tale -- almost as well worn as the myth that he opened the Carnegie after being made to wait too long at Nate 'n Al's -- has him calling his wife from La Guardia Airport to say he was bringing back $1,000 worth of pastrami from the Carnegie, then calling again from Denver to report that only $600 worth remained.
It was not as if Los Angeles had no delis. In addition to Nate 'n Al's, there is Langer's (famous for its pastrami, but in a dicey neighborhood); Art's in Studio City (where, as they say, "every sandwich is a work of Art"); the Stage in Century City (from which Mr. Davis once ordered half a pound of nova, a pint of cream cheese and six bagels daily for his "early-morning nosh"); Jerry's Famous Deli (said to have the best chicken soup, but also serving "Chinese" and "Mexican" food), and Canter's on Fairfax, a slightly down-at-the-heels place with a good bakery.
But none satisfied Mr. Davis, who opened his checkbook and let some of his pals -- among them, Don Rickles, Sidney Sheldon, Jackie Collins, John Madden and Freddie Field, who wrote out a fake check on a piece of matzoh -- buy small chunks of the place themselves. Several partners had sandwiches named after them; the Don Rickles and the John Madden each had plenty of tongue, and Mr. Madden's also included baloney.
Other Davis pals, like Tommy LaSorda and Liz Smith were immortalized free. So was Mia Farrow, who lent her name to the bizarre combination of pastrami on white with lettuce, tomato and mayonnaise. And so were Mr. Davis's golfing partner, his lawyer and his doctor, whose sandwich was built around a comparatively healthful chicken breast sandwich. Dubbing delicatessen was a task Mr. Davis seemed to relish: once, he put a seller of a large block of Northwest Airlines on hold to review sandwich nomenclature with Mr. Trager. One combination -- corned beef and pastrami on bagel -- was the "Marvin Davis."
Not everyone was happy with the designations. Mr. Trager said that Norman Brokaw of the William Morris Agency was so indignant over being linked to liverwurst that he lobbied for a change to turkey. David Geffen had his own selection -- with avocado and sprouts, it was the closest thing to the "mashed yeast" plate Woody Allen ordered in "Annie Hall" -- but says he never ate one, nor even set foot in the place.
During frequent inspection tours of the Carnegie, Mr. Davis was very much in his element. "Here I am, a rich man; I've got business all over the world, and I'm standing here counting heads in a delicatessen," he laughingly told Jay Weston, a producer who writes a restaurant newsletter, shortly after the Carnegie opened. "I should have my head examined."
He brought in Mr. Trager, who ran the New York Carnegie for seven years and spent much of his childhood at Murray's Sturgeon Shop on the Upper West Side. But some things could not be so easily imported. Local health codes and the spacious, ritzy site kept Pat Kuleto, the noted San Francisco restaurant designer, from recreating the endearingly chaotic quality of the original Carnegie, as did the tendency of Californians to sit around forever.
"Everyone is looking for a power table in L.A.," Mr. Trager said. "You 'lunch' in L. A. In New York, you eat."
UNWILLING to pay high rent on an idle operation, Mr. Kuleto recalled, Mr. Davis opened too quickly, without a trained staff or liquor license. "Crank it up; I've put too much money in this thing!" he said Mr. Davis exclaimed. Then, convinced the New York Carnegie was gouging him, he decided to buy the raw materials directly from its suppliers. As he did, complaints increased.
"I told Davis it was not up to the standard of the other place," recalled Milton Berle, who said he was another investor. "Strangely enough, I went into Nate 'n Al's more than I went into the Carnegie, which I owned." (Mr. Davis denied that Mr. Berle had put money in the place. Or, as he put it, "Milton never invested 10 cents to see the Statue of Liberty dance.")
Another problem was the help. For decades, the saucy, sassy shtick of waitresses like Kaye Coleman has been as much a fixture at Nate 'n Al's as blintzes or latkes. At the West Coast Carnegie, their spots were taken by aspiring actors and actresses.
"Every day," Mr. Trager lamented, "I had to show them which was the pastrami and which was the corned beef."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Pittsburgh Approves Buyer

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15

 BODY:
A cable television executive and his family have won the city's approval to buy the Pittsburgh Pirates, the city said today. John Rigas and five members of his family are forming a new entity to buy the Pirates. Rigas, from Coudersport, Pa., is chairman, president and chief executive officer of Adelphia Communications Corporation.
Talks with another potential buyer, the former Baltimore Oriole president Larry Lucchino, were suspended so he could concentrate on trying to buy the San Diego Padres. 
 A final sale price has not been agreed on, but the team's current owners were reportedly seeking about $85 million for the financially ailing franchise.
Mayor Tom Murphy said at a news conference late this morning that the city reached agreement with Rigas on Monday night on a new lease for Three Rivers Stadium, the terms of a loan from the Urban Redevelopment Authority and options that would keep the team in the city.

HEADLINE: Smoke, Not Substance, at APEC

 BODY:
The leaders of 18 nations who gathered this week at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Indonesia arrived with lofty talk of achieving a sweeping agreement to stimulate economic growth on the Pacific Rim, already among the most vibrant economic regions in the world. Their final communique enshrines a noble objective: free trade and investment by the year 2020.
Unfortunately, the APEC pledge fails to include a single substantive measure. The easy task is to commit to a vague goal a quarter-century away. The hard task -- apparently too hard -- is to take concrete measures that would challenge entrenched interests in each country. 
 The APEC countries call for free trade, but do not say if that includes services as well as manufactured goods. The participants call on APEC's industrialized members to achieve free trade 10 years earlier than the 2020 target for everyone, but does not say which countries would be included in the fast lane. Does that leave South Korea or China, for example, in or out?
Underlying the failure to produce a detailed agreement are fundamental differences among the group's members. The United States and Australia are both enthusiastic proponents of free trade, in part because both feared that the East Asian members might move without them. But Malaysia and others oppose free trade to varying degrees. Their problem arises in part from the fact that international trade rules, with one exception, prevent countries from extending preferential trade to each other unless they also extend it to every other trading partner. The exception applies only to countries that move all the way toward forming a free trade bloc -- like the North American Free Trade Agreement between Mexico, the U.S. and Canada.
The Asia-Pacific countries know that Congress is not about to approve another Nafta, especially if it includes low-wage bastions like Malaysia and Indonesia, without insisting upon rules about environmental protection and working conditions. That prospect scares many APEC countries out of tying themselves closely to the U.S. in a free-trade zone. The conference postponed dealing with fundamental difficulties like these for at least a year.
Even though it could not create a free-trade zone overnight, the APEC gathering could have made progress in specific areas. For example, the countries considered, but failed to adopt, a code to open up borders to foreign investors.
The trick for APEC is to turn the virtuous pledge into real progress. That will require aggressive action on small measures that would knock down tariff and non-tariff barriers. Free trade among Pacific Rim countries could then become something more than rhetoric.

HEADLINE: In Schools, Money Matters if It's Spent Wisely;
Nurture, Not Nature

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I write to offer a more hopeful perspective on the debate generated by the Charles Murray-Richard J. Herrnstein thesis on race and I.Q. (Education page, Nov. 9). 
 In 1964 and 1965, after eight-week summer transition programs at Dartmouth and Mount Holyoke colleges, 200 students, 14 and 15 years old, from low-income families (mostly black) entered some of our country's most competitive private secondary schools. They were chosen for motivation and demonstrated achievement, not I.Q. The purpose was to help them prepare to compete at our most selective colleges and universities. More than 8,000 youngsters have since participated in the program, called A Better Chance.
I have been revisiting those 1964 and 1965 integration pioneers, men and women now in their mid-40's. They include a research physicist, neurosurgeon, financial analyst, publisher and district court judge.
Thoughtful and articulate, they speak impressively about the value of caring teachers, traditional courses and high expectations; they speak about the nurturing of family and community; they speak knowledgeably about pressing social, moral and economic issues. In myriad ways, all strive to give back.
For the well-being of our society, it is as critical in 1994 as it was in 1964 that the Murray-Herrnstein thesis not prevail. The central issue is not I.Q., but rather how we can make good on a social contract that dignifies and respects the rights of every citizen, whatever the background, station or distinguishing characteristic.
 
CHARLES F. DEY
Old Lyme, Conn., Nov. 9, 1994
The writer retired as president of Choate Rosemary Hall, a private secondary school.

HEADLINE: The Fed's Moves: How Consumer Rates React

 BODY:
Six times this year, the Federal Reserve has increased short-term interest rates, trying to brake the economy, including a 0.75-percent jump yesterday. Some rates that consumers earn or pay have reacted sharply and promptly; others have shrugged off the Fed's moves.

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: Leaders Agree On Free Trade For the Pacific

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOR, Indonesia, Wednesday, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The glow of Tuesday's victory of creating the largest free-trade zone in the Asia-Pacific region dissipated today as President Clinton and President Suharto of Indonesia clashed over the issue of Indonesia's much-criticized human rights record.
Mr. Clinton stated frankly that relations between the United States and Indonesia would not reach their full potential unless there was an improvement in human rights, a senior Administration official said. 
 The President "raised the issue in strong and forceful terms," Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters in an appearance before Indonesia's official human rights organization.
But Mr. Suharto, who has maintained authoritarian rule over the country for nearly four decades, was unreceptive.
Mr. Clinton welcomed the fact that Indonesia has begun a serious dialogue with the leaders of East Timor, a former Portuguese colony annexed by Indonesia, and had begun to draw down its troops. But he suggested today -- as he said during his news conference on Tuesday -- that the people of East Timor should have more say over their own affairs.
Mr. Suharto replied that his Government is dealing fairly with a knotty problem of East Timor.
Both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher refused to meet with Timorese students conducting a sit-in at the United States Embassy since Saturday to draw attention to their struggle for independence. Lower-level officials continued to maintain contact with the group and provide protesters with rice, water and medical treatment, according to a statement from the embassy.
Mr. Clinton said he welcomed the assurance of the Government that there would be no recriminations if the students left peacefully.
Leaders of 18 Pacific Rim nations emerged on Tuesday from a grand colonial-era palace to extol the benefits of open markets and investment in the dynamic Pacific region and to move toward creating the largest free trade zone in the world by the year 2020.
The leaders, whose nations represent more than half the world's economic output, ended a day of free-wheeling talks with a "declaration of common resolve" that went far beyond the vague vision of their meeting in an Indian long house on a windswept island near Seattle just a year ago.
Both President Suharto, the host, and President Clinton said on Tuesday that the gathering furthered the goals of the group, which includes countries from four continents with per capita incomes ranging from less than $1,000 to $30,000.
But the victory was undercut by three days of demonstrations in Dili, the capital of East Timor.
Despite the promise of Indonesian authorities today not to seek retribution, the squatters requested asylum in Portugal on Tuesday, and it was granted. They said they would not leave the embassy grounds until Mr. Clinton left.
The issue of human rights is so sensitive that journalists were instructed on Tuesday at a news conference with Mr. Suharto in Bogor to pose only questions relating to the economic forum. When asked how he planned to resolve the problem of East Timor, Mr. Suharto said there no time to answer the question.
Mr. Suharto kept the spotlight on trade. "In Bogor, we have set the course and the direction of a future cooperation in the Asia Pacific area in particular and in the world in general," he said.
President Clinton defined the success of the meeting in terms of what was in it for America, predicting that relaxing trade barriers would open new markets, make American goods and services more competitive, encourage sales abroad and create jobs at home.
"From the beginning of this Administration we have worked to create high-wage jobs and a high-growth economy for the 20th century by expanding our ability to trade with and do business with other nations," he said on Tuesday. "The Asia-Pacific is the key to the success of this strategy because it's the fastest-growing region in the world, with rapidly expanding middle classes who are potential American customers."
Despite his recent foreign travel, Mr. Clinton said he does not see himself turning into a foreign policy President. "I expect the lion's share of my work will continue to be done at home," he said, adding, "It's been somewhat more busy on the foreign front than I could have anticipated in the last few months."
Mr. Suharto and his 17 guests were outfitted in custom-made batik shirts in varying shades of brown, black, beige and ochre.
Their declaration commits the group, known as Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, to develop a blueprint of what exactly free trade means -- whether it applies to goods or services or both -- and a road map to reach their goal when the leaders come together in Osaka, Japan, next year.
Developed nations like the United States and Japan agreed to end trade barriers by 2010, and developing nations agreed to follow suit a decade later.
Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mohamad Mahathir, long wary about the Asia-Pacific grouping and of American domination over the region's affairs, expressed strong concerns during the meeting about the declaration and said his country would proceed with trade liberalization at its own pace.
As if to prove him right about the risks of American dominance, the most prominent food vendors at a free restaurant set up for hundreds of journalists in the botanical gardens of Bogor were Wendy's, McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Dunkin' Donuts.
There is a never-never land quality about a pledge 26 years into the future. And while Tuesday's declaration is politically significant, it is not legally binding, and has no mechanism for enforcement.
Still, by breaking the psychological barrier and setting a concrete goal, however remote, it creates a framework for "building block" agreements on issues like rules for customs and standards.
 The article also reversed the names of the Malaysian Prime Minister. He is Mahathir Mohamad.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE INCREASES INTEREST RATES BY 3/4 POINT; JUMP IS LARGEST SINCE 1981

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Determined to prevent strong economic growth from feeding inflation, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates today by the largest amount since 1981 and left open the possibility of further increases. Banks followed by raising the rates they charge for loans.
The increases are likely to show up immediately in the rates charged millions of Americans on everything from home equity loans to credit cards to small-business loans. Already, interest rates on 30-year mortgages that were available at slightly more than 7 percent at the start of the year have risen to 9.05 percent. 
 While rising rates are intended to slow economic growth, the Federal Reserve's five previous increases, which began in February, have had mixed results. Some industries, like auto making, that depend on customers who need loans have had robust sales, while others, like home building, have begun to slow. Critics of the Federal Reserve say that interest rate changes take up to 18 months to show results and that the previous increases may yet do so.
The central bank today raised by three-quarters of a percentage point each of two short-term interest rates that it controls. Stocks, bonds and the dollar bounced up and down in value following the Federal Reserve's action but closed with little change.
The decision by the Federal Reserve came five hours after it reported that American factories operated at 84.9 percent of capacity in October, the highest level in nearly 15 years. When factories are working at top speed, production bottlenecks often occur and can lead to inflation as companies bid up the prices of scarce materials and skilled workers. [Page D6.]
"These measures were taken against the background of evidence of persistent strength in economic activity and high and rising levels of resource utilization," the Federal Reserve said in a statement.
The Clinton Administration responded to the Federal Reserve's action with restrained statements. Although President Clinton expressed hope this morning that Federal Reserve officials would "do their best to keep the recovery going," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the chief White House economic adviser, Laura D' Andrea Tyson, issued statements emphasizing the Federal Reserve's independence, avoiding any direct comment on interest rates while stressing the economy's overall health.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican scheduled to head the Senate Banking Committee next year, cautiously endorsed the Fed's move today. Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, warned that higher rates would hurt American workers.
Even before the rate decision was made today, more than 100 people from labor unions and community groups protested the anticipated increase outside the Federal Reserve headquarters, the first such rally against rising interest rates since the early 1980's.
A series of speakers pointed out that while the nation's unemployment rate may be relatively low now at 5.8 percent, 7.6 million Americans remain unemployed, while millions more are stuck in low-wage jobs.
The National Association of Manufacturers also criticized the move, contending that factories may have more capacity than Federal Reserve statisticians realize, given heavy corporate investment this year.
Alice M. Rivlin, President Clinton's budget director, warned today that more inflation might result if Congressional Republicans stimulated the economy by enacting tax cuts without matching spending cuts. That might push the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates. "It would certainly put enormous upward pressure on interest rates and the Fed would have to continue to raise rates," she said.
The Federal Reserve today acted on two rates. It raised its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 5.5 percent from 4.75 percent. And it raised the discount rate, which the Federal Reserve charges banks for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent from 4 percent. Both rates stood at 3 percent at the beginning of this year.
Big banks responded today by raising their prime rates to 8.5 percent from 7.75 percent.
Adjustable-rate mortgages are typically pegged to the interest rates on six-month and one-year Treasury bills, which had already risen in recent weeks in anticipation of action by the Federal Reserve today.
On the other hand, savers are clear beneficiaries of the higher rates. Since Jan. 1, the interest rates on one-year certificates of deposit have climbed to nearly 5 percent from about 3 percent, meaning that a $10,000 deposit held for a year would now earn an additional $185.
The Federal Reserve said that the vote to raise the discount rate was 7 to 0, meaning that both of President Clinton's appointees to the Federal Reserve Board, Alan S. Blinder and Janet L. Yellen, supported the move. The Federal Open Market Committee, which consists of the 7-member board and 5 of the 12 presidents of the Federal Reserve regional banks, determines the Federal funds rate. The committee will not disclose today's vote until Dec. 23, when it releases minutes of today's meeting.
In contrast to the Federal Reserve's last two interest rate increases, today's announcement had no indication that this would be the central bank's last such action for a while. But Wall Street economists said that the size of today's increase made it less likely that the Federal Reserve's top officials would raise rates again at their next meeting on Dec. 20, waiting instead at least until the following meeting on Jan. 31.
While the Federal Reserve has raised rates by a full percentage point in the past, most recently on May 5, 1981, Fed officials were unable to find any prior case today of a move of three quarters of a point.
The action appeared to represent a compromise between those officials most worried by inflation, led by J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, and officials more inclined to wait and see whether the strong economic growth actually produced inflation.
Officials worried about inflation have pushed for big increases in short-term rates that would shock bond traders into believing that inflation is under control, thereby halting the upward creep in long-term interest rates. Mr. Broaddus successfully pushed last spring for the Federal Reserve to abandon its initial quarter-point increases in favor of half-point increases in May and August, and he is believed to have favored an increase of a full percentage point today.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, has said that the central bank should err, if at all, on the side of raising rates too much. It is easier to reverse an unexpected drop in economic output by lowering interest rates than it is to stop an inflationary spiral with higher rates, he testified last summer.
Mr. Broaddus and three other Federal Reserve regional bank presidents, all advocates of higher rates, will rotate off the open market committee at the end of this year. Three of their four replacements are believed to be more concerned about maintaining the current economic expansion and less interested in higher rates.
One of the Federal Reserve's biggest worries is that prices for commodities and some industrial materials, like plywood and ball bearings, have been increasing steadily this year. Consumer prices have not yet reflected these increases, mostly because labor accounts for two-thirds of the cost of consumer goods and wages have been rising fairly slowly this year.
But the Labor Department reported on Nov. 4 that average hourly wages had spurted up 8 cents in October, to $11.24. As a result, Fed officials worry about whether inflation will remain limited to commodity prices.
"I don't think that can last very long; it's going to have to show through or recede," Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Federal Reserve Board governor, said on Nov. 4.

HEADLINE: Maturing Jazz Industry Opens Convention Tonight

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
The Jazz Times Convention starts tonight, which means that tired-looking, cigarette-smoking people from all over the world will gather to talk about what they heard last night, what kinds of deals can be cooked up today and who is sitting in with whom and where. For the next four days, the convention becomes jazz's business paradise, with bookers, musicians, radio programmers, record company executives, agents, club owners and critics swarming like fish around a particularly fertile reef.
The convention started in Washington 10 years ago as a casual meeting of some of the disparate elements that make up the jazz world. It has grown into big business, with attendance up nearly 20 percent from last year. This year's version draws nearly 700 people from across the country, along with people from India, Sweden, Russia, England and more. In its success, its internationalism and its growth, the convention suggests that jazz is taking itself more seriously as an industry, and flourishing because of it. 
 "More people in the industry are becoming more professional," said Lee Mergner, the convention's director and the associate publisher of the magazine Jazz Times. "It feels like people have their business skills together. Marketing is taken more seriously now, and a much more structured organization is out there to promote the music in both the nonprofit and commercial world. I think the convention just reflects what's going on. We're becoming institutional, in a good way."
While there may be a new air of professionalism to the convention, it is clearly set up to lure people with the promise of a good time. Holding the festival in New York again guarantees that people who have come for music business will be able to escape from business to hear some of the best jazz in the world. And the convention itself is featuring performances by Eric Reed, Hubert Laws, Henry Threadgill, Jacky Terrasson, Tom Coster, Milt Jackson, Wallace Roney, Kenny Garrett and many more. And record companies have bought showcases to expose acts that are either little known or are the centerpieces of their roster.
"This is a great way to get a buzz going about our performers, since all of jazz's cognoscenti show up," said Bruce Lundvall, the president of Blue Note Records. "And the musicians get the added advantage of being heard by bookers and agents from all over the world. It's an amazingly effective way of spreading the word."
The convention's panels hint at what the jazz world is thinking about, and they cover everything from radio promotion and distribution networks to finding sponsors for festivals. One is called "Jazz in Cyberspace." Another is on the European jazz-festival circuit, while another is about selling and licensing recordings in Europe. One asks jazz critics to take a hard look at themselves, and other is a tribute to the guest of honor, Sonny Rollins.
But underlying all discussions for the last 10 years has been one theme: how to expand jazz's role in the marketplace. The convention facilitates the general promotion of jazz that most of the people in the industry share, whether from self-interest or love of the music or both. Schmoozing is the balm that allows the muscles of the industry to function smoothly.
"Jazz is in a position now that some other musics were in decades ago, right on the verge of being taken more seriously as a commercial force," said Mr. Lundvall. "There are three serious jazz magazines out there now, where there had been one only a short while ago, and virtually every major label has a jazz program, a situation I've never seen before. The Jazz Times Convention, is the first step in developing some kind of a marketing consensus within the industry. It also the only national forum jazz has, which makes it very important."
One of the convention's main achievements has been to draw together all the microcosms that make up jazz. The owner of a tiny, independent jazz label from Tucson, Ariz., can deal with a European manager or with the owner of a small club in Milwaukee. Because its economics have until recently been on a fairly low scale, fans have been able to be involved with jazz, giving it as a business a home-grown and idiosyncratic feel. But it is changing, becoming more centralized at major labels and at institutions like Lincoln Center. The change means that jazz may lose some of the individualism it has as a business; it also means that some musicians, with power behind them, will find themselves in a better position.
"Organizationally speaking, jazz has been all over the place as a business, and I think that the music is coming of age as a viable commercial form," said Jeff Levenson, Billboard magazine's jazz editor. "It's always been fragmented, and now out of economic necessity, a unified front is important. The convention makes me suspect that jazz is coming to a new maturity in how it treats itself in the marketplace. And given how much potential money there is in the music, that's important."
Some nighttime events are open to the public, including Mr. Threadgill tonight at 11 o'clock at the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, and Rodney Kendrick, Bhaki Mseleku, Mark Whitfield and Django Bates and Human Chain at Fez, 380 Lafayette Street, East Village, on Friday night at 10.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 1994, Thursday

An article yesterday about the Jazz Times Convention in New York included a misstatement from the organizers about admission to an event tomorrow night at Fez, an East Village club, featuring Rodney Kendrick, Bhaki Mseleku, Mark Whitfield and Django Bates and Human Chain. It is open to conventiongoers only, not to the public.

HEADLINE: Assembly Speaker Voices Doubts On Pataki's Pledge to Cut Taxes

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Starting to build a Democratic case against Governor-elect George E. Pataki's central campaign promise, the Assembly Speaker said today that it would be difficult to cut taxes as quickly and deeply as Mr. Pataki has pledged, and added that the Assembly Democrats might offer a tax-cutting plan of their own.
The Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said at a news conference in Albany that New Yorkers would "understand if, in fact, any tax cuts have to go slower than were promised in the campaign." 
 As that new front was opening in Mr. Pataki's future battle with the Assembly Democrats, the Governor-elect managed to keep alive a feud from the past. At a news conference today at his headquarters in Manhattan, Mr. Pataki said he still had not returned a congratulatory telephone call from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who supported Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in the gubernatorial campaign.
"The Mayor can reach me; he knows where I am, and if he wants to call, I'll be happy to speak to him," Mr. Pataki said. He added: "I have not gotten a call that I'm aware of from the Mayor during business hours here from 9 to 5."
Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said that Mr. Pataki had returned calls today to United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, New York City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and Public Advocate Mark Green. All had called Mr. Pataki during working hours, she said.
Mr. Giuliani, who said he called Mr. Pataki twice on election night, responded: "This whole subject is getting very silly. The fact is, governors and mayors work before 9 o'clock in the morning and after 5 o'clock at night. So maybe we should move beyond this telephone call and work on things that are of substantive benefit for the city."
Mr. Pataki also said today that he soon would announce the formation of transition committees to deal with specific topics, like the state budget and perhaps a possible takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, something Mr. Pataki has alternatively said he would look at and then has said he opposed. As reporters and photographers were ushered into a large office where Pataki advisers were meeting, Mr. Pataki joked: "Well, we've got plenty of time. We've got six weeks to redo a $64 billion government."
Mr. Silver's comments about the possibility of a competing tax-cut plan made it clear that the Democratic-controlled Assembly would seek to keep the Republicans from staking full ownership of the issue.
During the campaign, Mr. Pataki proposed a 25 percent cut in state income tax rates, a reduction that would cost the state $5.6 billion a year in revenues by the fourth year. He said he would pay for the tax cut by curbing the growth in state spending and through projected annual growth in state revenues of 6 percent. Even after learning that the state faces a projected budget shortfall of $4 billion next year, Mr. Pataki has remained committed to his plan.
Mr. Silver suggested today that Mr. Pataki's economic assumptions were too optimistic. And he said the most obvious routes to cutting state spending -- reducing the state's aid to schools and local governments -- would simply pressure local governments to raise property taxes.
Mr. Silver said the Assembly Democrats might propose an alternative plan, presumably less ambitious, and that it might involve taxes other than the income tax. The Democratic strategy would provide cover for upstate Democrats who may feel torn between competing political pressures -- the pressure to maintain loyalty to the Assembly's New York City-based leadership and the pressure to respond to the message sent last Tuesday by upstate voters, who sided overwhelmingly with Mr. Pataki.
When the newly elected Assembly convenes in January, 58 of the 94 Democrats will represent districts in New York City, where Mr. Cuomo defeated Mr. Pataki by comfortable margins. But 58 votes does not make a majority in the 150-member Assembly, meaning that Mr. Silver also must appeal to the 15 Democrats from the suburbs of New York City and the 21 Assembly Democrats from upstate, where Mr. Pataki clobbered Mr. Cuomo.
To take a purely obstructionist position toward tax cuts could put those Assembly Democrats at risk. One upstate Democrat, Assemblyman William L. Parment of Chautauqua County, characterized Mr. Silver's dilemma this way today. "Over the years the Assembly has been controlled by New York City liberals," he said. "Now I suppose the question is whether they can count on us upstate bumpkins to vote Democratic. Well, aw shucks, I don't know."

HEADLINE: Museum of Modern Art Ends Troubled Search for a Chief

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it had finally found a new director, after a sometimes messy 14-month search. He is Glenn D. Lowry, the 40-year-old director of the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto and a specialist in Islamic art. He takes over on July 1, 1995.
Mr. Lowry is a surprise choice to succeed Richard E. Oldenburg, who announced in September 1993 that he planned to retire. Since then, several candidates had turned down offers from the museum, and the names of many others had been bandied about. Mr. Lowry's was not one of them. 
 The Modern's troubled search for its sixth director came to symbolize the difficulties museums across the country have had in finding people suited to the shifting requirements of the job, in which economic and managerial skills have increasingly come to outweigh the traditional visual and scholarly ones.
At the Modern, the world's pre-eminent museum of 20th-century art, the situation was more complex: on the cusp of a possible major expansion, it needed a fund-raiser and administrator, and, ideally, a scholar, but not one who would impose his, or her, tastes on the unusually independent group of curators. A new generation of curators, including Kirk Varnedoe, Peter Galassi, Margit Rowell and Terry Riley, had already begun to reshape the Modern, and to debate whether, and how, to redefine it for the next century.
The costly and time-consuming search that ultimately turned up Mr. Lowry actually began months before Mr. Oldenburg's announcement that he would retire, when the Modern's board said it would create the position of paid president, responsible for administrative and fund-raising duties, to share leadership with the director. The idea for such a president was scrapped with Mr. Oldenburg's decision to quit.
Several months of seeking for his successor among prominent directors, including Anne d'Harnoncourt of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, James Wood of the Art Institute of Chicago and Peter Marzio of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, turned up no one, and made the Modern's problems increasingly the subject of uneasy speculation in the art world about trustee conflicts and the desirability of the job there. Mr. Oldenburg agreed to extend his stay to the end of 1994, but his deadline was fast approaching and the search seemed stalled until Mr. Lowry's name surfaced.
Matters changed only in September when the Modern hired a new search firm, which quietly began to focus on young candidates who wanted the job, not solely on those people with long careers at other big institutions. Attention began to center on Mr. Lowry just a month ago, and even high-ranking staff members did not hear about him until this week.
Mr. Lowry brings to the post a background as a scholar and curator, but clearly not one whose area of expertise conflicts with that of anyone at the Modern. He has also had several years of directorial experience raising money and overseeing the construction of new buildings. That included a deeply acrimonious battle he waged with the Ontario provincial government, stemming from a $58 million project to expand the Art Gallery of Ontario.
Describing Mr. Lowry's appointment, Agnes Gund, the Modern's chairman, said: "He doesn't want to be a curator; he wants to be an administrator. So he won't be wishing he could do the shows instead of the curators. At the same time, he understands what a curator does. And he knew how to work with adversity in Toronto and raise money at the same time."
David Rockefeller, chairman emeritus and, with Ms. Gund, a co-chairman of the committee that looked for a new director, concurred: "It's sad we spent so much time looking at other people, but in another sense it was worth the time that it took. Both staff and trustees wanted someone with a passion for the arts, a scholar, if possible, and also a leader. Glenn has those things. And to raise $58 million in Toronto is the equivalent of many millions more in New York."
The Modern has been pressed for space from the moment it moved into its expanded quarters on 53d Street a decade ago. Lately it has been considering yet another expansion, next door or elsewhere, to accommodate its growing collection, particularly of large-scale contemporary art.
Referring to Mr. Lowry on a more personal level, Mr. Rockefeller added: "He's also basically comfortable in his skin and not threatened by other people. So he'll respect the curators but not be intimidated by them."
For his part, the trim, slightly graying Mr. Lowry said: "I hope I can be a catalyst for the different departments of the museum to work together, and to engage people here in an intense dialogue about art and the display of art for different publics. But I have no particular curatorial axes to grind."
Mr. Lowry was born in Manhattan in 1954, was reared in Williamstown, Mass., and graduated from Williams College there in 1976. He received a Ph.D. in art history from Harvard University in 1982, having written his thesis on Mughal architectural history. For two years, he served as founding director of Joseph and Margaret Muscarelle Museum of Art at the College of William and Mary, in Williamsburg, Va., overseeing construction of the museum and raising money for it.
Between 1984 and 1990, he was curator of Near Eastern Art at the Freer and Sackler Galleries of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. With Thomas Lentz, he organized "Timur and the Princely Vision," a major exhibition of Persian 15th-century art. The show, and its catalogue, were notable not just for their focus on exquisite objects but also for their emphasis on placing those objects in a social and political context, an approach Mr. Lowry says he hopes to encourage in programs at the Modern.
One of his most important achievements was to help acquire for the Sackler the celebrated collection of Persian and Indian painting that the jeweler Henri Vever, a neighbor and rival of Cartier in Paris, put together at the beginning of the century. The collection disappeared in 1938. But in 1984, unbelievably, Mr. Lowry's French-born mother, Laure, who has no involvement in the art world, happened to overhear at a dinner party in Paris that it was in the possession of the jeweler's grandson, Francois Mautin. Mr. Lowry, at first skeptical of his mother's news, tracked down Mr. Mautin and got the collection.
From Washington, Mr. Lowry moved in 1990 to become director of the Art Gallery of Ontario, one of the largest museums in Canada, with a collection from the early Renaissance to the present, its strength in 20th-century and contemporary material. His appointment there, as a young American Islamicist, was a surprise, too, and he immediately faced big problems. Ground had already been broken for a 100,000-square-foot expansion and 200,000-square-foot renovation. But the project started to run way over budget. Meanwhile, partly because of a severe recession, the provincial government, which heavily subsidized the gallery, reneged on promises to increase the amount it gave each year.
Mr. Lowry was forced to lay off 250 people, from a staff of 450, and shut the gallery down entirely for seven months. His actions were called Draconian. But at the same time, he oversaw a fund-raising drive to cover the costs of the expansion and make the museum less dependent on public money, partly by turning the gallery's shops, publications and restaurants into more profitable operations.
The gallery finally reopened in January 1993, to widespread satisfaction, its collections completely reinstalled and its staff up to 300 people. Mr. Lowry then brought a highly popular traveling exhibition of works from the Barnes Foundation near Philadelphia to the museum in September of this year, and under his tenure there were also shows of artists like Dan Graham, Michael Snow and William Morris.
After his appointment at the Modern was announced yesterday to the museum's staff, several curators there voiced their approval of his youth, energy, scholarship and ability to weather storms.
Mr. Varnedoe, chief curator of painting and sculpture, said: "One of the things that's most heartening is that he really wants to be a director. I don't think he's a frustrated curator."
Mr. Lowry is the first director of the Modern who comes to the job from another directorship. He is not, as it happens, the first Lowry to be director of the museum in its 65-year history. In 1972, Mr. Oldenburg took over after two brief and stormy directorships, one by John Hightower and the other by Bates Lowry, who like the incoming director, was not a specialist in modern art. His expertise was the Renaissance. He lasted less than a year. He is no relation, said the incoming director.

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: TRADE;
CLINTON PLEDGES TO PUSH FOR VOTE ON TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton and a parade of the fallen and the survivors in Congress vowed today to plow ahead with House and Senate votes on a world trade agreement after Thanksgiving despite some bipartisan opposition.
They argued that if the votes were put off until next year, the agreement, which took 12 years to negotiate with 123 nations, would certainly die. 
 Both White House and Congressional officials, including the Speaker-in-waiting, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said they believed that a deal would be struck with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the future majority leader, that would ultimately insure passage of the accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
But much negotiating remained, and all day, with a sudden frenetic energy, Clinton Administration officials led by Vice President Al Gore drew apocalyptic scenarios of what a defeat of the agreement would mean to the United States.
Using some of the more dire projections among the dozens of debatable estimates floating around Washington, they warned of billions of dollars in lost growth for the economy, lost chances to create tens of thousands of jobs and, perhaps most important to the White House, a loss of credibility abroad.
"We must pass the GATT, and we should do it right away," Mr. Clinton said in Jakarta, Indonesia, as he wound up a meeting with Asian leaders, who pressed him for assurances that the United States would not torpedo an agreement that America pioneered. "It is critical for U.S. leadership in the world."
To achieve passage of the agreement, Mr. Clinton finds himself in a particularly odd quandary: he must win the support of his newly emboldened Republican opponents, who are generally much greater advocates of free trade than is the President's own party.
"You have to imagine the Alice in Wonderland quality of this," said a senior Administration official who has sat in on many of the White House strategy meetings in recent days. "Here we are, trying to figure out how to get business leaders to put pressure on Republicans to vote for something Reagan championed and Bush almost implemented."
The Administration's hurried public relations campaign was reminiscent of its successful effort a year ago to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement, an accord that is dwarfed in scope by the far more complex pact now before Congress.
The awakening at the White House was spurred in part by a letter to Mr. Clinton on Tuesday from Jesse Helms, the incoming chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who threatened not to cooperate with the President's foreign policy initiatives unless the vote on GATT was delayed until the new Congress convenes in January.
Today, at a rally for business leaders pressing for the trade accord's passage, Mr. Gore and Speaker Thomas S. Foley dismissed the threats of Senator Helms, whose home state, North Carolina, is heavily dependent on textiles, the one industry that could be most damaged by the tariff reductions mandated by the agreement.
"The question of delaying GATT is really an issue of whether GATT passes at all," Mr. Gore said. "It is abundantly clear that a delay of GATT would kill it."
Passage of the agreement seems all but assured in the House, where Mr. Gingrich has repeatedly expressed support for it. Indeed, in a letter to the President today, Mr. Gingrich pledged to work toward "a bipartisan majority" to achieve passage.
But its chances in the Senate are uncertain. A senior Administration official said today that he thought the agreement was still three to five votes short of the 60 needed under budget rules that require a three-fifths majority for any measure that would increase the Federal deficit; GATT would cost the Government several billion dollars in lost tariff revenue over the next decade.
The key to passage is Mr. Dole, the future Senate majority leader, who said again today that although he generally supported the agreement, he would insist that Congress get greater leverage to make sure that the new World Trade Organization created by the accord would not force unacceptable changes in Federal and state laws.
In essence, White House officials said, Mr. Dole is demanding some kind of mechanism that would enable Congress, barred by legislative rules from amending the agreement in any vote this year, to review American participation if it determined that the World Trade Organization was consistently ruling against United States interests.
"I'd rather fix it and do it this year," Mr. Dole said. "If we can't fix it, then we can postpone it."
The bill will be shepherded in the Senate by Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the current chairman of the Finance Committee, and by the Senator who will succeed him as chairman in the 104th Congress, Bob Packwood of Oregon.
"If Senator Dole is with us, we will pass this rather handsomely," Mr. Packwood said today.
Over the next two weeks, the White House is planning a series of events to press the cause of GATT, borrowing many of the techniques it used in the last-minute push that won the Nafta vote.
Mr. Gore; Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; the United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, and other officials will be pressing free-trade arguments with farmers, journalists and business associations around the country, a senior White House official said today. Former Presidents will be urged to write articles of opinion for newspapers or sign letters in support of the agreement.
The politics of the new Congress has so overwhelmed the trade issue on Capitol Hill that the details of the agreement itself have seemed almost lost. The accord is so vast -- 500 pages, supplemented by about 22,000 pages of tariff schedules and country-by-country regulations -- that almost no one who will be voting on it has read it. Estimates of how much it would benefit the American economy, if in fact it would, vary so widely that they are almost useless. "The fact is," said one Government economist working the numbers, "we are all shooting in the dark."
Mr. Clinton's aides say the complexity of the pact may work to their advantage, by keeping GATT from becoming as heated a topic as Nafta was. But the accord's opponents, who range from the consumer activist Ralph Nader to conservative Democrats like Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina to Republicans like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Mr. Helms, are raising numerous objections.
The first is that the accord will be voted on by a lame-duck Congress, populated in part by defeated members. Moreover, under a rule governing the voting, Congress can vote only up or down, with no amendments. Under some interpretations, that rule, called "fast track" in Capitol Hill parlance, expires next year.
That means that in the new Congress, Mr. Helms and others could open the bill to endless amendments, and each of the amendments would then have to be renegotiated with all of the agreement's member nations.
The second objection raised by opponents is that the agreement should actually be considered a treaty. If it were, it would require even more votes in the Senate -- a two-thirds majority -- although no vote at all in the House. That objection has been supported by Laurence H. Tribe, the Harvard constitutional scholar.
The third issue, and the biggest one for Senator Dole, is the notion that the United States might be surrendering sovereignty to the new World Trade Organization. The fear is that American laws, like those that ban the importing of goods made by child labor, would be judged illegal under GATT. While the World Trade Organization could not order a change in Federal or state laws, it could authorize other countries to invoke sanctions against American products.
In reality, supporters of the accord say, there is little such risk: few countries would want to get into a sanctions war with the United States, and risk the loss of their own exports here.
The fourth objection is one now being seized upon by religious conservatives: language in the GATT implementation bill that, in their view, benefits what they call the liberal voice of the capital, The Washington Post.
The Post owns a controlling interest in a company that, under the bill, would receive a "pioneer preference" license from the Federal Communications Commission to build a new wireless telephone and computer network, using digital technology. The newspaper would be required to pay hundreds of millions of dollars for the right to use the frequencies, but the religious right has flooded Congressional offices in recent days with faxes arguing that those sums are not large enough.

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: THE PRESIDENT;
White House in Struggle To Take Back the Agenda

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Inside an executive mansion fairly swarming with political advice-givers and abuzz with strategy, the burning question these days is not just what President Clinton will do with a Republican Congress, but what he will do with a Democratic White House.
It is also the toughest question. And a week after Mr. Clinton and his counsels lost command of the national legislature and any claim to a political mandate, they are still searching for an answer. 
 As the President wrapped up a Pacific Rim trade conference in Indonesia and flew to Hawaii tonight, his aides in Washington were trying to compile a concise list of initiatives with which Mr. Clinton could at once outpoint the new Republican majority, stake out his political philosophy and appeal to broad swaths of voters.
The aides have an abundance of suggestions. One official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the list, which sounds more than vaguely like the Republicans', includes welfare reform, a modest health-care package, a line-item veto on Federal budget expenditures, term limits, campaign-finance reform and a tax cut for the middle class.
What the aides and the President lack is a consensus on which issues to highlight and, in some cases, even which positions to take. The Administration's explanation is that responding to a political sea change is a complex and arduous task, that Mr. Clinton has been abroad almost since Election Day, and that the best short-run strategy may be to see what Republicans toss into the legislative arena, and then to react to it.
But many Clinton advisers and friends also say that the rethinking at the White House is all the more hampered by internal difficulties. These people say that there are differences over whether to pursue a more centrist policy, uncertainty about the views and the role of First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, and even questions about the decisiveness of the President himself.

 In many ways these internal debates are nothing new to the Clinton White House, and most of the initiatives being revisited, and now reconsidered, are the same issues on which Mr. Clinton campaigned and won in 1992.
In principle, the debate among Mr. Clinton and his aides, who have frequently heard his views this week via long-distance phone calls, boils down to this question: Should the White House edge closer to the political center, or should it try to bolster its more liberal Democratic base?
The circle of advisers in this debate is wide, and the alliances among them are not always well defined. But White House aides and those who have talked with them say that in general the advocates of a more centrist position are led by aides like Bruce Reed, a domestic policy adviser; Jack Quinn, the chief of staff to Vice President Al Gore; Robert Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. Mr. Reed's roots lie with the Democratic Leadership Council, a moderate group that Mr. Clinton helped found and once ran as governor of Arkansas.
Among those who favor a more traditional Democratic strategy are Harold M. Ickes, a deputy to the White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta, and David Dreyer, an official in the White House communications office who has a voice in political strategy. Mr. Ickes, a New York lawyer, oversaw White House strategy in the last campaign; Mr. Dreyer was once an aide to the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.
Two of the President's senior advisers, George Stephanopoulos and Mark D. Gearan, are said to lie somewhere in the middle. Mr. Gearan was supposed to fly to Indonesia with Mr. Clinton but stayed behind to coordinate post-election strategy; Mr. Stephanopoulos went in his place.
Aides commonly assume that another highly influential adviser, Mrs. Clinton, leans to the views of Mr. Ickes. But even they are not so sure.
In Indonesia this week, as her husband said he was receptive to a Republican proposal for a Constitutional amendment on school prayer, Mrs. Clinton seemed much tougher. Mrs. Clinton said in an interview that there would be "real differences" between the White House and its rivals if Republicans truly took aim at social spending programs like Head Start or at gun-control measures.
"I'm not a political pundit," she said. But then she added: "I think the President has to stick with what he's stood for. He has to stick with his principles and protect the progress that's been made."
Some senior aides say that Mrs. Clinton's stewardship of health-insurance legislation last year was a principal reason that her husband became tagged as a big-government Democrat, and they expect her to take a less visible role in policy for the rest of his term.
But whatever the political leanings of advisers, aides say, the choice for Mr. Clinton is more subtle than a decision between old and new Denmocratic politics. Virtually all agree that the base of loyal Democratic voters is now so shrunken that it cannot insure Mr. Clinton's re-election by itself. The real problem, most say, is trickier: how to keep the party's liberal base happy and yet lure back former Democrats who left out of unhappiness with the party's liberal streak.
That is what the President accomplished in his 1992 campaign, in which he stressed broad themes like economic security, freedom from crime and the healing of social divisions that were easy for voters to embrace.
"The Clinton campaign in '92 was brilliant" in that respect, said one Democratic strategist who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
"The problem is that when governing, you have to make choices every single day," the strategist said. "It's one or the other. And you seem to be choosing sides."
In the view of many strategists from both sides of the debate, Mr. Clinton's seeming inability to choose sides has contributed greatly to his political undoing.
White House aides complain that the President has reduced the deficit, overseen sweeping free-trade agreements, established a program of national service and shifted Federal expenses to education and training, and gotten no credit.
But on issues that have excited voters -- homosexuals in the military, the appointment of aides like the civil-rights advocate Lani Guinier, or the removal of dictators in Haiti -- Mr. Clinton has tended to take firm stances on one side or the other, and then to retreat. His critics, as well as some supporters, say he has wound up only angering two segments of the electorate: the side that opposed his first decision, and the side that regarded him as weak when he deserted it.
In Washington, aides expressed hope today that Mr. Clinton would spend time in Hawaii resting and considering his political options. Nearly all of the top advisers who accompanied him to Indonesia -- including Mr. Stephanopoulos and John D. Podesta, the staff secretary -- were flying almost directly to Washington to join in the debate.
"The first answers have been relatively easy," said a senior White House official traveling with the President. "It's in the next set of questions and answers that things get a whole lot more difficult."

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Stern With Indonesia On Rights but Gleeful on Trade

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The United States and Indonesia today announced $40 billion in joint projects over the next decade, even as President Clinton warned President Suharto that the relationship between the two countries would never reach its full potential unless he treated his people better.
At almost the same time that Mr. Clinton was chiding the Indonesian leader for his country's inadequate human rights record, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown was witnessing the signing of 15 business deals that are part of the Administration's campaign of commercial diplomacy and will mean jobs for Americans. 
 By far the largest project is a $35 billion arrangement between Exxon and Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil company, to develop a huge offshore natural gas field. [Page D5.]
Since May, when the Administration discarded its policy of linking preferential trade benefits to China with an improvement in its human rights performance, the Administration has argued that the best way to spread democracy and improve the way a country treats its citizens is through increasing trade, not curtailing it.
In his photo session with Mr. Suharto earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton was stone-faced, but in a speech to American and Pacific business executives he did not disguise his glee at the news of the business deals.
"I know that there is increasing wealth in Indonesia and throughout Asia, but where I come from $40 billion is still real money -- and we're grateful for the business," he said. The audience applauded.
Indeed, two cultural divides over human rights in Indonesia were on display today: one between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Suharto, the other between the foreign and economic policies of the United States
Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Suharto in the opulent Jakarta Palace showed how resistant foreign leaders can be when the President of the United States comes in and suggests -- however gently -- how things should be done.
And the differences among Mr. Clinton's Cabinet officials as they sought to explain their messages underscored the tension between the Administration's stated desire to export American values and the need to export American goods.
Meeting for more than an hour after a summit conference of 18 leaders from Pacific Rim countries, Mr. Clinton told Mr. Suharto that his treatment of his people would inhibit ties between the United States and Indonesia and rob him of the chance to flourish as a world leader, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said.
Mr. Christopher told reporters before meeting with Indonesia's Government-appointed human rights organization that Mr. Clinton had raised human rights "in firm and forceful terms."
"The relationship between the United States and Indonesia can never reach the highest levels if the people of the United States don't have confidence that there is an effort here to respect the human rights of all the citizens," Mr. Christopher said.
Mr. Suharto, who has ruled with an authoritarian grip since the mid-1960's, apparently was not moved.
When Mr. Clinton praised Mr. Suharto's dialogue with the people of East Timor, the former Portuguese territory annexed by Indonesia two decades ago, but said they needed more autonomy, Mr. Suharto balked, Administration officials said.
"He believes that the Indonesian Government is dealing with the issue fairly," a senior Administration official said.
Over all, Mr. Suharto's remarks on human rights, the official added, "were along the lines that have been previously expressed by the Indonesian Government."
Another senior official said: "Suharto didn't back down one inch. He gave well rehearsed answers that he is used to repeating."
Mr. Suharto learned early this year that he is unlikely to face penalties if he does not bend to Washington's wishes. Shortly after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told Mr. Suharto in Jakarta that he had to do more on workers' rights if he wanted to retain his country's preferential trade privileges, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, abruptly suspended the Administration's review of the issue.
In May, the Administration severed the link between the trade benefits given China and its human rights policies. Since then the Administration has changed its thinking on the best strategy to modify behavior on human rights. The key, officials say, is not punishment but more trade and investment, which they believe will increase economic growth and help spawn a middle class with both consumerism and democracy in mind.
But the same officials acknowledge that the human rights situation in Indonesia has worsened in recent months with the banning of newspapers and magazines, more harassment of labor activists and new reports of torture by the military and police.
Along with the talk today about the need for Indonesia to do more on human rights was a message about the joys of trade. Indonesia is expected to spend more than $100 billion to improve its infrastructure by 2000, and the United States is determined to seize a large chunk of the projects.
Even as Mr. Clinton was mixing tough talk about human rights with happy talk about goals for free trade in the Asia-Pacific region, Secretary Brown was completing arrangements for 15 projects worth $40 billion.
This morning, seated next to Mr. Christopher as the Secretary of State criticized the Indonesian human rights record, Mr. Brown played good cop to Mr. Christopher's bad one. "Our strategy of commercial engagement, we believe, is the most effective strategy to have a positive impact on labor rights and human rights," he said.
To illustrate the importance of the economic component of the policy, Mr. Brown sat in on Mr. Christopher's meeting with the official human rights group and "was very persuasive in saying that we advance our commercial economic interests hand in hand with our human rights concerns," a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Suharto had hoped that as host of this year's meeting of the 18 leaders, known as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, he would focus attention on his country's economic progress and views on free trade.
Instead the focus was dimmed by demonstrations in Dili, in East Timor, and by a sit-in that began last Saturday at the American Embassy in Jakarta by 29 East Timorese who had demanded a meeting with Mr. Clinton or Mr. Christopher. Neither man nor any other senior Administration official has met with them.
Today Indonesian officials said that the Government was willing to allow the protesters to leave the country. Portugal has offered them asylum.
A number of Indonesia's major private rights organizations boycotted a meeting today with Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs; Stanley Roth, the senior Asia specialist at the White House, and Bowman Cutter, the deputy director of the National Economic Council.
A letter to Mr. Clinton, signed by leading private human rights groups, said, "Your unwillingness to meet with non-state actors in the pro-democracy movement seems to be part of the U.S. Government's inconsistency toward the improvement of human rights and democracy in Indonesia."

HEADLINE: Ukraine Votes to Become a Nuclear-Free Country

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Ukrainian Parliament put aside its longstanding reservations and voted overwhelmingly today to make their nation nuclear-free, removing roadblocks to carrying out two major arms control agreements.
In a move that the United States eagerly sought for some time, the Parliament agreed to sign the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, which pledges its signers, with the exception of the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France, to rid themselves of all nuclear weapons. 
 Since the breakup of the Soviet Union the Ukraine has been the world's third-largest nuclear power, with 1,800 warheads.
The Parliament placed a few conditions on the move, among them receiving assurances from the United States, Russia and Britain that they would respect Ukraine's borders and never use nuclear weapons against it. American officials said those conditions could be met easily and hailed today's vote.
"This is an immensely positive and welcome step," said Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott. "It is a very significant contribution to the security of the region and to the new independent state of Ukraine. It is also important for the national security interests of the United States."
Russia has said it would not put into effect the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which made deep cuts in long-range nuclear weapons, until Ukraine signed the nonproliferation treaty.
Both the Russian Parliament and the United States Congress have also said they were waiting for that to happen before taking up ratification of a subsequent arms accord, known as Start II. Taken together, the two treaties would slash the American and Russian stockpiles by two-thirds, so each country would have between 3,000 and 3,500 warheads.
Both Republicans and Democrats in Congress have generally been favorably disposed toward aid to the Ukraine.
Over the last three years, both the Bush and Clinton Administrations have repeatedly pressed Ukraine to join the nonproliferation treaty, fearing that failure to join would sow discord between Ukraine and Russia. But until today, Ukraine's Parliament had delayed a decision, seeking to use their warheads as a bargaining chip for international respect, foreign aid and security guarantees.
President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine has spent the last few weeks urging his Parliament to ratify the treaty, warning them that his scheduled state visit to Washington next Monday and Tuesday would be under a cloud if this irritant to better United States-Ukrainian relations were not removed.
Before the Parliament ratified the treaty in a 301-to-8 vote, Mr. Kuchma told legislators today that acceding to the treaty was vital to improve Ukraine's international reputation.
"Ukraine today has no choice between being nuclear or nonnuclear," he said. "The process of world disarmament depends on our decision today."
Clinton Administration officials said Mr. Kuchma would be received warmly next week because of today's vote and because, after years of economic deadlock, he has taken bold and painful steps over the last month to remake Ukraine's economy along free-market lines.
Last January, Ukraine signed an agreement in Moscow with the United States and Russia in which it agreed to dismantle its missiles and send its warheads to Russia for destruction. Ukrainian officials said today that they have shipped 360 warheads to Russia and are ahead of schedule in destroying their stockpile.
Administration officials say Ukraine's decision to join the nonproliferation treaty is an important guarantee beyond the trilateral agreement to lock in its commitment to scrap its nuclear weapons.
During a visit to Washington, the Ukrainian Defense Minister, Valery Shmarov, told reporters that his country needed $50 million more in American aid this year to help build 2,500 housing units for deactivated soldiers and missile experts.
"It is not a big price for better security," he said.
One White House official said the Administration would look positively upon Mr. Shmarov's request, which comes on top of about $700 million in aid that the United States has pledged this year -- half in economic aid and half to dismantle Ukraine's nuclear arms.
With today's vote in Kiev, President Kuchma is expected to formally present Ukraine's accession to the nonproliferation treaty on Dec. 5 in Budapest at the summit meeting of the 53-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
At that session, President Clinton, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Prime Minister John Major of Britain are also expected to provide Mr. Kuchma with the security pledges his Parliament is seeking. As part of its assurances, the United States plans to promise Ukraine, as it did in the trilateral agreement last January, that it would consult with Kiev if Ukraine is ever threatened militarily.
The United States, Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus will exchange documents that formally make Start I take force. Under that treaty and associated documents, Kazakhstan and Belarus also agreed to eliminate their nuclear weapons.
