HEADLINE: Court Blocks New Rule on Immigration

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Saying it raised serious Constitutional questions, a Federal judge today temporarily blocked California officials from enforcing the heart of Proposition 187, the much-debated immigration-control measure the state's voters overwhelmingly passed last week.
Judge William Matthew Byrne Jr. of Federal District Court here found that the proposition, which would deny most government services to undocumented immigrants, might cause undue hardships and also might pre-empt law-enforcement powers reserved for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
 "I find that there is a balance of hardship that tips in favor of the plaintiffs," Judge Byrne said at the end of a two-hour hearing that had been called to hear complaints about the proposition filed by a number of civil rights and immigrant groups.
"There are serious questions," the judge added, "as to due-process violations, liberty interests and also property interests."
The proposition passed by a 3-to-2 margin at the end of a fall election campaign in which it emerged as the dominant issue. It would cut off schooling and nonemergency health care to undocumented immigrants and would require education and health officials to report to immigration authorities any person known or suspected not to have proper documents.
Immigration officials say California has more undocumented aliens than any other state, and California officials say the government services for them costs taxpayers more than $3 billion a year.
As illegal immigration has increased in California, so too has concern about its impact on the state's economy. This fall, that concern finally boiled over and angry state residents successfully petitioned to have the proposition placed on the ballot.
While Proposition 187 applies only to California, the impact of its debate and subsequent passage has been felt around the nation, particularly in Washington and in other states that have large numbers of undocumented immigrants.
Leaders of the proposition movement here say they will next try to force Congress to pass stricter immigration controls. They also say they will take their cause to other states with large immigrant populations, like Arizona, Texas and Florida.
Civil rights groups and immigrant advocates have vowed to oppose any efforts to spread the Proposition 187 movement. They assert that not only is the measure unconstitutional but that the anti-immigrant tide in California also stems mainly from hardships rendered by an economy that is weaker than that of most other states.
Judge Byrne's restraining order will run for 10 days. At the end of that period, the plaintiffs said they would begin legal proceedings to have the proposition permanently enjoined and then declared unconstitutional, a fight that lawyers on both sides said could last for several years or more.
"When you win a temporary restraining order, you're well on your way to the bigger victory," said Stephen Yagman, one of the plaintiffs' lawyers. "The requirements for the first are much the same as the requirements for what follows. We've met the first."
Lawyers for the state argued in court today that the proposition sought only to solve a problem that the Federal Government had neglected. They said after the hearing that while the restraining order was in effect they would work to draw up plans to enforce the provisions of the proposition in case the restraining order is eventually lifted.
Judge Byrne instructed them not to publish or disseminate any of the plans.
Despite the court setback today, one founder of the Proposition 187 movement, Ron Prince, remained confident of eventual victory in the fight to save the proposition.
"We anticipated this," he said. "You're going to have pluses and minuses all the way. We'll continue to work -- and win."
In today's restraining order, Judge Byrne exempted two provisions in the proposition that increase penalties for manufacturing or using false immigration documents. He said those provisions raised no issues of undue hardship or constitutionality.
Defending Proposition 187 during the hearing, one state lawyer, Jon Ichinaga, argued that California would enforce the measure in a way that would be both constitutional and humane. "We believe that once our regulations are put into place, there will be no violations of due process," he said.
Mr. Ichinaga also argued that there was no reason to grant a temporary restraining order because it would be weeks, at least, before the state could draw up and use any enforcement measures.
Judge Byrne asked about an executive order issued by Gov. Pete Wilson that state officials first enforce the proposition by cutting off government services to pregnant women and nursing home patients. Mr. Ichinaga replied that the prenatal section would not go into effect for 60 days and the nursing care section would affect only undocumented immigrants applying for care, not those already under care.
A plaintiffs' lawyer, Mark Rosenbaum of the American Civil Liberties Union, countered that sick people and students were already being adversely affected by the proposition, even though it was technically not being enforced.
"People in this community, in large numbers, have stopped using services," he said. "We have surveyed 10 clinics that serve the undocumented in Los Angeles, hundreds of persons per day, and that population has dropped precipitously. We have the gravest of irreparable injury."
State lawyers denied that any injury was being done and urged Judge Byrne to permit the proposition to stand as the only effective instrument to halt the flood of immigrants across California's porous borders.
"The court has a responsibility, if possible, to find an interpretation of the statute that saves it," Mr. Ichinaga added.

HEADLINE: War on Kurds Hurts Turks in U.S. Eyes

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 10

 BODY:
As Turkey's war with Kurdish separatists has become ever more violent and uncompromising, the Government has faced a predicament: the more it succeeds, by its own accounts, the more it loses the tolerance of the United States and other Western allies concerned about its increasingly harsh tactics.
Now, the rift is deeper than ever. 
 The Turkish military says that this year it has killed more than 3,000 guerrillas from the separatist Kurdish Workers Party -- more than in any other comparable period in a decade of fighting that has now claimed at least 13,000 lives, including several thousand civilians.
Backing its troops with helicopter gunships and warplanes made in the United States, it has deployed more than 220,000 soldiers -- nearly half the army -- in its biggest campaign against the guerrillas, who number fewer than 20,000. And it has embarked on an effort to deny the insurgents supplies and support as winter sets in, hoping to starve, freeze and hound them into defeat.
The price, though, has been an unusual restriction on American military aid to this NATO ally, reflecting worries in Washington and elsewhere in the West over the jailing of elected Kurdish legislators and over reports that military tactics include a campaign to depopulate Kurdish regions through the forced evacuation and sometimes by the burning of hundreds of remote villages, just as Saddam Hussein once did in Kurdish northern Iraq.
But Turkey is a country that regards itself as a Western-looking democracy and, increasingly, the strains between those principles and what the military views as the dictates of war have led to a kind of dual national identity. In the wealthy west, the land looks to Europe; in the hardscrabble east, it plays by the harsher rules of a region bordering Iran, Iraq and Syria.
And the cost of the war -- estimates among Western diplomats range from $7 billion a year up -- is draining Turkey's debt-ridden economy so that spending on health and education has been cut.
Some 10 million to 12 million Kurds live in Turkey, mainly in the southeast. The basic issue in the war is the nature of the state founded by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk in 1923. With their Marxist ideology and separatist aspirations, the Kurdish guerrillas collide directly with the founding notion of Turkey as a land unified by language, faith and national identity.
It is only in the last few years that the Government has acknowledged what President Suleyman Demirel called a "Kurdish reality." Any concession toward Kurdish ethnicity, like the use of the Kurdish language in broadcasting or education, meets with strong political and military opposition as an erosion of Ataturk's notion of the state.
"This trial is not about us; it is about the Kurdish identity and the Kurdish problem," said Hatip Dicle, one of eight elected Kurdish members of Parliament arrested this year on treason charges and accused of being fronts for the Kurdish Workers Party, known as the P.K.K. He was speaking at his trial, which is still under way.
The move against the legislators, including the banning of their political party, the Kurdish Democratic Party, reflects the Government's urge to deny the separatists any political legitimacy. But the crackdown has taken its toll among Turkey's allies.
In September the United States Congress suspended $38 million in military aid, one-tenth of the total, and ordered the State Department to investigate Turkey's record on human rights.
The campaign in the southeast, now centered on the snowy, mountainous uplands of Tunceli province, has increased Western fears that basic human rights are being ignored.
"In Tunceli, it is the state that is evacuating and burning villages," Human Rights Minister Azimet Koyuoglu said in a newspaper interview last month. "Acts of terrorism in other regions are done by the P.K.K. In Tunceli, it is state terrorism." In all, he said, 600 villages and 790 hamlets had been evacuated.
While he revised his views under pressure from the authorities, his words found much resonance among the thousands of villagers who have been forced out of their villages by troops.
"First they empty the villages, and then they burn them so the P.K.K. cannot seek refuge in them," said Kamer Genc, a legislator from Tunceli. In recent years, economic and military pressures have forced at least half of Turkey's Kurds to flee the war zone.
Prime Minister Tansu Ciller says that when villages are burned, it is the work of guerrillas dressed as Government troops.
"The state does not burn villages," she told members of her True Path Party last month, arguing that since the local authorities in the southeast had authority to "evacuate" villages, there "is no need to clear these villages by burning them."
Such is the military's domination of Turkish war policy that the local military commander would not allow Deputy Prime Minister Murat Karayalcin to visit the area to look into reports that villages were burned last month.
The Kurdish Workers Party itself has a reputation for brutality, and many Western governments say it is a terrorist group.
Diplomats and human rights groups say the insurgents have killed villagers and burned down their homes to punish them for agreeing to take up arms for the Government as village guards. They have killed teachers sent to the region simply because they teach in Turkish, not Kurdish.
For several years now, as winter approached, Turkish officials have said that they were finally close to crushing the guerrillas. Then, in the spring, the war restarted. The current military campaign is intended to break the cycle.
"This year Turkey has had some successes," said a Western diplomat in Ankara. "But it has not come close to the military crushing" of the rebels.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall Despite Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Despite an increase in the Consumer Price Index that was smaller than expected, the prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the first time this week.
The report on consumer prices, a closely followed measure of inflation, sent long-bond prices up a half- point in the morning, but persistent fears that inflation could still accelerate quickly turned those modest gains into sharp losses by midday. 
 Adding to the day's negative tone was a weak dollar. There was also concern about more supply coming to a nervous market, as dealers looked ahead to the sales next week of new two-year and five-year notes.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32 , to 9311/32 , for a yield of 8.09 percent, up from 8.05 percent on Tuesday, or a loss of about $3.44 for $1,000 invested in bonds.
Traders said they saw the selling as a sign that investors had little trust that the week's bond market rally could be sustained.
"Despite the bullish C.P.I., there remains a perception that the current economic strength will soon push inflation higher," said Greg Jones, senior economist for MMS International. "The market appears to be unable to push higher on a sustained basis without any evidence of a slowing economy."
"The inability of the bond to break through 8 percent on the ideal combo of aggressive Fed tightening and lower inflation does not bode well for the market," he added.
Nor does the heavy supply of new issues being offered. The Treasury said yesterday that in addition to selling $27.2 billion of three- and six-month bills at its regular weekly auction, it would sell $17.25 billion in new two- and five-year notes on Monday and Tuesday, respectively, because the week will be shortened by the Thanksgiving holiday.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's sales, dealers are offering the notes at prices to yield 7.22 percent for the two-year note, and 7.75 percent for the five-year issue.
Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist for NatWest Securities, who said he was a bear before it was fashionable in this cycle, said the timing might be good for bonds from technical and fundamental standpoints.
"Investors are so busy being bearish that they do not see the signs of a slowing economy," Mr. Canelo said. Among those signs, he said, has been the performance of the stock market, the best leading indicator of the economy.
"In past rate hikes, stocks have rallied because it meant that the economy was getting stronger and that was good for business," he said. "But this time, there was a muted response to the interest-rate hike, suggesting that the previous rate increases are beginning to take effect."
Mr. Canelo noted, for example, that the yield curve was flattening, which historically has come as the economy has begun to show signs of slowing.
Among the other symptoms of the cooling economy, Mr. Canelo said, are a slowing of money growth, a slower pace of job creation, a fall in consumer confidence for five months, a fall in business formation for six months and flat help wanted advertising since midyear.
"What's most dramatic is that the slowdown is here, and nobody is noticing it," he said.
In the municipal market, bond prices fell amid a lack of investor demand, as states, cities and agencies sold $1.8 billion of new securities, the most new issues in more than a month.
But investors showed strong demand for issues with high credit ratings. The New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation, one of the few issuers in the state with a triple-A credit rating, sold $261 million of water pollution control revolving fund revenue bonds in a negotiated offering managed by Bear, Stearns & Company.
Investors' demand was strong enough that some yields were lowered five basis points in several maturities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The issues were priced to yield as much as 6.90 percent for one due in 2015.
Of the $1.08 billion of debt sold in the corporate market, the Household Finance Corporation sold $687 million of floating-rate notes backed by home equity loans in two parts, through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Some creative ways Republicans could deliver on the contract.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FASTER than a speeding bullet, more powerful than a locomotive, the new Congressional Republican majority is about to sweep away despised taxes, smash the pork barrel and balance the budget, all while leaping tall buildings in a single bound.
That, at least, is the promise of Newt Gingrich, Richard Armey, Phil Gramm and other "new" Republicans who have taken the election as a mandate for a conservative revolution. The real question is how far they are willing to go -- or can go -- to push an agenda that promises everything without explaining how it could be delivered. While numerous variations are possible, two core strategies seem most plausible. 
 Fudge the Numbers. The biggest obstacle to adoption of the fiscal provisions in Mr. Gingrich's "Contract with America" is the budget process.
Under reforms adopted in the 1980's, the estimated revenues and expenditures in the budget delivered to the White House must fit within the deficit targets. Van Doorn Ooms, a former House Budget Committee economist who now works for the private Committee for Economic Development, says "that somebody would have to come up with the budget cuts" to match the revenue losses in the contract. Republicans estimate those losses at $200 billion over five years.
One solution is to take a creative look at the numbers, applying what supply-siders call "dynamic scoring" to tax cuts. After all, only the Great Bean Counter in the Sky knows for sure whether capital gains breaks will lead to a blitz of productivity-inducing innovation.
By law, however, the estimates are made by the Congressional Budget Office using numbers provided by the Joint Committee on Taxation. And both agencies are now dominated by sticks-in-the-mud inclined to equate dynamic scoring with the sort of smoke-and-mirrors accounting that got a lot of savings and loans in trouble.
That may not stand in the way. Rudolph Penner of Peat Marwick ran the Congressional Budget Office in the 1980's. He says a Republican majority could pack the budget office and the tax committee staff with allies, thereby giving a Republican budget the benefit of every doubt.
As a complement, suggests Stanley Collender, director of Federal budget policy at Price Waterhouse, the Republicans might try "government on automatic pilot." They could cope with deficit nitpickers by writing legislation that would proportionately reduce social entitlement spending (other than Social Security) if the supply-side tax cuts failed to yield the expected bonanza.
If such legislation made it to the White House without the entitlement safety valve, President Clinton would face some unpleasant choices. He could veto the budget, risking blame for denying Americans all those painless tax breaks. From a purely partisan Republican perspective, this would be ideal. But while Mr. Clinton has on occasion risked the high road, it is hard to believe he would this time around.
Hence Mr. Collender speculates that the President would sign a supply-siders' budget, but counter it with a gambit. He would announce that as the budget law required he would sequester above-budget spending on entitlement programs unless Congress acted first. The idea, of course, would be to do what no Democrat has done before -- to pass the deficit buck to the Republicans.
There are some problems with this course. For one thing, Mr. Penner argues, it is far from clear that a majority of Republicans would go along with a supply-siders' putsch in the tax committee and the budget office. For another, Mr. Collender points out, "the bond market would go nuts" at the prospect of a flirtation with deja voodoo economics. Last but hardly least, it constitutes the sort of high-stakes political poker that is rarely played to the finish. So what's Mr. Gingrich's alternative?
Win a Few Easy Ones and Declare Victory. A balanced budget amendment -- even one that does not bite until the politicians responsible for passing it are long gone -- would surely be popular in talk-radio land. The Republicans could take the credit even if the President goes along. And if he opposes it, so much the better. Another idea is welfare reform that would cut total appropriations and leave it to the states to apportion the pain. This has the disadvantage of irritating Republican governors in the trenches and perhaps creating a few martyrs among the worthy poor. On the other hand, it would free a little cash to pay for a tax cut -- especially one designed to make maximum political waves with minimum immediate impact.
Consider the possibilities: individual retirement accounts with no tax deferral for contributions but no taxes on the payout, most of which would not occur until decades from now. Or what about child tax credits that are phased in over a decade or "neutral cost recovery" depreciation rules for business investment that would initially generate extra revenue but reduce taxes by tens of billions by the turn of the century. And there's plenty more where that came from.

HEADLINE: Offer Made At Gypsum Concern

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
The National Gypsum Company's chairman, C. D. Spangler Jr., offered yesterday to buy the company for $940 million, or $43.50 a share. But analysts ridiculed the price as far too low, and investors bid up the shares $12.0625, to $44.8125, in Nasdaq trading.
That price, however, represented a sharp increase from the $12.50 a share at which National Gypsum was valued 16 months ago, when the company emerged from bankruptcy protection. At that time, the senior creditors and the company's management, since replaced, told other creditors, including asbestos claimants, that the company was not worth a penny more. 
 National Gypsum, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., is the nation's second-largest maker of gypsum-coated wallboard, which is used mostly in houses. It credits its improved stock price to a rebound in the market for wallboard, as housing demand expands and industry overcapacity vanishes.
"It stems from a general improvement in the economy," a spokesman for the company, Alan V. Cecil, said.
The senior creditors, who ended up with most of the stock when the company emerged from bankruptcy, have now multiplied the value of their investments. The holders of $537 million in the most junior debt have less than 15 cents on the dollar.
The junior creditors said yesterday that the offer of $43.50 a share proved that investment bankers and former managers had underestimated the company's value.
"You can't imagine how it pains me every time I have to look back at this case," said Wilbur L. Ross Jr. of Rothschild Inc., who advised the junior creditors. Though a court approved the $12.50 share value, he noted that the company had improved its earnings by raising prices and cutting costs only after emerging from bankruptcy.
Mr. Spangler, a large North Carolina investor, began buying shares of National Gypsum a year ago and now holds a stake of 19 percent. In a letter to the company's board, he pointed out that he was offering a premium of 32.8 percent over Tuesday's closing price of $32.75.
But analysts sharply criticized his bid. Barbara Allen of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette called the $43.50 offer "mystifying and troubling."
"We will sell at $80," she said.
Last year, investment bankers at that firm, advising National Gypsum's former executives, vouched for a value of $12.50 a share.
Another dispute from the bankruptcy case could block the deal. The trustees for a $700 million fund to pay off asbestos-injury claims against National Gypsum have said recently that the fund might run more than $1 billion short, and that they may have to go to the company for more money.
In making his offer by letter yesterday, Mr. Spangler said the asbestos matters must be resolved to his satisfaction. The board plans to consider his offer soon and see if rival bidders emerge. Analysts said they feared that Mr. Spangler and LaFarge Coppee, a French cement company that holds 9.9 percent of National Gypsum and has pledged to vote with Mr. Spangler, could force the company to accept.
"I think it's a much better stock as a public company than as a buyout," said David Dwyer of Kidder, Peabody & Company. In view of the rising demand for wallboard and higher prices, the directors should accept no offer below $55, he said.
Mr. Spangler, who formally made his offer through the Delcor unit of Golden Eagle Industries, apparently his investment vehicle, declined to comment. His two main partners in the deal are Nationsbank and First Union, normally fierce rivals in North Carolina banking.
In his letter, he noted his disappointment with the decline in National Gypsum's stock price in the last eight months from a high of $52.75 in mid-March, which analysts attributed to fears that rising interest rates would choke off home building.
Mr. Spangler is one the largest shareholders of Nationsbank, with eight million shares. He is also president of the University of North Carolina system.
The banks' partnership -- "unprecedented," said W. Barnes Hauptfuhrer, a First Union investment banker -- reflects Mr. Spangler's influence in North Carolina. The banks have each agreed to put up $134.1 million for stock in the acquired company and as much as $187.5 million in loans. Mr. Spangler would contribute his own shares, valued at $168.4 million at the acquisition price, and a further $150 million.

HEADLINE: No Plans for Soon-to-Be Former Governor

 BODY:
It has come to this for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
"Governor Jim Florio called me yesterday," Mr. Cuomo explained to a radio interviewer yesterday about a call on Tuesday. "He says, 'So Mario, what's to be, here?' I said I think finally I'm going to have a legacy. Jan. 1, I don't have a place to live. I don't have a job. I'm going to be the first homeless, unemployed, former 12-year governor in the history of the state. By Jan. 9, I can picture myself all huddled, freezing on a cold pavement, you know, chilling my tush, telling some guy with a seven-day growth of beard, 'I don't want to go to your lousy shelter.' " 
 Mr. Cuomo was joking, of course. But eight days after his defeat by Governor-elect George E. Pataki, Mr. Cuomo still has not announced where he will live or how he will earn a living once he leaves office.
In the 30-minute interview on WAMC-FM radio in Albany, Mr. Cuomo also predicted that Mr. Pataki would have to break his campaign pledge to cut income taxes by 25 percent over four years. "I would not give up on the possibility that the next Governor would come to see things a little bit differently in the course of being Governor," he said. "For example, I don't think it's realistic to believe that he can do the tax cut he said he would do in the campaign. That's not in the cards."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Thomson Will Buy Medstat for $339 Million

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Thomson Corporation, a Canadian company whose media empire includes The Globe and Mail in Toronto and American Banker, said yesterday that it would acquire a medical data provider for $339 million in cash.
Thomson will pay $27 a share for the Medstat Group of Ann Arbor, Mich., a developer of health care information data bases and related software. 
 Medstat, which will retain its current headquarters and management team, sells its products and services to both health care providers and payers, including hospitals, health maintenance organizations, insurers and self-insured corporations. The data are used to analyze insurance claims and costs.
The offering price is 57 percent higher than Medstat's closing stock price of $17.25 on Tuesday. Yesterday, shares of Medstat jumped $9.25, to $26.50, in heavy Nasdaq trading.
The deal reflects a growing interest in health care information providers. Earlier this year, Dun & Bradstreet and the Electronic Data Systems unit of the General Motors Corporation announced a joint venture in health care information services, and other large information providers like Equifax and McGraw-Hill have also expressed interest, said Jason Rosenbluth, an analyst with Volpe, Welty & Company.
"It's a huge perceived market, but not a huge market in terms of dollars right now," Mr. Rosenbluth said. "It's at an embryonic stage."
Thomson already has a presence in health care, with its Medical Economics Publishing and Medical Economics Data units.
Yesterday's deal would give Medstat more critical mass and improved distribution in a consolidating health care market, analysts said. Medstat's data bases would complement Thomson's products.
"For Medstat, this deal adds some clout," said Dirk Godsey, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "Medstat lacked a big sales force with a position in the physician market. Thomson has the distribution channel but is constantly in the hunt for content; what Medstat represents is content."
Shares of Thomson were unchanged at $16.125 (Canadian), on the Toronto Stock Exchange yesterday.
The acquisition is the second announced by Thomson in the last three weeks. On Oct. 31 Thomson paid $465 million to acquire the Ziff Communications Company's electronic data base unit.
After announcing the purchase of Ziff's Information Access unit, the chief financial officer of Thomson, Nigel R. Harrison, said the company was considering other acquisitions.
For the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, Medstat had earnings of $7.4 million, up 45 percent from $5.1 million in the corresponding period last year. The company has about 500 employees, with offices spread across the United States, partly as a result of a series of acquisitions in the last few years.
"The strategic fit between the Medstat Group and the medically focused companies of Thomson offer real long-term potential to more broadly share information," Medstat's vice president of marketing, Vi Shaffer, said. "We wanted to align with a strong partner that shared our culture."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Exxon Leads Signers Of Indonesia Gas Deal

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation and Pertamina, Indonesia's national oil company, have agreed to develop one of the largest offshore natural gas deposits in the world.
The project, which Exxon says will eventually require as much as $40 billion in investment, was announced here today as President Clinton turned to business issues on his last day in Indonesia, after the conclusion of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum here. 
 With Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown presiding and members of the Indonesian Cabinet looking on, agreements were signed for a total of 17 projects involving United States companies. They ranged from construction of a 1.2-megawatt coal-fired power plant to the sale of aquatic weed harvesters to help clean Indonesia's waterways.
The Commerce Department put the value of all the American deals at $40 billion -- appraising the cost of the natural gas agreement at $35 billion, as much as $5 billion Exxon officials' estimate.
Mr. Clinton referred to the agreements in a speech to American and Asian businessmen here, as he reaffirmed his Administration's willingness to help United States companies land contracts throughout the world.
"I know that there is increasing wealth in Indonesia and throughout Asia, but where I come from $40 billion is still real money -- and we're grateful for the business," the President said.
Fritz Voigt, Exxon's vice president for gas, said at a news conference in Houston that it was too early to forecast how much the gas project would add to Exxon's earnings and revenue figures. He said that the project would not come on stream for eight years and that the terms of the sales contracts for the gas had not been fixed.
[In New York, Exxon's stock closed Wednesday at 60.625, up 75 cents for the day.]
The huge natural gas field, which was discovered in 1973, lies 140 miles northeast of Natuna, an Indonesian island about 700 miles north of Jakarta, the capital.
As Exxon officials described the project's complexity, huge steel platforms some as high as 60 stories, must be built offshore to extract the gas from the field, which lies 470 feet underwater.
The gas will travel by pipeline to a liquefied natural gas plant that will also be built on Natuna, an island 40 miles long and 28 miles wide. A marine terminal will be constructed on the island for supertankers that will transport the gas to markets like Japan and Korea, several thousand miles away.
Other American companies are expected to bid for some of the work.
Exxon Exploration, Exxon's local affiliate, and Pertamina expect to sell the liquefied gas almost exclusively in Asia. They are betting that major customers will be willing to sign long-term contracts at high enough prices to justify the huge investment, in which the first payoff will not be seen until 2002.
None of the gas is likely to be exported to the United States, Mr. Voigt said, because of the distances involved.
He added that he expected demand for gas in the Far East to double by the end of the century.
Once deliveries of liquefied gas start, it could help power the continuing growth of many Asian countries that are planning to build huge gas-burning power plants.
Among the other deals signed today, General Electric, Fluor Daniel, Combustion Engineering and Mission Energy were given contracts for various aspects of the construction of the 1.2-megawatt power plant, in which total American involvement will exceed $1 billion. California Energy said it would develop a geothermal energy project and Hughes Network Systems received a contract for wireless phone systems.
To some businessmen here, the salesmanship by the President and his Cabinet will yield far more tangible benefits than the vague declaration to create a free trading area by the year 2020 that was issued on Tuesday by the 18 nations that make up the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC.
"APEC is very strong on atmospherics and very low on take-home value," said Harvey Goldstein, chairman of Harvest International, a consulting firm here. "But the relationship is important. When the President visits Indonesia, it provides leverage for American business."
Many of the contracts signed today would have been reached in any case. Asked what role the United States Government had in helping achieve the contract for the Natuna gas project, E. W. Young, a spokesman here for Exxon International, replied, "Fundamentally none."
Secretary Brown disagreed, saying that the Government pushed for Exxon during the years that it took to negotiate the complex contract. He said Mr. Clinton's visit provided an incentive for Indonesian companies to conclude the agreements.
"A lot of business people were worried that if they didn't get done today, there would be no deal," Mr. Brown said in an interview. "Many of the deals would get done anyway, but how long would they take? In many cases we have driven the completion."

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Barely Rose Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Consumer prices barely budged in October, the Government said today, offering more evidence that inflation remains largely in check, despite signs of strong economic growth.
The Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of a percent last month, following September's gain of two-tenths of a percent. The report followed by a day the decision by the Federal Reserve to make the largest interest rate increase in 14 years in an effort to fight inflation. The central bank raised key short-term interest rates on Tuesday by three-quarters of a percentage point -- its sixth increase this year. 
 Last month's overall gain in the price index was the smallest since prices posted a similar rise in April, despite higher October prices for health care and new cars.
A drop of seven-tenths of 1 percent in energy prices last month helped hold down the overall index. Food prices, which remained unchanged, also tempered the general advance. In September, energy prices also fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, while food prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
The so-called core rate of inflaiton, which factors out the often volatile food and energy segments, showed a rise of two-tenths of a percent.
Economists stressed that the Fed's attempt to curb inflation was a pre-emptive strike. By taking some of the sizzle out of the recovery now, some say, the Fed will probably prolong the economy's ability to grow at a steady clip.
If Fed officials did not act now, "at some point they'd be forced to come in and slam on the brakes," James Glassman, senior economist at Chemical Securities, said. "That's what creates havoc. That's what triggers a recession."
Other data released by the Government suggested that the economy could strengthen further.
Americans' average weekly paychecks jumped 1.5 percent in October. The increase was the largest since a 2.3 percent gain in February 1982, the Labor Department said. In September, earnings showed a rise of seven-tenths of a percent.
The Commerce Department said inventories held by American businesses rose in September for a sixth straight month as businesses stocked goods for the holiday season.
Total business inventories increased five-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $907.2 billion -- well above Wall Street economists' expectations of a rise of one-tenth of a percent -- following a gain of nine-tenths of a percent in August. Most of the inventory increase occurred at the retail level.
But business sales, which surged 3.3 percent in August, declined for the first time since July, dipping two-tenths of a percent in September. As a result, the inventory-to-sales ratio rose to 1.40, from a record low of 1.39 in August. The September figure means that it would take 1.40 months to exhaust stockpiles at the September sales rate.
The consumer price figures showed inflation rising at a pace that was slightly slower than forecast. Economists on average had predicted that consumer prices rose two-tenths of a percent last month. Excluding food and energy, they expected prices to rise three-tenths of a percent.
"The recent data suggest that the Fed may indeed be ahead of the curve in its fight against inflation," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics); "Inventory-Sales Ratio" tracks total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales, seasonally adjusted, from April 1993 through September 1994. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
G.O.P.'s Tax Cut Theory: Bonanza or Bust?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
With a conviction that approaches religious fervor, many Republicans hold that certain kinds of tax cuts would significantly strengthen the economy. People and companies would earn more money as a consequence, they say. And the taxes paid on that additional income would offset the revenue lost from the lower tax rates, completely or at least in part.
In the budget lexicon, this is what is called dynamic scoring. 
 But the practice is heretical to the members of the revenue-estimating fraternity in both parties who for years have been in charge of trying to figure out what the consequences would be of various proposals to raise or lower taxes.
Dynamic scoring is suddenly an issue because the Republicans, who won control of the House and the Senate in this year's elections, are determined to enact a spate of tax cuts, including tax credits for middle-income families and a lower capital gains tax rate. Under the current budget law, each tax cut must be offset, dollar for dollar, by an increase in other taxes or a spending reduction. So what the estimators say about the revenue effect of a tax proposal is crucial.
Over the years the Treasury Department, the Office of Management and Budget and the staffs of the Joint Committee on Taxation and Congressional Budget Office have followed a forecasting system called static scoring to figure the potential effects of tax policy changes.
Under this system, estimators try to predict how individual taxpayers would change their behavior as a consequence of policy changes. For example, they try to figure how much cigarette sales would drop because of a higher tax on cigarettes. But they do not take into account the potential macroeconomic effect of tax changes, which means the effect on the nation's economy.
They assume the overall economy, and thus the number of jobs created and the level of interest rates and the size of the gross domestic product, will remain static.
Now, with Republicans running Congress, the budget fraternity may be confronted with dynamic scoring the way Pope Leo X had to face Martin Luther.
What worries many politicians and economists is that the Republicans will use dynamic estimates to show that their tax cuts would not cost the Government any money, or at least would not lose as much revenue as is shown by conventional forecasting. That theory is more or less what was followed in the early 1980's, when supply-side economics was in vogue during the Reagan Administration and the deficit soared.
Alice M. Rivlin, President Clinton's budget director, told reporters this week: "Tax cuts must be paid for. Tax cuts without spending cuts would increase the budget deficit and would be an irresponsible thing to do."
Republicans insist that they do intend to make spending cuts, though they have yet to identify which particular ones they have in mind. If the new Republican staff directors of the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation adopt the dynamic method of calculation, fewer spending reductions may be necessary to meet the requirements of the budget law.
If such calculations prove accurate in the years ahead, it could be a bonanza for Americans. Not only would their taxes be lower, but they would also have to give up fewer Government benefits.
But if dynamic calculations prove wrong, serious consequences could result. Budget deficits could be higher than expected, scaring financial markets and leaving Americans worse off.
In the case of one of the top items on the Republican wish list -- a lower capital gains tax -- the use of dynamic scoring would make a substantial difference and the debate over the difference has been going on since the Reagan Administration.
The Republican staff of the House Budget Committee, using conventional calculations, found that over a five-year period the Treasury would lose $56 billion in revenue from a capital gains tax cut.
On the other hand, Gary and Aldona Robbins, economic consultants in Arlington, Va., whose work is closely followed by many Republicans, assessed a similar bill using a computer model that factors in their view of how the overall economy would respond. This showed that the capital gains tax reduction would increase growth by four-tenths of 1 percent each year and that Government revenues would grow by $126 billion by the turn of the century.
In other words, a cut in capital gains taxes would not only require no offsetting spending reduction but could also be used under the budget law to pay for other tax cuts.
But Robert S. McIntyre, director of the Citizens for Tax Justice, a research center that works closely with Democrats, studied the same data and concluded that to the extent changes in the capital gains tax had moved the overall economy at all, the effect had been detrimental.
The problem is that the strength or weakness of America's $5 trillion economy is the result of many factors. Opinions differ over how much weight to give the size of the tax on capital gains, or any other factor.
That is why conventional economic wisdom says that the macroeconomic effects of tax changes should not be taken into account in budget calculations. "It's the safest approach," said Stanley E. Collender, director of Federal budget policy at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. "What's most important is to do it in a way that won't make things much worse if you're wrong."
But Norman B. Ture, a tax policy official in the Reagan Administration who is now president of a research center called the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, argues that it makes no sense to ignore reality.
"The only thing you can say for sure about static revenue estimates," he said, "is that they are certainly wrong. You know that tax changes have some effect. Why not work to find a way to make estimates that at least are less wrong?"

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
After a 55-year absence, Maxwell House coffee embraces the Times Square market again.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
MORE than five decades after advertising for Maxwell House last overlooked Times Square, the coffee brand will drop back into the neighborhood.
General Foods USA, which markets Maxwell House, plans to unveil an extravagant neon billboard -- the type that makers of outdoor signs call spectaculars -- on New Year's Eve, during the hullabaloo greeting the arrival of 1995. The ad will join others on the exterior of the Marriott Marquis Hotel on Broadway; it will be erected on the building's 46th Street side, around the corner from gaudy, glitzy billboards for Eastman Kodak and Hertz. 
 Maxwell House's second sign in Times Square, measuring 40 feet high by 60 feet wide, will echo the first, which according to company records stood from 1928 to 1939 about a block north of Duffy Square. The traditional touches include the brand's longtime slogan, "Good to the last drop."
The high-tech touches will include a translucent, three-dimensional coffee cup, 20 feet in diameter, and the rendering of Maxwell House's familiar final drip in a neon cascade to simulate an endless descent -- an eternal drop, as it were, ever falling, ever good.
The Maxwell House comeback is emblematic of the changing Times Square ad landscape. Improvements in the area's economic and physical health are helping to transform the lineup of marketers planting, or replanting, their brands' banners there.
During the 1970's and 1980's, when Times Square's bleak, shabby appearance discouraged visitors and residents alike, signs for American household-name products were supplanted by billboards promoting Japanese and Korean brands like Canon, Goldstar, JVC, Minolta, Samsung and Sony. They were lured by the international approbation for Times Square's image as the colorful "crossroads of the world," which still gleamed despite its dimming domestically.
But now, as the neighborhood's fortunes seem on the ascent, companies based in this country -- including Gap Inc., Hertz, Jockey, Kodak, Levi Strauss, NBC and Sara Lee -- are demonstrating a new, or renewed, willingness to associate themselves with Times Square.
Not only is Times Square "the heartbeat of New York," said Ann Marks, Maxwell House's vice president for marketing at the General Foods USA unit of Kraft General Foods in White Plains, "it's a national focal point."
And many of the brands whose signs are illuminating Times Square "are classic American brands," she added, "and that's what we consider Maxwell House." The coffee was introduced in 1892; it was New York's top-selling brand by 1925 and, Ms. Marks said, it still is (though nationally it is outsold by Folgers).
George Stonbely, president at Spectacolor, the New York company that specializes in spectaculars and is designing Maxwell House's, said: "The American companies see that the kind of presence they can have for their products and services in Times Square is unique. You can't get that tremendous size and impact on TV."
"It's no secret Times Square was really in the doldrums for many years," he added. "But starting with the Marriott Marquis in 1985, the area has gone through a boom. And the signs parallel the re-emergence of Times Square as a great entertainment center."
Spectacolor will lease and maintain the sign, which is being built by the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation in New York, the constructor of many spectaculars like the recently dismantled neon Joe Camel billboard for Camel cigarettes.
Neither Ms. Marks nor Mr. Stonbely would disclose the cost of the Maxwell House sign. But millions of dollars are required to build such a sign, lease the space under a multiyear contract, operate the sign and maintain it.
One difference between the old and new signs is that while the Maxwell House name and the "last drop" slogan will be back, the word "coffee" will be absent, perhaps on the premise that after 55 additional years of consumers' exposure to Maxwell House marketing, it would be redundant.
Plans for the spectacular's unveiling include a live radio broadcast, Ms. Marks said, reminiscent of the initial lighting of the first sign. That took place during a live broadcast of a radio program sponsored by Maxwell House and featured the brand's founder, Joel Cheek.
The plans also call for giving out free cups of Maxwell House to the New Year's Eve revelers, she added, in connection with a fund-raiser to assist the homeless and the charitable organization Habitat for Humanity.
For those who insist that Maxwell House is not their cup of coffee, the brand's sign won't be the only java jive in Times Square.
The Maxwell House spectacular will be across the street from a huge painted coffee cup that emits mock steam to promote the Eight O'Clock brand of bean coffee sold at supermarket chains including A.& P. That sign is on the southeast corner of 46th Street and Seventh Avenue.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Maxwell House will return to Times Square on New Year's Eve with a neon "spectacular," above, on the Marriott Marquis Hotel. The sign will echo its ad of more than five decades ago, left, which stood about a block north. (The Bettmann Archive)

HEADLINE: Mort Pye Is Retiring as Editor Of Star-Ledger after 31 Years

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

 BODY:
Mort Pye, editor of The Star-Ledger of Newark, New Jersey's largest daily newspaper in circulation, will retire at the end of the year, the paper announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by James P. Willse, former editor and publisher of The Daily News.
Mr. Pye, 76, has had one of the longest runs in the nation as a top editor of a major daily newspaper, arriving in the newsroom at The Star-Ledger in 1957 as managing editor and holding the post of editor since 1963. 
 In his 37 years at The Star-Ledger, the paper went from a weak position behind the prestigious Newark Evening News -- which folded in the early 1970's -- to a far-reaching power in the New Jersey economic and political landscape. It is ranked as the 14th largest daily and the 12th largest Sunday paper in the nation, with circulation approximately 456,000 daily and about 686,000 on Sunday, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulation.
Known for long work hours that rarely took him out of the newsroom and into public view, Mr. Pye said yesterday that age was finally overtaking his zest for the job.
"Next year I will be going into my 77th year, and I feel I no longer have the energy and stamina to continue operating the way I have in the past," he said in a statement. "Therefore, I have concluded it's in my best interest -- and the paper's -- for me to retire."
For Mr. Willse (pronounced WILL-zee), taking over the profitable and smooth-running Star-Ledger will be a sharp departure from his tenure at The Daily News, when the tabloid fought for survival in a series of changes of ownership, circulation declines, labor strife and revolving-door news staffs.
Donald E. Newhouse, the president of The Star-Ledger, called Mr. Willse "the ideal person to succeed Mort as editor of The Star-Ledger," adding, "He has the experience, the breadth of knowledge and the ability to work with people to continue and carry forward Mort's work."
Mr. Pye's wife, Florence, is a member of the Newhouse family, which owns The Star-Ledger.
Mr. Willse, 51, will be watched closely to see what changes he may envision for the New Jersey paper. It gives blanket coverage of sports, politics and statewide news, with 15 bureaus throughout New Jersey, though civic leaders in Newark have complained that it does not pay enough attention to the city.
"It's not a particularly exciting newspaper to read; the writing is still basic oatmeal," said John Kolesar, the former managing editor of The Camden Courier-Post.
Mr. Pye was sent from The Long Island Daily Press, another Newhouse paper, to Newark in 1957, when the city was still a prosperous business and manufacturing hub. At the time The Star-Ledger was regarded as a scandal sheet with a small staff and primitive production.
Over the years, he raised staff and circulation, built a new plant in Newark and, after a racial riot in 1967 set off white flight from the city, he pushed circulation far outside its traditional Essex County base.
He championed the arts and exerted the influence of the paper, at the same time working behind the scenes, in a long campaign for a sports complex in the Meadowlands. The complex eventually drew New York's two professional football teams across the Hudson. He also delighted in taking meandering weekend car trips around the state, checking out possible travel-page stories and circulation opportunities.
His name -- "Mort" to his staff -- and soft-spoken telephone voice were familiar in the state's power circles, but it was unlikely most readers of Mr. Pye's newspaper could name or identify its editor, such was the low profile he maintained over the decades out of the public eye.

HEADLINE: Thinking as the Fed Thinks

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
After yesterday's benign inflation report -- consumer prices edged up a minuscule one-tenth of a percent -- even more people were left scratching their heads over the Fed's big interest rate increase on Tuesday. What on earth, many asked, were Alan Greenspan, the moderate Republican who serves as Fed chairman, and Alan S. Blinder, the liberal Democrat who is vice chairman, thinking?
It is certainly true that there are few signs that inflation is a problem now. The broad measures of prices generally look quite reassuring. Producer prices, as well as the consumer prices that the Labor Department reported yesterday, have been rising slowly. [Page D6.] 
 Even taking into account last month's spurt in hourly earnings of production workers, wage gains are generally moderate. And productivity of the work force is growing a bit faster, on average, than it did during the 1970's and 80's.
But what the people at the Federal Reserve are worried about, many economists said yesterday, are a number of problems just below the surface that could lead to higher inflation sometime within the next year. That helps explain why the Fed decided to raise the two short-term interest rates it controls by an exceptionally strong three-quarters of a percentage point.
"Looking backwards, inflation is so well contained that it makes the Fed's move look extraordinarily aggressive," said Laurence H. Meyer, president of Laurence H. Meyer & Associates in St. Louis, who is neither a Wall Street economist nor a zero-inflation hawk. Still, he added, "I don't think it was crazy,"
Here's why. For starters, prices are not quite so well behaved as the Fed critics would like to believe. Commodity prices are rising rapidly and the crude-materials portion of the Producer Price Index, which fell five-tenths of a percent over all last month, has recently been heading higher. That is not always a sign that the price of finished goods bought by retailers will necessarily rise faster, but it often is.
Other data show factory capacity is becoming tight. At 85 percent, capacity use is a point or two beyond the 82 or 83 percent typically associated with rising inflation. If more people want to buy cars but the supply of cars is not rising apace, for example, prices tend to go up.
The most compelling cause for concern, many analysts believe, is that the economy is operating at full employment or maybe even past that point. Full employment does not mean everybody who wants a job necessarily finds one in a reasonable period of time. It simply means a rate below which inflationary pressures start to build.
That threshold, experience and studies suggest, may be about 6 percent, give or take a few tenths. Not only is unemployment now 5.8 percent, but growth is also sufficiently rapid to drive it down further.
"We're just a little bit on the other side of safety," Mr. Meyer said. "If you believe that full employment is 6 percent, and you understand the economy is growing 3.5 to 4 percent, then you can understand the Fed's action. They've got to slow the economy down to 2.5 percent growth or below."
Wait a minute, aren't we in a new economy? After all, there are more temporary workers, more flexible production, more foreign trade. All that, according to critics of the Fed, means that tighter labor markets do not necessarily translate into broad inflationary pressures.
The structure of the economy, however, does not change that quickly. Compared with the 1950's, 60's, even the 70's, there may have been big shifts. But as recently as 1988 or 1989, the unemployment rate was 5.3 percent (5.8 percent on today's measure). At that time, the rate of consumer and wage inflation was rising by a half to a full percentage point a year and commodity prices were climbing even more rapidly than today. That was certainly no rerun of the inflationary 1970's, but it was enough to set off alarm bells at the Fed and in the bond market.
In the late 1980's, most of the forces that were supposed to prevent inflation from breaking out were also present: military spending was shrinking, fiscal stimulus was absent, low-wage workers were having a hard time and big corporations were starting to eliminate layers of middle-management employees.
To be sure, freer trade and intense global competition are holding down price increases. But those factors were present in 1989 as well. Indeed, these days, import prices are rising more rapidly than domestic prices as a result of the weaker dollar.
Wall Street, of course, is always worrying about inflation. But on Main Street, the anti-inflation hawks in the financial markets seem out of touch with the real world.
Pressed by the bond market, the Fed appears to be excessively concerned about holding the line on inflation, according to a number of officials representing manufacturers and labor unions. Most working Americans might well prefer a little more inflation -- say 4 percent -- if that would mean unemployment could go as low as 5 percent.
The experience of the high-inflation years of the 1970's and early 80's, however, suggests that is impossible. Once unemployment drops below 6 percent or so, inflation does not just stabilize at a new, higher level, it keeps accelerating.
The Fed is also struggling to cope with the consequences of its previous actions. Even though the current state of the economy looks remarkably good -- with robust growth and low inflation -- there is plenty of evidence that the Fed is now making up for what it regards as mistakes it made earlier in the recovery. When the economy was slow to emerge from recession, the Fed pushed short-term interest rates below the rate of inflation and held them there for two years to give the economy an extra kick.
"They bought the story that pervaded the financial markets that we were on the brink of a double or triple dip and they eased excessively in response to those fears," said Stephen Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley.
The Fed kept policy expansive in 1992 and 1993 at the very moment, hindsight shows, when the economy was gathering steam. Interest-sensitive sectors like housing and autos were starting to recover. And the Fed's underestimation of the economy's strength continued well into this year as the central bank kept forecasting that its interest rate increases that began in February would slow the economy sharply and lead unemployment to level out above 6 percent.
In fact, the exact opposite seems to have happened. There is little evidence that the Fed's actions, at least those before Tuesday's big move, have done much to dampen the expansion. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, for example, shows that most upper-income households, after steadily scaling back plans to buy homes, cars, and appliances early this year, have regained most of their enthusiasm for shopping.
Led by Mr. Greenspan, the Fed's attempts to prevent an acceleration in inflation obviously carry risks, namely of a recession. That may be particularly true today because the central bank cannot necessarily rein in inflation as easily as it might have been able to if it had acted sooner.
Still, the potential benefit of keeping inflation low is a longer expansion. "This means this expansion could go on longer and means there is no reason for us to have a downturn in 1996 and 1997," said Wayne D. Angell, a former Fed governor who is now chief economist at Bear, Stearns.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Yields Some Ground Gained on Rate Increases

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar lost ground against most leading currencies yesterday and traders cited profit taking after Tuesday's strong gains.
Currency traders rushed to buy dollars on Tuesday after the the Federal Reserve's sharp increases in short-term interest rates reassured them that the Fed was committed to fighting inflation. Higher interest rates tend to bolster the value of a currency. 
 But the dollar's momentum faded yesterday as traders cashed in on the dollar's rise against the German mark and the Japanese yen in the last two weeks. A selloff in the United States bond market further undermined the dollar.
"The dollar kind of ran out of steam," said Robert White, senior vice president at Standard Chartered Bank. "The bond market has not reacted as positively as some people had thought."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5506 marks from 1.5561 marks on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 98.34 yen from 98.69.
Peggy Reed, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York, said the interest rate increases on Tuesday showed "the aggressive nature of what the Fed is willing to do in order to prevent an inflation situation from taking hold."
But the Fed did not indicate on Tuesday that the rate move would be the last in a while, she said, which created uncertainty in the markets about whether inflationary pressures had eased sufficiently to forestall additional increases in the coming months. Inflation erodes the value of American bonds and stocks held by foreign investors, thus discouraging the demand for dollars to buy such assets.
While the dollar weakened against most European currencies, it strengthened somewhat against the British pound after a report dampened expectations of an increase in interest rates.
The British Government reported yesterday that its chief inflation index rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in October from September, pushing the annual inflation rate up to 2.4 percent -- its lowest level since 1991. The pound has been stronger since the Bank of England last raised interest rates in September.
In New York, the pound slipped to $1.5723 from $1.5725. The dollar fell to 1.3045 Swiss francs, from 1.3095 francs on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Traders Can't Shuffle Their Decks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 16

 BODY:
A group of high-profile men gathered here this week to try to plot their separate courses for next year, but a large amount of their attention has been focused, figuratively at least, on coming events in Washington. They're not politicians but general managers of major league baseball teams.
"Right now there's so much that people don't know," Terry Ryan of the Minnesota Twins said. "You don't know what route you're headed. I'm sure we will not be getting the answers here. The people working in Washington with Mr. Usery will tell us." 
 Ryan, one of five rookie general managers at the annual meetings, referred to the negotiations that will resume Thursday in the Washington suburb of Herndon, Va. As the first order of business, under the watchful eye of Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, the owners' bargaining team is supposed to give the players' labor representatives a new proposal.
Although they won't send their coveted salary-cap plan into oblivion, leaving it instead on a corner of the bargaining table, the owners will present the players with an alternative proposal, this one outlining a luxury tax on payrolls that soar above a certain level.
It's another method of trying to control salaries, which is the owners' stated aim, and the players, after studying the figures for a couple of days, are expected to react to it the way they have to the cap they want no part of.
The general managers, of course, want to know what kind of economic system they will be working under, whether they will have limits on their payrolls or have to pay the tax assessor. But they also are eager to learn which players may be eligible for free agency and whether they will have to endure salary arbitration early next year. The existence of arbitration could affect their thinking on tendering contracts to some players by the Dec. 20 deadline.
Agreement or not, they should have their answers by a month from now. That's about the time the owners, if there is no agreement, are expected to declare an impasse in negotiations and impose their own rules in place of those in the expired collective bargaining agreement.
Until one or the other happens, though, the general managers forge ahead in whacking their way through an uncharted thicket.
"We're kind of treading water till this new system is in place," Dan Duquette of the Boston Red Sox said. "Most general managers are waiting to see what the new agreement will mean."
"We're all walking on eggshells," John Schuerholz of the Atlanta Braves said.
"Coming in as a new general manager," added Doug Melvin of the Texas Rangers, another of the rookies, "you want to be aggressive, but now you have to be a little cautious. Without knowing the system, it's a lot tougher than normal."
The absence of rules, however, never could inhibit general managers from talking trades; they talk trades whatever the circumstances, whatever the location. They haven't made any, but these meetings generally have been more about talk than action.
"I thought it would slow down the conversation, but I don't detect that," Bob Quinn of the San Francisco Giants said, after the morning business sessions broke up today. "Everybody is operating under a speculative mode and making their plans accordingly. We're still talking trade. Much of it depends on the service time of the players involved, but basically it's been business as usual, only on a more speculative basis."
Walt Jocketty, the St. Louis Cardinals' rookie, noted that the only safe trade to make right now would be the swap of a signed player for a signed player. "You have to be careful," he said. "You could lose someone."
He referred to the possibility that a new system could create a new class of free agents. In their June 14 proposal, the only one they have made, the owners said that players with four and five years of major league service could become free agents. The existing eligibility requirement is six years.

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
Playing the Numbers Game, Ownership Style

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
In an extraordinary group rant yesterday morning, the National Hockey League's assembled general managers expressed the usual arguments in unusually strident tones. They used sarcasm and anger to convey their frustration with the players union and portions of the news media who are skeptical when the 26 teams say they lost a total of $37.6 million last season.
Only a radically altered collective bargaining agreement, with restrictions on wages, can save the remainder of the already-damaged season and the future of the business, they said. Soon, they may hold their collective breath until they turn blue, or they may huff and puff and blow the league down. 
 They pleaded their case to the news media and told reporters to believe them on faith. They said they were insulted when asked to provide public documentation for their claims. Their numbers are none of your business, they said, although they use them to justify a 47-day lockout that has already wiped out at least a quarter of the season.
Glen Sather of the Edmonton Oilers said that Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the union, is "calling us all liars.
"I don't think Mr. Goodenow has really been negotiating in good faith," Sather said. "I think he wants to force us into a situation where we can't have hockey this year."
Would it bolster management's case, Sather was asked, if the league makes its finances public?
"As far as I'm concerned, yes, I'd like to make everything public so that we can get this thing over with," Sather said. "You imply these numbers aren't real. That's the same story I get from the players."
He said lying about finances can cause legal trouble.
"You think I want to go to jail?" Sather said. "We've already got one guy who's in this league going to jail." He was referring to Bruce McNall of the Los Angeles Kings, who this week was charged with financial felonies.
Sather then amended his intentions on disclosure. "I wouldn't want to make the numbers of our team public to all you guys," he told the assembled reporters. And Lou Lamoriello of the Devils said he would keep his ledgers private, too.
"Quite frankly, I don't think it's any of your business," Lamoriello said. "I don't want my books out there." Lamoriello also said, "If you think we don't want to be playing hockey, something's wrong with you."
Many executives, especially Harry Sinden of Boston, said repeatedly that the league has leveled with the union on finances. But John McCambridge, a lawyer for the union, said this isn't exactly true.
"They have given us compiled revenues, but no profit and losses statements, no expenses and no idea of which teams are losing or making money except for the Rangers," he said. "They told us the Rangers didn't make money last year when they won the Stanley Cup. No one believes that."
Ken Baumgartner, a vice president of the union, said that he was weary of "attempts to discredit Bob Goodenow" and that "if Bob is loathed that much, he must be doing a good job." Baumgartner noted that Alan Eagleson, who was ousted in favor of Goodenow and is under indictment on labor racketeering charges, appeared at the Hall of Fame ceremonies Tuesday in the company of Bill Wirtz, the powerful Chicago owner.
"What's wrong with this picture?" Baumgartner asked.
Back at the hotel, Sinden scoffed at the latest union proposal to restrict the contract rights of rookies, saying it's like giving a canoe to someone in a desert. Sinden also questioned the credentials of Marty McSorley, a union vice president who called the most recent player proposal a significant compromise.
"Marty McSorley, as far as I know, has been a player all his career," Sinden said. "Glen said McSorley started out these negotiations as an economist. He didn't realize McSorley was an economist. And I didn't realize he worked as a G.M. somewhere along the line."
Gary Bettman, the commissioner, said the specific figure on losses wasn't important. "Whether it's $37.6 million or 50 or 30, it's not as important as the over all health of this business," he said.
Bettman has proposed that an accounting firm audit the books and present its report to the players association. The union will soon counterpropose that an investment bank assess the same numbers.
When the conversation turned to player-sponsored exhibition tournaments, such as the three-night event in Hamilton, Ontario, last week, Bettman expressed skepticism over the announced attendance of more than 43,000.
"Despite the announced attendance, the building was half-full," Bettman said. When someone said "Gary, does that mean you don't trust union numbers?" Bettman smiled and replied: "That's what people tell me who were there. I would have announced what they announced also."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Boston Bruins' president, Harry Sinden, scoffs at the latest union proposal that would restrict the contract rights of rookies. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The Children of Guantanamo

 BODY:
What a difference three months make. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, has been safely re-elected as Governor of Florida. Fidel Castro is again preventing his people from setting out in rafts, and a U.S.-occupied Haiti is no longer sending forth masses of terrified refugees. As a result, the refugee question has cooled as a political issue in Florida and the Clinton Administration is testing the waters for another refugee policy U-turn.
For 28 years Cuban refugees arriving in the U.S. were automatically admitted under a double standard that distinguished them from other people fleeing government oppression and economic collapse. But in August the Clinton Administration began intercepting Cubans at sea, taking them to the Guantanamo Bay Naval Base and proclaiming that they would never be admitted to the U.S. 
 Pressed by Cuban-American groups, Mr. Clinton is considering allowing Cuban families with children under 17 quarantined at Guantanamo to enter the U.S. on humanitarian grounds. That category includes close to a third of the 24,000 Cubans housed at the base.
Humanitarian treatment of refugees is in the best American tradition. But admitting the Cuban families would raise a serious issue of fairness. There are 230 Haitian children under 17 housed at the same Guantanamo base. Are their families not also entitled to humanitarian consideration?
One crucial difference, of course, is that a repressive Haitian government is no longer in power, while one is in Cuba. But under law, the Haitians at Guantanamo are in exactly the same situation as the Cubans. Both groups said they feared going home. They still say so. Washington refused to uphold or even properly hear their claims, because certifying those claims would have allowed them to come to the U.S. Instead it said: If you feel unsafe you may stay at Guantanamo, but you may not come to the U.S. Both groups have lawsuits opposing this policy. Mr. Clinton is ready to relax that rigidity for the Cubans but not the Haitians.
Under existing policy, Haitians and Cubans can voluntary agree to return home and apply for visas to the U.S. from there. In that case, the Cubans would have much better odds of getting admitted. Under the agreement reached between Washington and Havana in September that ended the flow of raft people, opportunities for Cubans to win legal admission to the U.S. were greatly expanded. Up to 26,000 Cubans will be allowed in next year.
Yet while many of the Haitians formerly housed at Guantanamo have voluntarily returned to Haiti since the military regime was ousted, very few Cubans have done so. The simplest, most humane solution would be a one-time admission of all Cuban and Haitian families now at Guantanamo. But it is also possible for the Administration to make a principled distinction between Haitians, who can now return to a much freer country than they left, and Cubans, who still cannot. However, the long history of the political and racial double standard applied to Cubans and Haitians puts a special burden on the Administration. If it makes a distinction now, it must convincingly show that it is following fair and objective standards -- that it is not simply reacting to the political power of Cuban-Americans, and the powerlessness of the Haitians.
The conditions now prevailing in Cuba and Haiti are obviously different. But the humanitarian issues raised by Cuban and Haitian children in Guantanamo are not.
