HEADLINE: Misplaced Fears About the Fed

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision this week to raise interest rates in order to ward off inflation was, as expected, criticized from all corners. Manufacturers warned that higher interest rates would drive up costs and drive away consumers. Labor unions predicted layoffs. Politicians feared disgruntled voters.
The Fed, these critics argued, ought not to slow down the economy when inflation is low, seven million Americans cannot find jobs and tens of millions more cannot find work that pays good wages. Besides, they complained, driving up interest rates amounts to an unfair assault on vulnerable workers and an unseemly giveaway to rich bondholders. 
 Economic forecasting is primitive, so no one can prove the critics wrong. Perhaps the rate hike of three-quarters of a percentage point -- the sixth rise this year and the largest in more than a decade -- is unnecessary. Worse, it may be unwise, possibly tipping the economy into recession about the time the 1996 Presidential campaign gets under way. But the Fed presumably took all these factors into account and, after carefully sifting the data, has settled on a prudent course.
One indication is the unanimous vote. The policy was approved even by Alan Blinder -- recent Clinton appointee, unapologetic liberal and self-proclaimed "inflation dove" who, as an academic, opposed tight monetary policies more often than almost all his colleagues. What Mr. Blinder and the other Fed members noted was that the economy grew more than 4 percent over the past year. That pace is well above the rate, 2.5 percent, that most economists believe the economy can sustain. The 2.5 figure comes from adding growth due to increases in the labor force (1.0 percent) to growth due to productivity gains (1.5 percent).
The Fed also noted that its five previous rate hikes have not slowed the economy very much. Even the automobile sector, which should react quickest to rate hikes, is still expanding. The economy is creating about 200,000 jobs a month, which exceeds the number of entrants into the labor force so that unemployment has steadily fallen.
Indeed, the economy is operating close to capacity. Factory output is at record levels. Further growth will not produce many more jobs but could generate more inflation. If the Fed were to sit back and wait for inflation to spurt, it would then have to clamp down hard. That is what it did in the early 1980's, triggering the worst recession since the Depression. Chairman Alan Greenspan is committed to imposing modest restraint now in order to ward off harsh restraints later.
The charge that Mr. Greenspan's policy is unfair is weaker still. True, higher rates will drive up the cost of car loans and home mortgages. But the impact on families will be less feared: many of them will profit from higher interest payments on bank savings accounts, retirement and pension funds. Nor is the rate hike undiluted good news for wealthy bondholders; bond prices fall when interest rates rise.
American workers, especially low-paid ones, are understandably restless and apprehensive. Their wages have stagnated for two decades. But the villain is not the Fed but weak productivity. The biggest threat to vulnerable families would be for the Fed to let inflation rise, victimizing pensioners and others living on fixed incomes, and then tackle it by throwing the economy into recession. Unemployment hits low-paid workers hardest.
That would be worse than unfair. It would be cruel. So far Fed policy has produced steady, if unspectacular, growth without a pickup in inflation. That is no small achievement. Indeed, the muted responses to the announcement by Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, and Laura Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, indicate that, as much as they hope for robust growth, they recognize that the Fed is proceeding responsibly.

HEADLINE: Let the Democrats Act More Like Democrats

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The 1994 Republican landslide occurred because a small group of swing voters voted more Republican than they usually do. To recover, the Democrats must deal not only with the anger of those voters, but with the apathy of the 10-times-larger group that didn't vote. 
 Both groups shared a common viewpoint: that government doesn't work. The nonvoters said, "Then why vote?" The swing voters said: "Then why pay for it? At least the Republicans will cut taxes."
To win back any percentage of either group, the Democrats must ignore the advice to act more like Republicans. Instead, they must act more like Democrats.
The Democrats should stop telling people that things are going well or are on the mend. They are not. Real personal income for all but the wealthy continues to fall. Corporate and government downsizing have turned job security into an oxymoron. United States manufacturing continues to head overseas. Center cities continue to decay. Health care remains in crisis. Racism and other forms of discrimination continue to threaten our society's fabric.
The Democrats should propose and fight for programs to address these issues, modifying or abandoning those that have failed. President Clinton talked about some of these during the Presidential election, but excepting health care, he made proposals on few of them.
The proposals should be simple, direct and not consensus-producing. For instance, the tax structure rewards companies that move overseas and encourages excessive downsizing, helping to put millions out of work. The very rich pay far too small a percentage of the tax burden; the middle class pays too much.
We cannot produce a consensus on changing these things, but we can produce a broad movement behind proposals that address inequities if we keep them simple, don't back off or pretend they're good for all.
The Democrats should be unified in support of their proposals, as the Republicans were this year.
The Republican agenda fails to address the fundamental problems in the lives of average people. While there may be temporary tax or short-term economic changes, the long-term trends of deindustrialization, center-city collapse and increasing disparity between the rich and everyone else will continue.
Unless the Democrats fight for the changes people need, the swing voters and nonvoters will continue to believe that government can't work and will continue to desert the Democrats.
 
DANIEL E. LIVINGSTON
Hartford, Nov. 14, 1994
 
The writer is a labor and employment lawyer.

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: TRADE;
New Status Puts Dole in Crosscurrents on GATT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The phone is ringing endlessly at Senator Bob Dole's offices in Kansas and on Capitol Hill, but not just with congratulations for his new status as majority-leader-in-waiting.
Barely nine days after he was swept to a victory even he did not predict, he is caught in the cross-currents as Republican party leader and nascent statesman, as potential Presidential candidate and as a free-trader with second thoughts about the popularity of free trade. 
 It is not a happy place to be, especially when the argument is over an international agreement that everyone says will have a vast but unknowable effect on the fate of the world economy and that is so staggeringly dense -- four volumes costing $145 at the Government Printing Office -- that no one knows anyone who has actually read it.
"I wouldn't want to be Bob Dole," said Jerry Junkins, the chief executive of Texas Instruments, who is the head of a business lobbying group, the Alliance for GATT Now, that is trying to push the wavering Senator to support the agreement, which would cover 123 nations.
"Boeing is big in Kansas, and so are the farmers," he said, ticking off others with longstanding ties to Senator Dole who stand to gain from the agreement. "But he must be thinking about other things as well," he suggested, things that include primaries in New Hampshire and Iowa that are only 18 months away.
The vote on the world trade agreement, which will be taken up by a lame-duck session of Congress after Thanksgiving, has suddenly become the crucial first test for Senator Dole, who is currently the Senate minority leader. He is trying to convince President Clinton that unlike Representative Newt Gingrich, who is soon to be Speaker of the House, he is interested in compromise. He is trying to look like a statesman.
At the same time, Mr. Dole is feeling the heat from the right wing of his party, which would happily hand Mr. Clinton an embarrassing international defeat. And he has to decide whether to side with the growing numbers in his party who, after five decades of unquestioned support for free trade, now join many Democrats in arguing that it is a code word for destroying middle-class jobs and surrendering American sovereignty to an ominous-sounding group of anonymous foreign judges called the World Trade Organization.
Faced with so much pressure from so many sides, Senator Dole has done what he usually accuses the White House of doing on foreign policy issues: He has waffled. He likes the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, he keeps saying, because it will force America's competitors to lower their tariffs, to stop government subsidies of companies that compete with American industry and to to extend copyright protection to including computer software, sound recordings and movies, all strong American exports.
But he has problems, he keeps saying without being too terribly specific, with many provisions in the legislation. This afternoon, as Senator Dole traveled in Minnesota on what his office called personal business, his staff was putting together a modest list of changes that, in the words of one negotiator in the process, "will give him a way to protect himself politically."
The White House concedes that without Mr. Dole, the trade agreement is dead. So, Administration officials, in the first taste of the next two years, went out of their way today to say that they were sure that whatever Mr. Dole wanted Mr. Dole would get.
"I'm fairly confident at this point," said Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, who is negotiating with Mr. Dole.
The main issue continues to be finding a way for Congress to monitor the new World Trade Organization on a sustained basis and maintaining the threat that the United States could pull out of the agreement if the new group of international arbiters repeatedly rules against American environmental or labor laws, or other regulations for imported goods.
"This is an agreement that goes back to the Reagan and Bush years, and it has never been a partisan issue for Senator Dole. I'm sure we can work through any problems he has."
But Mr. Dole's problems with the trade pact have less to do with the agreement than the polarizing issues that lie just beneath its surface. Many in the Republican Party say last week's election was a landslide because they finally won over white high-school educated males whose incomes have stagnated in the past decade. They are the workers most hurt by free trade rules that allow in greater foreign imports. And they are the ones who are least likely to move to the new industries -- in high technology and in service industries -- that the Administration believes will continue to be the cutting edge of America's export drive into world markets.
But GATT is overwhelmingly supported by Mr. Dole's core constituencies, the people who are likely to finance any Presidential bid. More than 250 agricultural groups have backed it, convinced that European and Japanese farmers will be hurt far more by the tariff reductions than they will. The aircraft industry, led by Boeing, has been the most vociferous in favor of the agreement, because it limits foreign governments from subsidizing their own aircraft industries.
Mr. Dole is left to conduct an elaborate dance, not wanting to be blamed for the doom of a 123-nation agreement, and not wanting to appear to turn his back on those suspicious that their incomes and jobs are being sacrificed by a set of free trade principles.
It is a particularly difficult two-step because support for the pact will place Mr. Dole and President Clinton on the same side of the free trade issue -- just as the President is trying to get maximum political mileage out of his arguments that Asia and Latin America will be the source of millions of new jobs for Americans. It is a theme the President hit this week in Indonesia and will again next month in Miami, at a summit of Latin American leaders.

HEADLINE: Russians Grouse (at U.S. Embassy)

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Russians are once again complaining about long lines, red tape and bone-chilling rudeness from petty bureaucrats.
Only now they maintain that such typical Soviet-era indignities are rampant in the consular section of the American Embassy. 
 Ordinary citizens, and even a few journalists and former dissidents who have sought tourist visas to the United States, are increasingly indignant over what they describe as rude and humiliating treatment by American consular officers. The United States Embassy retorts that 80 percent of all visa requests here are granted and that the complaints reflect the Russians' misunderstanding of American bureaucracy and immigration law.
But the conflict is also a reflection of the new kinds of cultural clashes that have surfaced now that the grand ideological divide between the former superpowers has narrowed. Russians, accustomed to being treated by American diplomats as cherished allies in the struggle against the Communist Government, are now shocked and offended to find themselves treated no differently from Mexicans, Filipinos or Irish.
But even many American residents -- and a few United States diplomats -- complain that the American Embassy in Moscow has failed to adapt to the post-Communist era, remaining in some ways as insular and bureaucratic now as it was when under siege from a Communist Government. Paradoxically, as Russian society grows more free-wheeling and open, the suburban-style red-brick fortress America in central Moscow seems all the more impregnable.
The latest incident occurred earlier this month, when Sergei A. Kovalyov, a former anti-Soviet dissident who now is chairman of the Russian Parliament's human rights committee, picketed the embassy to protest a friend's visa denial.
In an open letter in Izvestia to the American Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, Mr. Kovalyov said his friend, Georgi P. Grigorenko -- son of another well-known dissident, the late Pyotr G. Grigorenko -- was denied a visa to visit his dying stepmother because the consular officer thought he might immigrate.
"The Communist authorities did not allow Georgi to go to the States to his father's funeral," Mr. Kovalyov wrote. "Now the U.S. consular service is doing the same."
Embassy officials said he should have called the political section first, where officers would have been more likely to recognize his name, and would have intervened.
Mr. Kovalyov replied that he tried to reach the one political officer he knew, but was not put through. Finally he telephoned a well-connected friend in Washington, who called Clinton Administration officials. Mr. Grigorenko was issued a visa the next day.
"I spoke to two consular officers and neither had ever heard of Grigorenko," Mr. Kovalyov said. "It's like a Russian diplomat at our embassy in Washington not knowing Martin Luther King."
Mr. Kovalyov's outrage proved embarrassing to an embassy staff that believed the visa controversy had been finally put to rest. This summer, the issue had reached a boiling point after a journalist, Yevgeniya Albats, wrote an article in Izvestia about the "humiliating" and "insulting" treatment she received when seeking a visa to the United States. "It was like being in a Soviet store in the middle of the 80's," she wrote.
The article caused such a stir that the Ambassador wrote a letter to Izvestia rebutting the article and explaining the consular section's constraints, which include having to interview as many as 500 applicants a day. But privately, embassy officials were dismissive about the accusations of uncouth behavior. One high-ranking diplomat said scornfully, "The Russians should know; they are connoisseurs of rudeness."
Most employees are housed in a red-brick embassy compound of condo-style apartments. The compound has its own basketball court, video store, bar, gym, football field, barbecue pits, post office and grocery store -- a kind of suburban American biosphere. Residents can easily avoid contact with Russian society, and many do.
The staff is large, with several new departments like the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Agency for International Development, but it is difficult to gauge how much it has grown over the last five years. The embassy personnel office was unable to supply the total number of employees.
All officials declined to be identified by name, because, they said, on-the-record interviews must first be cleared in Washington, a process that can take days and sometimes weeks.
Embassy officials said that their employees are exhausted and overworked, and that much time is tied up receiving Congressional and State Department delegations. Most employees keep 9 to 6 hours, and unlike the British and Finnish Embassies, the American Embassy closes for Russian holidays as well as American ones.
And while officials denied any discourteous behavior, in the aftermath of the criticism, the number of consular officers on duty was increased from three to six. An express line was also created.
The friction is partly a result of the inevitable antagonism between civilian petitioners and Government bureaucrats; there is rarely much joie de vivre in a motor vehicle registration line. But there are also peculiarly Russian-American misunderstandings. Many Russians complain that they are asked to state their income out loud. Ms. Albats wrote that such a question in Russia was as "indecent as in the States asking a stranger what kind of sex he prefers."
A 58-year-old employee of the Academy of Sciences, who spoke on the condition that her name not be used, said she was asked her income by a consular officer who was impatient, rude and never looked up from her desk. "We were used to that style in Soviet days," she said, "but we don't want to see it from America."
Russians often believe that a letter of invitation is the key prerequisite for a visa, but Congress mandates that the State Department presume that all applicants are potential immigrants and screen for ties, such as property or family, that would prevent someone from staying on in the United States. Most visa interviews are disconcertingly brief, lasting four or five minutes at most.
"A two-minute interview is tough," one diplomat said. "but in Mexico City, people are lucky to get 15 seconds."
The ultranationalist politician Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who toured the United States recently, did not undergo the embassy's scrutiny. The decision to issue him a visa was so sensitive that it was handled in Washington.
When the Texas millionaire Robert S. Strauss became Ambassador in 1991, he opened his doors to American business people, giving them his ear and granting them access, for a fee, to the embassy gym and cafeteria. Since then Mr. Pickering, a former naval officer and a career diplomat, has sought to limit the access of non-embassy Americans. Sometimes, the measures can appear a touch churlish: This Halloween, for the first time, non-embassy children were banned from trick-or-treating on the compound.
Many Americans, particularly in Moscow's growing business community, are as aggrieved as Russians by an institution they consider their own.
"The embassy is behind the curve in making the transition from a political/defense focus to an economic focus," said Richard Conn, managing partner of the law firm Latham & Watkins. "They don't seem interested in helping business. Ironically, our embassy is one of the last vestiges of the Soviet bureaucracy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Russians are complaining about their treatment at the American Embassy in Moscow. Irina Koltasheva checked instructions after being denied a visa to visit her son, a student in Los Angeles. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bishops Assail Rule Hostile To Immigrants

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops urged today that greater emphasis be placed on Federal immigration policies rather than relying on punitive local measures like Proposition 187 in California, which denies illegal immigrants nonemergency medical, educational and social services.
In a statement issued on the final day of their annual fall meeting, the bishops said the taxpayer frustration that fueled passage of Proposition 187 established an intimidating tone that could foster "harassment of persons who may look or sound 'undocumented.' " What was needed, they said, was a rational discussion of Federal policies that regulate legal entry into the United States. 
 "In seeking to cure social and economic ills, this proposition strikes at the most vulnerable among us -- children, the sick and the needy -- without addressing the larger social and political causes for the problems, especially at the Federal level," said the statement issued by Archbishop William H. Keeler of Baltimore, who is president of the bishops' conference.
In contrast to their statement on immigration, the bishops seemed intent on avoiding even the perception of political partisanship regarding school prayer. Congressional Republicans have said they support passage of a constitutional amendment guaranteeing a right to prayer in public schools. Archbishop Keeler, who was recently designated a Cardinal, said he would have to see the wording of any such amendment before taking a position on it.
But he suggested that ways be found to teach "basic moral values" in public schools.
The bishops' statement on immigration echoed a theme sounded several times this week during the conference: government's responsibility to help the poor. But the bishops also sought to portray the church as willing to help at home in times of need, noting that the church was already the nation's largest provider of charitable services.
The bishops were intent on sending a clear message of their disappointment in the negative tone that has dominated the nation's immigration debate. But Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles said earlier in the week that since half the nation's illegal immigrants entered the United States on temporary visas, the Government should develop better tracking mechanisms to prevent these visitors from overstaying their visas.
The California measure was a harsh and ineffective response, the Cardinal said. He also said that the church was considering fighting the proposition by filing friend-of-the-court briefs in legal challenges.
"I think some of the individualism of the 1980's really stuck," he said. "What we lost in the country was a sense of the common good."
Responsibility to communities, especially youth and the poor, was a recurring concern this week as the bishops urged a "moral revolution" against violence in American society, affirmed their belief that health care was a basic right and cautioned against welfare reforms that would limit or deny people government-financed social services while expecting charities to extend their care of the needy.
Focusing on a major source of that care, the bishops today also issued a revised set of directives to provide moral guidance to Catholic hospitals in an age of new technologies, increased demand and institutional partnerships.
The directives, which took six years to complete, reaffirm and clarify church teachings on topics like life-sustaining measures, partnerships with secular institutions and access to health care.
"This document reiterates that health care is a basic right," said the Rev. Tom Kopfenstein, a moral theologian who served as a consultant to the committee that drafted the guidelines. "Justice has become a medical, moral issue."
With a nod to the changing economics of health care and the drive for hospitals to join institutional networks, the directives say that under some conditions, Catholic hospitals could enter partnerships with hospitals that provide services that contradict church teaching, like artificial insemination. Approval for any such move would have to come from the diocesan bishop, the guidelines said. And even then, the Catholic facility must not participate directly in prohibited procedures.
While maintaining opposition to euthanasia and doctor-assisted suicide, the directives allow for the administration of painkillers that might hasten death; they also say that patients may refuse medical treatment that has no appreciable benefit.

HEADLINE: For Utilities, New Clean-Air Plan

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Opening the door to a lower-cost method for reducing "greenhouse" gases that contribute to global warming, two big electric utilities have made a first-of-its-kind deal to trade air pollution allowances.
The agreement, scheduled to be announced today by Niagara Mohawk, serving upstate New York, and Arizona Public Service in Phoenix, is the first in which the right to emit one type of pollutant is being swapped for another. 
 Even more significant, part of the deal involves using a portion of the million-dollar proceeds from a tax break to finance experiments in reducing climate-warming emissions outside the United States.
At first, the experiments will be modest. One reportedly high on the utilities' list is a plan to generate electricity in India with waste heat from sugar refineries that now just goes up the stack. Another is reforestation in Mexico, where Arizona Public Service is already building strategic alliances with electric utilities.
But the experiments could deliver immense benefits in the future. Almost all of the cheapest opportunities for reducing emissions of gases that are warming the atmosphere lie outside North America, Western Europe and Japan. Modernizing electricity production in China, for instance, offers one of the best prospects because the economy there is growing so rapidly, requiring China to burn enormous amounts of coal in highly inefficient power plants. An even simpler way to control emissions would be to repair leaks in Russia's poorly maintained natural gas pipelines, which spew methane into the atmosphere.
Government officials aware of the utility deal say it may point to a better way of meeting Washington's expected obligations under future international agreements to limit global warming.
The utility deal, by demonstrating the advantages of going abroad to reduce greenhouse gases in the least expensive way, also could open the way eventually to an international trade in pollution allowances.
"If we are going to deal with climate warming efficiently," said Robert Stavins, an environmental economist at Harvard University, "there will have to be international trading in which Western countries get credit for reducing emissions elsewhere."
The Clean Air Act of 1990 put a cap on utilities' emissions of sulfur dioxide, a byproduct of fuel burning that contributes to acid rain. But it allows utilities to meet their obligations by buying emissions "allowances" from other companies.
This market-based approach, the Environmental Protection Agency says, is already saving rate payers $400 million to $600 million a year. It works because one utility that finds a cheaper way to cut emissions can profit by doing more than the law requires, selling the right to pollute to another utility that would have found it more expensive to achieve those reductions itself.
Arizona Public Service can easily meet the requirements of the law in its own territory because it earlier agreed to pay for equipment to reduce the haze above the Grand Canyon. In the process, it is reducing sulfur emissions.
Niagara Mohawk is also in good shape because it relies on huge amounts of nonpolluting hydropower to meet the needs of its customers.
But both Arizona Public Service and Niagara Mohawk have a separate obligation to contain climate-warming gases, which for the most part consist of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels. The utilities signed the Clinton Administration's Climate Challenge Accord in April 1994, a voluntary agreement to do their part in meeting America's international treaty commitment to keep emissions of greenhouse gases under the levels produced in 1990. William E. Davis, the chief executive of Niagara Mohawk, says the company hopes to demonstrate that its method offers a better approach than "command and control regulations by Congress."
Niagara Mohawk expects no difficulties in hitting its greenhouse gas target. But Arizona Public Service does: "Demand for power in our service area is growing at double the national rate," said O. Mark DeMichele, the chief executive of Arizona Public Service, and "power consumption is already three years ahead of projections."
The Arizona utility thus needed help, which was forthcoming from Niagara Mohawk. Under a deal brokered by the Environmental Defense Fund, the New York utility agreed to absorb 1.75 million tons of Arizona Public Services' obligation to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in return for 25,000 tons of sulfur dioxide allowances.
Since Niagara Mohawk has no foreseeable need for the sulfur allowances it is reaping, the utility plans to donate the allowances to a nonprofit group (as yet unnamed), which will retire them permanently. Niagara Mohawk still benefits because it will be able to claim a corporate income tax deduction of about $150 a ton. "Northeast Utilities did precisely the same thing, donating sulfur allowances to the American Lung Association," said Joseph Goffman, senior lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund.
Utilities have been exchanging sulfur dioxide allowances for cash for some time, both in private agreements and through a commodities exchange maintained by the Chicago Board of Trade. The price of the allowance, however, has remained below earlier expectations.
The Climate Control accord deliberately offered utilities maximum leeway in meeting emissions reduction targets -- anything from insulating houses to subsidizing electric cars. The deal between Arizona Public Service and Niagara Mohawk shows that American utilities may be able to fulfill their obligations even more cheaply by finding foreign sources of pollution that they agree to clean up.
The Department of Energy, which has been not-so-quietly urging such experiments, plans to help by amassing a data base to be used for arranging international trades and verifying compliance.
The deal does have a few weak spots. This is not a free lunch for everyone: Some of the money to finance the experiment is coming from taxpayers in the form of deductions for the sulfur emissions. More is coming from rate payers and stockholders, since the utilities could choose instead to sell their extra sulfur allowances for a profit rather than donating them to charity.
But Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, defends the deal as a very cheap lunch. "Market solutions to environmental problems," she said, "will always be cheaper than direct regulation. And the utilities are anxious to play."


GRAPHIC: Two utilities have found a formula for turning each company's environmental strong suit into a benefit for the other, in a deal brokered by the Environmental Defense Fund. One gets a low-cost way to meet a commitment on greenhouse gases; the other gets a tax break that will pay for conservation projects. In the process, air pollution will be reduced in the United States and abroad.
 
1. THE SWAP
Chart: "A Novel Deal to Reduce Pollution"
 Niagara Mohawk transfers to Arizona Public Service credit for 1.75 million tons of reduction in carbon dioxide emissions required under a voluntary agrement many utilities have with the Department of Energy. In return, Arizona Public Service transfers to Niagara Mohawk j25,000 tons worth of sulfur dioxide allowances under the Clean Air Act's acid-rain program.
 Thw swap relieves Arizona Public Service of an obligation to find ways to reduce its own plants' emissions of carbon dioxide.
 
2. THE DONATION
 Instead of using or selling them, Niagara Mohawk donates the sulfur dioxide allowances to an environmental group (yet to be named) that will retire them, meaning no other polluter can use them. Niagara Mohawk gets a tax deduction for their market value of approximately $3.75 million.
 
3. RECYCLING THE MONEY
 Niagara Mohawk spends the value of the tax benefit - about $1 million - on conservation programs, including projects in its service area and in countries like Mexico and India where emissions of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide can be reduced at lower cost than in the United States.
 
(Sources: Niagara Mohawk; Arizona Public Service)

HEADLINE: Home Construction Drops First Time in Four Months

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The housing industry, until now mostly immune to rising mortgage rates, began to succumb in October to higher loan costs as new home construction fell for the first time in four months.
"It suggests that after eight months, the housing market may be reacting to higher rates," said David Lereah, economist for the Mortgage Bankers of America. 
 "The market has not collapsed," said Tommy Thompson, president of the National Association of Home Builders, "but it has peaked out and is starting a trend of continued downward movement."
The Commerce Department reported today that housing starts dropped 5.2 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.42 million, the smallest since June, when they plunged 8.9 percent, to 1.37 million.
The volatile multifamily sector, which includes apartments and condominiums, posted a 4.8 percent gain, to a 282,000 rate, following a 6.3 percent decline in September.
But the interest-sensitive single-family sector -- 80 percent of new housing -- fell 7.4 percent to a 1.14 million rate, the lowest level since severe weather stalled construction last winter.
Thirty-year mortgage rates, which were below 7 percent a year ago, have risen since February when the Federal Reserve started raising interest rates to forestall inflation and averaged 9.19 percent this week.
There were also these signs Thursday that other economic sectors remained robust despite earlier rate increases:
*The Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment benefits dropped by 5,000 last week, the fourth decline in five weeks and the biggest in nearly two months.
*The National Association of Realtors said existing-home prices rose 2.7 percent in the third quarter to $111,000.
*The Philadelphia Federal Reserve said its index of regional business activity fell to 30.5 from 33.2 in November, but it showed increases in jobs and the average workweek, and most indications of future economic activity rose.

HEADLINE: French Left Gets a Lift From Right

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Only weeks ago, French conservatives seemed certain to win next spring's presidential elections. Now, in a turnaround that could cheer American Democrats after their drubbing last week in mid-term elections, France's Socialists again have a chance.
Strangely, the Socialists themselves did little to achieve this. Rather, in what might also sound a warning to American Republicans, the Socialists have bounced back because French voters are now beginning to blame the right for what is wrong with France. 
 A Socialist, Francois Mitterrand, is still President, but conservatives have run both Government and Parliament since parliamentary elections in March 1993. Today, increasingly judged by their own record, the conservatives can no longer count on bitter memories of the last Socialist Government to help them.
Ideology seems to have little to do with this change of mood. Rather, many French feel that the country is still drifting, that the political establishment remains more interested in its own welfare than that of France. As a result, whoever is in office risks facing their wrath.
Last year Prime Minister Edouard Balladur inherited an economic recession, but he repeatedly promised that France would be on the road to recovery by now. But the economy remains sluggish, with unemployment still at a near-record 12.7 percent of the work force.
Then there is corruption. Two years ago, it was the Socialists who were besieged by corruption scandals. Now it is the the conservatives' turn. In recent months, three members of Mr. Balladur's Cabinet have resigned after coming under judicial investigation for corruption, and one is even in jail.
But the conservatives have perhaps most harmed themselves by putting on an extraordinary display of vicious infighting over who should be their presidential candidate next year. Until recently, with the political right set to win, the nomination battle was even more important than the election.
Now, however, the conservative vote is threatening to splinter, with the power struggle between Prime Minister Balladur and the leader of his own Gaullist party, Jacques Chirac, badly dividing the Cabinet and tearing apart the conservative coalition that holds 80 percent of parliamentary seats.
For this, Mr. Balladur is at least partly to blame. Mr. Chirac nominated him to become Prime Minister last year with the idea that he would pave the way for Mr. Chirac's own bid for the presidency. Instead, Mr. Balladur became more popular than Mr. Chirac and set his own eyes on the Elysee Palace. This month, Mr. Chirac declared his candidacy; Mr. Balladur will only announce his plans in January.
Other coalition members, including former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, are also thinking of entering the race. Two men further to the right, Philippe de Villiers, who leads an anti-European party, and Jean-Marie Le Pen of the extreme rightist National Front have already declared their candidacies.
Suddenly, haunted by how they snatched defeat from the jaws of victory in the 1981 and 1988 presidential elections, won by Mr. Mitterrand, the conservatives are desperately fighting their reputation for being a "losing machine."
In contrast, the Socialists, who in the past have shown their own penchant for internecine warfare, have united around Jacques Delors. And they plan to sit quietly until January when the former Finance Minister steps down as head of the European Union's executive commission.
Mr. Delors has not yet accepted the nomination, but everything suggests he will. This week, he said he would only do so out of a sense of duty, but his remarks coincided with publication of a book of interviews with him that had every appearance of a draft campaign platform.
"The traditional left represents only 40 to 45 percent of the electorate," he said in a television interview, "so we need to conquer new voters, to inspire the young and less young to make the necessary changes in our society."
His strength is that, having spent the last decade at the European Union's headquarters in Brussels, he enjoys respect in France without having become too familiar. On the other hand, having never run for major office here, he has little experience in the rough-and-tumble of campaigning.
The Socialist strategy, then, is to keep him out of the race as long as possible, to reinforce the image of a serene statesman without personal ambition while leaving the public to focus its attention on the spectacle of the battling right.
The latest polls say Mr. Delors is already running neck-and-neck with Mr. Balladur and is comfortably ahead of Mr. Chirac.

HEADLINE: Loan Arranged at Rockefeller Center

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Rockefeller Center Properties, the public company that holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it had arranged to borrow $225 million, averting what had been a looming financial crisis.
The deal does not affect the company's more fundamental problem: that Rockefeller Center's owner, the Rockefeller Group, which is controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan, does not have enough money to make the payments on the mortgage and may default on the loan. 
 Rockefeller Center Properties is a real estate investment trust whose only business is to hold the mortgage on Rockefeller Center. Yesterday it said it had reached a tentative agreement to sell $225 million in long-term debt to Whitehall Street Real Estate Limited Partnership, a fund managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Whitehall will also receive warrants and stock appreciation rights, allowing it to buy the equivalent of 19.9 percent of the company's shares at $5 a share.
Shares of Rockefeller Center Properties fell 37.5 cents, to $4, on the New York Stock Exchange, an all-time low.
In 1985 Rockefeller Group, then owned entirely by the Rockefeller family, took a $1.3 billion mortgage on the property, which is bordered by Fifth Avenue, Avenue of the Americas, 48th and 51st Streets. The money was lent by Rockefeller Center Properties, which raised $750 million selling stock and $550 million selling bonds.
In later years, the real estate trust bought back some of those bonds, borrowing money by selling short-term commercial paper. The repayment on that paper had been guaranteed by two letters of credit, one of which was set to expire next month and the other, which expires next June.
With banks largely unwilling to renew the letters of credit, the company faced a liquidity squeeze unless it found other financing. That is the reason it gave Goldman, Sachs the equity warrants on top of the interest.
Goldman, Sachs also received the right to appoint one member to the company's board. Claude M. Ballard Jr., a limited partner of Goldman, Sachs, is chairman of Rockefeller Center Properties' board, but he was not involved in the negotiations regarding the financing, said Stephanie Legget Young, a spokeswoman for Rockefeller Center Properties.
Goldman, Sachs was the initial underwriter of its stock in 1985. Kidder, Peabody & Company has been the investment banker for Rockefeller Center Properties.
In 1989, Mitsubishi Estate, Japan's largest property company, entered into the first of two transactions in which it bought 80 percent of Rockefeller Group for $1.4 billion. The real estate market in New York has since crashed and the rent that Rockefeller Group receives is substantially less than its costs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
SONY, STRUGGLING, TAKES A HUGE LOSS ON MOVIE STUDIOS

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
After months of optimistic statements, the Sony Corporation today became the latest Japanese company to acknowledge serious problems with a landmark American investment, announcing that it was taking $3.2 billion in losses on the value of the Hollywood studios that it acquired only five years ago.
In a surprise announcement, Sony said that because of poor box office results, a wave of executive resignations and rising costs, it could never hope to recover its investment in the studios, Columbia Pictures and Tristar Pictures, and was reducing their value on its books by $2.7 billion. 
 Sony said the studios also suffered $510 million in additional losses in the three months from July 1 through Sept. 30, because of the cancellation of movies under development, the settlement of lawsuits and the payment of huge sums to departing executives. Sony added that it had no choice but to sink even more money into the studios if it ever hoped to make them profitable.
The quarterly loss of $3.2 billion that Sony announced today is one of the largest reported by a Japanese company. But, to put it in perspective, it fell well short of the loss of $8 billion announced by the International Business Machines Corporation for the second quarter of 1993 and the record loss of $21 billion posted by the General Motors Corporation in the first quarter of 1992.
Still, it was a humbling admission for Sony and a stark symbol of the reversal in fortunes for corporate Japan. Sony, known for its innovative exports like the Walkman and video camcorder, had been at the head of the elite Japanese companies that poured money into the United States.
When Sony paid $3.4 billion for Columbia Pictures in late 1989, Americans feared that these overwhelmingly competitive companies, the engines behind Japan's huge trade surpluses, were taking control of the cream of the American economy. The anxieties grew when the Mitsubishi Estate Company bought control of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company acquired MCA Inc., which owns Universal Pictures.
The flood of investments, which included other trophies like Firestone, the tire company, and the Tiffany building, eased after 1991, when the Japanese economy entered a deep recession. Now, time has borne out those experts who had argued that many of the Japanese companies overpaid for what were in many instances ill-considered investments.
Earlier this week, it was disclosed that Mitsubishi Estate and its partners may be about to default on the mortgage on Rockefeller Center. And several weeks ago, the American executives of MCA, which is profitable, reportedly threatened to quit and leave the company rudderless if Matsushita did not either sell them the company or grant them autonomy.
Other Japanese companies in financial distress have been forced to unload well-known properties at big losses, from the Pebble Beach golf club in California to prestigious hotels in Hawaii.
Some Japanese investments succeeded, but usually when the companies stuck closely to businesses they knew well and built the properties themselves, like the American auto plants built by Honda and Toyota.
Sony, however, had always considered itself a cut above, with its innovative electronic gadgets and flair for garnering favorable publicity. The acquisition of the studios was seen as a bold attempt to marry Sony's expertise in producing electronic hardware with the "software" that ran on the videotape and CD players. Sony also acquired record and television production companies.
That was one reason today's announcement sent a grim message to the financial markets. Several analysts said they felt misled by Sony, because it gave no hint of the dire condition of its movie studios before dropping today's bomb.
"It seems like a realistic step, but I found the way it was handled highly irritating," said Joseph Osha, an analyst here with Baring Securities. "The real problem was that even after all this, they didn't articulate a clear vision for the movie business."
The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency, said it was considering lowering the rating on $7 billion of bonds issued by Sony. It said the write-off "raises questions as to the severity of the problems of the picture segment and calls for a reassessment of Sony's overall business profile and long-term strategies."
The announcement was made after the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed today. But on the New York Stock Exchange, where Sony is traded in the form of American depository receipts, the price fell $3.25, to $55.25, today.
Sony also reported that in the three-month period that ended on Sept. 30, it enjoyed an increase of 3.7 percent in sales, to $9.93 billion, from the corresponding period a year ago. Its music and electronics businesses produced positive results, Sony said, but the huge losses from movies produced an overall net loss of $3.2 billion during the period.
The company has suffered a string of box office disappointments and outright disasters recently. They include "Last Action Hero," "I'll Do Anything" and "Lost in Yonkers." Its latest movie, "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein," also threatens to turn into a disaster, grossing less than $18 million so far on production costs of $40 million to $50 million.
Several analysts said the biggest problem for Sony was that it was unable to manage its acquisitions. "The purchase itself was not necessarily a mistake, but they didn't know how to run it properly," said Yoshiharu Izumi, the analyst here with UBS Securities.
The difficulties began almost from the moment Sony made its purchase. Shortly after, it hired two successful film producers, Jon Peters and Peter Guber, to run the studios.
Legal disputes about their contracts with rival companies forced Sony to pay an astounding price estimated at about $700 million for their services. Despite the cost, Mr. Peters left not long after, and Mr. Guber departed last month, with the studios widely understood to be in trouble.
Sony invested several billion dollars bringing in more executives, paying a handful to leave, rebuilding some of the studio properties and introducing new technologies. Even so, its studios now rest in last place among the large Hollywood companies, in terms of market share.
In a statement, Michael P. Schulhof, president of the Sony Corporation of America, characterized the move today as the product of a "strategic analysis." But he did not say much about the strategy, except that it would involve reducing costs at the studios and an attempt to recapture some of the market share it had lost.
The company felt compelled to add in its announcement, "Sony's enthusiasm and commitment to its motion picture, television and video businesses is undiminished."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Survey Helps Push Bonds Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell modestly yesterday, as the Commerce Department's report that housing starts were down for the month of October failed to soothe investor concern about faster growth and accelerating inflation. A weaker dollar also weighed on the market.
Bonds initially made modest gains on the housing report, but the potential for gains was limited as a survey by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve of general business conditions in its region showed continued strength in economic growth. 
 The 30-year bond fell 10/32 of a percentage point, to 93 1/32 , for a yield of 8.12 percent, up from 8.09 percent on Wednesday. On the other hand, short-term bill rates were mixed.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, said, "The market remains convinced the economy is still very strong and that there are signs of upward pressure on prices, and even though the Fed may not raise interest rates further this year, investors believe the central bank will need to raise rates further next year."
Mr. Johnson pointed to yesterday's Philadelphia Fed report as one of many signs of upward pressure. Even though the manufacturing sector showed a decline from the surges in October, the report said, manufacturing activity was still robust and upward pressure on prices had not faded. "So the bond market is nervous, and nervous for good a reason," Mr. Johnson said.
Other nagging problems, Mr. Johnson added, are that foreign investors are backing away from the American market because rates are becoming more attractive elsewhere. Secondly, there is concern about the political standoff in Washington. "One of the big worries is that we are going to be facing higher deficits in the future, because while we get the tax cuts easily enough, we will not get the offsetting spending cuts, which are difficult to make," he said. "If you're looking for something to worry about, there is plenty."
Perhaps the most worrisome data coming out of the Philadelphia Fed survey, other analysts said, were the continued rise in delivery time for manufactured goods to reach the consumer level, which may indicate inflationary bottle necks developing.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International said the market could not shake this bearish trend because investors were worried about the economic rate of growth and had not yet seen any significant slowdown. "The market wants conclusive evidence that it is slowing," she said.
Ms. Rupert also cited the coming supply of new paper next week as a source of some market irritation. The Treasury will be selling $55.45 billion in bills and notes during a holiday-shortened week. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.26 percent, up 5 basis points from the previous day; the five-year note was at a price to yield 7.79 percent, up 4 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The market has already lost nearly a point since the Fed's interest rate increase on Tuesday, making it the third consecutive time this year that bonds have failed to sustain a rally after such a rise. "This last one was the shortest of the three," Ms. Rupert said. "It lasted a day or two."
Late in the day, when speculators realized that the long bond was not going to make new lows in this latest downturn, some rushed to cover short positions, sparking a small rally in the afternoon, halving the day's losses.
Short-covering occurs when speculators sell borrowed securities in hope of buying them back at a lower price and pocketing the difference.
In the municipal market, where demand for bonds has slacked amid mutual fund redemptions, prices in the secondary market fell for the second consecutive day.
And in the day's largest offering, Virginia, one of five states still rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, sold $225 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding won by CS First Boston. In an indication of good investor interest, the bonds maturing in 10 years were priced to yield 6 percent, about 8 basis points lower than other similarly rated bonds.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drifts a Bit as Dealers Await Report on U.S. Trade

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday in quiet trading.
Many currency dealers were awaiting today's report on the United States trade balance. A decline in the American bond market also weighed down the dollar yesterday. The dollar surged on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve raised the two short-term interest rates it controls. But both bonds and the dollar have since sagged. 
 "We got that pop in the dollar when the Fed raised the rates, but trading has been pretty lackluster over all since then," said Paul Alley, a trader at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. "The dollar really doesn't have a lot of direction and momentum on its own so we have been watching the bond market."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.5522 German marks, from 1.5506 marks on Wednesday. The dollar slipped to 98.30 Japanese yen from 98.34 yen.
Alfonso Alejo, senior proprietary trader at Sakura Bank Ltd., said that the bond market's weak performance suggested continued investor uneasiness about inflation, which was preventing the dollar from building on its rally earlier in the week. Inflation erodes the value of American bonds and stocks held by foreign investors, thus discouraging the demand for dollars to buy such assets.
Today, the Commerce Department will report on the United States trade balance in September. Economists expect the report to show a slight narrowing in the trade gap to $9.5 billion in September from $9.74 billion in August.
"If the trade report come in close to expectations it's going to be kind of a nonevent," Mr. Alley of Long-Term Credit Bank said. But an unexpected widening of the trade deficit -- particularly the gap with Japan -- could send the dollar lower against the yen, he added.
Traders fear that growth in the trade gap will lead to a glut of dollars as exporters from Japan and elsewhere seek to repatriate their profits by selling dollars for yen.
In other currency trading yesterday, the British pound slipped to $1.5710, from $1.5725 on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.3055 Swiss francs from 1.3095 francs, but rose to 5.3285 French francs from 5.3265 francs.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Orange Juice Prices Jump; Cotton and Oil Also Climb

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Orange juice prices jumped on commodity markets yesterday after Brazilian producers raised prices.
Other commodity prices gained. Cotton rose to five-month highs amid signs that a large United States crop would be absorbed in the face of reduced world supplies, while crude oil jumped amid rising demand from refiners. Lumber prices retreated. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 0.80 point, to 233.65. 
 Brazil's orange processors raised prices of orange juice concentrates yesterday to $1.30 a pound from $1.15 in expectation that a report today from the Brazilian Association of Citrus Exporters would confirm that the orange crop in the Sao Paulo state had been damaged by frost. The state grows 90 percent of Brazil's orange crop, the world's largest.
The move led traders to bet the crop estimate might be closer to the 250 million boxes of oranges predicted by some growers than to the range of 270 million boxes to 282 million boxes predicted earlier this season by the United States Department of Agriculture and Brazilian agriculture authorities.
On the New York Cotton Exchange, frozen concentrated orange juice for January delivery rose 4.75 cents, to $1.19 a pound, its highest price since Oct. 12, 1993.
Crude oil surged amid optimism that demand would pick up as refiners race to make enough heating oil for the winter and produce sufficient supplies of a new grade of gasoline to meet a Government deadline on clean-air requirements.
Crude oil for December delivery, which expires today, rose 28 cents, to $17.65 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Cotton rose to the highest price in five months amid hopes any excess from a record cotton crop in the United States this year will be absorbed by demand from abroad.
Smaller-than-expected crops in Pakistan, India and China could lead to higher exports of American cotton.
Cotton for December delivery rose 0.45 cent, to 74.85 cents a pound, on the cotton exchange, the highest price since June 22.
Lumber prices fell back on concerns that higher interest rates would dampen the housing market. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that housing starts dropped 5.2 percent in October.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, January Lumber fell $4, to $349.50 for 1,000 board feet.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The King Must Die

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
"Why do we want to kill our Presidents?" A doctor asked me that the other day, and left me wondering whether there is something about the American system, or the American psyche, that now makes the Presidency a hopelessly vulnerable institution.
"With the exception of Reagan, who was sui generis," he said, "we have cut off every President for nearly 30 years: Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter, Bush. Now it looks as if the same will happen to Clinton. 
 "We don't just say they failed at this or that. We say they failed as human beings, and we seem to get satisfaction from that idea. There's almost a glee about it: 'Boy, he really was terrible.' "
With each of those Presidents one can find a fault that led to his undoing. Lyndon Johnson dug us into the disaster of Vietnam. Richard Nixon was responsible for the lies and abuses of Watergate. And on and on.
Vietnam and Watergate, moreover, had lasting effects on the institution. We ceased to believe Presidents, to assume their good faith. The press became hostile, and has remained so. It did not give Bill Clinton even a brief honeymoon.
President Clinton, too, has inflicted many wounds on himself. From Zoe Baird to Lani Guinier, from Bosnia to prayer in schools, he has repeatedly failed to stand on principle.
But the doctor's point was that something larger is going on. Whatever the mistakes of this President or that, we want to find some fundamental, personal flaw in the man. Is that so?
What is undoubtedly true is that we expect far too much of the Federal Government nowadays. In this vast country, we think Washington can and should prevent local street crime. We expect it to repair family life, and make sure our incomes rise.
And the President is the great symbol of the national Government. We lay on him almost the personal burdens that King Henry V felt the night before the battle of Agincourt in Shakespeare's play: "Upon the King! Let us our lives, our souls, our debts, our careful wives, our children and our sins lay on the King!"
At least since the New Deal, we have had this romantic notion of what Presidents ought to do for each of us. Asking for the impossible, we are bound to be disappointed. And as in a failed romance, we turn bitterly on the one who has failed us. So the theory might go.
Now we are evidently returning to the pre-New Deal political system, Congressional Government. However much resolve President Clinton can summon up, the legislative agenda is likely to be set by the newly dominant Republicans in Congress. It is there in Newt Gingrich's "Contract With America," and no one should doubt the seriousness of his intention to carry it out.
Will the planned Republican measures fulfill our expectations? Mr. Gingrich has taken some welcome procedural steps, such as shaking up the House seniority system. But what about the substantive problems?
The rise in illegitimate births, especially among teen-agers, is one. Will a denial of welfare benefits to illegitimate children -- the idea being discussed by Republicans -- solve the problem? Will poor teen-age girls change their sexual habits if the Government takes their babies away and puts them in Gingrich orphanages?
Or crime. Longer sentences and more prisons have not affected the level of crime noticeably so far. Will even more savage policies turn the growing population of young men without hope into good citizens?
The economy is the problem causing the most profound discontent among Americans. Real per-capita income has been stagnant or declining for years. The rich have grown dramatically richer, while the middle class struggles to keep afloat.
Some of the Gingrich Contract's economic ideas are appealing: the $500 tax credit per child, for example. But the huge cost of the various proposed tax cuts would make the deficit balloon or require cuts in Social Security, Medicare and like entitlements on a similar scale. Will such a package ease American frustrations?
The concern is not an idle or a partisan one. Frustrated expectations can in time exact a heavy cost in politics. They can turn people against the whole idea of representative government. Unless political leaders begin to talk honestly about the limits of what they can produce, the present cynicism and anger may become dangerous.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Unfettered By Party, He's Set To Govern

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Maybe it was his insistence that he didn't "need to be governor" that most endeared Angus King to Maine voters.
This is a state, after all, with a fondness for mavericks, and this was a political season that favored outsiders. 
 So here was Mr. King, who had gone from legal services lawyer to public television talk-show host to multimillionaire businessman, offering himself as a sort of "people's choice" candidate, neither Republican nor Democrat, saying yes, he could best lead the state, but no, he wasn't going to be one of those career politicians.
He won, if narrowly, and as of January will be the only governor in the nation affiliated with no political party. He succeeds John R. McKernan Jr., a Republican, barred by law from seeking a third term.
At home here the other day, Mr. King was talking about the narrow margin of his victory in a four-candidate field in which he won 36 percent of the vote. Inasmuch as he beat the Democratic front-runner, former Gov. Joseph Brennan, by just 7,000 votes -- or 2 percent of the total -- anything may have made the difference, he said.
It certainly did not hurt that he had been endorsed by the novelist Stephen King, a staunch Democrat from Bangor. "Stephen King is a Maine icon," said Mr. King (but not a relative of the Governor-elect).
Maybe it was his appearance at 25 county fairs, from Blue Hill to Fryeburg to Farmington. Or, in keeping with the anti-insider sentiment of the voters, it may have been the last television debate, in which Mr. King closed by saying that Thomas Jefferson had instructed that his epitaph refer to him as the author of the Declaration of Independence, not as President. What matters is not your title but what you accomplish, Mr. King, who had already pledged that he would never run for any other office, told the audience that night.
"The next day," he said, "I was at Bath Ironworks shaking hands, and this very gruff guy, a welder, shook my hand and said, 'Nice Jefferson quote.' "
The election season's disdain for career politicians was particularly strong in Maine, where bickering between Democratic and Republican state legislators, along with a big budget shortfall, forced the government to shut down for two weeks in 1991.
Mr. King's only political experience was a two-year stint in Washington in the 1970's, as a counsel to Senator Bill Hathaway, a Maine Democrat. He says he has evolved from traditional liberal to "compassionate pragmatist," and describes himself as socially liberal and fiscally conservative. He likes to quote Winston Churchill: "If you're not a socialist when you're 20, you have no heart. If you're not a conservative when you're 40, you have no head."
At 50, Mr. King took a rare day off from campaigning in September to attend a Rolling Stones concert with his 41-year-old press secretary, Dennis Bailey, who is the lead singer in a local rock band, the Van Gogh-gos.
While he remains loyal to the Stones, Mr. King left the Democratic Party in 1993. "Democrats are a mainframe in an age of P.C.'s," he said. "They don't get it."
He himself happens to be on line.He fields questions from voters over the Internet, and while campaigning he wrote a book, about his vision for Maine, on a lap-top computer that he carries in his car. He also has a computer in his kitchen, which doubled as an annex to his campaign headquarters in a former Arby's restaurant. (Spotting the big Angus King sign on top, hungry tourists kept coming in last summer and asking for the Angus King special.)
Like countless candidates elsewhere this year, Mr. King stumped on an anti-bureaucracy platform. He promised to make Maine more friendly to business and, deriding the bitter competition between the parties here, adopted the slogan "partnership, not partisanship." He says his priorities include creating jobs in this state with a chronically high unemployment rate and closing a $200 million gap in a budget that always seems to be running a deficit.
A graduate of Dartmouth College and the University of Virginia Law School, Mr. King began his career as a legal services lawyer in Maine before going into business (and later moonlighting as the host of a public affairs program on public television in Maine). Last year he made $12 million on the sale of a company he had founded, Northeast Energy Management Inc.
While he spent nearly $900,000 of his own money on the campaign, he does not seem to have poured any of his profits into the modest two-story house he shares with his wife, Mary Herman, a former lobbyist, and their 4-year-old son, Benjamin.
"We put vinyl siding on the house," said Mr. King, sitting in a living room with well-worn furniture. "That was our big splurge."
The Governor-elect, who has three grown sons from a previous marriage, said he had no plans to move his family into the Governor's Mansion in Augusta, a 30-mile commute from Brunswick. He does not want to take Benjamin away from his best friend, 4-year-old Harry Swan, he said.
That sort of attitude fits right in with a Maine culture steeped in the self-sufficiency of lobstermen, potato farmers and loggers. Politically the state has an independent tradition dating from 1820, when it split off from Massachusetts. Mr. King will be Maine's second independent governor in 20 years, the last being Jim Longley.
"In Maine," Stephen King said, "people have shown this traditional tendency to say 'I smell fresh air' and not slam the window shut."
One of Mr. King's first post-election duties will be to mingle with Republicans and Democrats alike at a gathering of governors and governors-elect this weekend in Greenbriar, W.Va. If nothing else, he said, "I'll be able to caucus by myself."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 21, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about Angus King, the independent who was elected last week to be Maine's next governor, referred incorrectly to the site where governors were gathering over the weekend. It is is not a town but a resort, in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va.; its name is spelled Greenbrier.

HEADLINE: $15 Million Tax Break Keeps Viacom Jobs in New York

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
After a promise of $15 million in tax incentives from the city and a game of musical chairs in two New York office towers, Viacom Inc. has completed plans to expand in midtown Manhattan, more than doubling its office space in two of the four buildings it occupies.
The new space, about 750,000 square feet, means that Viacom will keep 4,450 employees in New York, with the expectation that 2,500 more jobs can be added in the next 15 years. Although the entertainment and communications conglomerate never threatened to move its headquarters out of the city, it had considered moving 1,600 clerical and administrative jobs to New Jersey before the incentive package was offered in October. 
 "The city came forward with a package of incentives that made it economically possible for us to stay here," said Carl D. Folta, a senior vice president of Viacom.
Viacom, which owns the cable networks MTV and Nickelodeon as well as Paramount Communications, is expected early next week to sign a 15-year lease for 500,000 square feet, or 11 floors, at 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street. Its Showtime subsidiary already has offices in the building. It is also adding another seven floors to the 28 it occupies at 1515 Broadway, a 54-story building at 44th Street that bears its name. The company's Simon & Schuster subsidiary last year renewed its leases for six floors at 1230 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street.
The new offices do not represent a total expansion for Viacom, since some of the space will be occupied by employees who are to move in the spring from the Paramount building at Columbus Circle, which is being acquired by Donald Trump for mixed use.
When the ink dries on all the deals, Viacom will occupy about 1.6 million square feet of New York office space in three buildings.
When Viacom acquired Paramount in March, a 450,000-square-foot building in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., came with it. Early on, the plan was to move a significant portion of Paramount and Viacom support staff, about 1,600 people, as well as some studio space into that building. City officials project that, had Viacom gone ahead with those plans, the city would have lost $821 million in annual economic activity, including expenditures by the company and its employees and about $18 million in city taxes. Now Viacom plans to sell that building.
"The incentives the city offered really made a difference," said Martin Turchin, the lead broker representing Viacom.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani offered the $15 million tax incentives to Viacom last month, just as a border war broke out between New York and Connecticut when that state lured the Swiss Bank Corporation from New York City with an incentives package.
At the time, the Mayor said the Viacom offer was similar to those made to six companies over the first 10 months of his administration, to retain a total of 30,000 jobs in the city.
"When one of the world's largest entertainment companies decides to make its headquarters here into the next generation, they are strengthening and enhancing the city's reputation as a place where the world does business," Clay B. Lifflander, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday.
Brokers say that Viacom has agreed to annual rents that start at more than $30 a square foot, the market rate for Times Square buildings, so that in rent alone the corporation will be paying millions of dollars a year.
Accommodating Viacom has not been easy. At 1633 Broadway, much of the space Viacom will occupy is currently occupied by Deloitte & Touche, a large accounting firm, which had been looking for sublet tenants for much of its space. The Paramount Group, the German real estate company that owns 1633 Broadway (no connection to Paramount Communications), has agreed to take back the lease and rent the space directly to Viacom, providing the firm can move out ahead of schedule.
The building at 1515 Broadway is almost fully occupied. Viacom has been negotiating with four tenants, offering undisclosed incentives to get them to move elsewhere. One has already moved, and the Urban Development Corporation, the brokers say, is near an agreement to give up 100,000 square feet at the top of the building. Two other tenants are still negotiating.

HEADLINE: THE NEW CONGRESS: TRADE;
White House Warns of Market Jolt if Trade Pact Is Defeated

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Raising the stakes in the Administration's effort to round up votes for a world trade agreement, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen warned today that its defeat could have "a very negative effect on the financial markets of this country."
 The prediction was a high-risk strategy for the White House: it sets up a prophecy that could become self-fulfilling if the 123-nation trade accord fails to get through Congress. 
 But other Administration officials agreed that the warning Mr. Bentsen gave in a meeting with supporters was legitimate and that lawmakers should know that the financial health of the country might be at stake.
 With four working days left before Congress reconvenes in a special session to take up the agreement, White House officials continued today to express optimism that they could coax the likely Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, to declare himself in favor of the pact. Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said today that "we've had some very good talks," adding, "I'd love to have this resolved by the beginning of next week."
 But one of the floor managers of the bill, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is in his last days as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, sounded a note of caution. "I'm glad the White House thinks there is no problem," he said, but added that he viewed the agreement as still in "considerable jeopardy." "It is not done, and it won't be until the President meets with the principals in Congress."
 Officials in Mr. Dole's office said that they were negotiating with Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, on side agreements that would allow Congress to review actions taken by the World Trade Organization, the body that would be created by the accord to police world trade.
 Opponents of the accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, argue that the organization would undermine American sovereignty and could ultimately force participating countries to weaken consumer protections, health regulations or other laws judged impediments to imports.
 Mr. Kantor dismissed such fears today, arguing that the United States could withdraw from the trade agreement at any time, with six months' notice. "This sovereignty issue is a scarecrow," he declared.
 But while the Administration expressed confidence that votes were moving its way, it did not act like that was the case.
 "It's crunch time," Mr. Bentsen told a group of supporters of the trade accord today at one of the pro-GATT events sponsored by the Administration that have become a daily ritual. "I don't want to see us the day after the final vote saying 'if we had just tried harder, but we came up one vote short.' That just must not be the case." Mr. Bentsen has been leaning heavily on his former colleagues in the Senate.
 Earlier in the day, commenting on the Republicans' call for a tax cut, Mr. Bentsen declared that the Administration, like the new Republican majority, favored a middle-class tax cut next year. But he quickly added that any such tax cut could not be allowed to worsen the Federal deficit.
 On GATT, the White House plans a series of events over the next few days to drive home its message -- that a Congressional defeat would humiliate the United States and undercut its foreign policy, that it would cost new jobs and billions of dollars to the economy, and that partisanship should not interfere with an agreement that was supported by both the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
 But, in relation to GATT, the warning about a negative reaction in the financial markets is new, although it is a page drawn from the successful campaign a year ago to win passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 A similar prediction was made earlier this week in testimony before a Senate committee by Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker, but was dismissed by opponents of GATT as a scare tactic by a supporter of the trade accord.
