HEADLINE: 12 Die as Arafat's Police Fire on Palestinian Militants

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GAZA, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat's police force opened fire for the first time on Palestinian protesters today, killing at least 12 people and wounding as many as 200 in street battles that raged for hours across the Gaza Strip's main city.
The police said an officer was also killed and 10 others were wounded when two police cars were set on fire. 
 It was by far the worst internal violence since Palestinian autonomy began six months ago in Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho, and some Islamic radicals opposed to Mr. Arafat warned of a brewing civil war. But leaders of the main Islamic group, Hamas, sought to allay such fears, saying they would work to keep Gaza from tearing itself apart in bloodshed.
Nonetheless, the rioting and shooting shocked Gazans, and potentially it was a devastating political blow to Mr. Arafat in his efforts to show that he and his struggling self-rule government command the allegiance of a majority of the Palestinian people and are capable of maintaining order.
Israelis and Palestinian moderates expressed concern about the possible consequences for their soon-to-resume peace talks to expand Palestinian authority beyond Gaza and Jericho to encompass the entire West Bank.
On Gaza's streets, Mr. Arafat was a reviled figure today, denounced by Palestinians regardless of political affiliations as a traitor and collaborator with Israel.
"I supported Arafat before, but now I hate him," said Jamil Kafarneh, a social worker who stood with protesters at one of the scenes of serious clashes, Palestinian police headquarters, formerly Israel's main prison here. [Page 8.]
A young man nearby shouted, "Arafat must hang for this!" and an older Palestinian, referring to the executed Romanian leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, said, "Arafat is worse than Ceausescu."
The street fighting produced a one-day casualty figure that was higher than in all but a few instances in the years-long Palestinian uprising against Israel, known in Arabic as the intifada. That worst day of the intifada was Oct. 8, 1990, when Israeli police officers killed at least 17 Palestinians during rioting at Al Aksa mosque in Jerusalem.
In the Gaza battles, many of those wounded were shot in the head and chest, and so the death toll could climb.
What appalled and enraged many Gazans was that this time it was their own forces, not the hated Israelis, who had taken aim on stone-throwing protesters. It was a mirror image of uprising scenes that had vanished in Gaza in May, when the Israeli Army withdrew from Palestinian towns and refugee camps after a 27-year occupation.
The Palestinian police blamed Islamic extremists, saying that radicals were looking for a fight and that officers had fired in self-defense. A police statement said extremists had fired first from the main Gaza City mosque, where the turmoil began just as Friday noon prayers were ending.
But there was no independent confirmation of that charge.
Witnesses said the roughly 200 helmeted police officers on hand had started the shooting, to break up a planned rally to denounce Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority and his self-rule agreement with Israel.
But the witnesses also said the shooting came after stones were thrown at the police by some among an estimated 5,000 to 10,000 worshipers at the Palestine Mosque. They became angry when officers pulled down loudspeakers that were to be used in the rally. At first, witnesses said, officers shot in the air, and then they fired into the crowd.
However the incident began, the authorities apparently decided to respond firmly in a showdown with Islamic groups and their supporters that had been building for weeks.
That was also the view of an Israeli negotiator with the Palestinians, Environment Minister Yossi Sarid, who said on Israel television, "I assume that Arafat reached the conclusion that it's either him or them."
The resulting clashes were ferocious, spreading quickly from the mosque to the police headquarters, another police post and to Shifa Hospital, where most of the victims were taken. All these locations lie in roughly a one-square-mile area of central Gaza City.
Rioting also spread this evening to Rafah, at the southern end of the coastal strip, where youths beat up a video-shop owner and smashed cafes and a movie theater. Dozens of youths marched on an Israeli Army checkpoint near the isolated settlement of Netzarim, where three soldiers were killed last Friday by a suicide bomber from the Islamic Holy War group. As the young Palestinians approached, soldiers pulled back to avoid a confrontation and watched as their outpost was set on fire.
Calm returned tonight. But from noon until well after sundown, Mr. Arafat's officers fired thousands upon thousands of bullets from automatic rifles to suppress angry Gazans whose weapons were stones. Most of the firing was in the air, in a vain attempt to scare off the protesters.
But often enough the police took dead aim. And the streets of Gaza City echoed for hours with the staccato of gunfire and the wails of ambulance sirens.
"They're acting like the Jews!" an old man screamed about the police as he watched a heavily bleeding youngster being carried from an ambulance into the Shifa Hospital emergency room, so overtaxed that some victims were treated on the bloodstained floor.
The comparison with Israeli behavior during the occupation was made by many people. Some saw Israel's hand in the episode, insisting that Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin had phoned Mr. Arafat and ordered him to carry out what Hamas in a statement called a "massacre."
"This was all done on the orders of Rabin and Clinton," a young Gazan said as he watched a doctor tend to a relative who had been shot in the back.
At Shifa Hospital, the rage against Mr. Arafat was almost palpable as ambulances and private cars pulled up every few minutes and, for long periods, even every few seconds, ferrying the wounded.
"All the time Arafat talks about democracy," said Iyad Kassem, an unemployed laborer. "Now we see how democratic he is."
The Palestinian police fared no better. When a wounded officer was brought to the hospital tonight, staff workers had to push back a surging crowd that was ready to grab the man from a stretcher and beat him.
Despite the anger, there were signs that Gazans were trying to keep the situation from spinning out of control.
At his offices along the Mediterranean shore, Mr. Arafat summoned his security chiefs to a strategy-planning session. There was no public comment, however, from him or his aides.
Hamas, while expressing outrage over the shootings, urged calm. In fact, the clashes at police headquarters, which lasted more than three hours, did not subside until Hamas leaders urged people over loudspeakers to go home. In short order, the large crowd dissolved.
"Hamas is very concerned that there be no civil war among Palestinians," said Sayed Abu Musameh, a leader of the militantly anti-Israel Hamas, whose formal name is the Islamic Resistance Movement. The rioting today, he said, was the produce of "rage against Israeli attacks and the way the Palestinian Authority is dealing with the people."
But Mr. Arafat's faction in the Palestine Liberation Organization, Al Fatah, issued a statement tonight in Gaza warning Hamas and Islamic Holy War that they were "crossing the red line" with attacks on the Palestinian Authority that "harm national unity."
Raising the specter of possible new clashes, Al Fatah said it was on "full alert" and would resist "conspiratorial plans on behalf of foreign parties." That was apparently a reference to Iran.
There was clear embarrassment on all sides over scenes of Palestinians battling Palestinians. People tried to block television cameramen from recording the clashes, and hard-eyed men who seemed to be security agents ripped the film out of at least one photographer's camera.
Three Palestinian journalists -- two photographers for The Associated Press and Reuters and a cameraman for Reuters Television -- were among those wounded by gunfire, two in the hand and one in the shoulder. It was not clear if the wounds were by chance or if police officers had aimed at the journalists.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Blames Lack of Benefits
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- The United States attributed clashes between Palestinians in the Gaza Strip today to a lack of concrete benefits from the peace process and urged the P.L.O. and donor countries to fulfill their commitments.
"Today's events have sent a warning signal that more must be done to bring the Palestinians equal tangible benefits of peace," said the chief State Department spokesman, David T. Johnson.
At a donors' conference last year, some 40 nations pledged $2.4 billion, but much of it has failed to arrive amid complaints from donors that the P.L.O. is not accounting for how it spends the cash.
United States officials said earlier this week that another conference was scheduled in Brussels for Nov. 29-30 to plug a gap in financing of start-up costs for the Palestinian Authority in Gaza and Jericho.
"We believe the P.L.O. has got to demonstrate that it can live up to its responsibilities and its commitments," Mr. Johnson said. "The international donor community must also live up to its commitments."

Chronology: "CHRONOLOGY: Violent Road to Palestinian Self-Rule"
 
By Reuters
 
 SEPT. 13, 1993: Israel and the P.L.O. sign a plan in Washington to bring self-rule for Palestinians in Gaza and Jericho and eventually all of the West Bank.
OCT. 13: Israel and the P.L.O. open talks in Egypt on how to carry out self-rule.
FEB. 9, 1994: Partial agreement is reached for security at border crossings.
APRIL 29: Agreement is signed in Paris with a framework for economic ties between Israel and self-rule areas.
MAY 4: Agreement on the details of self-rule for the Gaza Strip and Jericho is signed in Cairo.
MAY 11: First Palestinian police enter the Gaza Strip.
MAY 18: Last Israeli troops withdraw from Palestinian towns and refugee camps in Gaza.
MAY 20: Two Israeli soldiers are killed in a guerrilla attack on their Gaza Strip checkpoint.
 JULY 2: Two Palestinians and an Israeli policeman are killed during riots by Palestinians protesting delays at the main crossing point between the Gaza Strip and Israel.
 AUG. 29: Israel hands over education services to the Palestinians.
OCT. 9: Gunmen from the Islamic Resistance Movement, known as Hamas, kidnap an Israeli soldier. He dies in a rescue attempt five days later. The Palestinian Authority, under pressure from Israel, triggers anger as it rounds up hundreds of Palestinian militants.
 OCT. 19: A Hamas suicide-bomber detonates explosives on a Tel Aviv bus, killing 22 people and himself.
 NOV. 2: A member of Islamic Jihad, Hani Abed, whom Israel has accused of being behind the May 20 attack on Israeli soldiers in Gaza, is killed by a car bomb. Islamic Jihad blames the Israeli secret service and vows revenge.
 NOV. 11: An Islamic Jihad bomber kills himself and three Israeli officers at a military checkpoint. Islamic Jihad says the bombing is the first reprisal for Mr. Abed's assassination. The Palestinian Authority rounds up nearly 200 Islamic Jihad campaigners.
 NOV. 18: Palestinian police fire on demonstrators near a mosque in Gaza City, killing at least 12 people and wounding up to 200. (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Judge Rules Against System To Subsidize Hospital Care

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 18

 BODY:
For the second time this year, a Federal judge has sustained a challenge to Connecticut's system for subsidizing hospital care for poor patients, jeopardizing $150 million in Federal Medicaid grants to the state.
Judge Alfred V. Covello of Federal District Court here ruled Thursday that a 1974 Federal law covering employee benefits programs pre-empts the state system, which taxes hospitals and insured patients to cover the costs of hospital care for the indigent and the uninsured. 
 Under Medicaid provisions adopted in 1991, states that raise money to finance care for those groups are entitled to a 50 percent reimbursement from the Federal Government.
The decision is the latest of several conflicting rulings in Connecticut, New York and New Jersey that could affect states' abilities to regulate health care costs. The cases all revolve around the question of whether the Federal law on employee benefits plans bars states from controlling hospital costs and imposing taxes and surcharges on hospital services because it would force employee plans to shoulder costs that do not directly involve their members' health care.
The United States Supreme Court is to hear arguments in January in a case involving New York State that could address this question. In that case, insurance companies have maintained that state-imposed surcharges on some hospital services for some insured patients violate the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, or Erisa, which governs employee-benefit programs. They maintain that the law prohibits the states from regulating such programs, and that the law says that money paid into these plans can be used only to benefit their members.
New York has maintained that this is too broad an interpretation of the Erisa law.
While the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled against New York State earlier this year, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled the opposite way in New Jersey in 1993, saying that the Erisa law should not pre-empt state control.
In Connecticut today, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said the state would appeal Judge Covello's decision and seek a stay, pending the Supreme Court decision in the New York case. He described Judge Covello's summary judgment as a "sweeping pre-emption of states statutes by Erisa" and warned that "it would create damaging obstacles to effective and meaningful health care reform at the state level."
The case was filed by the Connecticut Hospital Association, which represents 31 hospitals. It argued that the state's 6 percent sales tax on hospital services, an 11 percent tax on hospitals' gross receipts and a cap on hospital revenue violated the Erisa law.
Susan Shimelman, the state's budget director, said that the taxes raised roughly $300 million, and that about the same amount would be redistributed to hospitals based on the number of patients they served who were uninsured, underinsured or on Medicaid.
Under this program, she said, "the inner-city hospitals are the net winners, and those hospitals that one might classify as suburban are generally contributing more than they're receiving."
Ms. Shimelman said the decision places the state's efforts to assist ailing inner-city hospitals at risk, as well as jeopardizing the $150 million the state receives from the Federal Government for conducting such a program.
William J. Doyle, the Hospital Association's lawyer, said, "If they're going to keep providing this money, they're going to have to find a different way to do it."
When New Jersey was faced with a similar decision in 1992, the state decided to use surplus money from its unemployment insurance fund to finance charity care, while deregulating hospital prices. Although an appeals court later reversed the ruling that forced the change, Kathleen A. Brennan, the acting director of the state's Healthcare Financing Program, said New Jersey had not returned to taxing hospital services.
She noted that the state was about to run out of surplus funds and was looking for other ways to finance the program.
But in Connecticut, there appears to be no surplus funds to draw upon.
"The choices are not going to be real pretty," said State Representative Joseph D. Courtney, co-chairman of the Legislature's public health committee.
It is not clear whether Judge Covello's ruling will take effect immediately or whether the hospitals will continue to pay the taxes until the Supreme Court issues its decision, expected in the spring of 1995.
This is the second time this year that a Federal judge has struck down provisions of the state's program to provide financing for uncompensated care.
In March, Judge Jose A. Cabranes of Federal District Court in New Haven ruled that similar measures were in violation of the Erisa law. That case, filed by District 1199 of the New England Health Care Employees Union, prompted the Legislature to modify its program, replacing strict price controls on hospital services with a revenue cap.
But Judge Covello ruled that the changes did not substantially affect the original ruling, as the taxes remained in place. "Statutes that have a substantial economic impact on Erisa plans, causing such plans to either increase costs or reduce benefits, are pre-empted by Erisa," he wrote.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Trying to Make the Numbers Add Up

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HERNDON, Va., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Bargaining representatives for major league baseball players continued to crunch numbers today and into the night to see if there is any room for negotiations on a new tax system team owners have proposed in hopes of ending a strike that has shut down the game for more than three months.
The union said the numbers in the owners' proposal were too punitive, but that they would continue to study the framework of the plan to see if there was room for discussion. For their part, the owners said they believe they are moving closer to the players' desires by tabling the concept of a "hard" salary cap, meaning a rigid one that would, according to the union, artificially limit salaries. 
 These new round negotiations, which will enter a third day at a suburban hotel here Saturday, remain cordial. But much work remains. That was evident in the descriptions of just what is transpiring at the table.
On Thursday, the owners proposed a tax designed to benefit the low-income clubs by taxing any club that crosses a payroll threshold of $34 million. They called their offer significant.
The players, who struck on Aug. 12 and had not witnessed any significant change in the owners' posture until Thursday, did not embrace the idea. Especially unsettling to the players are the numbers, which they say could stifle clubs' spending and therefore hold down player salaries.
Still, the players did not reject the framework today. They explained that they do not yet know enough about it. They also said that they do not yet know if that framework can, with some major or minor tinkering, be made into something all parties can use to end what has become the longest work stoppage in professional sports history.
"The numbers they plugged into their taxing system produces punitive rates -- that's clearly the case," Gene Orza of the Players Association said after a night of crunching numbers with the union's economists and before a two and a half hour negotiating session.
"It's obvious the numbers they plugged into their system will not fly," Orza continued. "The question is whether or not the system itself provides the basis for further discussions."
The answer to that question could come as early as Saturday morning. "It's very encouraging that we're going to continue to meet," said John Harrington, the managing partner of the Boston Red Sox who heads the owners' negotiating team. "Hopefully, we'll see a response and a counterproposal from the union tomorrow."
The second day of discussions on the tax proposal were conducted under the watch of Bill Usery Jr., the mediator called into the three-month-old baseball strike by the Clinton Administration. In the session, the players raised a number of questions and, Orza said, met with a "lot of good answers."
Then, Harrington said, "When the answer to the numbers evolved, that led to philosophical discussions on how the numbers shaped up."
Harrington also said that philosophical barriers were crossed, namely, he said, "the dropping of the hard cap. Not just abandoning it, but pulling it to the side."
It is a process that isn't guaranteed to end Saturday, or even Sunday because, said Donald Fehr, head of the union: "You have to gather information, you have to evaluate it, you then have to make sure you can duplicate what they did. If you can't, you don't understand what they did. Or they don't understand what they did, one of the two. That process has to go on as long as it has to go on. And it's not over, yet."
There is an indication that the discussions are medicinal in themselves. "They are being more candid," one person in the room said of the owners, whose proposal and interpretations were expanded on by the Phillies' Dave Montgomery and the Braves' Stan Kasten today. "In the past, we didn't have any discussions. At least now they're giving an effort."
The owners, while answering questions on the tax, also still have on the table the salary cap, which they first proposed June 14. However, it has been revised and, at least for now, pushed aside by the tax discussions.

HEADLINE: For the Young, Bright and Bored;
Long Island School Rescues Youngsters in Academic Limbo

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I.

 BODY:
Barbara Reiser felt pleased with her son Brian's new school after a teacher called last month with the results of the boy's first math test.
He had failed.
"Brian had never really been challenged in school before," Mrs. Reiser said. "But now he can't coast. It's a great learning experience for Brian. I expected him to be beside himself. But he handled it really well." 
 Brian is a 12-year-old who had become so bored at the public school he once attended that he would laugh at the textbooks. "Look, Mom," he would sometimes say at the start of a school year, "it's the same book I had last year only with a different cover."
But before Brian got lost in academic limbo, his parents enrolled him in the Long Island School for the Gifted, one of a few private schools in the nation whose classes are tailored to address the needs of bright children whose needs are not being met by the public schools.
The school, which requires I.Q.'s of at least 130, was founded in 1980 by Carol Yilmaz and a group of parents like her whose children found school boring and unchallenging. Mrs. Yilmaz's daughter Robyn, for example, had begun to sour on school by first grade because she was so far ahead of her peers.
Today, Robyn is a Harvard graduate, and the school her mother founded is flourishing, with 225 students. Last month, the school earned a rare distinction when two of its graduates were named the only New York State Advanced Placement Scholars for 1994. To be considered, a student must complete at least three college-level courses in high school. The two graduates of the school completed more than 10 such courses.
Mrs. Yilmaz sees the awards as confirmation of the critical role the school has played in cultivating the potential of the so-called gifted child.
"Every child deserves a good education," said Mrs. Yilmaz, who is now the school's director. "And gifted children need educations that challenge their unique abilities."
At a time when an increasing number of revenue-strapped school districts across New York State are eliminating programs for the gifted, schools like the one run by Mrs. Yilmaz are becoming alternatives of last resort for many children and their parents.
"The fact that districts are reducing programs for the gifted indicates that they don't see them as necessary as other programs," said Dr. David J. Irvine, who coordinates such programs for the State Department of Education. "That's why they are more vulnerable to changes in the economy."
Some parents and educators have long argued that classes for intellectually talented children are unnecessary, promote elitism and deprive other classes of brighter students.
In addition, critics say the special classes are merely a way to keep middle-class children in the public schools in places where students from poorer families, often black and Hispanic, predominate.
But advocates of such programs contend that intellectually talented children often become bored in mainstream classrooms and never develop the kind of good work habits that would help them get ahead.
Of the 40 million students in kindergarten through 12th grade nationwide, about two million can be classified as gifted, according to estimates by the Federal Department of Education. People who are considered gifted possess a wide range of talents, including I.Q.'s that are approximately 30 points above the average of 100.
"Many of these kids really need to be challenged in a special way in order for them to grow," said Roberta Tropper, the principal of the School for the Gifted. "But many people have this perception that gifted children don't need any special help because they already have an advantage. And that's just wrong."
Mrs. Yilmaz said that early on, Robyn felt frustrated with her schooling.
In nursery school, she was asked to color in letters with crayons even though she could already read. And by the first grade, Robyn knew how to multiply and divide while the rest of her class was learning to add and subtract.
"The school is really the product of a lot of frustration," Mrs. Yilmaz said. "That's why I can understand the anguish that so many parents feel in seeing their children not being challenged and becoming underachievers."
The school opened modestly, with 14 students inside the classroom of a synagogue in Freeport. Today, it shares a building with a branch of Adelphi University and has kindergarten through ninth-grade classes. Yearly tuition is $5,600 to $6,700, compared with the average annual per-pupil spending of $10,941 in public schools on Long Island and $8,556 statewide. The school has managed to keep tuition low by holding fund-raising drives and paying its teachers far less than the median for Long Island teachers of $62,898 a year.
Students are assigned to classes on the basis of their understanding of a subject rather than their age. So a child might be in a fourth-grade class for one subject and a fifth grade for another.
There are between 4 and 15 students in each class. They study advanced topics at a younger age than at other schools. In kindergarten, for instance, children are taught Spanish and science.
School officials take great pains to dispel the stereotype of these talented children as bookish and insulated. But the students display a decidedly academic flair, from humming along with the classical music that echoes through the hallways to discussing articles from newspapers that are handed out each day in homeroom.
A class of fourth graders seemed perfectly at ease probing the concept of positive and negative space during a recent lesson in contour drawing.
"I get it," Henry Mathies said, interrupting his teacher as she tried to explain the concept. "Can we start drawing now?"
Many parents say that their children would simply flounder without such a thought-provoking environment.
Consider the case of Carol Eisner of Lloyd Neck, L.I., who enrolled her 12-year-old son, Gregory, in the school five years ago. He had shown remarkable ability from early on, a boy who by age 3 could recite the lines in about a dozen storybooks.
"He would just say the words and turn the pages like he was reading," his mother said. "But he really wasn't reading. He had just memorized the stories from all the times we read to him."
He also developed a knack for math between the ages of 3 and 4. In a favorite drill, he would have his parents quiz him with math problems as they traveled in the family car. "Give me numbers," he would shout to them from the back seat.
But his intelligence seemed to become stifled when he began first grade at a public school.
One telling episode involved his refusal to complete several problems on the first page of his math book as his teacher had instructed him. Instead, Gregory did the harder problems on the last page.
Rather than encourage him, the teacher reprimanded Gregory.
"I just thank God we found the right school for him," Mrs. Eisner said. "Otherwise, he would have been lost."
Similarly, Brian Reiser, the boy who came to the School for the Gifted this year, had been complaining about school since fourth grade. To him, the subject matter had become painfully repetitious.
"The third grade was probably the last year I learned a decent amount of stuff," he said. "In the fourth grade, we basically reviewed what we learned in the third grade. And in the fifth grade, we reviewed what we learned in the fourth grade. There were some new things, but not enough."
His mother didn't know what to do. "I was at wits' end," she said, recalling Brian's occasional but emphatic collect phone calls from school. "He kept nagging and nagging."
But now he finds school stimulating and enjoyable. He has turned his math scores around by doing something that wasn't as necessary before: studying. "I've never really liked school," Brian said. "But this place is great -- for a school."

HEADLINE: Market Loses Ground; G.M. at 52-Week Low

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market drifted lower yesterday with trading distorted by the expiration of options, known as "double witching." General Motors, a leading stock, also drifted lower and established a new 52-week low, capping a nearly monthlong decline.
But bond prices were stable, and the dollar rose, helped by news of a narrowing of the United States' trade deficit with Japan. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.79 points, to 3,815.26, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2.10 points, to 461.47. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 1.17 points, to 764.67.
Only four stocks rose for every seven that fell on the New York Stock Exchange, where there were 801 advancing stocks and 1,422 decliners.
Days when different kinds of options expire simultaneously are known as either double or triple witching, depending on how many kinds of options expire, because of the mischief they are said to prompt.
On these days, prices have bounced wildly, and trading volumes have surged enormously, as traders have scrambled to use or lose options to buy or sell stock. But the very expectation of mischief has tended to breed restraint, so market distortions have moderated in recent years.
Yesterday, for example, the Dow swung only 42 points from its lowest point to the highest, and that action was extended over more than three hours. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was above average with 362.7 million shares changing hands, but only 25 percent above this year's average of 290 million shares.
In addition, the closely watched trade deficit figures were released yesterday, but the report affected the currency markets more than the stock market. The overall United States trade deficit widened 4.6 percent, to $10.1 billion. But a 7.4 percent narrowing of the deficit with Japan to $5.4 billion helped the dollar, which rose to 98.56 Japanese yen in New York trading, from 98.30 yen on Thursday.
Most interest rate-sensitive stocks fell following Tuesday's increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. The Standard & Poor's auto index, continuing a nine-month decline, fell to its lowest point of the year, 200.3.
General Motors, despite a meeting with analysts on Thursday, fell enough yesterday to establish a new 52-week low of 37 1/2 before closing at 37 3/4, down 3/4.
Bank stocks dropped, too, amid concern that rising interest rates would hurt profits. Citicorp fell 5/8, to 43 3/8; Chase Manhattan fell 1/2, to 35 1/2, and First Chicago fell 1, to 47 1/4.
Still, some groups rallied. Biotech stocks rose in the wake of Amgen's agreement to acquire Synergen, which prompted speculation of further consolidation in the biotech industry. Amgen fell 3/16 , to 56 7/8, while Synergen rose 321/32 , to 91/32 . Cephalon rose 1 1/2, to 9 1/4; Systemix rose 1 3/4, to 14 3/4, and Chiron, which is in talks to sell part of the company to Ciba-Geigy, was up 2 3/4, to 78 1/4.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.19 points, to 252.30, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.09 points, to 444.04.
Of the Dow industrials' 30 component stocks, 19 fell, led by Goodyear Tire, which slid 1, to 33 3/4. Of the S. & P. 500's component stocks, 318 fell, led by General Motors.
The most active stock, at 7.6 million shares, was the initial public offering of the Sports Authority Inc., a sporting goods-chain, which closed at 24. It is the second unit of Kmart to be sold to the public; Officemax went public earlier this month.
In Tokyo, stocks were lower yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 34.01 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 19,302.56. The Nikkei was up 18.2 points for the week.

HEADLINE: What Turkey Gives in Return for U.S. Military and Foreign Aid;
Arming Genocide

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Deadly Gifts to Greece and Turkey" (editorial, Nov. 13): 
 This century has experienced more acts of genocide than any other period: the Turkish extermination of the Armenians in Anatolia, followed by the genocide of the European Jews by the Fascist alliance, and near genocide in Bosnia, Rwanda and Iraqi- and Turkish-occupied Kurdish territories. These acts of mass extermination have coincided with the invention, introduction and sale of Western-made weapons.
 The more weapons are introduced anywhere, the more likely are war and genocide. This is particularly true for Turkey. Except for a minor contribution of troops in the Korean War, the weapons the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has supplied to Turkey have been used primarily against its own population. For example, the military coup in 1960 by Gen. Cemal Gursel led to the execution of the civilian Prime Minister, Adnan Menderes, and his foreign, interior and finance secretaries.
 NATO-supplied arms were used in the conquest of the Republic of Cyprus and its forceful partition. They are continually being turned against the Kurdish people, who have occupied southeastern Turkey and northern Iraq for thousands of years. These acts have been made possible by contributions from NATO and, more particularly, the United States.
 Turkey suffers from inflation of nearly 2,000 percent. Fresh drinking water is scarce. Transportation, housing, health, employment and safety are at a crisis level. How will the introduction of thousands of tanks and hundreds of fighter planes help anyone other than the ruling military oligarchy?
 And what does the United States have to gain by emboldening one of the most ruthless security organizations in existence? We need to consider what such shortsighted policy will do to the trust accorded the United States as a civilized country when we ask other countries to refrain from using or developing nuclear weapons and reduce their conventional weapons.
 How can I, a Kurd, ask my people to overlook the suppression and torture of 15 million Kurds in Anatolia, expedited by American-contributed weapons, and only pay attention to the few truckloads of canned foods sent to the 2 million Kurds in their native reservation in Iraqi-occupied Kurdistan?
 
OMRAN FEILI
New York, Nov. 13, 1994

HEADLINE: Fed's Vote in September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted 11 to 1 against raising interest rates at their Sept. 27 meeting, even as they saw signs that inflation might accelerate next year, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
"The ongoing inflow of information on the performance of the economy continued to indicate a significant potential for higher inflation down the road," the minutes said. 
 Indeed, the Fed's policy makers decided at their most recent meeting on Tuesday that short-term interest rates needed to be increased for the sixth time this year to keep inflation in check.
Still, the central bankers concluded at the September meeting that the slow growth of the nation's money supply meant inflation was unlikely to accelerate immediately.
While policy makers on the Fed's Open Market Committee did not raise rates in September, they took the technical step of voting for a shift toward favoring higher rates rather than stable rates.
The only dissenting vote was cast by the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., who urged an immediate rate increase that would respond to "signs of increasing price pressures and rising inflationary expectations," the minutes said.
The minutes show Fed policymakers were apprehensive that inflation might soon accelerate. "The risks of some rise in inflation rates probably had increased," the minutes said. And Mr. Broaddus said there was an additional risk: "A delay in implementing some monetary policy tightening would incur a substantial risk of a further increase in inflationary expectations."
Even so, the minutes show, other members of the policy-making committee were unsure whether earlier interest rate increases were already cooling the economy enough to keep prices from accelerating.

HEADLINE: September Trade Gap Widened

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The United States' trade deficit widened in September as a vigorous domestic economy drew in a rising tide of imports while export sales ebbed, the Commerce Department said today.
The gap between overseas sales of American-made goods and services and the value of all imports widened 4.6 percent, to $10.1 billion, from $9.7 billion in August. Exports fell, while imports, led by record purchases of foreign oil, increased for the fifth consecutive month.
"We're still an economy spending more than we're producing," said Robert Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. The widening came in part because the United States economy is growing much more strongly than the economies of Europe and Japan.
The deficit with Japan, however,shrank 7.4 percent in September to $5.4 billion -- the lowest since $4.4 billion in May. Japan regularly accounts for more than half the United States' total annual trade deficit, and the deficit with Japan has often been cited by the Clinton Administration in its efforts to open Japanese markets to American products.
The United States' trade deficit with Western Europe also narrowed, to $1.56 billion in September from $1.62 billion in August.
But the trade deficit with China surged 8 percent, to a record $3.5 billion. The deficit with Canada, the United States' biggest trade partner, grew to $1.45 billion, from $954 million in August.
Total exports weakened in September by five-tenths of 1 percent, to $59.67 billion.
Among exported goods, the Commerce Department said, sales were down in September for industrial supplies and materials and for a range of consumer goods as well as cars and parts.
Imports increased for a fifth consecutive month, rising three-tenths of 1 percent, to a record $69.8 billion. Imports of foreign-produced oil jumped to a record 261 million barrels in September from 241 million barrels in August. The previous record was 249 million barrels in June.
Lynn Reaser, an economist with First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, said the trade report showed the vigor of the economy. But she said that it also pointed to a leveling-off in the big monthly deficits with Japan and suggested that the trade picture should improve for the United States in 1995.
"I believe over the next year our export growth will begin to outstrip import increases," she said.
Accelerating recoveries in Japan and Western Europe should add buying power in those markets for goods that competitive American manufacturing industries will be in a position to supply.
Talks are currently under way in Tokyo on Japanese proposals to cut regulations that critics contend stifle trade opportunities in fields ranging from agriculture and financial services to auto parts and trade.
The Clinton Administration is also pushing for approval of the GATT world trade agreement, which, the Administration says, would open new export opportunities.
In September, the deficit in merchandise alone widened to $14.6 billion from $14.1 billion in August. The surplus on services was up to $4.5 billion, from $4.4 billion in August.
During the first nine months of 1994, Commerce Department officials said, the total deficit in goods was running at an annual rate of $148.8 billion. At that pace, the 1994 deficit would rank second to the record annual gap, which was $152.1 billion, set in 1987.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mexico Trade Increases
 DALLAS, Nov. 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- United States exports to Mexico rose 21.7 percent, to $37.5 billion, for the nine months since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect Jan. 1, the Commerce Department reported today.
Imports rose 22.8 percent in the first nine months of the year, to $35.7 billion, but the trade surplus with Mexico, at $1.8 billion, was virtually unchanged.
"Nafta is working for the United States," Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said today. "It provides a concrete example of the benefits of free trade."
Mr. Brown said that increased exports to Mexico were responsible for 130,000 jobs, and that Congressional passage of the world free trade agreement would multiply such benefits. Opponents of the North American pact, however, say that the Administration has understated the resulting job losses.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Narrower Trade Deficit With Japan Helps the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most leading currencies yesterday after a report showed that the United States trade deficit with Japan narrowed in September.
Despite a widening in the overall trade deficit to $10.1 billion from $9.68 billion, the imbalance with Japan slipped 7.4 percent, to $5.4 billion in September, the Commerce Department said yesterday. 
 A smaller trade deficit with Japan means that Japanese exporters have fewer dollars to sell for yen when they repatriate profits.
The deficit with Japan has also been a source of concern for many investors because they fear that the Clinton Administration may try to shrink it by seeking a lower dollar, which would make make imports from Japan more expensive.
In trading in New York, the dollar rose to 98.56 yen, from 98.30 yen on Thursday.
Although the trade gap with Japan is narrower, it is still large. Japan regularly accounts for more than half the annual trade deficit of the United States. The gap has put pressure on the value of the dollar, which is still near its record low of 96.42 yen, set in intraday trading on Oct. 25. Several currency dealers said yesterday that the news that Sony was writing $2.7 billion off the value of its American movie subsidiary suggested that the conglomerate might be selling yen for dollars.
"The view is that when Sony made their investment in Columbia Pictures they would have hedged it by buying yen," said David Gilmore, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "So if they're eliminating $2.7 billion off their books they would be unwinding that hedge."
But several traders said the possible fallout from Sony's financial difficulties was an excuse used by some traders who had taken a more positive outlook toward the dollar after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates on Tuesday.
The Swiss franc, meanwhile, fell on rumors of an imminent cut in official Swiss interest rates. A denial by the Swiss National Bank failed to support the currency. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.3185 Swiss francs, from 1.3055 on Thursday.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.5548 German marks, from 1.5522 on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.5655 from $1.5710.

HEADLINE: Treasuries End Mixed On Slow Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in lackluster trading yesterday.
The bond market received support from strength in the dollar and option expirations, analysts said. An attractive price of 97 for a December bond option helped underpin a late morning rally that pared the worst losses of the session. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond came off earlier lows to finish unchanged at 921/32 for a yield of 8.12 percent. Prices of shorter-term maturities were unchanged to slightly lower.
Concerns about the ability of the market to absorb next week's large supply of new two- and five-year notes weighed down prices yesterday. Lukewarm demand for the notes in when-issued trading has prompted dealers to squeeze yields a little higher to generate interests.
A two-year note was offered yesterday at a price to yield 7.28 percent, while the yield on a five-year note was 7.81 percent. Both notes were up a couple of basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. The Treasury plans to auction $17.25 billion in two-year notes on Monday and $11 billion in five-year notes on Tuesday.
The market received a small lift from a stronger dollar, which makes bonds more attractive to foreign investors. The dollar gained yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit with Japan narrowed in September.
But the overall trade deficit widened 4.6 percent for the month. The fear among investors is that the widening gap between United States imports and exports could drive the dollar lower, discouraging foreign investors from buying American bonds.
Some market analysts said yesterday that the market appeared due for an upturn. Bond prices fell on Thursday and Wednesday, and some say the market is becoming oversold. But any rally will be limited because investors continue to cash in on every uptick in the market.
Robin Mesch, chief analyst for fixed-income products at Thomson Research in Portland, Ore., said investor interest on the long bond had been been piling up at a price to yield 8.13 percent, or 9226/32 , in the cash market. "The market has run into congestion, and I anticipate there will be a massing of buyers at around that level," Ms. Mesch said.
"Next week, I think you'll see some directional movement initiated from a price of 9621/32 in futures trading," she said. "The time is ripe for the market to test one extreme of the trading range. But I think those gains will be capped at a price of 9818/32 for a yield of about 7.99 to 8 percent."
In the municipal market, where tax-exempt mutual funds have been hit with shareholder redemptions because of the rise in interest rates and loss of value, mutual funds continued to sell bonds to raise cash, causing bonds to slump for a third day.

HEADLINE: BANKING;
Trust Officers' Mission Broadened by New Law

BYLINE: By Andree Brooks 

 BODY:
IN literature, as in life, trust officers have been characterized as the most conservative of creatures, unwilling to take even minor risks with the money they manage. Tales abound of family assets that were depleted by inflation or of investments that far underperformed the financial markets.
In their defense, trustees have long said that they are hamstrung. A large body of law makes preservation of capital -- and thus risk avoidance -- their primary objective, explained Isabel Miranda, director of the trusts and estates department at Citibank in New York. 
But change is coming. On Jan. 1, the Prudent Investor Act takes effect in New York, which joins more than a dozen states in broadening the trustees' mission beyond capital preservation. The law was heavily promoted by corporate trustees and estate lawyers, who find clients increasingly concerned about investment performance.
"It's a major milestone," said Mary B. Lehman, managing director of private advisory services for the New York City office of the Bankers Trust Company. "Trustees will now be able to act like regular money managers."
The new law instructs the trustee to invest with an eye toward overall return, instead of limiting the trustee to the safest investments with the least chance of capital loss. Blue- chip stocks could be supplemented by small-company shares, for example.
Investments like stock options or international stocks may also be used. These vehicles, while risky in and of themselves, may actually reduce the volatility of an overall portfolio by rising when other holdings decline. The suitability of such investments will be based on the needs of the beneficiary and on the prevailing economic climate.
The law will no longer protect the trust officer who remains narrowly tied to bonds or bank deposits if those investments are likely to erode the value of the trust during a period, say, of high inflation.
Ms. Lehman said beneficiaries could now demand that trustees develop an investment strategy that met their needs -- not just one that preserved principal.
As an example, she cited a trust established for a widow and her two children. If the widow's primary need was income, the trust might have invested primarily in bonds to generate income while preserving principal. Under the new law, the longer-term needs of the children will have to be considered, requiring some assets to be devoted to growth investments.
The law does not go far enough for some. Trustees cannot normally be threatened with dismissal simply because their performance falls short of some benchmark.
"Why should they knock themselves out for performance when they have the assets locked up?" asked Standish Smith, the founder of Heirs, a group based in Philadelphia that advocates greater rights for trust beneficiaries. Heirs would like beneficiaries to be able to change fiduciaries for competitive factors like performance and fees. Right now, most state laws make such changes onerous unless egregious acts can be shown.
Without the threat of competition, corporate trustees will not be motivated to hire the high-priced talent needed to make trusts into strong performers, Mr. Standish said.
But he applauds the New York law as a step in the right direction, suggesting that beneficiaries should write or call their trust officers, alerting them to the change and letting them know the kind of strategy they would support.
Ms. Miranda agreed. "If a family really wants an aggressive strategy and we can document that fact," she said, "we can do a lot more. We can even use derivatives."
Not in all cases though. The wording of the trust document can take precedence over the new law, said Arlene Harris, a lawyer with the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler in Manhattan. If the trust creator specified a strategy, like maximizing income over growth, the trustee is still bound to comply.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The United States trade deficit widened by 4.6 percent in September. Imports increased for the fifth consecutive month. But the deficit with Japan -- which accounts for more than half of the overall deficit -- narrowed by 7.4 percent. [Page 41.]
Skoda is trying a bold experiment in auto production in an effort to improve quality and cut costs. The Czech company is giving suppliers their own place inside the assembly plant. The method takes the "just in time" system, which is widely used in auto assembly plants in Japan and the West, a leap forward. [41.]
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen warned that the defeat of the world trade agreement known as GATT could have "a very negative effect on the financial markets of this country." [11.]
 
Companies
T.W.A. failed to fix itself during a 19-month bankruptcy, emerging with a business plan built largely on hope. Many current and former employees say the airline continues to suffer from a number of bad decisions -- or indecision -- by its owners. [41.]
Amgen plans to buy a biotechnology rival for $240 million. The deal for Synergen reflects a consolidation in the industry. [41.]
Chase Manhattan will buy U.S. Trust's securities processing business in a stock swap valued at $363.5 million. [44.]
British Aerospace sweetened its offer for VSEL to $905 million, seeking to defeat G.E.C. in the takeover battle. [44.]
R. H. Macy will close the venerable I. Magnin specialty chain ahead of its merger with Federated Department stores. Nine of the Magnin stores will be put up for sale and the rest will be converted into either Macy's or Bullock's outlets. [44.]
Merry-Go-Round Enterprises is hiring a turnaround firm to guide it out of bankruptcy. The president of the firm, Meridian Ventures, will be named chief executive of the retailer. [44.]
Viacom plans to expand its headquarters in Manhattan, after a promise of $15 million in tax incentives from the city. [27.]
 
The Economy
Curbs on certain derivatives are being prepared by regulators from the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. The regulations would be the first to require certain sellers of derivatives to determine whether these potentially volatile financial securities are suitable for their customers. [41.]
 
Markets
Stocks faded as options expired and shares of General Motors fell to a 52-week low. The S.& P. 500 index dropped 2.09 points. [42.]
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged. Bonds were helped by the dollar but were hurt by concerns over a large supply of new notes coming to market next week. [45.]
The dollar strengthened against other currencies, bolstered by the narrowing of the United States' trade deficit with Japan. [53.]
Crude oil prices declined ahead of an OPEC meeting next week. Analysts expect the meeting will not lead to a reduction in global supplies. Coffee prices fell, while sugar climbed. [53.]
 
Your Money
Flexible spending accounts have survived, remaining a way for the typical family to save hundreds or even thousands of dollars. Some employers had feared the accounts would be eliminated in an overhaul of the nation's health care system. [38.]
Faced with bewildering choices in employee medical plans? Benefit specialists provide some basic guidelines. [38.]
Foreign bonds can offer very attractive returns. But there are risks, particularly political and currency-exchange perils. [38.]
The mission of trust officers will be broadened beyond capital preservation under a new New York State law. [40.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Macy to Close I. Magnin Specialty Chain

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Getting ready for its merger with Federated Department Stores next month, R. H. Macy & Company said today that it would close the venerable I. Magnin specialty chain by putting nine of its stores up for sale and converting the remaining four into either Macy's or Bullock's outlets.
Federated apparently rejected an 11th-hour $40 million bid for the entire chain from Jerry A. Magnin, whose great-grandmother founded the flagship store in San Francisco in 1876. That store is one of the nine to be sold. 
 Federated contends it can generate higher proceeds by liquidating Magnin's inventory and selling the sites -- which are either in hard-to-obtain downtown locations or high-end malls -- than by selling the ailing chain intact, Mr. Magnin said in an interview.
He said a revised bid for the remaining nine stores would be impractical. "You have to own it all or nothing," said Mr. Magnin, who owns two Ralph Lauren Polo Stores in Los Angeles. "I don't think there is any value there once you run a going out-of-business sale. It ruins your credibility."
He made the offer to save 2,000 jobs and to preserve a business he maintains is viable and an institution, which passed from family hands in 1944.
Carol Sanger, a spokesman for Federated, declined to comment on the offer.
After reviewing Magnin's prospects, Allen Questrom, Federated's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that a high-end specialty operation was inconsistent with the aim of the company to expand its core department store businesses.
In addition, he said, Magnin "is not expected to make a meaningful contribution to the combined company's bottom line in the future."
Yet, Macy's last-ditch effort to revive California's premier specialty retailer, known for its high-priced designer salons and elegant ambiance, showed progress.
Last year, Macy's closed five underperforming Magnin sites and tried to broaden the clientele by adding cutting-edge designers. Revenue rose to $329 million in 1993, compared with about $275 million the year before.
At its peak in 1990, Magnin had 31 stores in five states and revenue of $440 million.
"It's the death of the dowager empress of luxury retailing in the West," said Alan Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report, an industry newsletter.
Magnin has fallen upon hard times in recent years by straying from California, where profits were stretched too thin as the chain lost economies of scale in apparel buying and advertising. In addition, the chain failed to attract younger customers.
Moreover, Magnin's old-world customers, who still spend more on Chanel than any other brand, began to defect. The chain has lost market share to larger rivals like Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue.
Federated intends to convert the Magnin stores in Palm Desert, Woodland Hills, Palo Alto and Walnut Creek, all in California, to Macy's or Bullock's.
The remaining nine stores are to be sold piecemeal or as a group. These include at least two gems. The flagship San Francisco store in Union Square is a local landmark with a cathedral-sized ceiling. And the recently refurbished Beverly Hills site on Wilshire Boulevard, adjacent to Rodeo Drive, is sandwiched among Saks, Neiman Marcus and Barneys.
The Magnin catalogue is to be folded into Federated's existing direct mail business.
The sites "make a great opportunity for a retail player to make an acquisition and create a franchise in California in one fell swoop," said Joseph B. Rubin, a managing director of Kenneth Laventhal & Company, which represents some creditors in the Macy bankruptcy proceedings. He gave no estimate of what price the stores might fetch.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BOOK OF INTIMATE GRAMMAR, by David Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A dark and stunning Israeli novel whose protagonist, a post-Freudian little boy, forestalls the treasons and corruptions of adulthood by ceasing to grow at the age of 11.
 
CORELLI'S MANDOLIN, by Louis de Bernieres. (Pantheon, $24.) A high-spirited historical romance about events on a Greek island, mostly during World War II, when Italians and Germans occupy the place and try to control it.
 
A CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK, by Irving Howe. (Harcourt Brace, $27.95.) The book Howe was working on at his death last year, a collection of freestanding essays on the art of fiction, is mainly a record of the pleasures of thinking, and thinking acutely, about novels.
 
FAMILY, by Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) An extraordinary history of an ordinary family, in which the author plays the roles of gossip, pedant and loyal member, yielding a reunion strangers are welcome -- and fortunate -- to attend.
 
FATHERALONG: A Meditation on Fathers and Sons, Race and Society, by John Edgar Wideman. (Pantheon, $21.) An illuminating book-length essay that concerns many things, chief among them the author's struggle to bridge the gulf between himself and his father.
 
THE FOLLOWING STORY, by Cees Nooteboom. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace, $14.95.) An insignificant man who has experienced transformation by imagination awaits his turn at death in this "Eurofable" by a Dutch novelist.
 
THE LAST SHOT: City Streets, Basketball Dreams, by Darcy Frey. (Richard Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Mr. Frey examines the myth of deliverance through basketball on the courts of Coney Island, where black youths compete to be exploited by coaches, colleges and, in the rarest cases, by professional sports.
 
LENIN: A New Biography, by Dmitri Volkogonov. (Free Press, $30.) The wrath of a former believer runneth over in this polemic by a Russian archivist who has discovered enough smoking-gun documents to argue that every disaster of the Soviet Union was the fault of its founder.
 
TALKING FROM 9 TO 5: How Women's and Men's Conversational Styles Affect Who Gets Heard, Who Gets Credit, and What Gets Done at Work, by Deborah Tannen. (Morrow, $23.) A lively sociolinguist explores what her subtitle specifies.
 
THIS YEAR IN JERUSALEM, by Mordecai Richler. (Knopf, $23.) An engaging novelist's report on his youth as a Zionist and his travels in Israel, ventures that leave him content to be a Canadian.
 
UNDER MY SKIN: Volume One of My Autobiography, to 1949, by Doris Lessing. (HarperCollins, $25.) A remarkable life in a remarkable place -- the declining British Empire in Africa -- told by a novelist who for three-quarters of a century has conceded nothing to political, psychological or literary fashion.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 47; Column 1; Magazine Desk
