HEADLINE: Southern Africa's Old Front Line Ponders Its Future in Mainstream

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 19

 BODY:
As a summit meeting of southern African leaders was winding down last month, Frederick Chiluba, the elfin former union leader who is now the President of Zambia, lapsed into a pensive monologue.
Maybe Africa was not really cut out for Western-style democracy, he told his fellow heads of state with a sigh. How could a president get anything done with opponents constantly carping at him? Maybe the one-party state was the way to go, after all. 
 "To run our countries effectively, we have to be securely in control," he said, according to another participant in the meeting. Soon, leaders from South Africa and Zimbabwe, Botswana and Mozambique were all embroiled in this philosophical debate.
Not long ago, it would have been hard to find a quorum of African leaders who could argue from experience about the frustrations of democracy.
But while much of the continent languishes under warlords, despots, or martial rule, southern Africa is coalescing into a region of peace and political pluralism, sometimes crudely honored but remarkable by African standards.
Already this year 3 of the 10 countries that make up the bottom third of Africa -- South Africa, Mozambique and Malawi -- have settled domestic conflicts through negotiation and elections and joined the club of novice democracies.
Today leaders from across the southern part of the continent converged on this placid capital hoping to induct their newest recruit, Angola, a country that has spent most of the last 33 years at war.
Eduardo dos Santos, the Angolan President, arrived today for the scheduled signing Sunday of a treaty promising a cease-fire and a share of power for the Unita rebel movement.
But United Nations officials said tonight that the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, had refused to come for fear of his personal safety. The treaty was to be signed instead by less senior officials on both sides, indicating that even if the rivals stop fighting, they are a long way from trusting one another. If Angola can be calmed, a region of more than 100 million people will be at peace for the first time since the liberation uprisings of the 1960's.
Every country but one, the tiny monarchy of Swaziland, has passed through multiparty elections and all, with varying degrees of indulgence, tolerate political opponents.
The style and oratory have changed, too. Not long ago in southern Africa, the role model was the guerrilla freedom fighters, the battle cry was black nationalism infused with an anticapitalist economic populism, and the symbol of political dissent was the raised fist, often clutching an AK-47 assault rifle.
Now the role model is Nelson Mandela, the freedom fighter mellowed into a conciliator. The battle cry is growth and investment. The hip acronym is G.N.U. -- for Government of National Unity, the power-sharing arrangement embraced most famously in South Africa, but also used in Zimbabwe and contemplated in Angola and Mozambique.
Whether peace and democracy will take firm hold in southern Africa is a question the African presidents debate among themselves, as Mr. Chiluba's remarks last month indicated.
Sometimes the new African democrats seem less like a regional bloc than a 12-step support group -- reformed warriors who help one another resist the temptation to return to old, violent habits.
How did it happen that, on a continent more famous for slaughter and starvation, this region has become an advertisement for hope?
One reason is the demise of the Soviet Union and subsequent retreat of the superpowers, who for many years financed their proxies in a battle for strategic influence and ideological high ground.
Another is the domino effect of change in South Africa, the richest and most developed country in the region.
To defend its flanks against black insurgency, the apartheid rulers in South Africa sponsored wars in neighboring Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe), Angola, South-West Africa (now Namibia) and Mozambique.
With the election in April of a coalition Government led by Mr. Mandela, South Africa has been transformed into an alternative model of how to deal with enemies.
The change has given new life to the main regional political forum, which was originally formed to combat white racists in South Africa and still goes by the militaristic name of the Front Line States.
With South Africa now a member, that organization has begun to synchronize its diplomacy as a force for regional stability in ways unthinkable before.
When Lesotho's fledgling democracy was overthrown by the military last August, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Botswana brought pressure, including a threat to send troops, until the legal Government was restored.
When the leader of the Mozambican rebels announced a boycott during the country's first elections last month, the Front Line States summoned him to Harare, Zimbabwe, for a stern warning.
Front Line representatives have met twice here this week to orchestrate diplomatic pressure for peace in Angola, trying to halt a Government military offensive, and trying to convince Mr. Savimbi that it was safe to emerge from hiding.
Once the Angolan treaty is signed, it is widely expected that troops from the region will join the 7,000-member peacekeeping force to be deployed in Angola under the auspices of the United Nations, including for the first time noncombat troops from Mr. Mandela's South Africa.
"There is a fundamental resistance in South Africa to any military intervention in any state in southern Africa," said Rusty Evans, a senior official in the South African Foreign Ministry. South Africa is in the midst of rebuilding its white-led army, he noted, and besides, "we feel that we have got a history that we've got to live down."
"We were seen as a major destabilizer in the region," he said, "and our objective now is to build the confidence of our neighbors." But in the case of Angola, he said: "We would certainly be responsive. I'm fairly certain we would not send infantry. But without a doubt we will commit major resources to the lifting of land mines, reconstruction of bridges, and providing military medical facilities."
African officials and foreign diplomats point to a number of dangers that could stifle the promise of the region.
Aldo Ajello, the United Nations diplomat who nursed the peace in Mozambique, said the main question was whether African states could avoid the temptation to crush their opponents, driving them back to war.
Democracy is still far from free-wheeling in several states of the region. In Zimbabwe, President Robert Mugabe has never let rivals gain enough political influence to pose a serious challenge to him. Here in Zambia, where Mr. Chiluba was the victor in the first multiparty elections in 1991, the state-run media are filled with propaganda accusing opponents of undocumented crimes.
"What is esoteric for Africa is the concept of the opposition as a permanent component of the political dialectic," Mr. Ajello said. "In local culture, once the chief is selected, he is the bloody chief."
As a result, he and other Western diplomats have become strong promoters of including the opposition in some executive role, as South Africa has done.
But many Africans resent this advice as another example of Western paternalism, noting that few Western politicians share power with the opposition in their own countries.
Another danger to the region's peace is economic hardship. Unless the elected governments of southern Africa quickly begin to raise standards of living, they could face less-than-democratic challengers, or wide-scale banditry, or internal dissension, which could break down along ethnic lines.
And always there is the question of whether the outside world will lose interest just when these countries need rebuilding.
"Our biggest danger is a sense of Afro-pessimism," said Mario Pizarro, an Angolan banker and business consultant. The conflicts in Rwanda and Somalia and other African horrors, he said, have exhausted foreign donors and frightened off potential investors.
In formerly Marxist countries like Angola and Mozambique, Mr. Pizarro added, foreign help is needed to nurture a strong private sector, which could become a lobby for stability, much as South African business pushed the white Government there toward compromise.
"Peace is good for business," he said. "If you had a strong private sector in Angola like in South Africa, the war would have ended many years ago."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia, left, welcomed President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola at Lusaka airport yesterday. A cease-fire agreement to end 33 years of war in Angola is expected to be signed. (Reuters) (pg. 16)
 
Chart/Map: "IN THE REGION: A New Era in Southern Africa"
 The two sides in Angola's civil war are to sign a treaty today that could bring peace and democracy to all of Southern Africa for the first time since the anti-colonial uprisings of the 1960's. Except for Botswana and Swaziland, the countries in the region have undergone democratic transitions in recent years.*
 
Angola
 OLD CONFLICT -- Two of the rebel armies that ousted Portugese in 1975 turned on each other. The MPLA took power with backing from Soviet Union and Cuba, while Unita challenged with help from United States and South Africa.
RESOLUTION -- A peace deal in 1991 led to elections the following year.
 OPPOSITION -- Unita rejected the outcome and war resumed. The latest peace deal calls for better U.N. monitoring and a power-sharing role for Unita.
 
Namibia
 OLD CONFLICT -- 23 years of armed struggle against South African control.
 RESOLUTION -- Won independence from South Africa in 1990 and became a multiparty republic.
 OPPOSITION -- Under President Sam Nujoma, the country has forsaken Marxist economics and been genial towards political opposition.
 
South Africa
 OLD CONFLICT -- Repressive white rule gave birth to civil disobedience, violent protest, and lethal rivalry among black organizations.
 RESOLUTION -- After seven years of fitful negotiations, Nelson Mandela's African National Congress won democratic elections in April.
 OPPOSITION -- Most opposition groups, including the former white ruling party, are junior partners in a national unity government.
 
Zambia
 OLD CONFLICT -- One-party state headed by rebel leader Kenneth Kaunda since independence from Britain in 1964.
 RESOLUTION -- Mr. Kaunda submitted to political challenge in 1991 and, to the surprise of many, accepted defeat.
 OPPOSITION -- He has been holding rallies for a comeback try in elections next year, but is considered a long shot.
 
Lesotho
 OLD CONFLICT -- A monarchy under military rule since independence from Britain in 1966.
 RESOLUTION -- Lesotho last year held its first elections and threw out the ruling party.
 OPPOSITION -- In August this year the king and military threw out the democratic government, but pressure from Mr. Mandela and other neighboring democrats restored the elected rulers.
 
Zimbabwe
 OLD CONFLICT -- Black nationalist groups campaigned for independence, first against Britain, then against a renegade white regime headed by Ian Smith.
 RESOLUTION -- The defeated white regime yielded in 1980.
 OPPOSITION -- Robert Mugabe, the rebel commander who became President, has not installed a one-party state, but coopted the main opposition by making Joshua Nkomo, of the minority Ndebele tribe, his Vice President.
 
Malawi
 OLD CONFLICT -- After leading the protests that won independence from British rule in 1964, Hastings Kamuzu Banda consolidated all power in an eccentric, one-party despotism.
 RESOLUTION -- The country's first multiparty elections in May ended his 30-year personality cult.
 OPPOSITION -- Mr. Banda's party driven into parliamentary opposition.
 
Mozambique
 OLD CONFLICT -- Ruling Frelimo party, which led the ouster of Portugese colonials was bedeviled for 16 years by Renamo rebels, originally sponsored by white regimes in South Africa and Rhodesia.
 RESOLUTION -- After two years of ceasefire, incumbent president Joaquim Chissano and his Frelimo party won elections in October.
 OPPOSITION -- Renamo holds a large opposition bloc in Parliament, and there is talk of some kind of power-sharing.
 
*Botswana has been a multi-party democracy since independence from Britain in 1966. Swaziland has been a constitutional monarchy since Britain gave up control in 1968. (pg. 16)

HEADLINE: A Capitol Hill Empire Is in Eclipse, Ending a Long Reign by Its Emperor

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
After 14 years of unchecked expansion, the empire of Representative John David Dingell Jr. is being dismantled.
Like a plump Thanksgiving turkey, the House Energy and Commerce Committee, where Mr. Dingell has been chairman since 1981, is being readied to be carved up and dished out. Gleeful Republicans have begun to disassemble its muscular investigative unit and pass around its meaty legislative authority. 
 Unlike a few less important committees, which the new Republican majority plans to scrap entirely, Energy and Commerce is being reorganized. But the scope of that reorganization will be sweeping, and the fate of the legislative and investigative apparatus that Mr. Dingell created starkly illustrates the meaning of the change in House control after 40 years of Democratic dominance.
In the hallways of Capitol Hill, no committee came to symbolize the exercise of Democratic power more than Energy and Commerce. After years of complaining that the committee's reach was far too broad, the Republicans now have a chance to do something about it. Another impetus for stripping the committee of much of its power is that new Republican chairmen of some other committees are eager to exercise the authority that until now has belonged to the chief of Energy and Commerce.
Although it is the House's oldest committee, having been around in one form or another since 1795, Energy and Commerce grew to prominence only in this century, through decades of nurturing by Sam Rayburn. The Texas Democrat was its chairman when it cranked out mounds of New Deal legislation that created a vast new Federal regulatory bureaucracy in the 1930's.
Twenty years later, as Speaker of the House, Mr. Rayburn continued to expand the panel's oversight authority, and in the 1980's Mr. Dingell, who has represented his suburban Detroit district since 1955, built it into the biggest committee in Congress. Its Democratic staff alone numbered more than 140 people.
Under Mr. Dingell's control, Energy and Commerce was known not only for its prodigious law writing -- nearly half of all bills that reached the floor passed through the committee -- but also as an investigative powerhouse that was more than a match for the biggest corporations, academic institutions and Federal agencies.
The National Journal once observed that the Dingell committee claimed jurisdiction over anything that moved, burned or was sold. It oversaw clean-air regulations and securities markets, telecommunications and energy, railroads and toys and consumer protection.
Now, with the convening of the 104th Congress in January, Mr. Dingell will become the senior ranking member of the House of Representatives and the sole survivor among a group of senior lawmakers known as the Old Democratic Bulls. And he will find his old committee scaled back to a shadow of what it was.
Not only will it be considerably smaller and have far less authority, it will be in control of business-oriented conservative Republicans who have already made plain their intention not to take on industries like tobacco, aerospace and insurance in the same way Mr. Dingell, a former Wayne County prosecutor, did for years.
While details remain to be sorted out, Republican plans could reduce Mr. Dingell's own staff on the committee -- and on the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, which he also led -- to one-tenth the current size.
One development accompanying the reduction in the committee's strength has been a power struggle among rival Republicans. In particular, Mr. Dingell's successor as Energy and Commerce chairman, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, and the prospective head of the House Banking Committee, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, are locked in a fight over which committee should oversee Wall Street. The maneuvering is such that several industries have even joined in it, paying their lobbyists to engage in the fight over whom they should be lobbying.
This week many of the tenacious investigators of Mr. Dingell's oversight subcommittee, once feared by regulators, businessmen and scientists, began packing up and morbidly joking about their new careers come January.
"I'll be going to 14th and U, where the unemployment office is," said a senior staff lawyer who to the end insisted on speaking anonymously so as not to upstage the chairman, who was off on a hunting trip and could not be reached for comment.
Aides say the committee's remaining significant jurisdiction will be in health care, at a time when neither Congress nor the White House is much inclined to write any broad health care legislation.
In contrast, Mr. Dingell over the years pushed the committee's authority to the limits, in part by creatively interpreting its mandate. To the consternation of the Armed Services Committee, he held hearings on defense contractors in the 1980's, contending that the inquiry was an adjunct to his own committee's oversight of publicly traded companies.
His investigations helped force the resignation of the president of Stanford University, which spent more than $20 million to respond to his queries on its billing for government-financed research. They led a Nobel laureate scientist to retract a research paper. They uncovered mismanagement at the Food and Drug Administration and at the Environmental Protection Agency, and overbilling at large hospitals.
They exposed waste and fraud at the Pentagon: the Air Force's $640 toilet seat and the kennel fees that the military paid for the dog of a General Dynamics executive. They found corruption in the generic-drug industry. Everything from nuts and bolts to blood banks, bottled water and cardiac pacemakers are unquestionably safer now than they once were because of Mr. Dingell's efforts.
His allies have called Mr. Dingell's questioning penetrating, his investigations a sure sign of good government and his committee a haven to whistleblowers.
"The only people who will be happy about this change will be malefactors," said Michael F. Barrett Jr., who was chief counsel to the Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee from 1981 to 1991 and who has since represented some targets and witnesses before Mr. Dingell.
To his critics, though, the 68-year-old departing chairman was a bully, mean-spirited, vindictive and power-hungry. Many lawmakers saw more than a coincidence when he pushed for legislation to put a nuclear waste dump in Nevada after Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat from that state, took on the automobile industry, which Mr. Dingell champions, by advancing a bill to require higher gasoline mileage standards.
Joseph N. Onek, a lawyer for Dr. Bernard Fisher and Dr. Robert Gallo, prominent scientists whose research was attacked by the committee, says Mr. Dingell's staff recklessly abused its power.
"They were famous for leaking documents, generating press stories and acting in ways that one would not expect of a responsible Congressional committee," Mr. Onek said. "They would decide they didn't like people and then went after them in ways that were inappropriate."
In recent days, Mr. Dingell's Republican successor, Mr. Bliley, has been struggling to keep as much of the old Energy and Commerce Committee intact as possible, insisting that it would be unfair to him to have a dramatically diminished committee after he toiled on the panel in relative obscurity for 14 years. At a private meeting of transition officials on Wednesday, one participant said, Mr. Bliley pleaded with Republican leaders that "in their haste to get back at Dingell, the Republicans shouldn't be aiming their knives at Bliley's back."
But without Mr. Dingell's towering presence as the head of the committee, rival committees have begun to try to wrest control in areas like energy, railroads, the Coast Guard, the environment, Medicaid and Medicare. And banking groups have been lobbying to have oversight of their old rival, the securities industry, switched from Energy and Commerce to the Banking Committee. Wall Street lobbyists have been fighting back, telling members of Congress that the role should remain at Energy and Commerce, with which the securities industry has dealt for years.
In the scramble over jurisdiction, Republicans on other committees are hoping not only to gain more authority but also to rid themselves of issues they have found counterproductive.
For instance, Mr. Leach, of the Banking Committee, has told the Republican leadership that he would gladly take securities industry jurisdiction and in exchange give up the committee's oversight of Federal housing. Such a swap would greatly expand the Banking Committee's authority. It would also probably lead to the departure of several liberal Democrats who joined the committee to be involved in public housing issues and have also used it as a platform to criticize the bankers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: No Congressional committee reflected the exercise of Democratic power more than John D. Dingell's. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

 Under the Democrats, the House Energy and Commerce Committee has had the broadest jurisdiction of any committee in Congress, passing judgment on 40 percent of all legislation that has reached the floor of the House of Representatives.
 Under House rules, the committee, which has construed its jurisdiction widely, oversees legislation and investigations in the following areas:
 -- Interstate and foreign commerce
 -- All issues relating to national energy policy, conservation, the energy industry, interstate energy compacts, the Department of Energy and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission
 -- Inland waterways
 -- Railroads
 -- Regulation of interstate and foreicn communications
 -- Securities and exchanges
 -- Consumer affairs and consumer protection
 -- Travel and tourism
 -- Public health and healthcare
 -- Biomedical research

HEADLINE: Inflation Fuels Discontent Against Iran's Government

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Iranian demonstrators took time out from a week of state-sponsored anti-American rallies recently to redirect their anger against the Islamic Government and economic policies that have created a crisis of inflation.
At a demonstration this month commemorating the takeover of the United States Embassy during the Iran hostage crisis in 1979, nearly 500 students called for the execution of "capitalists" and denounced lawmakers for favoring wealthy merchants over low-income groups. 
 "Free market economic policies must be corrected," the protesters chanted. "The system must help the poor."
The protest, the second in two weeks at Teheran University, was only the latest example of unrest that signals a crisis of confidence in the Government.
In October, 800 students marched against legislation that would have required them to pay if they failed a course, although there is no tuition at the university. After the protest, Parliament defeated the bill.
Senior Government officials promised to continue a previously announced crackdown on speculators and profiteers who had been hoarding large amounts of food after the Government imposed price controls. But the economy has sent few encouraging signs.
Industrial growth is at 1 percent so far this year and buying power has been undermined by uncontrolled inflation that has sent some food prices soaring by as much as 4,000 percent since March.
"If structural changes are not made, social and economic opposition can turn into political opposition," said Changiz Pahlavan, a political scientist here. "On the one hand, the state is reluctant to bring about change because they fear that public expectations may rise. On the other, without change, they face a serious challenge. The official thinking is that if they put the crisis behind them, they will survive."
The crackdown on profiteers, planned after a series of urban riots in 1992, was interpreted by independent political scientists and economists here as a short-term remedy, neglecting the more fundamental issues: curbing Government control of the economy and fostering competition. With prices on some basic foods rising 100 to 4,000 percent since March, the Government released a list of "regulated" prices in October, warning violators of financial penalties and flogging.
Then the police, judicial authorities and civilian-clothed Bassij, veterans of the Iran-Iraq war of the 1980's, raided dozens of supermarkets and warehouses in a nationwide campaign. The raids yielded thousands of tons of hidden food supplies that merchants were accused of hoarding after the price-control system took effect, The Keyhan newspaper reported.
In Meshed, 460 miles east of Teheran, 600 tons of cooking oil and 140 tons of sugar were discovered this month. The manager of a Teheran department store, Abdulreza Jozani, was fined $13,000 for hoarding. Mr. Jozani was tried immediately after his arrest, as the Bassij held a public auction of goods at regulated prices, 25 percent less than market value.
"Two months ago a kilo of sugar was 30 rials, now it's 2,300 rials," said Morad Seifollahi, a bank employee who moonlights as a cabdriver to supplement his income of 200,000 rials a month, or $68. "Sugar, tea, cooking oil, butter and soap are luxuries in this country. Few people can afford them anymore, unless we stand on line for hours at auctions."
President Hashemi Rafsanjani announced this month that the crackdown against profiteers, branded "economic bloodsuckers," was part of an effort to turn the open market into an "Islamic market" where profit would have to be fair. He criticized the student protesters as immature and seditious.
Turning the oratory traditionally used for American and British "hegemonist powers" on merchants, Mr. Rafsanjani has accused them of "capitalizing on people's discontent."
The latest crisis was set off in March by a sharp increase in the price of state-run services with 60 percent for telecommunications, 100 percent for gas and 300 percent for electricity at plants and factories. Domestic and foreign airline fares jumped 100 percent. The rial fell nearly 60 percent against the dollar in the past year.
Moreover, with shrinking foreign currency reserves, the Government lifted subsidies on raw materials to industries, and more recently on sugar and cooking oil, whose prices jumped 2,000 and 4,000 percent.
Analysts attribute the volatility of Iran's economic transition to a lack of long-term planning, the emergence of monopolies and oligopolies that prevent market forces from working properly.
"We have a hodgepodge economy," said Kamal Athari, an economist and researcher at the state-run Urban Planning Center. "Wealthy bazaar businessmen and special interest groups have formed monopolies engaging in foreign trade and buying state-owned industries. This has prevented real privatization and the emergence of entrepreneurs, impending recovery, especially in the industrial sector."
Mr. Athari continued: "The Government has rejected the free-market logic and principles of command economy without offering a third way. It is slowly discovering that in the absence of an economic program and the appropriate social foundations, the whole system may collapse."

HEADLINE: Latest Rate Hike by the Fed Makes White House Nervous

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The first five times the Federal Reserve raised interest rates this year, the Clinton Administration was surprisingly accepting. But last week's big increase produced a more varied reaction, leading to worries and irritation among some of the Administration's most senior economic officials.
The concern at top levels of the Administration is that the Fed's actions this time may begin to threaten the 31/2 -year-old economic expansion that must continue through 1996 if the President is to have any serious chance of winning re-election. A top policy maker, who insisted on anonymity, called the rate increase "a more marginal decision on the part of the Fed" than the central bank's previous interest rate moves. 
 Only a few hints of irritation have appeared so far in public. Deputy Treasury Secretary Frank N. Newman indirectly questioned the move, saying at an economic policy forum here on Thursday that it is unclear whether the Fed's most recent rate increase is the right approach to forestall inflation or whether it will prove unnecessary.
To be sure, a range of opinion on the Fed exists within the Administration, from complete support to cautious dismay. The weight of opinion among senior officials still seems to lie in favor of grudging acceptance of the rate increases, but a slow shift toward disagreement seems to have begun.
Still, whatever happens, Administration officials say they plan to avoid following the examples of President George Bush and President Lyndon Johnson in publicly and vociferously criticizing the central bank. "We don't comment on the Fed," said Robert E. Rubin, the assistant to the President for economic policy. "We have enormous regard for the independence of the Fed."
Without exception, Administration officials say public remarks would stir fears in financial markets of conflict between the White House and the Fed, pushing long-term interest rates higher. Meanwhile, they would have virtually no effect on the central bankers.
Some officials even fear that public criticisms would prompt the Fed to push interest rates even higher to reassure financial markets of its continued independence.
Mr. Newman, the Treasury official, went out of his way in a subsequent interview to say that when he suggested on Thursday that the rate hike might prove unnecessary, he had not intended to criticize the Fed. "I intended to make no judgment one way or the other, but simply to point out that when one makes decisions based on projections of the future, one finds out in the future if they were right or wrong," Mr. Newman said.
The central bank has tried all year, with little success so far, to rein in the economy's strong growth on the belief that slower growth is necessary to prevent inflation from rising. But the Clinton Administration and many private forecasters believe the Fed will eventually succeed in applying the brakes, with growth at least beginning to slow in 1995 and 1996.
While the timing of the expected slowdown cannot be pinpointed, most economists believe its full brunt is likely to be felt by early 1996, just as the Presidential primary season gets under way. The Fed itself estimates that the full effect of Tuesday's rate increase will not be felt for 12 to 18 months.
The biggest impact from higher interest rates, economists say, comes not from the immediate rise in mortgage and car loan rates, but only later after companies decide that rates have risen so much that it no longer makes sense to build new factories or install extra equipment.
Important corporate investment and purchasing decisions are commonly made a year or more in advance, which makes it very difficult for anyone to predict with confidence how long it takes before monetary policy affects the economy.
Publicly, Administration officials play down the possibility that the Fed's actions will lead to a sharp slowing of economic growth. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in an interview on Thursday that he expected the economy to grow 3.3 percent this year and slow to a 2.7 percent pace in the next two years.
Even though Administration is not prepared to condemn the Fed interest rate hikes, that has not stopped some Congressional Democrats from expressing their fears. "I think the effects of this are going to be disastrous to the economy and that's going to be disastrous to the Democrats," said Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a New York Democrat on the House Banking Committee who follows monetary policy.

HEADLINE: In Florida, a Nightmare for Farmers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 18

 BODY:
John Alger has had a string of luck so rotten that when he steps into his flooded fields of sweet corn he can only joke. "We keep kidding that we rescued three Cuban rafters crossing across here," he said, pointing over the muddy flats where Tropical Storm Gordon turned 630 of his acres into a miniature Straits of Florida.
The storm's wind and rain ruined crops on tens of thousands of acres across the southern half of Florida this week, and vegetable prices are already increasing in some Eastern grocery stores as a result. But for farmers in Homestead, the crop losses came with an odd twist: although this city south of Miami bore the brunt of Hurricane Andrew in August 1992, its vegetable crops suffered more at the hands of this much weaker tropical storm. 
 "Hurricane Andrew was very inconvenient, but this is going to hurt my pocketbook more," Mr. Alger said.
It is mostly a matter of timing. When the 1992 hurricane hit, farmers were nine weeks away from planting, but this time the tropical storm drenched crops that were weeks away from harvest. In 50 years, "this is the worst flooding we've seen during the growing season," Mr. Alger said.
It is the sort of loss that comes with the territory in Florida, where a cold snap can leave orange groves useless and the blessing of year-round harvests carries the curse of Caribbean storms. But for Mr. Alger, a Cornell-educated, 35-year-old grandson of farmers, the recent storm was the worst of three weather disasters in as many years.
First came Hurricane Andrew, whose damage was mostly covered by insurance. Then there was the March 1993 "Storm of the Century." Now, he said, Tropical Storm Gordon has ruined more than $2 million worth of his crops, mostly potatoes and sweet corn, and washed away $265,000 in seed, fertilizer and herbicide. In a good year, Alger Farms grosses $7 million. "I'm going to have to start all over again," he said.
Mr. Alger's crop damage is a small fraction of the loss in the region, where at least 35,000 acres of planted crops were ruined, said Tom Kirby, executive director of the Dade County Farm Bureau, a nonprofit group that represents the growers whose fields lie between Miami and the Everglades.
Over all, the storm may have cost Florida's agriculture industry $336 million, the state Department of Agriculture said. The high winds shredded leafy crops like lettuce, and the rain inundated squash, corn, green beans, peppers and other crops. The state grows about half of the nation's winter vegetables.
[Gov. Lawton Chiles asked President Clinton on Saturday to designate the counties hardest hit by Gordon as disaster areas, the Associated Press reported. Damage estimates were still coming in, so the Governor did not specify which counties needed the declaration.]
Although this storm was worse for vegetable growers, it was nothing compared with Hurricane Andrew's destruction for the community as a whole, or even for all farmers. Dade County's tropical fruit farmers lost practically nothing in this storm, but were out about $300 million when Hurricane Andrew blew through, Mr. Kirby said.
As the flood waters recede and farmers start to plow under their ruined crops, the economics of what happens next are simple, Mr. Kirby said, "Of course people are going to lose jobs," he said. "There are going to be a lot less crops to harvest."
As Mr. Alger stood outside his packing houses, a Mexican farm worker walked up with her two children, looking for work. He apologized and told her the harvest would not begin until February or March.
Consumers will feel the effects of the storm at the market. Patty Sheehan, the market news administrator for the Florida Department of Agriculture in Orlando, said that already the wholesale price of Florida cucumbers has tripled and green beans have nearly doubled.
Even with high prices, the farmers' heartache is rarely felt by those who eat their produce every day, Ms. Sheehan said. "People expect that when they go to the store their food will always be there, but when something like this happens you realize that their food depends on acts of nature, that farmers are out there dealing with the elements."
Mr. Alger's next step is to make a run up to Belle Glade, about two hours north, to buy new, fast-growing seed. "We're going to go right back and plant," he said. "We'll be working Thanksgiving Day. That's the son of a gun about farming. You're dealing with perishable products, and they don't know if it's Christmas or Thanksgiving."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Alger, left, his manager, Rob Bishop, right, and Robert Shekels of United Agricultural Products inspecting damage on Friday from Tropical Storm Gordon. Mr. Alger said his crop loss were $2 million. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Deep-Pocket Braves Set a Budget

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The Atlanta Braves have nine players signed for the 1995 season (what 1995 season, you ask?) at a total of $30 million. That's more than 11 teams spent, or would have spent without the strike, on their entire payrolls this year, but the Braves don't plan to break Ted Turner's bank.
"Actually, we have our own internal budget, which has been the admonition of agents and players, especially in the last three months," John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager, said. "We've taken their words to heart. They all said you don't need any kind of cap; all you have to do is set up a budget. So we're going to do that." 
 Schuerholz declined to say what the Braves' budget is, but it will result in a lower payroll than this year's $43 million, which was second only to the Yankees' $47 million.
Six of the nine players the Braves have signed for next season will earn from $3,733,333 to $5.5 million. The roster includes Greg Maddux, David Justice, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Fred McGriff and Roberto Kelly.
The Braves, though, haven't committed the most money for 1995. They are, in fact, fourth in the current salary standing behind Toronto ($34.8 for 7 players), Detroit ($31.7 for 7 players) and the Yankees ($31.4 million for 11 players).
The Blue Jays' lineup of dollar signs is particularly impressive: Joe Carter, $7.5 million; John Olerud, $5.75 million; Roberto Alomar, $5.5 million; Duane Ward, $4.75 million; Paul Molitor, $4.5 million; Devon White, $4 million, and Juan Guzman, $2.8 million.
 
General Managers on a Budget
 In holding their annual meetings at the opulent Phoenician last week, the general managers were not practicing fiscal responsibility in these trying economic times for major league baseball. But several members of the group went slightly out of their way to do just that.
Bob Quinn and Brian Sabean of San Francisco stayed at the Scottsdale Plaza Resort, where the Giants stay in spring training and get a rate of $85 a night. Kevin Malone and Bill Stoneman of the Montreal Expos stayed at the Marriott Suites in Scottsdale for $75 a night each.
"You know the Montreal Expos," Malone said. "We're cost effective. We were here for eight nights and saved $110 a night each. We might be able to sign a six-year minor league free agent with what we saved. He could help us win a pennant."
 
Hot-Stove Trade Talks
 The hottest trade prospect to emerge from the general managers' meetings involved the high-spending Braves and the economy-minded Expos. The trade would send center fielder Marquis Grissom to Atlanta for Ryan Klesko, a platooned left fielder, who is younger and considerably less expensive.
Grissom, who batted .288 and was third in the National League with 36 stolen bases, earned $3.56 million last season. Whatever the Braves' budget is, Grissom and his new salary would be able to fit into it far more easily than he would in the Expos' economic lineup.
Klesko, who as a rookie hit one home run every 14.4 at-bats, and 17 in 245, will have the kind of salary the Expos like -- low.
The hangup in a possible exchange would be Grissom's status. If the clubs, either unilaterally or in an agreement with the union, create a younger class of free agents, players with four or five years of major league service, Grissom would be eligible. The Braves could trade for him and sign him to a multiyear contract, but Grissom, who lives in the Atlanta area, would be in better bargaining position if he waited to find out if he could become a free agent.
 
Canseco's Name Batted About
 The most intriguing trade suggestion that surfaced during the week was the idea that Texas, Houston and Boston would engineer a three-way transaction involving Jose Canseco. Kevin Kennedy, the Red Sox manager, had Canseco in Texas and is said to want him to move to Boston with him.
The Rangers need starting pitching, which the Astros could provide, perhaps along with center fielder Steve Finley, for Canseco. Canseco would then be shipped to Boston for a package of players. The only problem is there seems to be more talk outside the lines of a possible deal than within them.
At the close of business Friday, Bob Watson of the Astros and Doug Melvin of the Rangers had not spoken since Wednesday.
 
Housecleaning in Houston
 To hear some people talk, the Astros are prepared to jettison all sorts of players -- pitchers Greg Swindell and Pete Harnisch, third baseman Ken Caminiti and center fielder Steve Finley being among the most prominent and highest paid. Not true, the general manager says.
"I have been charged with being competitive at a price that has us break even or make a small profit," Bob Watson said. "Do all that and sign Jeff Bagwell. So I have my work cut out for me."
Bagwell is the National League most valuable player who is not going anywhere unless the labor dispute is settled, he receives service credit for the 52 days of the strike and four-year players become eligible for free agency. Second baseman Craig Biggio and two young outfielders, James Mouton and Brian Hunter, are not escaping Houston either.
"I wouldn't trade any of them," Watson said. He will trade other players, he added, but not on a wholesale basis.
"We will attempt to move some people," he said. "It won't be as severe as some people think. Yes, Mr. McLane lost money. Yes, we didn't meet our projection in attendance. But whatever we do, we will be competitive."
Drayton McLane Jr., the owner of the team the past two years, has said he has suffered large losses since his acquisition of the team from John McMullen. People in Houston, who never appreciated McMullen for saving the team for the city when he bought the Astros in 1979, said for the last few years of his ownership that once he sold the team, attendance would skyrocket.
McLane, however, hasn't seen fireworks at the box office.
 
Yanks' No-Return Policy
 The most telling aspect of the recent development with tickets to baseball games in New York wasn't that the Yankees raised the price of 4,300 choice box seats by $8 while the Mets maintained their prices at 1992 levels. It was the difference in their policies, as well as attitudes, on deadline for payment.
The Yankees require payment in full for season tickets by Dec. 12. In previous years, the Mets have asked for complete payment by the end of the year. But this winter the Mets have told their fans they need send only a 50 percent deposit by that time, then complete their payments by Feb. 15.
Furthermore, if the labor dispute is not resolved by the end of March, Mets fans may ask for their money back. The Yankees have made no such offer.

HEADLINE: Nov. 13-19: A Nuclear-Free Ukraine;
Moves in the Ukraine Bring Elation to U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
What a difference four months makes. When Leonid Kuchma, former director of a missile factory, was elected Ukraine's President in July, the Clinton Administration feared that he would be another neo-Communist hack who would do little about the problems Washington was worrying about: Ukraine's 1,800 nuclear warheads and its collapsing economy. But when Mr. Kuchma visits Washington on Tuesday, he will have done virtually everything President Clinton has asked.
 Last Wednesday, thanks to vigorous arm-twisting by Mr. Kuchma, the Parliament in Kiev voted to eliminate Ukraine's nuclear arms, putting aside the belief that such weapons could make Ukraine a power to reckon with. The Clinton Administration hailed the vote because it removed roadblocks from two major strategic arms-reductions treaties that had been stalled. 
 Mr. Kuchma has also pushed through some painful reforms aimed at curing Ukraine's economic ills, including staggering inflation. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

LENGTH: 760 words

HEADLINE: Clear but Hypocritical

 BODY:
Overlook, for just a moment, the brutality of their ideas. Representative Newt Gingrich and his band of ideologues have enlivened U.S. politics -- indeed, engaging the public in political discourse that is supposed to be at the core of democratic society. They ran on a platform that told Americans how they would transform society by, in part, ripping away every strand of the social safety net.
With government out of the way, they said, civil society would bloom. The Democrats -- led, in the final weeks of the campaign, by President Clinton -- held the contract up to voters for ridicule. The voters decisively picked sides. 
 One thing that makes this year's election remarkable is its aftermath. Mr. Gingrich and his deputy, Dick Armey of Texas, have continued to say what they believe and do what they said they would without excuses or temporizing. In comparison to the Democrats, their press conferences have been clear, if nothing else. When was the last time Speaker Tom Foley or the majority leader, Richard Gephardt, or the President gave voters a legislative vision undiluted by irreconcilable promises, one for each constituent?
Unfortunately, the contract about which Mr. Gingrich is so clear is full of benighted and mean-spirited ideas. The anti-government theme borders on the fetishistic. The tax cuts are reckless. The spending cuts are oblivious to need. Presumably the voters knew this before they voted and will now get some of what they chose, for better or worse.
That much cannot be said about 1992. President Clinton ran on one set of -- we now know -- lightly embraced ideas, packaged as New Democratic. They were then blended into mush with the help of Mr. Foley and Mr. Gephardt. In that sense, voters do not deserve the President they have.
Yet no commentary about the current scene can leave Mr. Gingrich draped in praise. Eventually, one must pierce the vigorous presentation and get at the ideas themselves. Here, the Republicans turn as hypocritical as the Democrats they thrust aside.
Take, for example, the proposal to cut taxes on capital gains -- the profit that investors earn on the sale of, for example, bonds, stocks and real estate. The stated purpose is to give entrepreneurs greater incentive to invest. Stated that way, even some liberals might be tempted to embrace the idea.
But look closely. The contract would cut taxes on the sale of stocks, bonds and real estate that investors already own. That could not possibly spur future investment. The proposal amounts to a huge windfall for affluent investors, but does little to ignite the "animal spirits" of entrepreneurs.
Republicans defend their plan by claiming it will "unlock" investors from old investments, channeling money into new, spiffier projects. This too makes little sense. If Joe decides, in the face of lower taxes, to sell his General Motors stock to Mary, the paper shuffling puts no money into the coffers of General Motors for investment in plant and equipment.
The Republicans could have solved the problem by limiting their tax cut to new investments. They did not -- suggesting they are more interested in rewarding rich constituents than in spurring the economy. At least when Democrats go overboard in redistributing money, they more often do so on behalf of the needy instead of the already rewarded.
The contract also proposes boosting the nation's pathetic saving rate by opening up tax-subsidized retirement accounts to upper-income families. This too could be tolerated by voters interested in fairness if the actual proposal was not so skewed. It would allow wealthy workers to close down existing retirement accounts, pay taxes on the withdrawal and open up a new retirement account on which no taxes would be owed when cashed in at retirement.
This sneaky design would generate extra revenue in the next few years -- when the budget laws require Congress to pay attention -- and rob the Treasury of huge amounts later on when workers retire. For a party that preaches balanced budgets and fiscal prudence, the proposal borders on deceit. The contract also promises to balance the Federal budget -- a $700 billion deficit reduction that Republicans nonsensically declare would be zero.
On examination, the contract is at once bold and disheartening. The Republicans told voters they would cut government off at the knees and on this score they seem true to their word. Apparently it was too much to ask that they also live by their other declarations in favor of fiscal prudence and honest numbers.

HEADLINE: In America;
No G.O.P. Imitations, Please

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Representative Charles Schumer put it best: The Democrats created a vacuum and the Republicans filled it.
 Mr. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said last week: "Any Democrat who wants to revitalize the party has to start from the basic premise that while there were lots of other factors, the Democratic Party was ultimately to blame for the election fiasco. Yes, the Republicans were nasty. Yes, right-wing talk radio emphasized the negative. But those kinds of things can only succeed when there's a vacuum, and we created the vacuum." 
 The vacuum formed when Democratic politicians, for whatever reasons, became estranged from their base. That base, for decades, has been made up primarily of ordinary working men and women -- decent people struggling to pay the rent or the mortgage, to raise their families in a reasonably safe and comfortable environment, to get their sons and daughters through school.
 In Mr. Schumer's words, "We lost sight of the average American."
 This suddenly seems obvious to almost everyone. But there are right ways and wrong ways to reclaim the hearts of working men and women. And one of the wrong ways is to define the so-called average American too narrowly.
 Nearly every post-election analysis points out that 62 percent of white males voted Republican. There is general agreement that the Democratic Party has to get a substantial number of those voters back. With that in mind, groups like the Democratic Leadership Council are aggressively urging Democrats (and especially President Clinton) to lurch to the right.
 This is good advice for those Democrats who survived the Nov. 8 debacle but still would like to commit suicide. Whether the Democrats know it or not, voters are not clamoring for imitation Republicans. They can have the real thing. It should be recalled that the D.L.C., with its cynical cadre of high-tech pollsters and analysts, gave us Mr. Clinton in the first place, along with his carefully crafted, wishy-washy, please-all-people, stand-for-nothing message. The result is that it no longer matters which way Mr. Clinton lurches. He has lurched too much already, which is how he has achieved the almost impossible feat of being perceived simultaneously as a stealth liberal and a closet conservative.
 (Elizabeth Drew, in her book "On the Edge," tells how Mr. Clinton announced his variation of a Bush Administration program for urban enterprise zones. Clinton aides were worried that a high-profile event would look too "inner city," so the President announced the program in a telephone conference call with mayors.)
 Instead of sneaking to the left or the right, instead of being ashamed of groups that have supported the party for decades, the Democrats could use a dose of authenticity. They need to discover an honest way to attract votes from white men while at the same time getting the support of working people who are African-American, who are women, who are Latino and Asian, who belong to labor unions, who are Jewish, etc.
 This is not some wild, impossible task.
 "We have to build bridges," said Mr. Schumer. "There are some issues, like crime and jobs, where you can go into a middle-class white suburb and to an inner city, and when you talk to the average person in those places they will tell you the exact same thing.
 "If you notice, in Newt's 'contract' there is not one mention of jobs. That's the number one thing that the 62 percent of white male voters are concerned about."
 Mr. Schumer paused. "You know," he said, "I think that ultimately people are upset because for the first time in American history it is not a given that their lives will improve, that the trend is upward, that in 10 years you'll be better off, and that almost certainly your children will be better off than you have been.
 "What they want is to see government as a force relevant to their lives, making their lives better. They'd like to see that, but they don't. We have to change that."
 To forge a comeback, the Democrats have to do something real about issues like employment and crime, issues that everyone cares about. If they can do that, the voters will come flocking from the right and the left.
 If not, they will endure a long stay in the lonely regions of powerlessness and irrelevance.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NORTHWEST BRONX;
Intricacies of Redistricting: Draw, and Then Draw Again

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
From Morris Heights up to Riverdale, School District 10 spans a diverse racial and socioeconomic territory, from its poor southern neighborhoods to its richer northern ones.
A plan to redraw the district -- one of the city's largest in geography and student population -- along north-south lines was scrapped amid an outpouring of criticism that it was tantamount to racial segregation. But a revised plan to split the district in western and eastern sections, while not eliciting the same level of opposition, has left many doubting it, too, underscoring the intricacies of redistricting in a racially and economically mixed area. 
 District 10's turmoils reveal how a plan to increase minority representation on school boards, no matter how well-intentioned, can go awry among the very people it is intended to benefit. Recently, black residents in District 22 in Brooklyn joined with whites to fight off a proposal that would have guaranteed black representation in one district by creating two virtually segregated districts. In a system where people suspect that resources are meted out according to political strength, it is perhaps not surprising that minority parents would recoil from boundaries that would cut them off from better-organized white parents.
The District 10 plan is one of several recommended by a panel that was appointed by the Board of Education to redraw districts for the first time in more than two decades. The plan is designed, among other things, to help the city comply with the Federal Voting Rights Act.
The central Board of Education is to hold a series of public hearings next month before making final decisions in February on proposed changes to 10 of the 32 districts.
In District 10, whites account for only 8 percent of the student population, but six members of the nine-person school board are white.
Under the original plan, new boundaries would have created a southern district with mostly black and Hispanic voters, who presumably would have elected minority representatives on a new board. But critics on all sides said the proposal would have left only minority students in the southern half, where low-performing schools with high numbers of poor students would be concentrated. They feared that the southern district, bereft of the richer northern half, would become politically powerless. What's more, in the northern half, the school board would be predominantly white, but the student population would remain predominantly minority.
"The plan went overboard by segregating the school boards," said Jeffrey R. Korman, a member of the District 10 board.
The panel responded by drawing a new plan that cut the district roughly along the Grand Concourse. It said that while the east-west division would not offer the same benefits to minority voters as the first proposal, these new districts would more closely reflect the current district's racial makeup and avoid lumping poorly performing schools in one district.
Some said the new plan might actually be a political setback for black and Hispanic residents.
Carlos R. Cortes, a member of Board 10, said the western section, with the heavy voting population in Riverdale, would elect a predominantly white school board. Furthermore, the eastern section would also lean toward a white school board because its northern, white neighborhoods typically turn out in big numbers. Because a vertical redrawing would divide, and dilute, the minority voting population in the southern neighborhoods, Mr. Cortes said he favored keeping District 10 intact. He said that in recent years, minorities had become more active, electing three representatives to the school board, and that any changes would disrupt the momentum.
"Dividing our district in any form, it's not going to increase minority representation," Mr. Cortes said. "It's going to be back to the good old days when the white population controlled the majority of the student population." NORIMITSU ONISHI

LENGTH: 3536 words

HEADLINE: Shop BIG

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
THIS was the year the big stores took New York, the year those cavernous, low-margin, high-volume temptoriums that challenge both the old-time department store and the friendly neighborhood bookseller arrived, in critical mass, and began to remake the face of shopping as we know it.
From the Flatiron to upper Broadway, Northern Boulevard to the Grand Concourse, these stores that till now had largely shunned the city as too cramped, too expensive, and perhaps too determined to be hip, are moving in, opening up and proclaiming themselves proud to be big. 
 In the popular mind -- and with at least a little encouragement from the marketing folks -- they are "megastores," "superstores"; the new Toys "R" Us opening on Union Square proclaims itself "the world's biggest toy store." Actually, though, they are several different things. Some sell all manner of one thing -- books, housewares, clothing; others are essentially department stores. Some aren't really even that big.
What they all are, in retail argot, is "value retailers," usually part of national or regional chains that offer lots of stuff at low, low prices. They provide maps and grocery-style shopping carts and basically try to get you to buy as much as possible under one roof. Their roof. And though a lot of New Yorkers, and especially Manhattanites, still cling to a way of shopping that is vaguely European and highly inefficient, stopping at one place for this, another for that, the big stores are clearly winning some converts.
"The traditional form of retailing is being changed throughout the United States, and we were the last bastion," acknowledged Walter F. Loeb, who publishes the monthly newsletter Loeb Retail Letter. "Consumers today are value-driven. They will spend more in these value stores."
As they do, city planners, concerned that New York is still losing too many retail dollars to the suburbs, are studying proposed zoning changes that would make the city more hospitable to some big stores. Which has small-business owners and others arguing that changing the way New Yorkers shop amounts to irreparably changing the city's character, too.
Which has me -- confined to the city and conformed to its habits for most of my adult life -- feeling curious and confused. Fortunately, the early start of the holiday season (Hannukah begins next Sunday night, then onward to Christmas), gives me an opportunity to do some shopping and, I hope, clear my head. So I fill a coat pocket with subway tokens and hit the pavement.
 
DAY 1: SAMPLING
 My first stop is Today's Man, one of two, soon to be three, Manhattan outlets offering designer (and designerlike) menswear at discount prices. This one, opened in September, is spread over three floors of what used to be Conran's, at 81st and Broadway, just across from that New York megastore of gastronomy, Zabar's. I begin at the top, with the traditional look. Here a blue blazer from Brookcraft, the store's brand, costs $79, while the same style from Halston costs $149, or two for $259.
And thus, fresh out of the starting blocks, I begin to understand the marketing psychology of megastore shopping: nurturing the continual urge to buy more, supposedly for bigger savings. I'm not sure if I've caught it yet, but I've never seen so many empty suits in my life.
Onward. The sales staff couldn't be nicer. Of course, I am one of only two shoppers in this part of the store on a Wednesday morning. (The other one is a man who is trying coats on by himself and mumbling.) They're going to strike out with me, though; I've just discovered I lack the confidence to buy menswear off the rack, even, or especially, for people I am related to.
On my way out, the pull of tradition, and a whiff of the most amazing aroma, leads me two doors down to the Broadway Nut Shop, in business at 2246 Broadway for the last 54 years and tended by Howie Gold and Larry Ring. Attract his attention, and Mr. Gold will take you on a guided tour of the shop, which, along with nuts, specializes in licorice. There are tins of pure Liquirizia di Calabria ($3.90 for four grams) and Dutch licorice kittens, German licorice spun in wheels, English pink, yellow and black licorice allsorts, even licorice toffee, a seeming contradiction in terms. For the holidays, there are marzipan Hanukkah shapes (a menorah, a Torah) for $2.75, and bags of gold-covered chocolate coins (80 cents).
Just down Broadway, at 79th Street, is Filene's Basement, part of a chain that all began in Boston. As an experiment, I stop first at Charivari, around the corner at 79th and Amsterdam, and buy a woolen vest for $75. Then I enter Filene's and wait for the chagrin to hit.
It never does. I am surrounded by white blazers, patterned sweaters with patterns busier than the IRT at rush hour, giant wool mufflers and stockings with unfamiliar labels. This is on the first floor. Upstairs is the men's department, where I see a lot of dress shirts and work boots, as well as cashmere sweaters for $99. But all around me is evidence of disarray, like jackets left in heaps on the floor by shoppers apparently unmoved by the instruments of corporate thought control. "It's Not What You Spend, It's What You Save," clamors one sign, near the shirts. "Don't Even Hesitate," urges another.
I'm hesitating. But I owe it to myself to check out the dress-up clothes. I have the eerie feeling of being in another city, another time. There is a beige Albert Nipon suit, shades of Nancy Reagan, circa 1981. Examining a black, beaded Theo Miles evening dress, a trio of women murmur "C'est jolie," only to realize that there is a gaping hole in the middle of the gauzy top. I've decided to cut and run. But then I see someone I know, with hangers over her arm. She says she browses here all the time.
"You would come and hope to find a needle in a haystack," explains my friend, more the passionate bargain-hunter than I will ever be. I dash home so the baby sitter can leave.
 
DAY 2: GETTING PSYCHED
 I wake up with only slightly sore ligaments and hit the pavement. Today's destination is Chelsea, which seems to be ground zero for the city's new Brobdingnagian stores.
First is Staples, opened last year at 23d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. It has everything you might expect from a discount place, like harsh lighting and giant shopping carts standing by. But as my cart and I wheel down the first aisle, I fall in love: This place has everything we never have at home. There are bundles of legal note pads, $5.49 for a dozen. There is a package of Scotch tape, four rolls and dispensers for $3.99. Clasp envelopes. Bulletin boards! Pencil sharpeners!
There are also computers and computer accessories, software, fax machines, desk chairs and assorted other office essentials, including a jumbo pack of nondairy creamer (36 ounces for $4.59).
"It's confusing sometimes," says Debbie Murray, a secretary for a nearby construction company. "Sometimes the employees don't know what they have or where things are. Sometimes they're not the greatest prices, either." But still, there she was that morning, looking for a briefcase. "A lot of the smaller stores in the area are much more expensive," she conceded.
Thus reassured, I buy some Scotch tape, thinking that if I ever buy any presents, I'll be prepared to wrap them, too.
A block south, at 675 Avenue of the Americas, is the newest of the brood of Barnes & Noble superstores, a 35,000-square-foot urban mall-as-gathering place -- books, the now-obligatory cafe, even a theater, superimposed on the columned and atriumed cast-iron glory of the old Adams Dry Goods Store building.
This may be a superstore, and I may be just blocks from one of New York's surviving old-style bookstore rows, 18th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, but all the neighborhood types curled up in Barnes & Noble's soft chairs make for a sure sense of community. I see a famous children's-book writer scribbling in her journal in the cafe. I glimpse a colleague, going to see the puppets. I run into another friend, who tells me that when she was locked out of her apartment for a day recently, she came here, rather than pester the landlord. "They had a nice bathroom, I could get something to eat, I could read," she said.
I decide to take a break and do just that, especially since this is my chance for a guilt-free dip into "A Greater Love," Christopher Wilson's tattle on Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles. Unmolested -- and, I hope, unseen by anyone who knows me -- I read the entire transcript of the couple's notorious telephone conversations.
Eventually I give it up and walk three blocks south on Avenue of the Americas to Bed, Bath & Beyond, an indoor bazaar of household products that opened in November 1992, and recently grew from 50,000 to 82,000 square feet.
At the door, they hand me a map, which is my first clue that this is going to be a very big shopping experience. A surreal strawberry smell hangs in the air, which I eventually trace to the candle department. Shoppers wander the wide main aisles, then disappear into the side pockets in search of something. Among them are people from the neighborhood, like Claire Baksa, who was wheeling her daughter through the children's section.
"I don't really like big stores," she said. "They're intimidating. This wall-to-wall stuff is too much for me. But I live around here, so I just put up with it. This is kind of a big-store area."
There are lots of useful-looking household items, like ergonomically designed vegetable peelers (I get two, for $8.99 apiece) and some you might be able to live without. How about a toilet-brush holder, shaped like a big cat? $19.99. Queen-sized water-bed sheets, $39.99? Aquis, the super-absorbent hair towel, for $15.99, may be just the thing for that one relative who never speaks to us. I see a Great Wall of toaster ovens, a tower of Brita water filters. There are Joyce Chen wok sets, men's flannel pajamas printed with cowboy boots, crushed-velvet covered boxes, a bath mat shaped like a holly leaf. Shoppers appear to be evenly divided between those seeking just one or two things, who seem stunned, and people, usually the very young, who are trying to furnish new apartments and seem thrilled.
I've seen something we need at our house: plastic dishes featuring characters from "The Lion King." I put two in my shopping cart, thinking that, at $19.99, they're not exactly cheap. Then I head uptown.
Software is a good 90's kind of present, and I've been seeing it here and there in my travels. But the biggest assortment is at Comp USA, a 26,000-square-foot computer store that extends along Fifth Avenue from 37th to 38th Streets. People were clustered around a demonstration of "Under a Killing Moon," a CD-ROM featuring a hapless detective named Tex Murphy. It sells for $54.99. There is also "Doom II" for $38.97 and Tie Fighter ($39.99), about intergalactic pirate wars but nevertheless, in the season of peace, "a perfect gift for the youngster," the sign says.
And there is software for grown-ups: "Wedding Workshop" ($36.99), which offers to "prioritize the guest list" and track gifts and expenses; and my personal favorite, "Scrabble," which makes the computer figure out every possible word that can be formed from up to eight letters and must be the ultimate in cheating, if you plan to play with other people who didn't bring their Macintoshes to the summer house.
Next door to Comp USA is Lord & Taylor, and I dash inside to bask in the glow of a thousand little lights and extraneous decorations. And I see Lion King dishes selling for $24. I go home feeling smug.
 
DAY 3: STUFF, AND A VIEW
 Bradlees opened just two weeks ago -- 140,000 square feet on six floors in the old F. W. Mays building, which had been vacant since 1988. Along with assorted merchandise, it offers beautiful views, particularly from the escalators, of Union Square.
This is still clearly a work in progress. The ceiling features exposed I-beams, there's a loud hammering coming from the back, and the cashiers seem less than clued in to store procedures, like correcting an overcharge.
Bradlees sells some of everything, but I am happiest on 5, where they have a lot of plastic sleds. Last winter, I pounced on what turned out to be the last sled in New York, right around New Year's Day. I also paid $20 for it, and here, the same sled -- a year of inflation later and with the Farmer's Almanac forecasting snow -- is $14.99. Other meaningful toys, most on the third floor, include a game called "Splat! The Bug Squishin' Race Game," which costs $17.99 and sounds like something you could play right in your own home, probably in the kitchen, late at night. They also have the Fisher-Price Tough Trike, the vehicle of choice in city playgrounds, for $24.99.
I am about to get out in one piece when I stop by the video department and see "Snow White," for $19.88. After buying it, I begin to feel that I am enjoying this too much. I run to the nearest Japanese restaurant, where I wind up spending whatever I saved, and then some, at the sushi bar.
 
DAY 4: BURBLIKE
 Time is marching on, and so am I -- to Ozone Park, Queens, and the Home Depot that opened late last year.
Most people seem to come here by car, and that's a good thing. I take the A train from Manhattan, more than an hour into Queens, and disembark at Rockaway Boulevard. Then I take a 15-minute bus ride along the boulevard to the store.
But the reward is vastness, a la jumbo-jet hangar, full of amazing stuff I didn't know you could buy or would want, like giant rolls of scratchy black roofing paper; pieces of newel posts and balustrades; wind turbines, shaped like Ottoman Empire headgear, and the mystery material on the I-beams at Bradlees: Popcorn Ceiling Roll-on, priced at $19.35 for a 4.5-gallon drum. There is the whine of band saws, the beeping of a forklift that roams the sales floor, the whisper of money changing hands.
This is do-it-yourself country, and the principle applies, apparently, to shopping methodology as well. All around the store are half-opened cartons, apparently clawed at by curious shoppers. I see a man proudly pushing a cart loaded with sacks of quick-setting concrete, and wonder who he's buying for. I watch a woman in an elegant coat, holding a purse in one hand and tugging energetically at a 14-foot length of base molding tucked into a rack with the other. (She prevails, but then shouts, "This one is crooked!") The only thing they won't let you do yourself, as far as I can tell, is use the saw.
I am totally stumped for gift ideas, since I'm not shopping for my super, until I discover, in a side aisle, little tiny brooms with red handles. The price is right ($3.92). I place two in my cart which, in my absence, has been hit by something (maybe the forklift?), spilling tea all over my newspaper.
My next stop is Long Island City, but before I leave I go across the street for a quick fix of Queens' ethnic diversity at the Oscar Foods West Indian Grocery, at 111-03 Rockaway Boulevard, which actually sells a lot of East Indian products, like embroidered shalwars, traditional long tunics worn over slacks, gold-tone filigree jewelry and cassettes featuring stars like Anil Kapoor.
Tops Appliance City has long drawn city dwellers to the suburbs (Westchester, New Jersey) for appliance supermarketing. In September, it opened its first New York City store on Northern Boulevard; it's 45,000 square feet, all on one floor, and speaking of feet, mine are getting sore. But I press on and in, following a woman who has told me, since the subway, that she was furious because a TV she bought a month ago had not been delivered. She disappears, and I am left looking at the vacuum cleaners, which are close to the door. Most impressive here is the din: broadcast Muzak competes with rap surging from portable stereos and tentative notes played by people trying out electronic pianos, and bass vibrations thundering from the car-stereo demonstration room. And of course, the television corner is pretty noisy, too, with its 100 or so screens all tuned to the same Costa Rican soccer match. I check out the price of a television as big as the Ritz: $2,499.99. But there is free delivery from this store, whose parent company is publicly traded on the Nasdaq exchange, according to a sign by the entrance.
I skulk toward the exit without buying anything, but I've been spotted. "Oh!" cries a sales manager. "Are you leaving our store?" Yes. Before I have to crawl.
 
DAY 5: TOYS 'R' ESSENTIAL
 I wake up, groggy and upset from dreaming about an appliance delivery that never happens. Also, my feet are in total pain. I consider completing this mission on skates, but can't find my wrist guards. A broken arm, together with my broken feet, I decide, would be very depressing.
So I take the N train to DeKalb Avenue and a Toys "R" Us that opened a year ago to the tune of 42,000 square feet. Cart at the ready, I find two happy shoppers, Ginger Matera of Bushwick and Mayra Rodriguez of Red Hook, who are doing their Christmas rounds weeks ahead of time. "Kids ask for expensive things, and if you buy them everything they want you'll be eating macaroni and cheese for a month," Ms. Matera says. Her two boys, she says, want Game Boy hand-held electronic game sets this year, and the store has them for $49.99 with its coupon, versus $89 elsewhere.
Does she ever feel lost and suburbanized when shopping in a store this size? "No," Ms. Matera says emphatically. "Brooklyn is Brooklyn."
And in Brooklyn, the Tough Trike is $19.99, $5 less than Bradlees was charging. A Radio Flyer red wagon is $44.99. A red stocking that could contain a 2-year-old is $6.49. Three rolls of Hanukkah paper are $3.99. Pinatas, shaped like clowns or lions or unicorns, are $6.99. The most far-fetched toy, a Toys "R" Us-emblazoned 1918 runabout car bank, is $7.48. Something I want, which could be unique to this store: slippers with duck, elephant and frog faces on them, that emit pertinent animal sounds when pressed. The elephant has a particularly authentic-sounding shriek; all are $7.99.
I buy two pairs of the animal slippers, a pair of pinking scissors, a set of paintbrushes and a box of watercolors, spending a total of $27.01, and leave the store right behind a woman who is bellowing "Shut up!" at her crying child.
I take the D train to the Bronx and the biggest, by far, of all the big new stores: the 317,412-square-foot Caldor at 2501 Grand Concourse. Like a hermit crab, Caldor moved last year into the empty shell of what was for years an Alexander's. And either because of the Spanish-speakers in the neighborhood, or some overarching corporate vision, the store's sign sports a big acute accent aigu over the "d." The store dwarfs neighbors like Tiger Kim's, which sells mostly sneakers but also nostalgia in the form of Mets hats ($9.99).
At Caldor, I've decided to make a beeline for pet supplies, in the basement. I've been searching for a rubber newspaper toy for a friend's puppy, and sure enough, I find "The Daily Growl," in a choice of colors, for $1.99. Corny antler sets, to be tied onto the head of your dog or cat, are 25 cents, on clearance.
Some children are running through the toy section, laughing and setting off all the computerized singing "Christmas Bop-a-Tune" animals. Up on the second floor, in toddler clothes, I see two cashiers having an argument; one pretends to high-kick the other in the back. The escalator between here and the third floor is broken, so I walk up to housewares, which I skip, and then to 4, where there are snow shovels ($3.99 to $19.99) and a Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers Battle Wheeler 4x4 that costs $159.99. With a top speed of three miles per hour, it might be just the thing to get me through this shopping expedition.
It all ends, finally, after I track down a plastic Santa Claus lawn ornament that, for $39.99, kind of sums up my odyssey: He's suburban-looking, he's hollow, he's rubbing his stomach (not his feet) and his face puffs with glee.
 
New Rules for Big Stores?
 Current city zoning laws, amended in 1974 in the spirit of shielding industry from encroaching retail businesses, restrict large stores on the basis of what they sell, says Barry Dinerstein, a senior planner with the Department of City Planning.
Large stores are permitted in most of the city's manufacturing zones as long as they do not sell clothing, furniture, carpets, electronics or variety goods. Owners of those types of stores must apply for a special permit, as must people planning to build department stores and supermarkets.
But under changes being studied by the Giuliani administration, designed to draw more big stores to the city, stores would be restricted by square footage, not by content. "The hope is to make it big enough to allow the discount department stores to locate here," Mr. Dinerstein said, "but we don't want regional malls."
The review process for the proposal, which is bitterly opposed by many small-business owners, is expected to take about 18 months.
