SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: COPING;
Help for the Transportationally Challenged

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
STEPPING out of my building the other day I came this close to being run down by a man delivering food on a bicycle. I never saw him until he brushed past, and I don't think he ever saw me. He was too busy cackling and gesticulating at another food deliveryman in the street. They were racing.
I didn't scream this time and give chase. I simply visited Charles Komanoff, my transportation therapist. He sighed. "This is one group of bicycle riders I have not been able to reach. Part of the problem is that many of them don't speak English. And when I go to their stores and restaurants, suddenly their managers don't speak English, either." 
 "I guess you are also going to tell me," I said, "that they are on sidewalks because the streets are gridlocked with the real villains, cars and trucks."
"I think you are letting them off the hook too easily," he said, smoothly. "We figure that 20 percent of food deliverers ride on the sidewalk; many of the rest ride against traffic and through red lights. Sure, it's faster for them, they've got hot food and they can get more runs in, but there's no excuse."
I relaxed, always a mistake, and Mr. Komanoff moved in quickly, as if he was threading among stalled cars. "We also figure that less than 2 percent of bike messengers ride on the sidewalk, and hardly any commuters. These two groups have joined together. Wouldn't you rather have more bikes in the city than cars and delivery vans? We think there is something public-spirited about riding a bike. Plucky. We are not complicitous in the car culture."
Catching my gorge on the rise, I said: "You guys have a certain arrogance, a self-righteousness. You want to ride a bike, fine, go ride a bike. But a lot of people can't or don't want to ride. Understand that the car is a room of your own, one of the few places anymore you can be by yourself, listen to your own music, smoke, whatever."
Mr. Komanoff listened and nodded. We were sitting in his office at Komanoff Energy Associates, on Lafayette Street, among flickering computer screens, drawing boards, piles of stats concerned with the state of a world consumed by its consumption. A Harvard-trained economist, the 47-year-old Mr. Komanoff has long been one of the clearest consultants, consumer advocates, media sources and expert witnesses on nuclear energy problems. Balding, bearded and bespectacled, he looks almost as smart as he is. But not nearly as slippery.
"A lot of what you say is right," said Mr. Komanoff. "I would like to be relieved of my anger and my hubris. I would like to feel no more socially valuable than anyone else. Because I am no better."
Now you understand why I go to Charlie Komanoff when I feel bike-battered. He himself began riding seriously only about 20 years ago, and now has that compact, non-Vertical Club hard body that comes from physical exercise for a functional purpose. Along the way, he became involved in the advocacy group Transportation Alternatives, and a spokesman for spokes.
"Through the 70's, we were riding the zeitgeist," he said. "Mayor Lindsay closing the park on weekends, a new energy policy, the oil embargo, a transit strike. But in the Reagan 80's, the stretch limo replaced the bike as symbol, and there was fear and loathing of the messenger. I felt that way, too, for awhile. And then they took to the streets against the 1987 midtown bike ban. They had the organization, they had the spirit, they were great."
The zeitgeist seems to be blowing against Mr. Komanoff lately. He is downsizing his consulting business. Saturdays in the city, once a day for easy riding and walking, seem to be choked with more cars than ever, especially downtown. The bike messengers are absorbed by the battle to unionize their dangerous, underpaid, marginalized work. And the voices of old biddies like me are raised against reckless riding when perhaps we should be rethinking the stinking car and making it pay its way.
"I think you're angry at bikers for two reasons," Mr. Komanoff said. "First of all, you actually see a person you can focus anger at. You rarely see the driver of a car or truck clearly. It's harder to be angry at a machine. And second, no argument from me, a lot of these bikes just don't follow the rules. But look at statistics: Last year in the city, 13,811 pedestrians were hit by cars, 289 killed, and 664 pedestrians were hit by bikes, 2 killed. Also, 14 bicyclists were killed in collisions with cars."
And then, Mr. Komanoff spun his numbers into a human face.
A month ago, he and his partner, Judy Levine, a fund-raiser for progressive causes, had a son, Daniel, and moved from Stuyvesant Town to Duane Street, leaving Daniel's grandmother in Peter Cooper Village. A two block walk to visit became an hour on buses.
"Here's a physically fit woman in her 60's who could ride a bike over if there were safe lanes. In a saner city, grandma and grandson could be together more often."
I thanked him for the session, and walked home, temporarily smiling, or at least not scowling, at wheelies. But I kept looking both ways.

HEADLINE: Public Needs, Private Answers -- A special report;
Business Districts Grow, At Price of Accountability

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
More than a decade after New York City business and property owners began creating self-taxing districts to clean, patrol and upgrade their neighborhoods, the districts have spread to virtually every corner of the city, delivering services that once were the sole responsibility of city government.
And though their efforts have generally won broad praise, critics say that some have grown too powerful and have taken over municipal duties without sufficient oversight or public accountability. 
 On the Upper East Side of Manhattan, for instance, residents and elected officials are embroiled in a bitter debate over a plan to set up a vast new district that would employ a private security force of up to 500 officers. Opponents say it would cost too much -- possibly $200 a year for owners of co-ops and commercial properties -- and they worry that the security force would not provide the civil rights safeguards that the city police force does.
Across the country, more than 1,000 business improvement districts, or BID's, as they are known, have been set up in the last two decades, but their greatest impact has been in New York, where their numbers, size and financial clout dwarf those of BID's in other cities. Thirty-three have been established from Harlem to Brighton Beach, and at least 30 more are planned.
With squads of uniformed security officers and sidewalk sweepers, the districts have made vast improvements in many parts of the city -- reducing crime, cleaning up streets and restoring a sense of pride among merchants and the public. Some of their strongest advocates are in City Hall.
"They are filling in for government," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on Tuesday in a Manhattan speech to more than 200 BID members, directors and staff workers. A vigorous advocate of privatizing municipal services, the Mayor has made a series of recent appearances in support of creating more BID's.
But as the districts grow in numbers and power and become a more integral part of city life, they are also facing mounting questions. In many districts business owners complain they have not been given enough of a say in setting policy.
And in a few cases the districts' reach has extended so far into law enforcement and social services that critics question whether they have become de facto governments with limited public accountability.
"We are talking about a whole new subdivision of government that is not accountable to elective officials," said City Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, who represents part of the Upper East Side and who opposes the proposed district there.
"If anybody has a complaint about these security people, there sure wouldn't be a Citizen Complaint Review Board," added Mr. Eristoff.
The criticism goes beyond the work of security patrols.
Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said her organization was planning to sue the Grand Central Partnership, the city's largest district, over a program in which the partnership pays homeless people $1.16 an hour to remove other homeless people from automated-teller vestibules.
"They are pitting the poor against the poor," Ms. Brosnahan said.
In a few districts, there have been power struggles that resemble hostile corporate takeovers, and some property owners say they wish their districts had never been formed.
"The city is saying create as many as you want, and we are getting the flavor of the month," said Robert Richards, executive director of the Chamber of Commerce of Jamaica, Queens, where warring factions of property owners have waged a proxy fight for control of a district. The losing faction, claiming that the district's new board has withheld $787,000 it owes to its creditors, has filed suit seeking to force the district into bankruptcy.
"Instead of cooperation, the BID's are attracting greed," Mr. Richards said.
 
Getting Results
The Business Of Improvement
 Across much of New York City, the districts are providing street improvements and services that for decades have fallen through the cracks of city government. This year, New York's 33 districts will collect $32 million from their members for projects that advocates say would be performed less efficiently, and at higher cost, if they were taken on by the city.
Two of them, the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership, have issued $56 million in bonds to rebuild sidewalks, install new street lights and provide other expensive improvements.
"The whole BID phenomenon is a reflection of the public's hunger for high-quality services," said Carl Weisbrod, the former head of the city's Economic Development Corporation. He will become president of a district covering Wall Street and most of lower Manhattan when it is formed in January.
Under a 1981 ordinance, property owners can create a district through a simple majority vote of all owners in a designated area. They must then submit a plan for the kinds of services the district will provide and obtain approval from the City Council.
Once formed, the districts are financed through an offbeat partnership between the owners and the city's Department of Finance. The department collects annual assessments from all property owners and turns the money over to their districts.
Failure to pay is subject to the same penalty as failure to pay taxes -- foreclosure. So far that has not happened.
For property owners the financial structure means paying taxes to the city and assessments to the district -- in many cases for the same sort of services, like police protection and street cleaning. "This is double taxation," said Nancy Brandel, president of Harbor Property Management, which manages two office buildings that will be assessed fees as part of the new Lower Manhattan district.
Still, complaints about the district's taxing powers have been rare. According to the city, Ms. Brandel was one of two people who filed formal objections among the hundreds of property owners in the new district.
The services and improvements the districts have brought run the gamut. On the side streets of midtown Manhattan, the Times Square Business Improvement District last week finished installing 125 high intensity floodlights to improve safety and encourage nighttime pedestrian traffic. Several blocks south, the Fashion Center district plans to hang flags and banners from light poles.
In Queens, the Woodhaven district has special "Bank Day" security patrols on the first day of each month, when retired people deposit their Social Security checks. In Brooklyn, the Brighton Beach district runs advertisements in English- and Russian-language newspapers to promote its shopping area.
Last month, while announcing city approval of the huge new district in lower Manhattan, Mayor Giuliani also announced rules intended to streamline the creation of more. He added that the city would expand a program giving groups of property owners up to $60,000 to help form districts.
"These local democratic institutions are essential to New Yorkers' quality of life," the Mayor said.
But as democratic institutions, the districts are hybrids. Though created by a vote of property owners, they are governed as much by the desire to produce results as by the checks and balances of constitutional law.
Moreover, a recent analysis by the city found that fewer than half the members surveyed had received written announcements of their districts' annual meetings. The study of 24 districts found wide variation in the efforts by BID's to communicate with their members. For example, it said the Times Square district and some others "take pains to update" their membership lists, but that more than 90 percent of member addresses provided by the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation were in error.
"The irony is that the BID's have a splendid record of achievement in improving communities, but their internal processes are so sloppy," said Nicholas Fish, chairman of Community Board 5, which covers seven districts in midtown Manhattan.
Other experts have more fundamental concerns.
"Put a gun to my head and I'll accept BID's," said Peter Salins, a professor of urban planning at Hunter College and senior fellow of the Manhattan Institute, a politically conservative research group. "But this is a perverse exchange of responsibility between the public and private domains."
 
Grand Central
Help to Homeless Raises Questions
 Few neighborhoods provide a better example of the power of BID's than the area around Grand Central Terminal.
"If you were the Mayor of Paris, I'd be ashamed to show you this," said Daniel Biederman, who heads three of the city's most prominent districts, Grand Central Partnership, the 34th Street Partnership and the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, at a combined salary of $305,000.
His brief display of outrage, during a walking tour of the Grand Central district, came over what he described as an example of urban tawdriness -- the bright colors and garish signs on a hot dog cart sitting on a sidewalk on 43d Street.
The cart notwithstanding, Mr. Biederman had many improvements to show. There were new street lights, signs, wastebaskets and planters brimming with impatiens. Around the terminal, where hailing a taxi used to mean jostling with traffic and homeless people trying to commandeer luggage, there were two new taxi stands.
Street crime in the area has been sharply reduced, according to the police, in part because of the district's 42-member private security force, which is on patrol from 8 A.M. to 11 P.M. every day. The guards do not carry weapons and must call the police when they see a crime, but property owners say their presence is a powerful deterrent.
The many homeless people who once congregated in and around Grand Central are now absent. That is largely because of a homeless program run by the district, which provides a nearby shelter, job training and temporary housing. But many others have apparently left the area, after BID counselors encouraged them to move on.
While Mr. Biederman's district has been praised for reducing a seemingly intractable social problem, its methods have also drawn scorn.
When the district set up its plan for the homeless in 1989, it created a board consisting only of Mr. Biederman and two colleagues on the district's staff. Property owners in the BID wanted a separate board for the homeless program because they "were concerned about their own potential liability," Mr. Biederman said.
That attempt to avoid liability strikes Ms. Brosnahan of the Coalition for the Homeless, and several people involved with other BID's, as an attempt to skirt public accountability.
"I had assumed that these muckety-muck business people were providing oversight, but I am shocked," said Ms. Brosnahan.
The program, which provides training in building maintenance and other fields, assigns homeless people to automated-teller vestibules to try to persuade other homeless people to seek counseling, or else to leave.
Although it pays far less than the minimum wage, the Grand Central Partnership says it gives housing, food and job training to the homeless, and intends the $1.16 an hour only as a "training stipend."
The Partnership has a contract to provide its bank services at several Manhattan sites outside its own district. And now, it has applied for a major contract with the New York City Department of Homeless Services to use its trainees to work with the homeless across the city.
And that has provoked the lawsuit by the Coalition for the Homeless, which it says it will file this month on behalf of 17 former employees of the Partnership program. But the suit is also intended as a defense of the Coalition's own franchise as a provider of homeless services.
"We don't see a distinction between Coca-Cola and the Grand Central Partnership," said Lisa Daugaard, legal director for the Coalition. She said the Partnership, with low wages, "is squeezing out competent providers who work with trained professionals."
 
Brooklyn
Business Conflicts Divide a Board
 In a few smaller districts, the common goals that originally brought property owners together have fallen victim to internal disputes, and some owners say they think their investments in the districts have soured.
"It looks like schlock city out there," said Peter Aschkenasy, co-owner of the 112-year-old Gage & Tollner restaurant on Fulton Mall in downtown Brooklyn, where Abraham & Straus and a handful of other fashionable retailers have for decades maintained an uneasy coexistence with discount outlets.
Mr. Aschkenasy was a member of the board of the Fulton Mall district until last year, when the entire board was ousted in a fight between the discount merchants and owners of large businesses.
Once in power, Mr. Aschkenasy complained, the new board members relaxed the rules on splitting up retail space, and some merchants put up garish new signs. As a result, he said, attracting more businesses that appeal to wealthier shoppers appears to be much less likely.
Not all business people in Fulton Mall agree with Mr. Aschkenasy, but some say the board's upheaval underscores the fractionalized interests that can create problems at any time for improvement districts.
"We are very much interested in maintaining the dignity of Fulton Mall," said Charles Chera, the owner of several buildings on the mall, who led the effort to oust the district's former board and is now its chairman. He said the previous directors had ignored "the wide diversity of people who shop here" and the needs of merchants who serve "working class customers."
To some advocates of the BID's, such competing interests are simply democracy in action.
"Periodically, you are going to get new blood, and that is all for the good," said Lawrence O. Houstoun Jr., a consultant who has worked with business groups in several cities, including New York.
 
Upper East Side
A Security Force Of Private Guards
 The biggest battle may have just begun.
"We believe the police are doing a superb job," said Lucius J. Riccio, Transportation Commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins and now chief neighborhood organizer and lobbyist for the proposed Upper East Side district. "But they are the first to admit they need public assistance."
The district would encompass every block from 59th to 96th Street and from the East River to Central Park. It was proposed by Howard Milstein, owner of Douglas Elliman Real Estate, which has dozens of buildings in the neighborhood, and it has support from officials of the Parks Council, the Fifth Avenue Association and the Council of New York Cooperatives.
But it has also provoked growing opposition. Last month, three state legislators who represent the Upper East Side, Senator Roy M. Goodman and Assemblymen John Ravitz and Alexander B. Grannis, opposed the plan, saying that low crime rates on the Upper East Side made it unnecessary and that a private security force would add to the neighborhood's reputation for elitism.
Although some established districts include apartment and co-op buildings, the Upper East Side district would be the first to be primarily residential, requiring it to resolve such questions as how to assess rent-stabilized buildings.
While Mr. Riccio insisted that the district was being planned as a BID, others say it would more closely resemble a residential improvement district. In a mini-battle of semantics, still others are calling it a "security district."
Mr. Riccio said he did not expect the plan to be voted on by the City Council until late next year, but co-op boards and business owners in the neighborhood have already been asked to support its outlines.
The BID would employ 350 to 500 security officers, with 70 assigned to foot or motor scooter patrol at any time. That would be more than double the number of police officers assigned to the neighborhood.
As in other districts, the security officers would be unarmed and would be required to call the police when they saw crime. They could make citizen's arrests until the police arrive. "They would mainly be a source of information for the police," Mr. Riccio said.
Details of whom would be assessed, and for how much, remain to be worked out, but the plan being circulated calls for owners of commercial space and co-ops to pay an average $100 to $200 per unit each year. Owners of the most valuable properties would pay more than $200.
The plan has provoked skepticism among civil rights lawyers, who say they fear such a large security force would overstep the bounds that normally limit private security guards.
"As critical as we are of the N.Y.P.D., at least they are accountable," said Norman Siegel, director of the New York chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Without a formal complaint process, he said, anyone whose rights are violated by security personnel in a BID "may have no option but to sue, and most people can't afford it."
Councilman Eristoff said he opposed the plan in part because its security force might cause the police to withdraw officers from the neighborhood, despite agreements by the police and the Sanitation Department not to reduce services.
Mr. Riccio said there was no cause for concern.
"We are not trying to do the cops' jobs, just help," he said. If that leads to an increase in property values, he said, "I don't see why that is a bad thing."

An article on Nov. 20 about the debate over business improvement districts misstated the stance of the Council of New York Cooperatives on a proposal for a business improvement district on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The council has taken no position; it has not endorsed the plan.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2394 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
A Parellel Art World, Vast and Unruly

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
THERE'S NO ROOM FOR FAKERY," SAID Carol Lay, neatly drawing a line in the sand between underground comics -- her world -- and high art. She was sitting in the living room (and studio) of her apartment in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn talking about cartooning's double requirement -- drawing and writing skills -- that can make it seem even more demanding than higher art forms. Ms. Lay became a cartoonist after a disenchanting period studying fine art at the University of California, Los Angeles, in the early 1970's. "Let's just say I took one too many courses in Conceptual Art," she continued, smiling only faintly.
 Aline Kominsky-Crumb, one of the first women to publish in underground comics, was more blunt. "I like the fact that I do things that people read on the toilet," she said, speaking from her house in Sauve, a small village in southern France. "Comics are cheap and funny and throwaway. I definitely want to stay away from the pretentious end of the art world." 
Welcome to the world of underground comics, a place where art and life, fact and fantasy and, of course, words and images mingle with unusual directness and often highly combustible results. Underground comics took the the stage in two New York shows last season: "Comic Power," at Exit Art, concentrated exclusively on the subject, while "Bad Girls," at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, included a handful of cartoonists and comic books. At a time when artists like Nicole Eisenman, Amy Sillman, Sue Williams, Lily van der Stokker and Katie Merz are gaining prominence by using cartooning riffs to make visually compelling, mordantly feminist paintings, there is increasing interest in women who do the real thing.
 The female underground began to approach critical mass in 1990, with the publication of "Twisted Sisters," an anthology edited by Ms. Kominsky-Crumb and Diane Noomin, which sold briskly in regular bookstores, not just comic-book stores. In 1993, Trina Robbins's "Century of Women Cartoonists" appeared, with two chapters on the underground. And last summer, Twisted Sisters struck again, with a series of four comic books that will be collected into a second anthology, "Twisted Sisters 2: Drawing the Line," in April. The publication will be marked next summer with an exhibition of the original drawings at the Cartoon Art Museum in San Francisco.
 Like the art world, the underground comic universe is teeming with talented women, and they are making their presence felt in what has been a largely male preserve. Working primarily from their own life experiences, these women are taking the underground tradition of raunchy revelation and self-exposure to places they have never been before.
 Their work may constitute one of the 20th century's most accessible, most psychologically detailed portraits of the many forms of female life and life style. This portrait, limned by cartoonists of every race, creed and sexual inclination, veers in tone from the tragic to the riotously funny, often within single images. It encompasses an exciting range of visual styles, from semi-photographic to semi-legible, and touches on a dazzling array of subjects, mundane, sacred and taboo. Everything from artistic crises to bodily functions is fair game, including childhood, marriage, childbirth, sexual encounters of all kinds (incest included), dreams, revenge fantasies, and other forms of violence both real and imagined.
 Women cartoonists have had a boost from a general explosion of interest that is driving parts of the comic underground into the daylight of mainstream pop culture. The evidence is familiar: Matt Groening's "Simpsons" on television, Art Spiegelman's "Maus" among Pulitzer Prize winners, Robert Crumb's slacker version of Eustace Tilley on the cover of The New Yorker.
 This rising comic underground is a vast and unruly parallel art world with its own history and traditions, its own elders and prodigies, its own factions and issues. It is rife with people who, as Robert Motherwell said of painters, carry the history of their medium in their heads. And because cartooning pays so little, it has a fragile, pure-of-heart precariousness evocative of the New York art world of the 1940's and 50's.
 Instead of gallery shows, this universe has comic books, which come in solo and group varieties and are published irregularly by presses with wry, iconoclastic names like Last Gasp, Rip Off Press, Fantagraphics, Kitchen Sink Press and Drawn & Quarterly. Instead of Jackson Pollock, it has the legendary Robert Crumb, who, as de Kooning said of Pollock, "broke the ice" when he brought forth Zap Comics in the counterculture ferment of San Francisco in 1967, liberating the comic form from the mainstream superhero genre and its audience of teen-age boys.
 Since then a lot of water has passed under the bridge, and through much of it women cartoonists have had to swim upstream. Zap and its successors in the 1970's and 80's, Arcade and Weirdo, replaced what Caryn Leschen, a San Francisco cartoonist, called "guys in tights flying around fighting each other," with the hormonally challenged nerd, and the hero-adventure story with first-person tales of sex, drugs and rock-and-roll that often landed them in court. (Not for nothing do the words "mature readers" or "for adults only" emblazon the covers of nearly all underground comic books.) But these comics published cartoons by women only sporadically, if at all, and their raunchy, heavy-breathing stories frequently portrayed women in a degrading manner. (Even the New York comic book World War III, a paragon of raised consciousness that started in the early 1980's, tends to be dominated by male cartoonists.)
In opposition, several all-women underground comic books, including It Ain't Me Babe Comics and Wimmin's Comix -- were founded in the early 1970's, and Wimmin's, at least, is still going strong. In the 1980's, under the editorship of Ms. Kominsky-Crumb, Weirdo began publishing a fair number of women.
 TODAY WOMEN CARTOONISTS form a rich and sprawling network of generations, styles and publications that spreads coast to coast. Like most cartoonists, they tend to cluster in and around New York, San Francisco and Seattle. Their work can be found in individual comic books (there are roughly a dozen by women) and group comics like Real Girl, Diva, and Dykes' Delight, an English comic book devoted to the work of lesbian cartoonists. Self-syndication is a growing practice, both among mainstream cartoonists like Nicole Hollander, and among others like Lynda Barry, Carol Lay, Nina Paley, Alison Bechdal, Heather Mc Adams and Caryn Leschen, whose work appears in the numerous alternative weeklies published in the United States, Canada and other parts of the world.
 To find out what these women were up to, it was necessary to absorb quantities of information, read comics until the eyes threatened to go belly up, and keep a list of women cartoonists that soon topped 160. It also involved meeting and interviewing a series of ambitious, opinionated but remarkably approachable women, whose natural habitats tended toward small rooms crammed with books and papers that were much more like writers' studies than artists' studios. And it meant falling in love with the underground comics themselves, with their amazing compression of narrative and emotion, their graphic density, and the cunning grid of framed images (called panels) -- surely one of the most irresistible of all modernist conventions.
 They are definitely art, these little movies that seem projected on a page for your eyes only. Mass-produced yet overtly handmade, they can brim with artistic intention and personality. They are both as malleable and as resilient as painting. They seem altogether different from garden-variety newspaper comic strips scanned for their punch lines with the morning coffee. And since comics cost almost nothing to create, they are open to all comers, which may explain their attraction for women.
 "Cartooning is the cheapest art you can possibly do," said Phoebe Gloekner, a former cartooning prodigy, now 33 years old, who lives in San Francisco. "All you need are some pen nibs and a bottle of ink." Ms. Gloekner, who has recounted her childhood experiences of sexual abuse in her powerfully rendered, quasi-realistic cartoons, summed up the narrative possibilities of her medium when she said, "If you can think it, you can make a cartoon about it." (And you can probably get it into print without having to ask anyone's permission, especially within the expanding substrata of self-published mini-comics and of "zines," a major training ground for up-and-coming female cartoonists. In this area, keep an eye out for Megan Kelso's Girl Hero and Shira Levine's Noisy Jewelry.)
 Like Carol Lay and Ms. Kominsky-Crumb, many women cartoonists planned to be fine artists but went AWOL from art school and gradually came to recognize a cartoonlike form of private journal or letter writing as their "art." Others, including Ms. Gloekner, have been seriously enamored of cartooning since childhood. By age 11, Leslie Sternberg, the unofficial historian of the comic underground, was earning lunch money by making drawings of naked women for the boys at school. Roberta Gregory, one of the first openly lesbian cartoonists, grew up seeing cartooning as a serious career option because her father drew for Disney.
 THESE WOMEN TEND TO BE impressively multidextrous, pursuing different media and forms of expression for both fun and profit. Most of them do illustration work, which pays better than cartooning, and have other sidelines, like writing children's books or doing performance art. Heather Mc Adams sings in her husband's rock band, makes experimental films, and sometimes translates her cartoon characters into ceramics and petit point. Ms. Gloekner supports herself and her daughter with the exacting art of medical illustration.
 If you look through a lot of underground comics by women past and present, it is apparent that the genre has grown and improved and the number of impressive artists increased over the years. Today's comics are often better produced and stylistically more distinctive than their predecessors, as if the artists themselves are more convinced that they are making art, not just an amusing, slightly subversive form of entertainment.
 Especially enthralling are the new ways that women, as well as men, are stretching and elaborating the cartoon format, changing the shape of the panels, giving the divisions between them a special character, or doing extreme things with space. Ms. Gloekner, telling the tale of a chance sexual encounter in a doorway, puts the reader exactly in the woman's shoes, looking down at her own breast as it is grasped by a strange man.
 Other distinctive fusions of word and image include Debbie Dreschler's dark, nuanced tales of childhood and adolescent pain rendered in a close, textured style that is best called quilted; the whiplash, mad-as-hell drawing-writing with which Roberta Gregory brings her most popular character, Bitchy Bitch, to seething, hilarious life; Heather McAdams's willfully awkward renditions of the trivia of her own life parlayed into universal jokes; and Ms. Kominsky-Crumb's stream-of consciousness narrations of her life, rendered in a claustrophobic, offhand style, each frame crowded with thought and speech balloons.
 Comics may be absorbed in a more direct way than so-called high art. The ones you like insinuate themselves into the mind like a good rock song; you can pore over them again and again, appreciating the humor, the line and textures, the reality of the characters, the economy of the sequences.
 Not all cartoonists stick to autobiography. Some, like Julie Doucet, a widely admired young Canadian cartoonist, convert their emotions into extreme fantasies of violence and sex -- mitigated by a soft, rather innocent drawing style -- that have only a tangential relationship to reality. Diane DiMassa, creator of the mini-comic "Hothead Paisan, Homicidal Lesbian Terrorist," specializes in violent female revenge fantasies that can thrill the (female) soul. In one memorable DiMassa strip, a heavyset man sits next to Hothead on a park bench, carelessly letting his leg touch hers, an experience known to most women who ride subways. Fulfilling an untold number of rush-hour fantasies, Hothead simply whips out an ax and chops off the offending limb. INCREASINGLY, COMICS HAVE A freedom and tenderness that enables them to do things that other forms of expression can't manage nearly as effectively. Furthermore they can be both general, abbreviating reality, and highly specific, locating a viewpoint with utmost precision. Ms. Gloekner's image of a grasped breast has a movie-camera extremeness about it, but in a movie the image would go by too fast; in cartoon form the experience is frozen, available for the mind to mull over. Similarly, the tales of incest told in Ms. Gloekner's work would be much harder to take on film, and yet much less vivid if written in narrative form.
 Happily, underground women cartoonists are not setting a good example; like their male counterparts in the underground, they are telling unvarnished truths. So doing, they offer evidence that women are subject to the same feelings, torments and desires, and capable of the same unspeakable acts and fantasies as men. Like the so-called sitcom "Roseanne" and the ironically violent 1992 movie "My New Gun," their work removes women from either doormat or and pedestal status and seeks to put them on an equal footing with men.
 Cartoons are frequently compared to therapy by the people who make them. If you can make a cartoon of it, you can be rid of it. The process is the visual equivalent of Freud's talking cure -- a drawing cure, if you will. Perhaps all good art offers a similar kind of cure to both artist and viewer alike; cartoons just acknowledge it more openly. Cathartic and direct, touching on experiences that befall everyone but are also highly personalized, the underground comics have always been among the most efficient ways to see one's life flash before one's eyes in nonthreatening circumstances. These days that life is increasingly of the female persuasion.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Fernando Henrique Cardoso;
Having Left Campus for the Arena, Winner in Brazil Shifts to Right

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

 BODY:
IF Fernando Henrique Cardoso, Brazil's President-elect, had run for office in the United States, his opponent would have had a field day dredging up his past.
 A leftist, though hardly revolutionary, professor who cited Marx and criticized the West when it was fashionable in the 1960's and 1970's, Mr. Cardoso left a wealth of material for dissection, especially the book "Dependency and Development in Latin America," a seminal text still used in American graduate schools as a period piece on political mood of the 60's and 70's. 
 Mr. Cardoso ran on a capitalist platform of increased foreign investment, privatization of inefficient state enterprises and fiscal responsibility. As finance minister, he had engineered the plan that cut inflation from 45 percent a month in June to 1 percent a month in October.
 Mr. Cardoso's campaign positions were quite different from the beliefs he espoused in his book, but the differences never became an issue because he had built a reputation as a centrist senator. Faced with his past, Mr. Cardoso's best defense would have been that he is a changed man.
 "He now seems to be more of a social democrat than a socialist, but he was never a flame-throwing revolutionary," said Marc Chernick, an assistant professor of Latin American politics at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington. Mr. Cardoso's victory in October was a defeat for one of the Brazilian left's current standard bearers, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.
 "It is ironic that Cardoso stops the left," Professor Chernick said, "because he was somewhat of the intellectual godfather of the left." Mr. Cardoso was arrested, blacklisted and exiled by the military regime that ran Brazil from the 1960's to the 1980's for his writings and political activities.
 The quotations are from "Dependency and Development in Latin America" and from campaign interviews and writings. (Mr. Cardoso wrote the book with Enzo Faletto, a Chilean historian. It was first published in 1971 and was published in English by the University of California Press in 1979.) By the periphery he means the developing world, and by the center he means the wealthy West. KEN BROWN
 "It is not realistic to imagine that capitalist development will solve basic problems for the majority of the population. In the end, what has to be discussed as an alternative is not the consolidation of the state and the fulfillment of 'autonomous capitalism,' but how to supersede them. The important question, then, is how to construct paths toward socialism."
-- "Dependency and Development in Latin America"
 "I am in favor of deregulating the economy. To put an end to inflation means to deregulate the economy, right? The economists invented indexation of the economy to correct the devaluation of the currency. When inflation disappears, indexation will disappear. As we want to defeat inflation, we will deregulate the economy."
-- Oct. 6, 1994, news conference.
 "A real process of dependent development does exist in some Latin American countries. By development, in this context, we mean 'capitalist development.' This form of development, in the periphery as well as in the center, produces as it evolves, in a cyclical way, wealth and poverty, accumulation and shortage of capital, employment for some and unemployment for others. So, we do not mean by the notion of 'development' the achievement of a more egalitarian or more just society. These are not the consequences expected from capitalist development, especially in peripheral economies."
-- "Dependency and Development in Latin America"
 "I am certain we must continue to fight inflation, because inflation is what impoverishes Brazil and the Brazilian people. Inflation causes an unfair distribution of income, it prevents calculations from being made and it prevents domestic and foreign investments."
-- Oct. 6 news conference.
 The international economy has gone from the devil to the savior for many Latin Americans, including Mr. Cardoso.
 "Of course, imperialist penetration is a result of external social forces (multinational enterprises, foreign technology, international financial systems, embassies, foreign states and armies, etc.). What we affirm simply means that the system of domination reappears as an 'internal' force, through the social practices of local groups and classes which try to enforce foreign interests, not precisely because they are foreign, but because they may coincide with values and interests that these groups pretend are their own."
-- "Dependency and Development in Latin America"
 "The international system is a field of opportunities, of resources, that must be sought naturally. We are a great country, with a clear vocation for an active and responsible participation in world affairs."
-- "Let's Work, Brazil" (Cardoso campaign manifesto)
 "It has been assumed that the peripheral countries would have to repeat the evolution of the economies of the central countries in order to achieve development. But it is clear that from its beginning the capitalist process implied an unequal relation between the central and the peripheral economies. Many 'underdeveloped' economies -- as is the case of the Latin American -- were incorporated into the capitalist system as colonies and later as national states, and they have stayed in the capitalist system throughout their history. They remain, however, peripheral economies with particular historical paths when compared with central capitalist economies."
-- "Dependency and Development in Latin America"
 "The process of liberalization of the economy and opening toward the outside world will continue, not an objective in and of itself, but as a strategic element in the modernization of our economy."
-- "Let's Work, Brazil"
 While his books were full of ideology, Mr. Cardoso is now more interested in policy.
 "We stress the socio-political nature of the economic relations of production, thus following the 19th-century tradition of treating economy as political economy. This methodological approach, which found its highest expression in Marx, assumes that the hierarchy that exists in society is the result of established ways of organizing the production of material and spiritual life. This hierarchy also serves to assure the unequal appropriation of nature and of the results of human work by social classes and groups. So we attempt to analyze domination in its connections with economic expansion."
-- "Dependency and Development in Latin America"
 "Privatization cannot be proposed or carried out under ideological banners. Privatization imposes itself in order to increase society's investment capacity, to increase competitiveness and, where it is the case, improve management.
-- "Let's Work, Brazil"

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2638 words

HEADLINE: ENCOUNTERS;
Law, Conducting and Mathematics in One Package

BYLINE: By ERIKA DUNCAN 

 BODY:
WE began at 10:30 in the morning on the Saturday of the Labor Day Weekend in the Paradise Diner, Sag Harbor's "greasy spoon," reminiscent of the places in the city where the lawyer, conductor, mathematician Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg might occasionally meet a client before going on to dinner at a setting just slightly more elegant.
We moved through the day as he talked, gesticulating nonstop as if he were still conducting some invisible orchestra, first out to the Sag Harbor pier -- "and I do often meet a client on a jetty or a small strip of beach," he was saying in the kind of aside that so often would come in between his lines, this lawyer who practices without an office or a secretary or an answering machine, partly to spare his clients overhead, partly because he never meant to be a practicing lawyer, not really. 
 Even as he was telling me how, when he was a graduate student in philosophy at New York University, he became obsessed with wanting to teach mathematics, for which he had no formal degrees, and persisted until finally he was given an unwanted summer session, as he was telling me about how suddenly in the early 50's, when his academic career was safely under way, his earlier interest in entering the musical profession began to resurface, going backwards and forwards in time, for he never dropped one thing in order to pursue anything else, he told me that "of course it all had happened simultaneously, otherwise I would be several hundred years old."
Somewhere along the line, friends persuaded him, much against his inclination, to take a summer job working for I.B.M., and the summer job lasted for 20 years, which didn't deter him from guest conducting for the New York Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein, nor from taking over the directorship of the Mannes Colege of Music. It didn't deter him from working on a book of seminal texts charting the historical evolution of symbolic logic, along with Jean van Heijenoort, who once was Trotsky's private secretary and bodyguard, another "temporary" endeavor, that lasted seven years, and brought him permanently to East Hampton.
He stopped for a minute, and started to discuss Brahms and the problems particular to conducting him that do not occur in either Bach or Stravinsky, why it is very satisfying to a conductor to have one set of problems at a rehearsal and another set at a performance entirely.
He had never meant to be a lawyer, he repeated, when already engaged in multiple simultaneities of life at 49 -- fully engrossed in both his music and his work at I.B.M. -- he suddenly began to study law. "I saw it as a kind of midlife sabbatical," he explained. "As a recharging of the batteries. I wanted to write a book on how software could be legally protected.
After three years of study he took the bar exam, more the way he had needed to walk into college when he was still in high school, as an exercise of sorts, then half-heartedly joined a law firm, quickly phasing out in order to write his book.
Then the phone started ringing, writers, musicians, computer people, people from his many academic worlds. "When a 25-year-old starts to practice law, he needs to be part of a firm. Who would go to a 25-year-old with no clients?" he interjected. "At my age it was very different."
Before he knew it he was brushing up on copyright litigation to help the dentist/artist Frederick Franck and the historian Joel Carmichael, and estate law for the family of Dwight Macdonald.
The phone never stopped ringing, which is one of the reasons, perhaps, that he doesn't have an answering machine.
We moved from the edge of a mooring on the end of the pier, where the pleasure boats coursed, to a bench where the early autumn sun streamed down on us, as I felt he was telling me not the story of one life, but of many, many overlapping lives.
Wherever he was, he was elsewhere. Miraculously, whether it was I.B.M. or New York University or the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, or the Mannes College of Music, he was released without question from being full-time, to whatever else it was that he felt he needed to do.
"Only once in my life, I felt the need to see a psychiatrist," he said. "It was when I suddenly felt the urge to re-enter the musical profession. I remember sitting bolt-upright in the middle of the night when it suddenly occurred to me that I could predict the next 40 years of my life. This so terrified me to have everything so pre-destined and pre-ordained."
He discussed it for just a few sessions, until the psychiatrist reassured him that he didn't think it would be dangerous to go ahead.
He told about a feeling, perhaps akin to that first premonition of danger, he had had when he passed the bar exam, as if already he could anticipate it all.
"The book about software copyright law never came into being," he said as the years seemed to fall away, and his wide face turned boyish as it so often does, as he described how his living quarters have turned into "one huge file, and I am juggling 300 clients who fortunately don't have something coming up every week."
Only when he was looking around and would suddenly stop talking would his ever-gesticulating arms grow still, as now for a moment he stopped to watch the boats, and I studied his red polo shirt, the same in winter and summer alike. For he never seemed to feel the cold.
Only every once in a while, when the temperatures would creep down near to zero, did he conform enough to custom to put on an overcoat, more to appease curious questioners in the street than because he really needed one. And he made it a point of pride that he only wears a suit while doing litigation in court.
"Once I was criticized for conducting so much of my practice over dinner," he explained. Eccentrically meticulous about picking up the bill, regardless of the economic circumstances of his clients, he felt such hospitality created a far nicer ambiance, safe from their telephones and his.
"There are probably clients who like the idea of a walnut-paneled office, but the cost is passed on to the client. I am always shocked by the enormous cost of legal services. Often smaller claims must be forgotten, because they are not worth the overhead. There really has to be a better way."
As the sun persisted, we moved from our bench on the pier to a bench down on Main Street that was more in the shade, with the tourists still passing and thronging about us. And still Stefan was undaunted. And still our visit would go on till half past 6; he would call me the next weekend to say there was still more he had to say, and then the next.
"Being a family lawyer is a bit like being an old-fashioned family doctor," he explained. "If you start out with someone in copyright law, you will not want to abandon him just because you don't usually do divorce, or because you don't like to handle cases between landlords and tenants."
"And I hate to send a bill before something is finished. And as we all know, these things can go on for years. And often, although they tell me it is poor business, when a client does not win a case I am tempted to lower the bill."
He was talking about how the Austrian Cultural Institute had gotten him involved in the case of Madame Piscator, the widow of the theater director who is now in her 90's. His face saddens as he tells me of her plight. Someone in her bank, suspicious of her contributions to various impoverished people in the theater community, had reported her to a social work agency. A legal guardian who had been appointed for her had put her into a mental hospital.
After having her freed, Stefan was now fighting to have her human and artistic rights restored, her right to visitors, her right to a secretary to transcribe the book that she is writing, to determine her own spending. His face saddens as he talks of the fact that such a thing could have happened in the United States today, and then grows animated again as he ventures to explain some of the crazier quirks of the current legal system.
I watch his gesturing, his face.
Once someone who observed him teaching at I.B.M.'s Systems Research Institute commented that he taught as if he were queuing in some distant trombone.
He wants to cut down on litigation, he says, because he wants to write a book about how the court structure itself encourages corruption in the presentation of evidence.
He also wants to write a book called "Encounters," treating the various people he has known, and another called "Beholden to No One," "that would be not so much about my own life but a portrait of the times [he] had passed through."
He wants to write a primer on a system for entering musical notation into computers that he developed while working for I.B.M. and I wonder, was it in the interstices between time -- jumping on a plane once a week in the early 60's to conduct the St. Louis Philharmonic, or, in the late 60's, to chair the department of conducting at the University of Southern California -- as he tells me rather wistfully that before the invention of the modern jet engine his often 42-times a year commutes would be periods of much greater accomplishment.
And as if there had been no pause, he is telling me the story of a friend of a friend, who ended up in the hospital at the age of 88 without a proper will, how he was called in at the last minute. "A dynamic rearranging of my schedule," he called it, even as he explained that he usually likes to sleep late, to stay up, when he is in New York City apartment, until the first edition of The New York Times comes onto the newsstands. Nonetheless, he rushed to the hospital, stayed up half the night, and by 11:30 in the morning had come up with the proper will.
"Ninety percent of client contact is psychology," he says. "You get a real glimpse into the abyss. Especially with divorce litigation. Especially with estate litigation."
Then he pauses for a minute. "I admire people who do criminal law. I could never really do it. Those people are the real heroes. They certainly don't get many thanks from society at large."
For a moment a man comes along the pier side, walking a German shepherd. Stefan excuses himself to go pet the dog. "German shepherds are my real friends," he says, returning.
"And yet I believe that someone accused of crime is entitled to a fair trial. I don't know when I will be accused of a crime -- I don't think that I've done one -- but if I am accused I want to have a fair trial."
Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg was born in Heidelberg, in 1927. The Mengelberg family, boasting many musicians, had been in the Rhineland for centuries. One was said to have known Beethoven and was portrayed with a violin in an oil painting in the house where Stefan grew up. His granduncle, Willem Mengelberg, deriving from the Dutch strain of Mengelbergs, was the conductor of the famous Concertgebouw Orchestra in the Netherlands, where he played a major part in creating what is now taken for granted as the virtuoso orchestra.
The family had been Catholic until Stefan's maternal grandfather had rebelled against the authority of the Catholic church and had become Protestant. One distant ancestor was the abbot of the famous German monastery at Heisterbach, and legend would have it that a monk began to meditate on the notion of time, to ask how it was that God could be infinite in time. He took a walk, and when he came back it was 100 years later, and he had learned something about time and infinity.
Was it this secret inheritance that gave Stefan his interest in symbolic logic and time? Stefan and his brother, almost from the beginning, had been brought up by their mother, a professor of economics whose friends included Hannah Arendt and Paul Tillich. Their father, a lawyer, who was to end up in Argentina, was "much remarried" and gave him many, many half brothers.
His paternal grandmother was Jewish, and it was from her that Stefan's older brother got his blond, blue-eyed coloring, so extreme that he might have been able to play Siegfried in any opera house. Nonetheless, according to the Nurenberg laws, the two boys were seen as borderline cases. "Only if we had joined the Hitler Youth would our Jewish grandmother have been 'forgotten.' We had cousins who were admitted to the Hitler Youth and taken to Berlin where anthropologists measured their noses."
This of course was out of the question. Stefan's mother, one of four female university professors in Germany at the time, had done her dissertation on the fiscal policies of the Social Democratic Party, and she was immediately dismissed when the Nazis came to power.
The family lived for three years on the outskirts of Frankfort, and then moved to Wuppertal, now the home of the Pina Bausch ballet company, where they lived for another three years before coming to the United States. Stefan's mother was given a position at Iowa State College in Ames, Iowa, where Stefan would begin his American life.
As his anecdotes ran from those of his clients to those he had worked with closely, as he told me suddenly about Ruth Fischer, whose assistant he had been when working as a graduate student in philosophy, who was the founder of the Austrian Communist Party, and then later, for a short while, the head of the German Communist Party, "a position unheard of for a womaen half-Jewish" -- a sense of feisty, full-blooded apprenticeship emerges, tales of initial resistance followed by what was always a meeting rather than a tendency to worship or be too much influenced.
And yet when the avant-garde composer Stefan Wolpe, whose symphony he edited and then conducted, asked him what was his original contribution, he spoke about the fact that he did not necessarily think it a negative thing to "serve," that there were so many worthy people and endeavors in each of the fields that he was in, and in a way his translating -- for example, the essays in the history of logic -- served a greater purpose than his writing just one single brilliant piece.
I think of how Stefan explained to me that really it was a good thing he was not an outstanding research mathematician, in terms of the teaching of mathematics. "For outstanding research mathematicians are unable to teach the pitfalls, since they never fall into the pits."
And then, the lives not over yet, he starts to tell still other tales of suddenly, last year, beginning to edit the journal put out by the National Association of Scholars. They are tales of trans-Atlantic phone calls over the placement of a single comma that might alter the whole meaning of a phrase, and how he loves those calls, whatever time they take, however much they cost, what a wonderful experience it was to be working with a philosopher from Oxford, though it really was ridiculously expensive.
And strange it was, as he would talk, whether it was about the earlier work he did for Dwight and Gloria Macdonald, or the quarrel over a famous actor's building a chimney in East Hampton six feet from his unknown neighbor's property, as case history moved into life and back again, the boundaries between himself and those he talked about seemed to disappear.
Day seemed to disappear into night, as the time of our talking seemed to grow later and later, and eventually it was 6 o'clock in the evening, and then 6:30, and then 6:35.
So passed a carefully timed timelessness, a willingness to give each moment, each legal encounter, as long as it takes. And yet it was strange, in his life, as he described it, I felt each moment spent generated more time, until I knew we could continue on forever and forever, that every new beginning and impression, every seeming ending was only another chance to be beginning again.
 Erika Duncan is a novelist and essayist who lives in Sag Harbor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stefan Bauer-Mengelberg, a lawyer-conductor-mathematician, in Sag Harbor, where he sometimes sees a client. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: Amid Affluence, Hunger Is at Home

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
LAST Monday morning, 74-year-old Stefan Szymik arrived at the soup kitchen at Grace Episcopal Church here for his first hot meal in three days. The former machinist, a homeless man who said he lived meal to meal on Social Security checks, had purchased a package of luncheon meats from the local A.&P. two days before but had eaten little since.
Like many of the 80 or so other people in the dining room -- the elderly, the newly unemployed, homeless and disabled among them -- Mr. Szymik had come to depend on the bounty of the soup kitchen. 
 Another man, Harold Chavis, 48, said he used to be a tractor-trailer driver and that he comes to the soup kitchen every day. A man of few words, Mr. Chavis described himself as "homeless and hungry."
A 43-year-old woman, who would identify herself only as Roxanne, was also waiting for a meal, as was her daughter, Fatima, 2, who sat quietly at a table counting coins in her pink plastic purse.
Victoria Stewart, 35, a former telephone operator, and her companion Bubby Seabrook, 46, who said he had worked as a pediatric nurse, had come for a free meal, too, because they were out of work now and living on public assistance.
It was the first hot meal for many since the weekend, when the soup kitchen was closed, and some said they had stolen food from supermarkets during the two days to get by. Others had visited food pantries, where they received dried goods and food staples to tide them over. Others described a network of church-run soup kitchens, where they could count on a hot Sunday meal.
A few, however, said that although they had eaten little for several days, they were not hungry.
"The less you eat, the less you want to eat," Mr. Szymik explained. "You learn to get by."
According to Second Harvest, a national nonprofit hunger relief organization in Chicago, 10.4 percent of the population -- close to 26 million Americans -- are fed by local food banks throughout the United States.
Like Fatima, 42.9 percent are children. And like her mother, Roxanne, 26.8 percent of the nation's hungry are single parents.
Another 8.1 percent are elderly, like Mr. Szymik, many of whom are living on fixed incomes.
Others are newly unemployed, like Ms. Stewart and Mr. Seabrook, and social workers say it is especially difficult for them in a county like Westchester, where housing and other cost-of-living expenses run high.
In Westchester, where the mean household income was more than $48,000 in 1990, according to the Census Bureau, the statistics on hunger follow the national patterns -- although those studying the problem locally say the county presents a special picture.
"Poverty and hunger tend to be invisible in Westchester, and most people like it that way," said Priscilla Denby, who is directing a study of hunger at Pace University.
But attitudes have recently begun to shift, and Dr. Denby said that in telephone interviews with Westchester residents during the study, respondents were asked if they would be willing to spend another $100 in taxes to feed the poor. The survey found that 61.5 percent would.
According to the university study -- titled "A Growing Hunger: A Study of Food Inadequacy in Westchester County, 1993" -- even though the county is one of the wealthiest in the nation, one-third of Westchester's residents have "had to choose at some time between being hungry or paying the rent."
Numbers from the county's Department of Social Services show that 9,078 residents received food stamps during the fiscal year 1993-94, up from 8,700 the year before.
The Pace University survey also says poverty and hunger are not confined to the big cities of the county, and interviews revealed "pockets of problems throughout Westchester."
"Wherever it occurs, in the southern tier cities of the county or in the suburbs, poverty and hunger are joined at the hip," Dr. Denby said.
Ghassam Karam, assistant professor of economics at Pace University and a coordinator for the hunger study -- he prefers to call it "The Other Westchester" -- said that according to the 1990 census, 58,164 Westchester County residents were listed as living below the poverty line, which is considered to be $14,700 a year for a family of four.
But the actual number for those who are "hungry and in need" was probably closer to 135,000, if one includes residents living at 200 percent of the Federal poverty level, he said.
Dr. Denby described "a new type of person" who was going hungry in Westchester, saying that "more and more, it's the newly unemployed that we are seeing."
At Second Harvest, which represents 189 food banks and 50,000 agencies nationally, Christine Vladimiroff, president and chief executive officer, said that the "face of hunger was changing."
"Increasingly," she said, "we are seeing the working poor, who receive minimum pay and no benefits.
At Food-Patch in Millwood, a local food bank allied with Second Harvest, Christina Rohatynskyj, the executive director, described it as "a broad spectrum of people who are suffering, who are having to ask themselves, 'Do we buy the kids shoes, or do we eat? Do we pay the rent or do we eat?' We're talking about people who never dreamed they would enter the emergency food network."
Food-Patch, which stands for People Allied to Combat Hunger, fed 200,000 people during the 1993-94 fiscal year, with about 43 percent of those being children, Ms. Rohatynskyj said. The organization distributes food to local food pantries, soup kitchens and emergency shelters.
Food banks and soup kitchens are now worried that sources of Federal funding for their relief efforts will be jeopardized by the change in administration and Ms. Rohatynskyj said, "We're all feeling threatened."
The food banks expect even less money from Congress to buy United States Department of Agriculture commodities -- like butter, cornmeal and canned meat, beans, fruits and vegetables -- to distribute to the food pantries. The Government's $25 million budget to purchase commodities for food pantries was down from $85 million last year.
Meanwhile, as the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays approach, food pantries and soup kitchens continue to feed the poor, relying increasingly on private donations.
At the Ossining Food Pantry in Trinity Episcopal Church, Aileen Hunt, a supervisor, said her organization was distributing bags of groceries that contained a three- or four-day supply of food to 115 people a week.
The typical mix of groceries for a mother and two children from the food pantry includes soups, vegetables, cereal, dried milk, beans, oil, peanut butter, jelly, tunafish and pasta -- worth about $28.
For Thanksgiving, turkey hams, which are pressed turkeys flavored like hams, will be distributed by the pantry, along with 150 turkeys.
At Grace Church, Lesma Howard-Zepeda, director of the nutrition center, said that although the soup kitchen was receiving less money from donors and had already seen a $14,000 shortfall this year in its $110,000 annual budget, it would keep its doors open, and full-course holiday meals would be served.
"At holiday time we talk of abundance," said Ms. Vladimiroff of Second Harvest, "and some are offended that we only pay attention to the hunger problem at this time of year. Our hope is that what happens at Christmas and Thanksgiving carries over."
"The numbers keep going up for domestic hunger," she said, "Maybe we don't see the bloated stomachs, the skeletal frames" and the orange hair from vitamin deficiency, "the graphic images of famine and death, but the problem in this country is not going away."

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
The Credit Card: We Love It, We Hate It

BYLINE: By JOSEPH NOCERA; Joseph Nocera writes the Profit Motive column for GQ magazine. His history of the credit card, "A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class," was published last month by Simon & Schuster.

 BODY:
WHAT is the defining act of the American consumer? Easy. It is handing a salesperson that slim piece of encoded plastic -- the credit card. What is harder to answer is why so common an act is such a mystery.
On the one hand, we love the Card. There are 1.15 billion credit cards in circulation, amounting to nearly 10 for every American cardholder. This year, collectively, we will charge about $700 billion of goods and $325 billion of debt on them. 
 And, every year, we love it more. In 1970, the average balance on credit cards was $649. By 1986 it was $1,472. This year, it will be $2,800.
But we also hate the Card, with which banks can make money from both merchants and cardholders. "I think the banks, ever since the moneychangers were driven out of the temple of God, have been trying to perfect some plan whereby they can collect from both sides," railed Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and head of the House Banking Committee, in 1967. He spoke for all of us.
Partly, we fear the Card's temptations. "Unless we bring credit cards under control," cautioned former Senator William Proxmire at the same time, "we are likely to produce a nation of credit drunks." Even by that early date, few still subscribed to the naive views of one early observer, who, shortly after the bank credit card was born in 1958, said its major use would be "to take advantage of sales -- to buy your skis in the summer and your barbecue grill in the winter."
Everyone also knew that banks would hardly stand in the way of the credit card's considerable temptations. After all, banks' most profitable customers are those who get into debt, stay in debt and pay the minimum balance -- just the minimum balance -- on time.
We still share all these sentiments, and strongly so. In some of my recent research, people spoke with surprising anger and resentment about banks trying to "lure" them into debt. "Why do they keep sending me preapproved solicitations? Don't they know I already have six credit cards?" Or, "I hate the way they raise my credit limit when they think I'm not looking." When we walk around with $10,000 to $15,000 of credit in our pockets, we come face to face with issues of willpower -- or lack of same. And we resent those who put us in a position to succumb.
But even as we speak irately of the tempter banks, even as we view the credit card as a bit sinful, we see it as a status symbol and a key to the good life, and hand it over the counter. In one recent study, 22 percent of respondents described themselves as "uncomfortable using credit cards." Who were these people? Mastercard holders.
The Card carries other mysteries. Why were Americans so willing to accept 18 percent and 20 percent interest rates on their credit cards, while other rates fell dramatically? The banks do not know. But they knew the behavior -- which is why they kept rates high for so long.
And, in store visits, why do consumers spend more with a credit card than with either cash or checks? No one knows.
And why do so many people who are able to pay off their card balances every month nonetheless run up debt? Again, no one knows.
But the Card keeps growing. "Have you ever tried to rent a car without one?" asked Alex Hart, a former head of Mastercard. The question suggests how far things have come. In 1965, the Bank of America ran a publicity stunt in which a man lived for a month using only his BankAmericard. We have traveled from the possibility of using only a credit card to the virtual impossibility of not doing so.
But the industry sets its sights still higher. If the technology is ever so instantaneous that you can pull out your card at, say, McDonald's, its triumph will be complete. You will love the Card even more. And you will still resent it.

HEADLINE: The Most Regional Region

BYLINE: By Charles B. Dew; Charles B. Dew is a professor of history and the director of the Oakley Center for the Humanities and Social Sciences at Williams College. His most recent book is "Bond of Iron: Master and Slave at Buffalo Forge."

 BODY:

THE SOUTH IN MODERN AMERICA
A Region at Odds.
By Dewey W. Grantham.
Illustrated. 359 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $30. 
DEWEY W. GRANTHAM took on a tough assignment when he agreed to write "The South in Modern America." Mr. Grantham, a distinguished historian at Vanderbilt University, was asked to compress into one moderate-sized volume the history of the South from the disputed Presidential election of 1876 to the Clinton election of 1992. When one considers that the twin peaks of New South historiography -- C. Vann Woodward's magisterial "Origins of the New South, 1877-1913" (1951) and George B. Tindall's equally formidable "Emergence of the New South, 1913-1945" (1967) -- together took over 1,200 pages just to reach the end of World War II, the dimensions of the challenge facing Mr. Grantham become clear.
Yet in many ways he has managed to meet this challenge, and he made two decisions at the outset that were crucial to his success. He chose to rely heavily on existing scholarship -- the book is "essentially a synthesis," he notes -- and he decided to concentrate on a limited number of major themes. The result is something of a minor miracle: a reliable and eminently readable history of the South since Reconstruction in slightly more than 350 pages, even with the footnotes at the bottom of the page.
"The South in Modern America" has four principal themes. The first -- the enduring competition between North and South -- is the most obvious. Although Mr. Grantham gives some attention to economic and cultural rivalries, his major concern is political conflict. While the Democratic Party was rising to dominance in the post-Reconstruction South, Republicans were achieving majority status in much of the East and West, and it was not until a transplanted Southern Democrat, Woodrow Wilson, won the Presidency in 1912 that the South, led by powerful Congressional committee chairmen, returned to the pinnacle of national power in Washington.
A similar pattern re-emerged during the Great Depression when Franklin D. Roosevelt, late of Hyde Park, N.Y., and Warm Springs, Ga., captured the White House. F.D.R. was so wary of offending the Southern barons who dominated Capitol Hill that he refused to support a bill to make lynching a Federal crime. To do so, Roosevelt feared, would end any chance he might have of getting his economic and reform legislation through Congress. The more recent era has witnessed a stunning reversal of the South's traditional role in Presidential elections as the Republican Party has grown dramatically all across the Sun Belt. In both the 19th and the 20th centuries, Mr. Grantham correctly points out, race has been the single most important force shaping the contours of Southern politics.
Race also figures largely in the second and third major themes of the book: the ways in which Northerners and Southerners have compromised with one another since Reconstruction and how this process of accommodation led at times to a substantial degree of regional convergence. The South had no monopoly on racism during the period Mr. Grantham covers. Indeed the outside pressure the Federal courts, and eventually the national executive and legislative branches, put on the South during the "Second Reconstruction" -- the civil rights struggle -- was in many ways an anomaly. During World War II, it came as no surprise when a race-baiter like Senator Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi told his constituents that Roosevelt's Fair Employment Practices Committee was "nothing but a plot to put niggers to work next to your daughters." What may surprise some readers is that men like Bilbo were able to garner enough Congressional support outside the South to kill F.E.P.C. in 1946, and this case was by no means an isolated instance.
Mr. Grantham's fourth theme is the one he turns to at the end of his story: the problem of regional identity. He probes this topic by examining Southerners' religious life, their profound sense of place and family, their impressive literary tradition and their "subculture of violence," and he comes to the quite reasonable conclusion that the South retains its status as "the nation's most distinctive region."
There is much more. In addition to race and politics, Mr. Grantham examines the dramatic transformation of the Southern economy in the 20th century; he discusses the enormous impact of both World War I and World War II on the South, and he sketches the main outlines of the cultural changes that occurred in the region. Clearly Mr. Grantham could not cover everything in a volume of this length (the role of Southern women is given very modest space, for example), and he sometimes moves at breakneck speed to push the story along. But "The South in Modern America" is nonetheless a superb study. Readers seeking a compact, up-to-date history of the New South need look no farther than this book.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
