HEADLINE: What's New York the Capital of Now?: Deals;
A Day's Worth

BYLINE: By JON GERTNER 

 BODY:
Hey, buddy! Need a (pick one) blue-chip stock/manuscript/polo horse/Cartier necklace/dime? Consider this chronicle of just a handful of the deals that went down on one day, October 17, 1994.
 
2:00 A.M. -- Con Edison sells its metropolitan customers 3,633,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity, worth approximately $500,000, over the next 60 minutes.
 
3:30 A.M. -- Luna, a horse that just participated in the U.S. Open polo championships on Long Island, leaves Kennedy Airport for Argentina via cargo jet. Mersant International Ltd., a Queens-based freight forwarder hired by Luna's owners, clears the horse through Customs and the Department of Agriculture.
 
6:05 A.M. -- A beat-up box truck loaded with pumpkins, gourds and gooseneck squash pulls up to Gus Theos's U.S. Evergreen store at 805 Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan. Theos pays about $1,200 for the lot; he'll sell the smaller pumpkins to retailers for about $4 each. The larger ones, some weighing upward of 100 pounds, will fetch $40 each.
 
7:45 A.M. -- After three weeks of negotiations, General Electric announces the sale of the troubled investment house Kidder, Peabody & Company to Paine Webber. G. E. will receive 21.5 million shares of Paine Webber common voting stock, $100 million in 20-year 6 percent convertible preferred stock, and $250 million in 20-year 9 percent preferred stock. Total value: approximately $670 million.
 
8:10 A.M. -- Five Board of Education employees set out from 65 Court Street in Brooklyn to deliver some 97,000 paychecks, two weeks' pay, to schools in Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Manhattan. (Staten Island, in a characteristic show of independence, sends its own driver.) Total value: $186,795,574.69.
 
9:20 A.M. -- An undercover police officer buys one glassine envelope of "Killer Bee" heroin on Suffolk Street in Manhattan. Price: $10. The dealer is promptly arrested and brought to the Seventh Precinct station house.
 
9:30 A.M. -- Tom Protenic, a "relationship manager" with Chase Manhattan Personal Financial Services, approves a $400,000 mortgage -- a 15-year fixed loan at 8.25 percent -- for a doctor and his wife, who are buying a new house on Staten Island.
 
9:35 A.M. -- The crew for the NBC soap opera "Another World" arrives at Benner Medical Props in Manhattan to pick up gurneys, stretchers, defibrillators and other medical paraphernalia. Rental price for the week: approximately $3,000.
 
9:45 A.M. -- A private investor in Manhattan, through his broker in Connecticut, buys 1,000 shares of General Public Utilities at 25-3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
10:05 A.M. -- Marine Midland Bank announces that it has made a deal with Inner City Press, a South Bronx community group that had challenged the fairness of the bank's lending practices. Marine Midland promises that over the next three years, it will lend a total of $15 million to borrowers in the South Bronx and Upper Manhattan.
 
10:30 A.M. -- Thomas Dunne, an executive editor at St. Martin's Press, purchases the U.S. rights to "The Seventh Scroll," the 25th novel by the South African writer Wilbur Smith, whose previous book, "River God," was a best seller. The deal is negotiated by Dunne and Charles Pick, Smith's agent in England.
 
10:35 A.M. -- After a burst of spirited bidding at Christies' East in Manhattan, auctioneer Christopher Hartop awards Lot 50 -- "Victorian Five-Piece Silver Tea and Coffee Service on a Matching Two-Handled Tray" -- to C. & T. Mammon, a London silver dealer who was bidding by phone. Hammer price: $11,500
 
11:00 A.M. -- Managed Healthcare Systems, a New York HMO, donates $20,000 to the Minority Scholarship Assistance Program at New York City Technical College.
 
11:15 A.M. -- The New York City Finance Department opens its mail to find checks totaling $12.93 million in real-estate taxes. Also, Albany has sent $5.06 million in health aid and $3.7 million in education aid, while the Federal government has sent $37.36 million in welfare and other payments.
 
11:37 A.M. -- At the We Can redemption center on West 52d Street in Manhattan, John F. exchanges 480 12-ounce cans and 30 1-liter bottles for a voucher. He cashes the voucher at Freeman Check Cashing, on Ninth Avenue, for $25.50.
 
11:45 A.M. -- The family of a deceased woman pays Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn $838, covering today's "opening" fee -- for digging a grave and lowering the coffin. Her ancestors had bought what is now considered a 12-grave plot on August 15, 1899. These days, a plot that size cost about $48,000.
 
12:37 P.M. -- Smith Barney "crosses" -- that is, sells from one of its brokerage clients to another -- 250,000 shares of McDonald's stock, at 27-1/2 per share. Value of the transaction: $6,875,000.
 
1:50 P.M. -- The Ad Store, on East 30th Street in Manhattan, announces it has won the advertising account for Vagabond Shoes, USA, the new Connecticut-based branch of a Swedish company. Estimated yearly billings are just over $1 million.
 
2:30 P.M. -- Gary Hobbib, president of High Noon Management, finishes negotiating a royalty agreement with Columbia Records in Los Angeles. The agreement concerns "Making Me Sick," a song by the band Bash and Pop, which will appear on the soundtrack of the movie "Clerks."
 
2:40 P.M. -- Alexandra Stango, a real-estate broker for the Corcoran Group, completes the sale of a seven-room co-op on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The new owners: a stockbroker, his wife and their two children. Price: $650,000.
 
2:55 P.M. -- Sixty-one cartons of women's sweaters arrive at Kennedy Airport from China, to be delivered by truck to a wholesaler in Manhattan's garment district. F.O.B. price: $75,000.
 
3:00 P.M. -- A Florida collector purchases "Dirty Painting," a 1987 oil-on-canvas painting by the artist Arman, from the Marisa del Re Gallery on East 57th Street in Manhattan. Price: $120,000.
 
3:45 P.M. -- At a jewelry sale at Sotheby's, on York Avenue in Manhattan, executive vice president John Block auctions off a Cartier diamond necklace, circa 1930, for $211,500, to an anonymous buyer.
 
4:15 P.M. -- Allen Gross, president of GFC Capital Resources, completes the sale of Astoria Manor, a defunct catering hall on Astoria Boulevard in Queens. The property, which was foreclosed by a commerical bank, is being bought by a group of New York-based investors for $2.6 million.
 
5:00 P.M. -- The "first crossing" -- the daily 45-minute trading session conducted after the official close of the New York Stock Exchange -- ends, with 93,000 shares, worth an estimated $3,103,725, having changed hands.
 
7:00 P.M. -- A driver for the Skyline Credit-Ride car service picks up a passenger at Bankers Trust Plaza, 130 Liberty Street in Manhattan, and drives him to La Guardia Airport. The cost: $26, billed to a corporate account.
 
7:05 P.M. -- At a midtown Manhattan office, two matrimonial lawyers, Rona Shays and Bernard Rothman, reach a settlement concerning a Manhattan couple who are filing for divorce. Both lawyers maintain that the agreement reflects a 50-50 split.
 
7:20 P.M. -- In the basement of the Transit Authority headquarters on Jay street in Brooklyn, money-room employees finish counting the tokens and cash collected from turnstiles and token booths during the day. The total: 1,094,025 tokens and $5,659,764 in cash.
 
8:31 P.M. -- A Los Angeles art consultant, via fax, buys eight Marianne Engberg photographs -- flower abstractions done with a pinhole camera -- from the Staley-Wise Gallery. Price: $1,000 to $2,000 each.
 
11:30 P.M. -- In the West 20's, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues in Manhattan, several men negotiate the price of various sexual acts with several women -- who turn out to be undercover police officers. "Operation Losing Proposition" will ultimately net 29 suspects, ranging in age from 18 to 52. Seventeen suspects are taken to Manhattan Community Court, on West 54th Street, for arraignment.

HEADLINE: Farmland Preservation Is Lagging

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY 

 BODY:
A STATE program started 14 years ago to preserve New Jersey's diminishing farmland has so far saved 22,080 acres -- an average of about 1,575 acres a year. But during the same period, an average of 10,000 acres a year has been sold for development, state records show.
Further, state officials acknowledge that despite efforts in recent years to streamline the application process, insufficient local and state funds, political delays and the state's relatively high land values have contributed to large backlogs in applications for the State Farmland Preservation Program. As a result, the state approves fewer than a dozen applications a year for farmland preservation while hundreds of others are routinely turned down. 
 "We have more farms than we have money," said Donald D. Applegate, executive director of the state's Agricultural Development Committee, which operates the program in cooperation with county and municipal planning boards. "It is a highly competitive situation."
Figures provided by Mr. Applegate and other officials show that farmland presevation applications from farmers have numbered 450 or more a year. But only an average of 10 small farms are saved each year.
"It is a small percentage of the total farm acreage that has been preserved when you look at the gross," Mr. Applegate said. "We have plenty of farms yet to go."
Altogether, the program has spent $114.5 million for preservation. About $33.5 million of that has come from county and municipal government, while the state's share of $81 million has come from state bond issues.
Still, farmers, as well as national and state farm experts, defend the program. They say it has been successful and has produced local clusters of preserved farms, as well a motivation for farmers to go on rather than sell their land.
"There is a certain amount of frustration, but the program is successful and has its merits," said Steven J. George, a nurseryman in the Morris County community of Mendham. Mr. George is president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, which is the political and lobbying arm of the agriculture industry.
The frustration, Mr. George and others said, is born of a continual shortage of money to finance the program. Some critics say that will change only when a permanent financial source is found. Since its inception, the program has run on money from $150 million in bond issues.
Linda B. Webber, a planner and the preservation administrator for Hunterdon County, said that under the program a farmer approved for preservation is paid the easement value of his land while still retaining full ownership. Easement value, she said, is the difference between the land's market value and its hypothetical worth with a permanent deed restriction, which prohibits transfers of deeds for development purposes.
In return, the farmer agrees to add the deed a restriction barring the sale of the land to developers.
For instance, Mrs. Webber said, if a farmer can prove the land is worth $10,000 an acre to developers and $3,000 an acre if preserved, the state will pay the farmer 60 to 80 percent of the $7,000 difference, while the county and the municipality pick up the remaining 20 to 40 percent.
Among other criteria, competing farms are judged on size and assessments, soil quality, water and soil conservation features, proximity to other preserved farms or other open spaces, and their long-term value to agriculture, officials said.
Deborah Bowers, the publisher of the Farm Preservation Report, a nationwide independent newsletter on the subject, called New Jersey's program "very successful." In a recent telephone interview from her office in Maryland, she conceded that no state program could ever hope to stay ahead of the huge losses in farmland that were still occurring.
"Land saved will never be a significant amount compared to development," she said. "There is a lot more money to be made from development than preserving it for future generations."
But she noted that a recent survey she did of the nine states with preservation programs showed that New Jersey had spent "much more than any other state" to save farmland.
New Jersey's program, she said, protects important farms within an agricultural area and the protection stabilizes the agricultural industry in those particular communities. "What we call the impermanence syndrome steadied, so that farmers feel that maybe there is a future for farming where they are," Ms. Bowers said.
The state committee's current list has 48 farms that have received approval for $16 million in state easement purchases this year. Of these, five farms were approved in 1992 but held over. Perhaps more important, 71 farms have qualified to be purchased next year, but only $19 million of the $44 million that is required to do so will be available, officials say.
"We suspect that we will not have enough money for most of the 71," Mr. Applegate said. He said only $69 million remained from the three bond issues used to finance the program since 1981. Not all counties and municipalities have come up with the 20 to 40 percent contributions, he said.
Mr. Applegate said that under a cost-sharing agreement, the state also pays half of a farmer's soil and water conservation improvements in return for his not selling his farm for development for eight years.
Candace M. Ashmun, president of the Morristown-based Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissions, said that preserving farmland first arose as a priority from a blue ribbon commission appointed in the 1970's by Philip Alampi, who was the state Agriculture Secretary. By the late 70's, Ms. Ashmun said, it had been incorporated into the master plans of both the State Planning Commission and the Pinelands Commission, of which she is still a member. She said the idea was primarily to offer economic protection for farmers facing even greater development pressures than they do today.
By 1980, Ms. Ashmun said, state officials felt that a farmland preservation program was sorely needed, not to thwart development, but to make farming more secure and attractive to younger farmers.
Farming plays such a major role in New Jersey economy that Ms. Ashmun and others contend that agriculture has deserved the special protections afforded not only by the preservation program but through tax exemptions and other regulatory relief.
Figures provided by the Crop Reporting Service, an agency within the United States Department of Agriculture in Trenton, show a precipitous decline in New Jersey farmland for the last decade. For example, in 1981, when voters approved the first $50 million bond referendum, there were 1.3 million acres of farmland in the state.
Disagreements over how to administer the program delayed payments to the first farmers until in 1985. By then, there were 960,000 farmland acres, a loss of 70,000 acres.
Further, the 1994 figures show an aggregate loss of 140,000 acres since 1981, leaving the present total of 860,000 acres of farmland. This is an average loss of 10,000 acres a year since the program began.
But the state and national farming experts, as well as the New Jersey farmers themselves, say the program has fostered a new optimism among farmers for the future of farming. They say at least some farm owners are not so easily succumbing to the lure of developers these days.
Keith Wiebe, an economist with the Economic Research Service of the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington, said most of the nine states that have state-run preservation programs are in the Northeast. Other states have privately financed land trusts or no programs at all, he said.
Some New Jersey farmers say the long wait in having their applications approved is worth it in the end for them and their families.
Gary Mount has owned Terhune Orchards in the Mercer County community of Lawrence Township for 19 years. He said he had unsuccessfully applied for an easement purchase since 1982, his application having been repeatedly denied.
At $11,180 an acre, farmland in Mercer is among the highest in the state. The statewide average is $6,942 an acre, said Robert Battaglia, the chief state statistician for the Crop Reporting Service.
But Mr. Mount said he was happy that an application for the state purchase of 55 of the 225 acres he owns or rents was finally approved this year. "It has been frustrating and upsetting at times, but we stuck it out," he said.
"I am 50 years old now," Mr. Mount said. "Before I got the approval, I would plant these dwarf apple trees that we have. They take 12 years to mature before you break even, and I wondered if anyone would be around to harvest them at their peak, or if they would even be there."
Now, he said, "we will be able to retire a lot of our debt, keep the farm and still make a living from it." He added: "Someone will harvest those apples. That is ideal."
 
An Exporter of Food
THE relatively high cost of farmland in New Jersey, state agriculture officials say, is attributable to rich soils and the easy accessibility of many farms to 22 major markets out of the state.
Since the State Farmland Preservation Program began purchasing farm easements in 1985, the average cost for an acre has been $5,500. The average market price per acre as of last June was $6,942, according to the Crop Reporting Service in Trenton. Of the 21 counties in the state, only Hudson has no assessed farmland, officials said.
Donna Callaghan, the chief of the State Department of Agriculture's bureau of market development and product promotion, said that 70 percent of all New Jersey farm products are exported. "About 30 percent of what we grow here stays here," she said.
Joseph Tarpine, a market reporter for the department, said "at least three-quarters" of the produce sold at the six-day-a-week Vineland Auction, which is in Cumberland County and is the largest block auction of its kind in the nation, is sent to other states.
This, he said, includes the 8,200 tons of lettuce, peppers, peaches, cabbage, spinach, escarole, beets, tomatoes, herbs and other crops that were bought there up to Oct. 15. Purchased by 35 brokers and buyers, the auctioned products will bring farmers about $44 million in receipts this year, Mr. Tarpine said.
Farmers in the Cumberland County area sell half their products through the auction and half privately, Ms. Callaghan said.
While much of this produce is shipped to Philadelphia, New York, Boston and Pittsburgh, Mr. Tarpine said, shipments also are made to 18 other cities, including Montreal and Miami.
"We produce a lot more than we use," said Stephen J. George, president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau.
Ms. Callaghan said it was difficult to arrive at a more precise figure for New Jersey's farm exports because of the "circuitous route" that some of them take. "Some of it may leave for Philadelphia or New York," she said, "but find its way back to supermarkets in New Jersey."

HEADLINE: Angolan Government and Rebels Sign Treaty to End 19-Year War

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The enemies who have fought since 1975 for control of Angola signed a treaty here today promising to end the last war in southern Africa and to collaborate in rebuilding their rich and devastated country.
The accord, which calls for the guns to fall silent on Tuesday, is the third such pledge to end Angola's relentless fratricide. But it is the first to guarantee a share of power to the Unita rebel movement, and the first to be backed by plans to deploy thousands of armed United Nations peacekeepers. 
 Despite the determined optimism put on for the signing, the credibility of the treaty was diminished by the absence of the rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, who sent word that he was unable to leave his hideout in Angola because the Government would try to kill him.
Even after a truce signed last Tuesday, which was supposed to create a more trusting climate for today's peace pageant, diplomats said that the Angolan Army had continued shelling Unita positions and that the rebels had also launched attacks.
The treaty was signed today by Gen. Eugenio Manuvakola, a senior guerrilla commander and secretary general of Unita, and by Venancio de Moura, the Angolan Foreign Minister.
Afterward, the Unita general clutched the Foreign Minister warmly and then hugged the Angolan President, Jose Eduardo dos Santos, who had planned to sign for the Government but stepped back when Mr. Savimbi failed to appear. The embraces inspired the day's only roar of emotion from the throng of diplomats wilting inside a heavily guarded conference center.
"I pray to God that this will be the last peace agreement on Angola," Alioune Blondin Beye, the United Nations special representative to Angola, said later.
In 1991, the last time Angolans signed a peace deal, it was hailed as fruit of the new world order that emerged after the cold war. The United States and the Soviet Union, which had helped finance the warring rivals, helped push them to peace, which lasted about 18 months.
This time, peace in Angola is viewed as a milestone of a different sort -- a sign of how southern Africa is moving, against the continental trend, toward reconciliation and democracy.
But how soon Angola will join South Africa and other neighbors that have turned their attention from violent conflict to economic recovery is a subject of deep skepticism.
The United Nations, which is to police the deal, plans to move cautiously. Only a few dozen monitors will be deployed at first to watch the cease-fire, and only if they are convinced that both sides are abiding by the treaty will they eventually move in about 7,000 peacekeepers.
While participants insisted that the treaty was not devalued by the lack of Mr. Savimbi's signature, his absence raised questions about whether he could muster the trust to disarm his men and claim positions in the Government, as the treaty provides.
"If there is no political will, if there is no good faith, then anything, no matter how small, can ruin it," said Maj. Gen. Chris Garuba, a Nigerian mediator at the peace talks.
African leaders who assembled here to encourage Angola's reconciliation were less upset with Mr. Savimbi than with the Angolan Government for continuing its successful military offensive despite a chorus of international calls to stop.
On Saturday night, at a closed meeting of leaders from the southern region, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe strongly criticized the Angolan Government for continuing to attack for three weeks after peace talks were concluded.
"None of us have ever trusted Unita," Mr. Mugabe was quoted as saying by one guest at the meeting. "We think the Government had a right all these years to defend its sovereignty. We supported you.
"But things have changed. Why the escalation at this moment? Why at this moment, when the signing was imminent?"
Mr. Savimbi, whose exact whereabouts have not been disclosed, was offered safe passage to Lusaka on a United Nations airplane. But his deputies said he did not trust the Government to assure his security.
Foreign intermediaries who took part in the peace talks offered other explanations for Mr. Savimbi's failure to come.
One was that the proud guerrilla leader might have felt that it would be humiliating to make an appearance when he was widely seen as defeated on the ground. Another was that he might have been catering to a hawkish faction in his movement that rejects the treaty.
There were also renewed rumors that Mr. Savimbi was sick, injured or even dead, although Mr. Beye, the United Nations representative, met him recently and found him in good health.
The treaty is the product of 12 months of talks so glacial in their progress that at one point the negotiators spent an entire week quarreling over the name of the joint commission that will work out the timing and details of the reconciliation. They finally called it "The Joint Commission."
The treaty text has not been made public, but drafters say it spells out a list of officials Unita will appoint as a junior participant in the Government, including governors in 3 of Angola's 18 provinces, plus Cabinet ministers, ambassadors and mayors.
Although Mr. Savimbi has been widely reported to have been offered the position of Vice President, the signers today said his role in the future government had not been settled.
"When we see that Dr. Savimbi has the political will to participate in the process of national reconciliation, we will be able to solve this question," said Mr. de Moura, the Angolan Foreign Minister.
Angola, a country of 10 million people rich in oil and diamonds, has scarcely known peace since 1961, when the first nationalist rebels began an uprising against Portuguese colonizers.
No sooner was independence won in 1975 than the liberation fighters turned on each another. Mr. dos Santos's Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola was supported by the Soviet Union and Cuba; Mr. Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known by the Portuguese acronym Unita, was backed by the United States and South Africa.
Mr. Savimbi and Mr. dos Santos signed their first peace treaty in Zaire in June 1989, but they soon differed over exactly what they had signed, and by August Mr. Savimbi announced a return to full-scale hostilities.
In May 1991, the two men met in Portugal and signed a peace that included internationally monitored elections. This time, the war stopped long enough to hold elections in September 1992. Outpolled and with his army never fully disarmed, Mr. Savimbi resumed his war, making major gains against a Government that had let down its guard.
The accord signed today provides for a runoff presidential election, because Mr. dos Santos won in 1992 with less than 50 percent of the vote. It would not take place until the United Nations decided that the country was stable, and Mr. Savimbi's popularity seems to have declined sharply during the last two brutal years of fighting.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. GOVERNORS CAUTION CONGRESS ON SOCIAL AGENDA

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 20

 BODY:
Buoyed by their biggest victory in 25 years, the nation's Republican governors and governors-elect sought today to put some distance between themselves and the Republicans who will control Congress.
They urged the new Congressional leaders not to be distracted by social issues like school prayer and warned that they did not want the Federal budget to be cut at the expense of the states. 
 Arriving here for the annual conference of the Republican Governors Association, several delegates brushed aside two centerpiece issues of Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker-in-waiting: his proposals for an overhaul of welfare and for a constitutional amendment to allow prayer in schools.
They took care not to directly attack Mr. Gingrich and some even embraced his call for a balanced-budget amendment, but only on the condition that such an amendment would include language barring the Federal Government from passing on the increased financial burden to the states.
But at least 20 of the governors and governors-to-be crowding the podium at a news conference this evening asserted that their independence from Washington, even if that meant keeping distance from the new Republican leaders.
"We're balancing budgets, we're reforming welfare, we're fixing health care, we're dealing with crime," said Gov. Mike Leavitt of Utah, the new president of the association, which now has 30 members. "Our message will be to Congressional leaders, people of this country: Give us the ball and get out of the way. We can solve these problems."
Gov. Pete Wilson of California said flatly: "We believe the states that we have been privileged to govern are just that. They are sovereign, proud states of the United States. They are not colonies of the Federal Government."
Echoing his colleagues who argued that Republicans should emphasize economic stability rather than social issues like school prayer, Gov. John Engler of Michigan said, "If we don't deal with the economic issues, we'll need more than prayer to solve our problems."
Several governors who flanked him, as well as partisans in the audience, broke out in applause.
The news conference today, the first public lineup of so many newly elected governors, vividly demonstrated their political importance. Though the transition of power in the House and Senate has drawn much attention since the election, not since 1968 have Republicans controlled so many governors' offices.
Republicans became governors in eight of the nation's nine most populous states, states that have the most electoral votes and that will be crucial in the 1996 Presidential elections. The only big state that rebuffed the Republicans was Florida, where Gov. Lawton Chiles withstood a challenge from Jeb Bush.
Many of the governors who were re-elected earlier this month won in landslides, particularly in the industrial states along the Great Lakes. For that reason, the opinions of these governors, and their proposals for cutting taxes, add to their weight in the party.
In one manifestation of the importance, the meeting today was swarming with lobbyists who were angling to meet the chief executives-to-be and their aides.
Despite their talk of independence, several governors insisted that they could work well with the new Republican leaders in Congress. In an initial effort at keeping relations smooth, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin and some colleagues met earlier today in Washington with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who is expected to become the next majority leader, Dole and other Senators.
"They're eager to cooperate with us," Mr. Thompson said. "And that is such a change of philosophy and common courtesy that we've been asking for so long. And it is really refreshing to go to Washington and have somebody come in and say, you know, they'll listen to us."
But the comments of the governors today amounted to a preview of the possible intraparty fissures among members of Congress and the governors. Many Republican governors said the midterm elections were a referendum on their successes at cutting taxes and bringing other innovations to states, not simply a reflection of approval of Mr. Gingrich and his "Contract With America," a list of 10 tax cutting and budget-balancing proposals by Republican candidates for House.
Even Mr. Thompson, who has initiated several welfare plans in his state, made plain that he had little tolerance for Mr. Gingrich's proposal, which would cut off benefits after two years, require recipients to work and prohibit benefits for mothers who have additional children while on welfare.
"Each of us in our own way have gone to Washington on bended knee, to kiss the ring, to get a waiver in order to do something," Mr. Thompson said. "All we're saying now is we don't want to have to go through the mating dance."
The governors were also adamant that they did not want Congress to be distracted by social issues like school prayer and abortion. Gov.-elect George W. Bush of Texas, for one, said he saw nothing wrong with organized prayer in schools, but he questioned whether it should be such a focus in Washington.
"I have no problem with a school prayer amendment so long as it is not mandate to our local Texas school districts," Mr. Bush said, "and each district school board gets to make that decision. My priority is for Texans to be running Texas. And I hope that that's the message that comes out of Congress. We're pretty good at what we do in Texas, and we like to be left alone by the Federal Government as much as possible."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, appearing this morning on the NBC News program, "Meet the Press," said that an amendment legalizing organized prayer in schools was a poor idea and that Republicans should concentrate on economic issues.
"I hope that the legislature, that Congress understands that what got everyone elected this year was fiscal issues," she said, "that the people want to see less government, less taxing, less spending by the government and that's where we put our emphasis."
The remarks by the governors also seemed to reflect the early angling for possible candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996.
Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, a moderate on social issues who has been mentioned as a possible Republican Presidential contender, appeared on "Meet the Press" to position himself more to the right as he defended Mr. Wilson's support for a referendum in California that cuts off most government support for illegal immigrants. Mr. Wilson is also considered a possible nominee.
"Different states should be able to handle it their own way," Mr. Weld said. "If Texas wants to say, 'We're going to educate the children of illegal immigrants,' at least that's the choice of the state."
But on school prayer, his position was clear. "A moment of silence, fine," he said. "Mandatory prayer, no."

The governors want Congress to emphasize economic matters. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Young Democrats Brace For Life Beyond the Hill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The worst part of the way things are going in Congress nowadays, said Regina Wood, is the way Republicans keep barging into her office to size it up.
"It's a little disturbing that they don't wait until we're out," said Ms. Wood, a 23-year-old staff assistant to the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, who was defeated by his Republican opponent after 32 years in Congress. "They're bidding for our office space." 
 As a result of the Republican landslide on Nov. 8, 37 incumbent Democratic members of Congress lost their jobs -- not to mention more than a thousand people in their offices and on committee staffs.
In one respect, young Democrats who find themselves unemployed have it relatively easy: They can seize on low-paying offers or jobs outside Washington that older victims of the elections cannot accept because of financial obligations or a reluctance to move their families.
While young Republicans arrive daily, lured to the nation's capital by job offers from the Republican National Committee or Republican consulting operations, the young Democrats whom they will replace -- like Ms. Wood -- are scrambling to find new jobs and are tightening their belts until they do.
As Republicans sample the views from their prospective Congressional offices, Democrats gaze upon a bleak job market, deal with their anger, fill out law school applications and grapple with what one young Democrat called "Republican arrogance."
Ms. Wood will send out her resumes to other offices on Capitol Hill, but she knows there are more young Democrats than entry-level jobs in a place that serves as a magnet for ambitious political cubs. Seeking opportunities in the opposite camp is almost never done.
"There's no question that this is a humbling experience," said Patrick Dorton, a former aide to two Democratic Congressman. "The elections were a very grounding experience for a Democrat who was flying high in 1992." At 26, Mr. Dorton is considered a veteran among younger staff aides, and he has frequently been sought out for advice since the elections.
Life without prospects on Capitol Hill is unnerving for a group of young staff members accustomed to walking with their heads held high, Mr. Dorton said.
"I feel angry more than envious," said a 26-year-old Democrat at the Department of Health and Human Services who requested anonymity. "I think it's really annoying, especially to people two years ago who were on top of the world."
She said that those who could afford or who were willing to take on additional educational loans, were using the opportunity to return to school.
"Almost every friend I have in Washington is leaving their political career and going to graduate school -- most to law school," she said. "After working in politics awhile, you're not ever going to go anywhere unless you have a concrete skill, and politics is such a hollow thing to build a career on."
But Greg Klein, who works for A. T. Kearney, a large management consulting company offered another suggestion. A young Democrat with a bachelor's degree and two to three years of experience on the Hill, Mr. Klein said, has the "makings of a nascent lobbyist."
And Robert Gray 3d, the 26-year-old press secretary for Representative Peter I. Blute, a Massachusetts Republican and former campaign aide for the Bush-Quayle campaign, says "juris doctor Democrats" may be turning tail too quickly.
"It would behoove the talented Democratic staffers who are considering leaving to stick around," he said, so that they can help their party try to re-elect the President.
Although Mr. Gray and Mr. Dorton differ politically, they remain best friends and roommates. "Most of the people here on the Hill are young people in their 20's first, and Republicans and Democrats second," said Mr. Gray, adding with a laugh, "I don't think I'm going to make Patrick do extra chores or anything like that."
But not everyone is up to the challenge of bipartisan friendship. "This is politics, and their ideas lost," said George Frondren, 25, executive director of the College Republican National Committee. "That's the bottom line. I don't feel bad for them."
For almost every departing Democrat, there's a young Republican who is arriving. Chris Wilson, the 26-year-old campaign manager for David McIntosh of Indiana, who was just elected to the House, said he never considered moving to the East Coast until now.
"For young Republicans, Washington will be viewed as a utopia," Mr. Wilson said.

HEADLINE: Takeover Of Kemper Is Dropped

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Unable to finance its proposed takeover of the Kemper Corporation and having seen its stock price plunge 27 percent since it made the offer, Conseco Inc. yesterday called off the $3.25 billion deal.
The move came after Citibank, the lead lender, indicated that it probably would not be able to finance even a lowered bid, one person close to the negotiations said. Rising interest rates had made the loans needed to complete the deal more expensive while depressing the value of Kemper's brokerage and mutual fund businesses. 
 Kemper made the deal with Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind., while it was fighting a hostile offer from the General Electric Company. Yesterday's news now leaves it free to entertain offers from G.E. or anyone else. Since Conseco said on Nov. 2 that it wanted to lower its offer from $67 a share in cash and stock to $60, Kemper has received private expressions of interest from G.E., the Chubb Corporation and Sun America, one person at Kemper said.
It is not clear how much another party would be willing to pay, or whether any deal will occur. G.E. had originally offered $55 a share, and indicated a willingness to go to $60 before the Conseco bid appeared.
The dropping of the deal was announced in statements by the two companies; neither company's executives were willing to speak to reporters. The statements quoted Stephen Hilbert, Conseco's chief executive, and David Mathis, Kemper's chief executive, as saying it had become clear to both parties that the transaction could not be completed.
Mr. Mathis said the board of Kemper, a financial services and insurance company in Long Grove, Ill., "remains committed to the goal of maximizing value for our shareholders and we plan to explore all possible alternatives as expeditiously as practicable."
Conseco's efforts to finance the deal were public and embarrassing. It said it might sell its stakes in one or more insurers it controls. That sent the prices of those companies up, only to fall after it became clear that no buyers were available at the prices Conseco sought.
Banks led by Citibank were to put up $1.22 billion in loans. But Citibank told Conseco that given the declining results at Kemper, it needed to get new commitments from the other banks and refused to guarantee success.
Another $750 million was to be raised by selling bonds through Morgan Stanley & Company. The brokerage firm had issued a letter saying it was highly confident it could sell the bonds. Morgan Stanley never withdrew the letter, but an inability to arrange other financing rendered the commitment moot.
Under terms of the cancellation, Conseco will get no money from Kemper even if it arranges another deal, both sides said.
Under the defunct deal, Kemper's life insurance operations were to be transferred to a Conseco-controlled partnership, Conseco Capital Partners II, while the brokerage and mutual fund businesses would have remained with Conseco. That meant that a big part of the bank financing had to be based on the mutual fund business, which has been hurt by withdrawals from Kemper's bond funds this year.
Kemper's stock has already fallen as it became clear first that Conseco was having trouble arranging financing and then that it would have to cut its offer to complete the deal. The shares closed at $48.625 on Friday, down 19 percent from the peak of $65 they reached on June 23, the day the Conseco bid was announced.
But the stock remains 19 percent above the share price of $40.875 it closed at on March 11, just before G.E. entered the fray. And its financial condition has worsened. Largely because of declining prices for the bonds it holds, Kemper said its book value on Sept. 30 was $29.21 a share, down from $38.24 at the end of 1993.
Mr. Mathis said Kemper's delayed annual meeting would be held on Dec. 23. At one time, G.E. had mounted a proxy fight for that meeting, but dropped that effort after Kemper agreed to put itself up for sale.
Conseco's share price had plunged amid fears that the Kemper acquisition would dilute Conseco profits. Mr. Hilbert denied that, saying cost savings and growth would make up the difference, but many on Wall Street were skeptical.
The dropping of the Kemper bid may thus help to push up Conseco stock, but the public fiasco could erode confidence in a management that had developed a substantial Wall Street following.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

GRANDPARENTS IN THE AGE OF AIDS
As the AIDS epidemic rages, grandmothers across the nation are increasingly thrust into an old role with a new twist: they are caring for adult children dying of AIDS and for the grandchildren, in some cases also dying, who are left behind. Heterosexual AIDS infection jumped 130 percent from 1992 to 1993 (an increase due in part to a change in definition), and experts estimate that as many as 125,000 children will lose their mothers to AIDS by the year 2000. These children are increasingly left in the care of relatives, family friends and social agencies. 
 In 1992, there were 865,000 children under 18 being reared by their grandparents. Last year, that number jumped to more than one million, according to Census Bureau information analyzed by the American Association of Retired Persons. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
A MENTAL PATIENT KILLS ANOTHER
A man who was acquitted of murder by reason of insanity 10 years ago walked out of a state psychiatric center in Brooklyn, then, after returning almost 12 hours later, stabbed a fellow patient to death, most likely with a knife obtained while roaming the city, the police said. The ease with which the patient, Daniel Alvarez, 48, escaped from the Kingsboro State Psychiatric Center and was able to smuggle a knife past officials raised new questions about the security and operation of the aging mental health center. B3.
 
JUDGING THE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PROGRAM
Since Mayor Giuliani's new initiative to combat domestic violence went into affect Aug. 15, the Police Department has made an average of about 300 arrests weekly in family violence cases -- a 15 percent increase over 1993. Advocates for victims of family violence have given Mayor Giuliani high marks for effort for the program, but say the program has gotten off to a slow start in some 76 precincts. B3.
 
MAN CHARGED IN PLOT TO KILL OFFICIAL
A 33-year-old convicted killer has been arraigned on charges that he conspired to assassinate District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens, an assistant prosecutor and the judge who handed him a life sentence. The charges say that the suspect, Armando Hernandez, put out a $50,000 contract on the three officials. The judge was identified as David Goldstein of State Supreme Court in Queens, but officials would not release the name of the assistant district attorney. B3.
 
BICKERING AMONG G.O.P. COUNCIL MEMBERS
For a while, they seemed a fairly merry little band of legislators. But through a combination of smoldering animosities and fallout from other political feuds, the seven Republicans on the City Council are showing that Mayor Giuliani and Governor-elect George E. Pataki are not alone in the bickering within their party. B7.
 
3 CORRECTION OFFICERS SUSPENDED
As sporadic food and work strikes by inmates at Rikers Island continued, three correction officers were suspended after refusing to fill in for striking inmates assigned to the food service detail, a Department of Correction spokesman said. B3.
 
REGION
 
PATAKI MAKES A DEBUT
A year ago, when the Republican Governors' Association met in Phoenix, it was Christine Todd Whitman's show, a coming-out party for a new political star who had toppled a Democratic incumbent by promising deep cuts in state income taxes. This year, Governor-elect Pataki of New York is just a face in the crowd at this year's meeting. B7.
 
TRIMMING NEW YORK'S MEDICAID SYSTEM
There is no debate about it. New York's Medicaid system, the kudzu of health care programs, needs pruning. It is one of the most expensive and expansive Medicaid programs in the country, and Governor-elect Pataki has pledged to cut it. But how? Metro Matters, B7.
 
N.J. TRANSIT SEEKS 4 NEW RAIL LINES
Economic and environmental concerns may put electric trains back on four suburban routes being considered by New Jersey Transit. The lines would extend north and west into Paterson, West Orange, Summit and Plainfield from a proposed rail line linking Elizabeth and Newark. The entire system would connect to the Newark Airport monorail, now under construction. B7.

HEADLINE: Cam Lo Journal;
In the Free Market, Vietnam's Poor Pay a Price

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAM LO, Vietnam

 BODY:
In the poorest part of the poorest part of the country, all the talk about Vietnam as Asia's newest economic power is a distant whisper.
The rice farmers who tend the arid, gritty soil along Vietnam's central coast say they are thankful that their crops can fetch higher prices in newly free markets. But the land here in Quang Tri Province is so unproductive that even when prices go up the effect for most farmers can be measured in pennies. 
 Among the 400,000 people of the province, many farming families earn less than $200 a year. And in some years, when the land is washed over by salt water that floods in from the South China Sea, there is no crop at all.
"I have seen pictures of Hanoi and the other big cities, and I think they must be like paradise, like a dream," said Ho Thi Dong, a 40-year-old laborer, her sun-leathered face framed by a conical bamboo hat and a frayed yellow ribbon loosely tied around her neck. "But here in the country, I think life is more difficult than before. The Government cannot help us as before."
As the Vietnamese Government abandons Communism to make way for the free market, the services that millions of Vietnamese had come to depend on are crumbling.
In Government schools across Vietnam, students are suddenly being asked to pay for their books and, in some cases, for classes. Those who cannot afford them are being pulled out of school by their parents.
Vietnam's health care system, once fully financed by the Government and considered a model for the developing world, is giving way to a private system that requires patients to pay for medicine and a doctor's care.
For farmers, there is no longer the promise that in years of flooding or drought the Government will step in to help them survive by providing seed and fertilizer.
The loss of Government services is one thing in a place like Hanoi, the capital, or Ho Chi Minh City, formerly known as Saigon. Under a free market and with billions of dollars in new foreign investment, Vietnam's cities are booming, and most of this nation's city-dwellers have never lived so well.
But the new economic system means something else in a place like Quang Tri Province, where the people are about as poor as any on earth, where few foreign investors come to visit, and where the opportunities of the free market can easily be swept away by flood or drought.
The Government began to cut off free services four years ago, directing some of the money to projects like roads and electricity lines, which are desperately needed to attract foreign investors.
"It's logical for people to pay something for medicine and education in a market economy," said Do Duc Dinh, a Government economist who is deputy editor of The Vietnam Economic Review. "In the cities, this has been no problem. The problem is with the 10 percent of the population that still cannot afford these services."
In the scrublands of Quang Tri Province, Mrs. Dong, the laborer, surely falls into that second category. Abandoned years ago by her husband, she supports two children on an income of about $12 a month, typical in the province.
One recent morning she was being paid by the local forestry department to lug two heavy baskets full of tree seedlings, the baskets tied to the ends of a bamboo stick that dug deep into her shoulder as she walked. The seedlings, she said, would be planted on hillsides in hopes that when grown they will form a windbreak against the hot, dry eastern gusts that parch the farmland each year.
Mrs. Dong lifted the pole from her shoulder and sat down to rest. She gently rubbed her stomach, which has troubled her for years.
"I have trouble keeping food down," she said. "In the old system, I could go to the doctor and get the stomach medicine for free. Now, I must pay for the medicine myself."
Because of the illness, Mrs. Dong's life has been reduced to a month-by-month calculation: Can she find the $2 to buy stomach medicine and an extra $2 for vitamin tonic for her ailing 6-year-old daughter? "Sometimes I cannot afford the medicine for either of us," she said.
A few miles down the road at the Quang Tri Provincial Hospital, Dr. Phan Huu Tai, a surgeon and the hospital's director, took a visitor on a tour of the dank operating room, pointing to the rusting 20-year-old anesthesia equipment and, on the moldy wall, an ancient air-conditioner that barely worked. "Sometimes in the terrible heat of the summer, the electricity will die, and we must operate by flashlight," he said.
There is no money for renovations, he said. The central Government's contribution to the 300-bed hospital has been cut by about one-third since 1990, to about $90,000 a year, and his own salary has dropped to $50 a month.
"The idea is that the patients can pay us to make up the difference," Dr. Tai said. "I think what is happening instead is that when some patients become sick, they just do not go to the hospital anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vo Van Hung, 10, in Quang Tri Provincial Hospital after losing a hand when he tried to dig up an American-made shell left from the Vietnam War. As the Government abandons Communism, it has cut its contribution to the hospital by a third, to about $90,000 a year. Other services are also crumbling. (Jean-Luc Lenee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Extended Family Of Immigrants Mourns Victims Of Van Accident

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Balbir Singh's family left the Indian state of Punjab in the kind of serial migration that has been an article of faith for immigrants to the United States for more than a century. First came his brother-in-law, then his sister and her son, and then, in 1989, Mr. Singh.
Looking for economic opportunity and an escape from the civil strife in Punjab, they settled together in Flushing, Queens, and became part of the Sikh community whose life revolves around a temple in the Richmond Hill neighborhood. Mr. Singh delivered newspapers until two years ago, when his sister, Kulwant Singh, got him a job at the National Wholesale Liquidators Store where she worked, in Bethpage, L.I. He quickly rose to assistant manager, and frequently drove a company-owned van in which other store employees who lived in Queens rode to work in a car pool. 
 On Saturday morning, at age 31, Balbir Singh died behind the wheel of that 1987 Ford Club Wagon van, in an accident that also claimed the lives of two of his co-workers and injured 13 others. All of the victims were from India or Pakistan and most were, like Mr. Singh, from Punjab, which for years has been riven by conflict between Sikhs and Hindus.
One victim, who died at Mary Immaculate Hospital, was identified yesterday by a hospital spokesman as Surinderpal Madhar, and the Chief Medical Examiner's Office identified the third as Iqbal Singh, 23. It was not clear yesterday whether Iqbal Singh was related to Balbir Singh, but Singh, which means lion, is part of the name of many Sikhs.
At the Gurdwara Sikh Temple in Richmond Hill, Sukhbir Singh, a temple spokesman, said yesterday that nearly all of the 16 people who were in the van were members of the tight-knit temple. "They work six days a week and come to temple every Sunday," he said. "Every time we do anything for our community, they help. We belong to each other."
Iqbal Singh and Surinderpal Madhar often worked in the temple kitchen, cooking meals for newly arrived Punjabis, and donated money to the temple, he said.
He said that three Rajijathain, high priests from the Golden Temple in Punjab, the heart of the Sikh religion, were on their way to Queens for a memorial service to be held at the Richmond Hill temple today at 10 A.M. Sikhism is a monotheistic religion that blends elements of Islam and Hinduism. Its male adherents traditionally wear turbans and ceremonial swords, and many serve in the Indian military.
One of the injured, Jaqir Singh, 30, was a farmer in Punjab until he emigrated in 1985. He lives in an apartment in Jamaica, Queens, with several other young Sikh men. A friend, Parmjit Singh, said Jaqir Singh's goal was "to save money, bring his wife and family here and have everybody together."
His wife is on her way to the United States, but rather than embarking on a hopeful new life, she will be going to her husband's bedside at Jamaica Hospital, where he is in critical condition with severe head wounds.
Many of the victims got their jobs through a network that has been a hallmark of Indian immigrants, producing concentrations in such businesses as gas stations and truck companies.
Neil Rosen, vice president of National Wholesale Liquidators, based in West Hempstead, L.I., said that when the first of the chain's 12 discount stores opened in 1984, one of the first people hired was a Punjabi man. "He brought in his cousins, his brothers, everyone," he said. "It seems there are always people from the Indian subcontinent coming in, looking for work, and they seem to bring each other in."
Balbir Singh, who was single, found a home of sorts at the store, where nearly all the employees are from India. "He loved his job, all the workers, all the employees," said Kulwant Singh, who no longer works at the store. "He was a very hard worker."
Balbir Singh helped his nephew, Sundeep Singh, 18, a student at Aviation High School, get a part-time job there, and the teen-ager was in the van when it crashed. He suffered head injuries. Yesterday, at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Sundeep Singh, in a daze, a purple bruise covering much of his face, leaned his head against his mother's shoulder as she wept for her dead brother.
At the National Wholesale Liquidators store in Bethpage, in a strip mall across the street from a former Grumman plant, stunned employees yesterday went numbly through the routine of arranging displays of plastic Santas and boxes of cookware.
Mr. Rosen said the employees were distraught when the store opened yesterday morning. "So I closed the doors, and brought them all together and told them that we're family, and everybody had tears in their eyes, including me," he said. "These people are not of my same hemisphere or my religion, but you work with people for years, and it's family."

HEADLINE: Apple Lawyer Will Become New Director Of Gay Group

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The nation's largest gay political organization has reached into the corporate world for an executive director to guide it through what promises to be a tumultuous period in the gay-rights movement.
Elizabeth Birch, the 38-year-old chief litigator at Apple Computer Inc., is to be named today as executive director of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, an organization that is based in Washington and claims more than 80,000 members. The fund fights discrimination against homosexuals through organizing, lobbying and financial support for political candidates. 
 "I'm not naive," Ms. Birch said yesterday. "I understand it will be enormously challenging. But I continue to be optimistic, as someone who comes from outside Washington, that there is a wonderful trend going on in America.
"Even in the midst of the largest Republican sweep in 20 years, America has simply refused to institutionalize discrimination," she said, referring to the defeat of referendums in Oregon and Idaho seeking to abolish gay-rights measures.
Ms. Birch was involved in the battle last year between Apple and Williamson County, a suburban county north of Austin, Tex. The county commissioners balked at giving the company a tax abatement on the construction of an $80 million office complex because Apple offered benefits to the partners of gay employees. But after Apple said that as a matter of principle and economics it would not build without the breaks, the county awarded financial incentives for the project.
Ms. Birch lives in Boulder Creek, Calif., near Santa Cruz. She was co-chairwoman of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force from 1992 until this year. She joined Apple in 1989 and has served as general counsel of the Claris Corporation, its software subsidiary.
The campaign fund spent four months looking for a successor to Tim McFeeley. Jean Harris, a special assistant to San Francisco's public health director, applied for the job but told the search committee that they ought to choose Ms. Birch. "She's a tough cookie," Ms. Harris said. "She's got a corporate image, brains and the ability to take the risks that need to be taken."
John Laird, a former mayor of Santa Cruz, Calif., has worked with Ms. Birch on gay causes for almost a decade. "She can walk into a room and immediately connect with people from the corporate world," he said. "But that's not to take away from her street-level activities, which have also been good."

HEADLINE: Keeping in Touch With the Victims of Domestic Violence

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
A son hit his 65-year-old father with a shovel, leaving deep cuts on his left hand. A young man got into an argument with his live-in girlfriend over their sex life and the argument escalated so furiously that she called 911 out of fear he would beat her. A man burned his common-law wife's face with a cigarette during a fight.
These brief descriptions of some of the 16 domestic incident reports that Police Officer James O'Donnell reviewed last Monday morning gave only a glimpse of the violence that went on behind closed doors last weekend in the 120th Precinct on the northern part of Staten Island. 
 But they led Officer O'Donnell and a detective he works with to open investigations into the cases and make follow-up visits to offer counseling and legal advice to the victims.
The domestic incident reports, which are separated from other 911 emergency complaint reports so they receive special attention, are part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new initiative to combat domestic violence. The core of the plan is to record and track all such complaints and give higher priority to collecting evidence in such cases.
Under the plan, at least one patrol officer and one detective in every precinct have been assigned to try to prevent family disputes from escalating into serious violence. The initiative also requires officers to make arrests if such violence does occur.
"We get a small victory every day," said Officer O'Donnell, "getting a case opened for a possible arrest, getting the people to go to court for an order of protection, just getting the women to call me to help out."
Since the program went into effect Aug. 15, the police have has made an average of about 300 arrests weekly in family violence cases -- a 15 percent increase over 1993 figures. In theory, the increase in arrests should deter future offenses and reduce the number of children exposed to violence at home -- a condition criminologists say often turns children into violent adults.
Advocates for victims of family violence have given Mayor Giuliani high marks for effort, but they say the program has got off to a slow start in some of the city's 76 precincts. They say the increase in arrests is below what it should be, given that it comes as emergency calls have increased substantially due in large part to the publicity surrounding the O. J. Simpson case.
"The principles are right on target, but implementation has a long way to go," said Dorchen Leidholdt, director of the Center for Battered Women's Legal Services, a private group offering legal representation to victims throughout the metropolitan area. "Giuliani's mandatory arrest policy is a step forward."
Part of the problem, the advocates say, is the department's shortage of computers for filing complaints. But they also note that domestic violence officers receive only one day of special training and that the regular patrol officers who respond to the 911 calls may lack the sensitivity to handle such cases and do not always follow orders and make arrests.
Capt. Joseph A. Lehan, the commanding officer of the 120th Precinct, acknowledged the problems, saying the policy "is still in its embryonic stage." But he said, "It's not like the old days when the radio car came to the scene of a dispute and what was acceptable was to tell the husband to take a walk and cool off."
A number of other cities have installed similar programs in recent years, but because few resources have been devoted to them, results have been mixed.
New York's program has proven more effective in the 120th Precinct than in many others in the city, in part because it is one of 12 where officers work in tandem with a social worker employed by Victims Services, a private nonprofit agency.
Last week, Officer O'Donnell and Marile Adams, a fellow domestic violence officer, took their daily drive through Staten Island's neighborhoods -- going from areas of graceful Victorian-style homes to graffiti-marked public projects to follow up with people who had lodged domestic violence complaints.
The tour demonstrated both how family violence crosses class lines and the difficulty of the task the officers face. At one home, nobody answered the door bell. At the home of a woman who said her husband had beaten her, the officers could not get past the door because a female friend said the woman was asleep. The police left some literature on domestic violence.
Frustration followed frustration until the group arrived at the West Brighton home of an unemployed 24-year-old woman who was trying to start a new life after her husband was sent to jail on a gun charge two months ago -- an arrest that followed the woman's complaints that he beat their 2-year-old child. The woman was home and gladly let the officers in.
The officers wanted to know if she needed any help in relocating to a new home. She listened carefully to her visitors' advice on how to make sure that her estranged husband does not find her once she moves.
"You may want to put this behind you," Officer Adams said. "But if you leave the precinct, I can let the domestic violence officer in the next precinct know, so we can keep track of you and help if we are needed."
The woman thanked them for the advice, and expressed surprise about all the attention she was suddenly getting. "Before this incident came down," she said, "when I called the police before they didn't do anything."

(Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hair Spray, Rifles, Toys (and Jobs);
A Discount Megastore Wins Friends and Influences Rivals

SERIES: When Wal-Mart Comes to Town -- A retail giant and a community's economy: last article of a series

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREENPORT, N.Y.

 BODY:
When Wal-Mart opened a huge discount department store in Columbia County last spring, no one tried harder than Pamela Taylor-Farrell to warn mom-and-pop businesses that their survival was at stake.
But nearly eight months later, Ms. Taylor-Farrell, the former president of the downtown merchants association, has been won over by the other side: Now a self-described "Wal-Mart groupie," she roams the gleaming aisles of the store after work on each payday. 
 She has stocked up on Suave hair spray and Revlon cosmetics. She has bought hand weights, an aerobic step and an exercise slide. And after shedding 82 pounds in recent months, she has sought out Wal-Mart to rebuild her wardrobe, snatching up L'Eggs thigh-high stockings, bras and black stirrup pants.
"I took a hard line against them and felt I fought a good fight," said Ms. Taylor-Farrell, the advertising manager of a local newspaper. "There's just too many damn attractive things. And they're at a reasonable price."
Like countless other places across the country, Greenport and the neighboring city of Hudson have seen long-time shopping patterns upset by the arrival of the nation's largest retailer. On a recent afternoon, hundreds of cars lined Wal-Mart's spacious parking lot, while only a few people strolled along the cobblestone sidewalks of Warren Street, Hudson's main thoroughfare and the shopping district closest to the new store.
It is difficult to assess the sales performance of the new store, because the Arkansas-based chain is notoriously secretive. But a manager at the Greenport Wal-Mart said the sporting goods department alone, fueled by brisk sales of hunting rifles, would exceed $1 million in business before the end of November.
And sports is only one of the store's 23 departments, many of which compete directly with several dozen Warren Street establishments, including Town Fair, a 44-year-old toy store; Airhead Balloons/Hudson Flower Market, a gift shop, and the J. C. Rogerson Company hardware store, which has anchored downtown Hudson since 1832.
As the merchants of Warren Street enter their first Christmas shopping season since Wal-Mart came to town, many say that Wal-Mart has bitten hard into their customer base, which had already been eroded by shopping malls in the Albany area. No one has gone out of business, but there are rumors that several shops are on the brink.
Some merchants are responding to Wal-Mart's arrival by slashing prices, others are increasing their advertising budgets and at least one, Rogerson's hardware, has installed a computer atop its 19th-century checkout counter to make its inventory control more sophisticated.
For the most part, each is acting alone. Despite studies showing that a Main Street must present a united front to survive Wal-Mart, the merchants of Warren Street have been unable to agree on a strategy. In June, their bickering led to the quiet dissolution of their long-time merchants association, the Society to Promote Our Unique Town (S.P.O.U.T.), of which Ms. Taylor-Farrell was president.
"Of course I feel guilty," said Ms. Taylor-Farrell, who used to shop Warren Street every week but now does little more than get her hair styled at Lisa Marie's Beauty Shop. "But like everyone else, I have to stretch my dollar."
Although uneasiness lingers on Warren Street, the new Wal-Mart has raised spirits elsewhere. County officials say they are thrilled with a 6 percent increase in sales tax revenues in the third quarter, attributable largely to Wal-Mart. Consumers from as far north as Schoharie County and as far south as Dutchess County say they are glad to have a new shopping option within a one-hour drive. And numerous Wal-Mart workers, many of them unemployed earlier this year, say they are fortunate to be working at the store, even if the starting salary is only about $220 a week.
For Don Michalek, 25, a former Navy petty officer who had been out of work for over a year, being hired as the manager of Wal-Mart's sporting goods department gave him and his wife the financial security to have a second child. Two months after the store's March 30 grand opening, Mr. Michalek's wife learned she was pregnant.
"Without the job," said Mr. Michalek, one of 250 full- and part-time workers, "it would have been 'No way!' "
For decades, Wal-Mart has been a retail force in small towns across the West and Middle West. But the discount retailer was virtually unknown in the Northeast until three years ago. Since then, the company has opened 35 Wal-Mart's in New York, 10 in New Jersey and 4 in Connecticut. By early 1996, the company plans to have 71 stores in the three states.
Wal-Mart -- which has 2,102 stores nationally -- transcends other discount merchandisers by offering generally lower prices, sugary-sweet service (the Greenport store, like every other Wal-Mart, has a greeter at its front door) and a state-of-the-art distribution network, analysts say.
Joan Koweek, whose parents founded the Town Fair toy store on Warren Street in 1950, has already learned that Wal-Mart can be a formidable foe, dropping prices on select items to near cost as a way to lure consumers. For example, Ms. Koweek discovered that the Exersaucer -- a baby walker that she was selling in the mid-$50 range -- was being sold at Wal-Mart in the low $40's. She quickly lowered her price, as well as the prices of a number of other toys, including Bed-Time Barbie (reduced to $12.99 from $16.88) and a child-size car from Little Tikes (reduced to $34.95, including a company rebate, from $49.95).
After noticing a drop in traffic on Warren Street immediately after Wal-Mart opened, Ms. Koweek said customers had recently begun to return. Since her store traditionally does 40 percent of its annual business in November and December, she is taking no chances, buying additional billboard space and adding a new line of educational toys that Wal-Mart does not carry.
"It'll be an interesting Christmas," Ms. Koweek said, the store's original hardwood floor creaking beneath her. "I'm looking forward to the challenge."
Dennis McEvoy, one of the owners of Rogerson's hardware, has tried to keep Wal-Mart in perspective. In June, Mr. McEvoy's father, John -- a fixture in the store for 55 years -- died at 68 after battling a stroke and then liver cancer.
The younger Mr. McEvoy, a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, has embraced his father's role with gusto, identifying the voices of most customers on the phone before they say their names, just like his dad did. With Wal-Mart's sizable hardware department just two miles away, Mr. McEvoy has taken steps to modernize the 162-year-old store: his front window now displays the seasonal promotions of a national hardware wholesaler; he sets prices on new items with an eye on his new competitor and he is carrying a Mikita 1/2-inch cordless drill that he never stocked before.
"We're trying to get a little bit more aggressive," Mr. McEvoy said.
Other stores that do not compete directly with Wal-Mart have found they have flourished in the giant's shadow. Berman's Furniture, which is a few hundred yards south of Wal-Mart on Route 9, has seen its business increase 30 percent, thanks to Wal-Mart customers who stop by on their way home.
And revenues at Sweeps, a Warren Street shop that sells and services vacuum cleaners, are up 15 percent. That's because the owner, Jeff Bagnall, lined up informal service agreements on virtually every major brand of lawn mower, snow blower and vacuum that Wal-Mart sells.
"Every day," Mr. Bagnall said, "I thank God I'm in the repair business."
But Wal-Mart -- with a selling floor as big as two football fields -- is not for everyone. Eunice Nabozny, stopping by Sweeps on a recent afternoon to pick up a belt for her Hoover vacuum, said she much preferred the 200-year-old brick storefronts of Hudson to the hustle and bustle of Wal-Mart.
"I guess I'm getting old," said Mrs. Nabozny, her 4-year-old grandson Christopher in tow. "I like family-type stores, the personal touch of the little guy."
Surprisingly, sometimes so does Wal-Mart.
Earlier this year, the Wal-Mart managers were scrambling to replace the frayed American flag that waves from the store roof and is central to the chain's image. They eventually found it at Rogerson's hardware, for $60.89.
"I think the old man is smiling down on that one," Mr. McEvoy said.
 
 
 
THE SERIES SO FAR
 The most recent article of this series on Wal-Mart's arrival near Hudson, N.Y., appeared on March 31. It described the store's opening day. An article on Jan. 24 examined the hopes and prospects of job-seekers and the store's interview process. The first article, on Nov. 28, 1993, looked at the effect Wal-Mart was expected to have on businesses along Hudson's main thoroughfare, Warren Street.

HEADLINE: At Conference Of Governors, Pataki Makes A Quiet Debut

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 20

 BODY:
A year ago, when the Republican Governors' Association met in Phoenix, it was Christine Todd Whitman's show, a coming-out party for a new political star who had toppled a Democratic incumbent by promising deep cuts in state income taxes.
This year, Governor-elect George E. Pataki of New York used a similar playbook to unseat perhaps the most prominent governor in the country. But he is just a face in the crowd at this year's meeting, just one of 11 Republicans about to take over statehouses that were previously Democratic or independent. 
 And despite his campaign assertion that "I want to be Christie Whitman," at least when it comes to cutting taxes, Mr. Pataki seems to have little interest in captivating the conference with his debut. Mrs. Whitman, whose victory in New Jersey made her one of only two new Republican governors elected in 1993, stayed for three days last year, delivered a speech and spoke frequently to reporters. Mr. Pataki is staying for less than 20 hours, spending most of it behind closed doors and then leaving for a family vacation, the second since he was elected 12 days ago.
Mrs. Whitman is staying until the meeting ends on Tuesday, according to her aides, and Governor-elect John G. Rowland of Connecticut plans to join the group on Monday, according to conference officials.
Mr. Pataki said today that he felt it was more important to spend the next week focusing on his transition, even though he will be doing it from an undisclosed vacation spot out of New York. But the decision also seems to reflect the emerging style of a leader who has made few public appearances since his election and has rejected numerous chances to grab the national spotlight, including network television interviews.
Few of Mr. Pataki's colleagues here had met him before (he did not attend a school for new governors in West Virginia this weekend sponsored by the National Governors' Association). But his reputation as a Cuomo slayer preceded him.
Gov. John Engler of Michigan, who won a second term this month, said Mr. Pataki had "sort of folk hero status already."
Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi said Republican leaders took "special pride" in Mr. Pataki's defeat of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "Old Mario had sort of burnt out, hadn't he?" Mr. Fordice said.
Though Mr. Pataki's early departure means he will miss speeches by the incoming leaders of the House and the Senate, Representative Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the Governor-elect acknowledged that he needs an education on Federal issues affecting New York.
"One of the reasons that I'm here is because I haven't looked at the Federal issues in the past and I want to take a look," he said.
At times while discussing state-Federal relations today, Mr. Pataki sounded strangely like Mr. Cuomo. He said he favored a Federal balanced budget amendment, but, like Mr. Cuomo, he said Washington must not solve its fiscal problems by passing obligations on to the states. And he pledged that his proposal to cut state income taxes by 25 percent over four years would not force local governments to raise their taxes.
"I don't think it helps in Washington if they balance the budget in Washington by shifting the costs and the taxes to state government," he said at a news conference with other governors. "So I think we are all pretty much in agreement that we want to see the Federal Government pass a balanced-budget amendment but do it in such a way that controls your costs and doesn't just shift your costs."
He added in an interview: "Part of the reason we're in the economic straits we're in right now is because the Federal Government has not imposed the discipline it should have and is passing costs of past programs to future generations."
He refused to say where he would spend the next week, saying only that it was out of New York and that he would return next weekend.
"My last vacation, which was a weekend and a Friday, I probably spent 40 hours on transition matters," Mr. Pataki said. "It was more a physical distancing than a stopping of the process of transition. And that's the same this time. I'll be physically with the kids and Libby out of New York State, but we will be working every day, many, many hours on transition."
