HEADLINE: Review Set Of Nasdaq's Operations

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq stock market, under mounting pressure from antitrust regulators, litigious investors and the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced yesterday that it had appointed a seven-member committee, headed by former Senator Warren Rudman, to review its governance and operations.
The committee includes Peter S. Lynch, the former manager of the Fidelity Investment's Magellan Fund and an author of books and articles on investment strategies, and two former S.E.C. commissioners, Irving M. Pollack and A. A. Sommers Jr. 
 The announcement comes a month after the Justice Department announced that it was investigating Nasdaq dealers for possible antitrust violations and to determine whether bids were rigged on stocks to keep the spreads high. The department has not made a direct target of Nasdaq, a network of securities dealers linked by computer and phone.
Mr. Rudman said he agreed to head the committee on Wednesday, after being asked by Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Joseph Hardiman, the president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the Washington trade group that runs Nasdaq.
An industry executive involved in the selection process said Mr. Levitt had persuaded Mr. Rudman to serve and had worked closely with Nasdaq executives in choosing the other panel members.
"I feel very enthusiastic about the choice of the panel members, and I wanted the committee to be headed by someone with impeccable credentials for probity and integrity," said Mr. Levitt, who declined in a telephone interview to comment on his involvement in the panel's selection process. Mr. Levitt added that the caliber of the panel members "will in my view reinforce public confidence in the over-the-counter market."
The panel, to be called the Select Committee, was named by the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers. The purpose of the committee will be "to review all of the operations of Nasdaq, its governance, its regulatory role, and how it treats large and small investors," Mr. Rudman said.
Professor Marshall E. Blume of the Wharton School described the committee as "a very high-level group of people, in their integrity and knowledge of the regulatory process," adding: "But they don't have a good financial economist in that group, and they could use a high-level person from a corporate entity that raises capital through Nasdaq-type listings, since ultimately that's what these markets are about."
A. Jared Silverman, chief of the New Jersey Bureau of Securities, said the panel "is heavy on Federal regulators, but a lot of the complaints come in on the lower end of the market from investors, through the states."
In an interview, Mr. Hardiman said Nasdaq would have "important announcements" about changes in its market structure today or tomorrow. He declined to describe them, but an industry executive with knowledge of the announcement said Nasdaq planned to expand its limit-order protections to investors, in orders up to 1,000 shares between Jan. 1 and June 1. After that, he said, there would be no limit on the level of protection.
Under pressure from Mr. Levitt, Nasdaq proposed a rule to let many small buy orders be executed at the lower bid price rather than the higher asked price, if customers put in what is called a limit order. The S.E.C. has indicated that it wants to expand that rule, and Nasdaq appears to have complied.
Several class-action law suits have questioned the fairness of the Nasdaq market, and some investors have long awaited a change in the governance of the board, which is weighted toward industry members, to include more public members. Others have lobbied for stronger enforcement procedures and better disciplinary oversight.
Mr. Hardiman said the new committee's purview would not include issues that are the subject of litigation against Nasdaq market makers or are the subject of the Justice Department inquiry, because "there should be no interference with the Justice inquiry or civil litigation."
But Mr. Silverman, the New Jersey regulator, disagreed. "If you're doing a top-to-bottom study, you should be looking at all aspects of Nasdaq," he said, adding: "By roping off the antitrust area, you're not looking at the questions raised about the spreads, the small-order execution system, and questions about the problem brokers. And those are some of the key issues."
Mr. Rudman, although he has no direct experience with market trading, served for six years as chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, which supervises the S.E.C., and is a former attorney general in New Hampshire, where he prosecuted investor-fraud cases.
His committee "will look at that area, to see if the operations are carried out with fairness," he said, adding, "But we won't look at it through the same glass that the Department of Justice is looking at it."
He retired from the United States Senate in 1992, and is now a partner at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. Mr. Lynch, now a member of the board of trustees of the Fidelity group of funds, is the author of "Beating the Street," a book on investment strategies for small investors. Under Mr. Lynch, the Magellan Fund invested heavily in Nasdaq stocks.
Mr. Pollack, a former S.E.C. commissioner involved in the deregulation of the securities market, is now special counsel to the law firm of Storch & Brenner. Mr. Sommers, also a former S.E.C. commissioner, is chairman of the Public Oversight Board of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
The other committee members are Stephen L. Hammerman, vice chairman and general counsel of Merrill Lynch & Company and a former chairman of the N.A.S.D. board; Jean W. Gleason, a longtime securities lawyer who is a partner in the law firm of Fulbright & Jaworski and former director of the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, and Robert H. Mundheim, general counsel to Salomon Inc. and its Salomon Brothers subsidiary and former general counsel to the United States Treasury Department.
Mr. Hardiman's target for completion of the study is the end of March.
"I don't see that they will be able to do any new research in that time limit," Professor Blume said, "since realistically the first draft would have to be completed by the end of February."
Mr. Rudman said that the committee's work could be done by early spring, "since I'm not interested in dragging this out," adding, "But if that doesn't give us enough time, then we won't have it in by then."
Mr. Hardiman said he "doubted" that penny-stock frauds would be looked at by the committee, "since that issue is in hand." He added that although the committee is free to look at listing standards, "our standards exceed those of the American Stock Exchange."
However, Mr. Silverman commented, "There are stocks on exchanges listed that are sold with the same techniques that we found objectionable in the case of penny stocks." He added, "We think that's an area that needs to be looked at because it goes to the question of sales practices."
Mr. Rudman said he did not want to name specific areas the committee would investigate, "since we're going to meet and ask many people about what specific issues should be addressed."

HEADLINE: Melvin Eggers, 78, Syracuse University Chancellor

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Melvin A. Eggers, the chancellor of Syracuse University from 1971 to 1991, died yesterday at his home in DeWitt, a suburb of Syracuse. He was 78.
He had a long illness, said John Harvith, a spokesman for the university. 
 Dr. Eggers, who retired in August 1991, was the ninth chancellor at Syracuse, and also held the title of President. He was succeeded as chancellor by Kenneth A. Shaw, who said yesterday, "He has left this institution with a legacy for excellence."
And Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said "As one of my teachers and later as a colleague, Melvin Eggers set a standard for excellence that has helped me both as a professional and as a person."
Dr. Eggers is widely seen as having strengthened Syracuse academically. In the 1980's, while the university upgraded many of its academic programs, its enrollment flourished, 10 new buildings were opened, and its basketball and football teams became national powerhouses.
New construction in Dr. Eggers's era included the Carrier Dome, a 50,000-seat indoor sports complex that was built with the state's help.
But as time passed, the university suffered as the number of high school graduates declined and college costs rose steadily. The school also faced growing competition from the State University of New York.
By October 1991, Syracuse had lost about 1,700 undergraduates in two years. That loss was the primary cause of a $9.5 million budget deficit for the fiscal years 1990 through 1992. By October 1991, undergraduate enrollment was about 11,500 students.
At the time, Thonmas F. Cummings Jr., vice president for enrollment management and continuing education at Syracuse, said enrollments at Syracuse and at many other private colleges and universities where tuition had rapidly increased were being hurt by a recession-induced pinch on family incomes as well as stiffer competition among educational institutions for the fewer students then available.
Dr. Eggers was born in Fort Wayne, Ind., and earned bachelor's and master's degrees in econmics from Indiana University in 1940 and 1941, respectively. He received a Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1950.
During the academic career that then unfolded, he co-wrote several books and articles on economics. He joined the Syracuse faculty in 1950 as an assistant professor of economics and rose to be chairman of the economics department before being appointed provost and vice chancellor for academic affairs.
Dr. Eggers is survived by his wife, the former Mildred Chenoweth, a brother, Oscar, of Prairie Village, Kan.; a daughter, Nancy Beilstein of Tustin, Calif; two sons, William of Pittsford, N.Y., and Richard of Manhattan, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Why Neil Simon Decided to Turn His Back on Broadway

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
In his still-definitive 1969 book about the Broadway theater, "The Season," William Goldman predicted that virtually all straight plays would soon be Off Broadway. The reason, he argued, was simple: the high costs "make doing anything but mass appeal plays a lunatic Broadway venture."
There is no playwright with more mass appeal than Neil Simon, and it has taken 25 years for the prediction to come true for him. But America's richest, best-known playwright is hunting for a 500-seat Off Broadway theater for his newest comedy, "London Suite." 
 That news was followed by a second thrust through Broadway's doublet: "Angels in America," the Tony- and Pulitzer-winning play that became one of the theatrical events of the decade, will close next month at a loss of $660,000.
How could this happen?
The answer is basic economics. While big musicals are raking in record amounts on Broadway -- "Showboat" is selling more than $900,000 worth of tickets a week and "Sunset Boulevard" is opening with a $37 million advance -- the returns on plays are so meager and unpredictable that Off Broadway is not only a hedge against disaster, but a good bet for making money.
Taking that bet, Mr. Simon's producer, Emanuel Azenberg, agreed to open his calculations to scrutiny. By his reckoning, he would have to raise $1.6 million to mount the show on Broadway, but only $660,000 to do it Off Broadway. With the lower operating costs, he said, the numbers add up: "Off Broadway, 400 seats at $40 makes me a smash. On Broadway, 400 seats at $55 closes me down. You tell me -- what makes sense?"
Off Broadway, in fact, has become so attractive that the biggest brake on producers is that there are so few comfortable, convenient theaters.
Audiences are willing to buy $40 tickets. Labor is nonunion. Shows that do well can still earn the "they loved it in New York" label needed to go to London and on tour. And while it takes a smash hit to make money on Broadway, Off Broadway a critics' darling, a snob special or a merely popular comedy can turn a profit.
Even though a 500-seat Off Broadway house can sell only $160,000 worth of tickets a week while a 1,000-seat Broadway house can theoreticaly sell over $400,000 worth, the smaller venue's running costs are so much lower that the profit margin is greater.
There are many equations in a production budget, but the crucial one running through the producer's mind is: If we don't flop, how soon do we turn a profit?
"In the old days -- up to 1970 or '75 -- you could do 100 performances of a comedy and recoup with a healthy profit," said Frederick M. Zollo, who produces plays on and off Broadway, "Angels" among them. "Not any more."
Most shows have eight performances a week, so 20 years ago, by Mr. Zollo's calculations, they would earn profits shortly after 12 weeks. Today, if a Broadway play costs $1 million to mount -- and that's dirt cheap -- and ends each week $50,000 to the good, it "earns out" in 20 weeks. Twenty weeks times $50,000 is, however, ridiculously optimistic nowadays.
"Millennium Approaches," the first half of "Angels," opened on May 4, 1993, and is to close Dec. 4. That's 83 weeks. It cost $2.2 million to mount and about $200,000 a week to run. At closing, it will still owe investors $660,000. (The second half, "Perestroika," was mounted with a $1.4 million loan, since repaid.)
"Angels" is not typical because it was lavish, seven hours long and broken into two parts. It may yet recoup from tour, regional and movie income. "I'm optimistic about that, I'm even bullish," said Margo Lion, one of the producers.
But as far as Broadway is concerned, it's a financial bust. Mr. Simon has far less to fear because his comedies about feuding heterosexual couples and television comedy writers are more likely to earn years of royalties from suburban dinner theaters than is a "gay fantasia on national themes." His "Jake's Women," which lost money on its seven-month run on Broadway in 1992, is now $100,000 in the black.
But even if "London Suite" was a big hit, not earning out quickly could be dangerous. Rave reviews fade. The original cast leaves. Ads that once looked fresh turn yellow on the page. The winter slump follows the summer slump, the Labor Day-Yom Kippur double whammy fades into record snowstorms: producers have no shortage of excuses for bad weeks.
Here is how Mr. Azenberg figures his Off Broadway prospects:
"Six actors, one set, only a few props change. I don't have to get marquee names. On Broadway, you'd be smarter if you did, and that's not easy to achieve."
Off Broadway theaters use nonunion stagehands, ushers and box-office workers. The biggest expense is "loading in": installing the set and lighting it. Loading "London Suite" Off Broadway would cost $8,000, Mr. Azenberg's staff calculated: 12 workers at $13 an hour, with dinner if they put in more than eight hours. On Broadway, it would cost $175,000: 30 to 35 men (because carpenter, electrician and props jobs are separate), getting $25 to $37 an hour, along with vacation pay, benefits and payroll taxes that bring the producer's cost to $41 to $61 an hour. Plus overtime at up to $90 an hour.
"You're taking something made of plywood and canvas and putting it up at the cost of a house with plumbing and a foundation that would last 300 years," Mr. Azenberg said.
"Load-in" costs include running the theater. A typical Broadway box office has five employees costing, with benefits, $1,150 a week each. An Off Broadway office has two, costing $550 a week each.
For advertising before and just after the opening, Mr. Azenberg would spend $350,000 on Broadway, but at most $100,000 Off Broadway, most of that on posters and newspaper ads. "Off Broadway, you're not permitted the illusion that advertising will bring in an audience," he said. "You know word of mouth does it."
The $1.6 million Broadway capitalization would be $660,000 Off Broadway. But only $440,000 of that would actually be spent. (All productions raise more than they must spend. The difference is a cushion against a flop: for refunds, advances against royalties and bonds posted with the unions. If the show flies, the investors get the money back.)
"The ticket price will be $37.50 to $40," he said. "Five hundred seats times 8 performances a week times $40 a seat is $160,000. You take 20 percent off for discounts and theater parties. That's $128,000. Now, if the show costs me $60,000 a week to run, even if I did only 80 percent of $128,000, I still make $25,000-plus a week after paying royalties. If I can do that for only 18 weeks, I pay off the $440,000.
"To do that, I only need to sell 400 seats a night. You do that on Broadway, you're out of business."
And the logic is compelling. How hard can it be to find 400 people a night who want to see Neil Simon, especially if they think they're getting him wholesale?
One need only look at how other name playwrights have fared recently -- Albee, Miller, Mamet, Wasserstein -- to follow the trend.
Edward Albee's latest play, "Three Tall Women," has been at the Promenade, a 400-seat Off Broadway theater, for seven months. It has three actresses, one set and six costumes. Elizabeth I. McCann, the lead producer, said she raised $375,000 -- and spent only $214,000 -- because the cast and set were already assembled by the Vineyard Theater. "If we'd had to do it from scratch, it would probably have cost $475,000," she said.
The play recouped its investment in the first eight weeks.
"We have 100 lighting instruments in the air, while a Broadway house has 1,000, easily," she said. "Our costumes come off the rack -- at Bloomingdale's, but still. . . . On Broadway, for whatever reason, most are specially made, even if they're contemporary."
She refused to go into her weekly running costs because she fears that Mr. Azenberg has his eye on the Promenade, which is fairly pleasant for an Off Broadway house and conveniently on the Upper West Side. As it turns out, she's right.
Arthur Miller's newest play, "Broken Glass," closed in January after running at the Booth Theater on Broadway for nine weeks. It lost $700,000 of its $800,000 capitalization, said Robert Whitehead, the lead producer. In retrospect, he said, he wishes he had done the play under auspices of the Broadway Alliance, a union-producer agreement that cuts costs at some theaters in return for caps on ticket prices. But the Booth was not an Alliance theater, he said, and his cast would not have accepted the $2,500 salary cap.
Wendy Wasserstein's play "The Sisters Rosensweig" was that rarity, a smash hit.
David Mamet's two-character, one-set "Oleanna" is a movie now, but it ran at the Orpheum Theater on Second Avenue for 15 months. It was capitalized in 1992 for $325,000, of which only $230,000 was actually spent, said Mr. Zollo, the lead producer.
On a good week, with most of the 350 seats selling for $35, it grossed about $95,000. Weekly expenses were $39,000 plus royalties and extra rent based on the gross, for a total of about $56,000.
"It could spin off nearly $40,000 a week," Mr. Zollo said. "It made over $1 million just Off Broadway. Then it had very successful tours and a London production."
Off Broadway, Mr. Zollo also produced "Marvin's Room" by Scott McPherson, "Key Exchange" by Kevin Wade and "Sex, Drugs and Rock-and-Roll" and "Pounding Nails Into the Floor With My Forehead," both by Eric Bogosian.
" 'Marvin's Room,' didn't quite break even," he said. " 'Sex, Drugs' cost $120,000 to put on and made a lot of money at the Orpheum. 'Key Exchange' did very well. 'Pounding Nails' cost $200,000 and did well."
"If we'd put 'Pounding Nails' on Broadway," he added, "It would have cost more than $200,000 just for the sets."
"I don't see any light at the end of the tunnel," he added. "I don't see anything making it on Broadway except a British play that has an imprimatur, or a star vehicle."
Mr. Simon and Mr. Azenberg apparently agree.
"When Neil and I started talking about doing this," Mr. Azenberg said, "he asked, 'What would it cost?' I said '$500,000.' He said, 'We could lose that much; it would be O.K.' Believe me, he's not worried about the money any more. He wants people to see his play. And he wants the investors to get their money back."
Mr. Simon puts up most of his own backing, but his other investors are people who have been in on earlier Azenberg or Simon vehicles, relatives and old friends -- some decidedly not rich.
"But it's not just the investors," Mr. Azenberg said. "You need the theater to be a venue where a playwright can make a living. Otherwise, he's a screenwriter."

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The Economics of Prenatal Care

 BODY:
Fearing that purely altruistic social arguments would never carry the day, health care advocates have long claimed that the expense of offering prenatal care to poor women would be more than offset by the savings in preventing premature births and other costly problems. But now Dr. Frederick Cornell, who directs maternal and child-health programs at the University of Washington in Seattle, and Dr. Jane Huntington, a Seattle internist, have analyzed the more than 100 papers on which that contention was based -- and found them flawed.
Those who do not receive timely prenatal care are predominantly poor minorities at high risk of having premature and low-birth-weight babies. Reducing that risk, the doctors say, takes a kind of care -- identifying and treating drug and alcohol abuse, for example -- far more comprehensive than that provided by the average prenatal program. That takes more money. 
 The new study does not prove that prenatal care does not save money; it merely says the evidence cited is inadequate to prove that it does. But cost should not be the criterion for providing that care. In a society as advanced and wealthy as ours, prenatal care should be provided to all.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Self-Deportation?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The victory in California of the movement to deny schooling and medical services to illegal immigrants who are not actually bleeding to death is the first skirmish in the war on unwed welfare mothers.
That's because both Proposition 187 (punishing some 300,000 alien schoolchildren for the sins of their fathers) and the Gingrich approach to welfare reform (withholding support when unemployed single mothers have additional children) are based on this philosophy: the most cost-effective way to change behavior is to make life unbearable under present behavior. 
 During the recent resurgence of righteousness, Gov. Pete Wilson of California was described in this space as "the best candidate with the worst issue" and Prop. 187, which he strongly supported, was denounced as a "nativist abomination."
I came to admire him when, as a Senator, he exposed the abuse of the franking privilege by incumbents. Early this year I reported Richard Nixon's prediction that a California comeback victory would make Wilson the front-runner for the '96 Republican nomination -- and if running-mated with Gov. Christy Whitman of New Jersey, the ticket would win. Visiting Washington last week, Pete Wilson invited me over to screw my head back on properly.
About the nativism charge: he is eager it be understood that he is not anti-immigrant, only anti-illegal immigrant. "One in four Californians are legal immigrants," he says, "and don't need lectures on the contributions of legal immigrants. In fact, they are the most vociferous critics of illegal immigration. . . . The issue is the rule of law."
O.K., with a sizeable portion of voting Latinos in favor of curbing their illegal competitors, let's grant that most of the proposition's supporters are neither nativist nor racist. Support from those who resent all immigrants, legal and not, surely came Wilson's way, but it does not mean he shares their prejudices.
About the privacy-intrusion charge, turning teachers into immigration agents: "Teachers don't enroll students," Wilson says, implying it is only the administrators' job and not the teachers'. He says that school districts everywhere ask for proof of residence, and adds that all applicants to Federal jobs must produce verifiable citizenship documents. (He's against national ID cards.)
Maybe he can bolster that defense of 187 in court with regulations against discrimination or intrusion in its enforcement. But no administrative amelioration is likely to alter the requirement that schools have reverse truant officers assigned to root out those sneaky little offspring of illegales trying to cop a freebie education (to which the Supreme Court has ruled they are entitled, and with conservative justices, stare decisis ain't dead yet.)
What's Wilson's purpose in all this? To get budget-cutting Washington to reimburse California $2.5 billion a year for state services to the illegals? To get the Feds to stem the tide of invaders, many of whom sashay in as tourists?
Yes to both, but more: "If it's clear to you that you cannot be employed, and that you and your family are ineligible for services, you will self-deport."
I take the import of that to be: make 'em so miserable that they leave the country. To which many law-abiding Americans, especially tax-burdened Californians, would say: Hooray!
Ebenezer Scrooge is my hero, too, but that neatly theoretical "economic disincentive" won't disincent -- because being miserable here doesn't compare with the misery they ran away from.
Do we really want to drive most illegal families deeper underground, many to lives of crime? Would we rather have 300,000 children on the streets, learning costly delinquency -- or safely in school, becoming potential citizens and taxpayers?
Pete Wilson wants an immigration plank in the Republican platform. Fine; it should include Federal reimbursement, amnesty, border control -- but none of this creation of an uneducated, unmedicated underground.
After our talk, I am prepared to withdraw the charge that 187 is driven primarily by nativism. But in terms of practicality and of the American spirit, a government policy of making any child's life miserable is still an abomination.

HEADLINE: DOLE TIES SUPPORT OF TRADE ACCORD TO TAX CONCESSION

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Seeking to wring concessions from a politically weakened White House, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas said today that he had told Clinton Administration officials that he would be more inclined to vote for a worldwide trade pact if the White House dropped certain objections to a cut in the capital gains tax.
Administration officials said today that they had promptly dismissed the offer made by Senator Dole, the likely majority leader. 
 Senator Dole's proposal was the latest Republican effort to gain as many concessions as possible from the White House in exchange for supporting the pact. The Administration has already agreed to address some of Mr. Dole's previous demands in return for his support, provoking criticism of Mr. Dole by more conservative Republicans for not driving a hard enough bargain.
Mr. Dole said today on the ABC news program "This Week" that he made his latest proposal during a meeting on Saturday with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen; Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, and Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff.
Mr. Panetta said this afternoon on the CNN news program "Late Edition," "I don't think he's going to get a commitment from us that we're going to suddenly support a capital gains tax cut," particularly as part of the trade accord.
In a telephone interview this evening, Mr. Kantor declined to comment on Mr. Dole's linking of taxes and trade, but said that the Administration was still trying to allay his concerns about the trade pact itself. Mr. Kantor said that the Administration "made good progress this weekend" to find the votes to pass the agreement.
If approved, the 124-nation trade accord would reduce tariffs around the world and extend the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, to farming and service industries like accounting. It would also create a World Trade Organization to referee international trade disputes.
Until today, Mr. Dole's most strenuous objections had focused on whether the pact would undermine American sovereignty.
Without Senator Dole's support, the accord, which is awaiting debate next week in a special session of Congress, could die in the Senate where it faces a particularly difficult test. The chamber's rules require at least 60 senators to waive a requirement that the pact's tariff reductions be balanced with extra taxes or spending cuts.
Mr. Dole said today that the waiver should be coupled with a change in the Administration stance on capital gains taxes. "You're going to make money with a capital gains rate reduction," he said. "And according to Treasury, you lose a lot of money. And we'd like to say, 'Well, come on now, if we're going to waive the budget on GATT, maybe we can waive the budget on what you suggest capital gains may be scored.' " Mr. Dole was referring to the way that policy makers count, or score, the effects of tax cuts.
Mr. Dole said that lower taxes on capital gains -- the increase in value of stocks, bonds and business investments -- would increase Federal revenue.
But the Joint Tax Committee of Congress and the Treasury Department have long calculated that any cut in capital gains taxes would cost the Government billions of dollars in revenue, with the exact amount depending on the depth of the cut. And the Administration wants spending cuts to balance any loss in Federal revenues.
Republicans have contended that such calculations vastly overstate the cost of the cut because they exclude the effects that a capital gains tax would have on the overall economy.
The Republican position, which Mr. Dole called today for the Administration to adopt, is that a capital gains tax cut would help the entire American economy by encouraging people to sell long-held stocks, bonds and business holdings and invest the proceeds in other, more productive businesses. As these more productive businesses expanded, Republicans say, the extra tax revenue from them would make up for the money lost in the original tax cuts.
If the Republican approach of looking at a tax cut's overall economic effect, known as dynamic scoring, were adopted, then Congress could approve a cut in the capital gains tax without matching spending cuts. But Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, strongly criticized the scoring method at a breakfast with reporters last Tuesday, saying it would lead to much larger Federal budget deficits.
As recently as Thursday, Mr. Bentsen said in an interview that any tax cuts would have to be fully balanced with spending cuts, and his press secretary, Joan Logue-Kinder, repeated this position today.
In the Reagan and Bush Administrations, Republicans, including Mr. Dole, generally spoke in favor of the pact. But strong opposition from conservative Republicans, who contend that the World Trade Organization would undermine American sovereignty, have made it hard for potential Presidential candidates like Mr. Dole to support the deal.
Wall Street firms and business executives have long sought lower capital gains taxes. But making such a cut has proved politically infeasible without a broad tax cut for less wealthy Americans, and because budget rules require that a tax cut be offset with spending cuts or increases in other taxes. The budget rules are aimed at shrinking the growth of the Federal deficit.
Although eager to strike a tough bargain with the Administration on trade, Mr. Dole toned down the rhetoric on other issues coming from some of his Republican colleagues in recent days.
For example, he tried to smooth over the dispute touched off by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the incoming chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who said on Friday that he thought Mr. Clinton was unfit to be Commander in Chief of the United States military.
"I must say, I had reservations early on," Mr. Dole said. "I think he's up to the job now."
Mr. Clinton is "doing better all the time," Mr. Dole said, citing American efforts to keep peace and install a democratically elected government in Haiti, as well as to continue efforts toward peace in the Middle East.
"Jesse was just giving his opinion," Mr. Dole said. "I think he'd rather have another Commander in Chief."
On CNN, Mr. Panetta called Senator Helms's comments "reckless." He added, "They send terrible signals abroad to both our enemies and our allies about our ability to come together on foreign affairs issues."
Mr. Dole also voiced doubt that a constitutional amendment allowing organized prayer in schools could pass.
"I don't think we ought to get bogged down" on such divisive matters, Mr. Dole said
He added, "If we're going to bring about change, we better bring up some measures we can pass, so the American people will get the message that we're serious about it."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about Senator Bob Dole's linking of support for a world trade pact to a cut in the capital gains tax referred incorrectly in some editions to the relationship between a tax cut and a change in Federal budget rules. If the overall economic effects of a tax cut are counted in a manner suggested by Republicans, it can be enacted without matching cuts in Federal spending.

HEADLINE: Takeover Fight Transfixes the Swiss

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZURICH, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In Switzerland, discreet finance and genteel business manners are a way of life, and the rare corporate takeover is quietly handled behind closed doors.
 But now the Swiss are getting their full share of a knock-down, drag-out fight over control of the country's largest financial institution, the Union Bank of Switzerland. The bank is so big that its global assets nearly equal Switzerland's gross national product, but that has not put off Martin Ebner, a rich, brash Swiss financier whose actions are in the tradition of American takeover specialists like Carl C. Icahn and T. Boone Pickens. 
Mr. Ebner, who controls 16 percent of Union Bank's voting shares, wants to reshape the giant from an institution that offers almost every banking service and earns a respectable profit into a lean bank concentrating on high-profit private banking and securities underwriting.
 The current managers, he asserts, are trying to hold on to their jobs and are sluggish and lack innovation. Their institution far underperforms the banks he idolizes most, he says, like J. P. Morgan and Wells Fargo in the United States and Lloyds Bank of London.
 Not surprisingly, executives at Union Bank profoundly disagree. They note that the bank, with a 25 percent share of the Swiss mortgage market, cannot freely move mortgage rates up and down as international money markets and their rates shift. In 1991, for example, Robert Studer, the bank's chief executive, was called to testify before Parliament to explain why the bank pushed its lending rates up one-half of a percentage point.
 The furor over the Union Bank battle has made for a frenzied Swiss press. One Zurich daily is running a 12-part series on the battle and a financial daily, Cash, is offering prizes totaling $32,000 to those who most closely guess how much of the proxy vote Mr. Ebner and U.B.S. get at a special shareholders meeting scheduled for Tuesday.
 What is at stake is not just control of Union Bank but also its role as a Swiss institution. To address the perceived threat, the bank's board has scheduled the special shareholders meeting, at which the board hopes to pass a resolution that would radically reduce the voting power of Mr. Ebner's stock and that of investors who support him.
 "Mr. Ebner's objective is not for U.B.S. to live as a healthy bank for the next 200 years and be a support to the Swiss economy," Mr. Studer said. "He wants us to focus on areas that require much less capital, and then take the excess capital we have built up and hand it over to shareholders to make them rich."
 What has turned into a national debate on entrenched management versus investor greed is playing out in a rapidly changing corporate environment. For decades Switzerland was renowned as a closed country, veiled in bank secrecy, that left wealthy Swiss families and big financial groups in control of Swiss institutions. While bank secrecy remains, the Government is trying to broaden ownership of many hallowed financial institutions, primarily to make sure they will be able to tap the growing international capital markets.
 During the summer, Parliament approved a law that stops Swiss banks from refusing to sell so-called registered shares with special voting powers to foreigners. Since the 1970's, the Government had limited the sale of registered shares to the Swiss, to keep control of its banks, it said, out of the hands of Arab investors and drug cartels.
 In 1992, Parliament passed a similar law removing ownership restrictions on industrial corporations. And by the end of next year it is expected to relax its restrictions on foreign ownership of Swiss real estate.
 But even as politicians seek to bring in more foreign capital, they resist the idea of foreign control. The new banking law that takes effect on Jan. 1, for example, requires that an individual or corporation whose holdings reach 10 percent of a bank's shares must notify banking authorities of that holding, and grants the authorities the right to revoke the voting rights on the shares if they deem that person unfit to influence the institution.
 Similarly, a law that will go into effect next year will make greenmail more difficult and hostile takeovers more costly by requiring anyone who buys one-third of a company's stock to make an offer to the company's remaining shareholders. That would make it difficult for someone to gain effective control with a minority stake.
 Mr. Ebner has been the Union Bank's largest shareholder since 1991, after he persuaded Swiss pension funds to bankroll his company, BK Bank Zurich AG, which became a major shareholder in U.B.S.
 Through BK Bank Zurich, he began criticizing the management of Union Bank, and in 1993 he complained vigorously when the bank's board removed a director, Christoph Blocher, a prominent right-wing industrialist who strongly opposed any attempt by Switzerland to join the European Union.
 Mr. Ebner also holds stock in Union Bank through BK Vision AG, an investment company in which the Rolex Holding Group, which makes the famous watches, is a major shareholder.
 At the bank's annual meeting this year, Mr. Ebner proposed that the board be trimmed to 9 directors from 23, arguing that it would streamline the bank and make it more innovative. Although his plan was voted down, he won 40 percent of the vote, which frightened the bank's management. Soon thereafter, Mr. Studer and the chairman, Nikolaus Senn, began trying to figure out how to reduce Mr. Ebner's voting power.
 Mr. Ebner's strategy was built on his recognition that the bank's registered shares, which could be owned only by Swiss nationals, were out of favor because of their limited liquidity, and were valued at roughly one-fifth of the bearer shares that could be owned by anyone. Yet both types of shares have equal voting rights, so Mr. Ebner realized that he could have five times the voting power by buying registered shares.
 To head off Mr. Ebner, Mr. Senn and Mr. Studer decided to propose at the company's 1995 annual meeting that a new type of share be created, for which all existing shares would be exchanged -- but with the exchange reflecting market value, so that each registered share would get one new share, but each bearer share would get five. That would leave Mr. Ebner with a hopelessly weakened position.
 After Mr. Ebner approached the bank's management during the summer and said he was close to cementing support for a controlling interest in the bank, the board decided it could not wait until 1995 and called for Tuesday's special shareholder meeting.
 The bank's return has averaged about 10 percent in recent years, a level Mr. Studer says is high given the large reserves the bank has to keep. Not so, argues Mr. Ebner, who says Union Bank could have returns in the 15 to 20 percent range, similar to that of institutions like Morgan and Lloyds.
 Mr. Ebner seems to practice what he preaches, operating out of a comfortable but far from lavish office on the top floor of a shopping center building. BK Bank has no secretaries and no corporate cars and invests solely in a handful of stocks it considers undervalued. Mr. Ebner likes to take large positions in companies and then try to influence management to become more efficient and profitable.
 But if Mr. Ebner loses the vote on Tuesday, he might lose something else that analysts have said he is looking for -- respect.
 "Until now he counted on being part of the Zurich financial establishment," said Hans Kaufman, chief of Swiss research at Bank Julius Baer in Zurich. "That is his great goal. But if he loses this, he loses face and will always remain an outsider."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 1, 1995, Wednesay

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Nov. 21 discussed a battle over the owner ship of the Union Bank of Switzer land. It recounted recent moves to permit more foreign investment in Swiss companies, including banks, after years of tight restrictions. Re calling the evolution of the banking law over the last 20 years, the article referred to what legislators and bankers perceived as a threat from "Arab investors and drug cartels."
In referring to Arab investors, the article should have made it clear that in the 1970's, as the Swiss were drawing up the legislation, it was aimed at Middle Eastern countries that had just acquired huge amounts of money from oil and were invest ing around the world.
 The article should not have linked the concern about those Middle Eastern countries to a debate about possible investment by drug cartels; the legislators' discussion of a threat from drug money occurred a decade later.
Letters from an Arab-owned in vestment group, challenging the No vember account of the Swiss events, prompted a review of the article.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. PROPOSAL WOULD OVERHAUL WELFARE SYSTEM

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Republican team taking over the House of Representatives will propose a welfare bill that eliminates a decades-old guiding principle of poverty and food programs: that anyone who qualifies for these benefits automatically gets them.
Under the proposal drafted by House Republicans for submission in January, Congress would set an overall annual limit on welfare spending and replace food stamps and child-nutrition programs with a lump sum payment to each state. 
 The Republicans would consolidate 10 nutrition programs into a "food assistance block grant," cut the available money by 5 percent and then set a limit on future spending. The limit would be adjusted for increases in population and food prices in the prior year.
The programs to be consolidated in this way include food stamps, the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children and the school lunch and breakfast programs. The food stamp program costs $25 billion a year and helps feed 27 million people. The program for women, infants and children, or WIC, serves 6.2 million people at a cost of $3.1 billion a year. The school lunch program costs $4.5 billion a year and feeds 25 million children a day.
House Republicans said today that the bill would also require state welfare officials to provide the Federal Government with information to help identify illegal immigrants. The proposal would also curtail aid to aliens, both those who are in the United States illegally and many of those who are legal residents.
Each of the bill's proposals is big enough to insure long, impassioned debate next year, but one is particularly striking.
Under the Republican bill, people now eligible for welfare, food stamps and free school lunches would no longer have a legally enforceable right to such assistance. Instead of such "entitlements," specific sums would be appropriated each year for food assistance and welfare. If the money ran out before the end of the year, benefits could be scaled back, people could be removed from the rolls or new applicants could be turned away, depending on state decisions.
House Republicans, led by Newt Gingrich, the Speaker-in-waiting, have said they will bring the bill to the floor within the first 100 days of the next Congress, as promised in their 10-point "Contract With America." A copy of the bill was obtained by The New York Times from state officials who have been following the issue and meeting with House Republicans.
As such, it will be a focus of debate in the House next year and appears to have a better chance of passage than any other welfare bill. But to become law, it will have to pass the Senate, where some senior Republicans have supported expansion of food programs. It would also be subject to approval by President Clinton. Mr. Clinton's willingness to veto measures he opposes, and his ability to sustain those vetoes, are two of the imponderables of the next Congress. A veto can be overridden by a two-thirds vote of each chamber.
While Mr. Clinton has called for overhauling the welfare system, he has focused on job training and limits on the duration of welfare payments, not on food programs.
The Republican bill would repeal the Food Stamp Act of 1977, the Child Nutrition Act of 1966, the National School Lunch Act of 1946, the Emergency Food Assistance Act of 1983 and several other Federal laws intended to prevent hunger.
It would replace the money allocated under those laws with the new block grant, which states would use for the general purpose of food assistance but without having to follow the detailed nutrition standards set by existing laws and regulations. Current rules say, for example, that school lunches must supply at least one-third of the recommended dietary allowance for various nutrients. In addition, under the proposal, states could provide people with cash instead of food stamps.
Republicans said their proposal would save money and force Congress to face up to the cost of welfare and food assistance, rather than continue these programs on autopilot.
But Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the Democrat who has been chairman of the Agriculture Committee for eight years, said the Republican proposal would "lead to a dramatic increase in hunger and will leave states stranded to deal with the fallout on their own." He said he had worked closely with Republican senators like Bob Dole of Kansas and Richard G. Lugar of Indiana to strengthen food programs.
Mr. Lugar is expected to become chairman of the Agriculture Committee. Mr. Dole, who is in line to be the new Majority Leader, said in 1982 that "the Federal Government should retain primary responsibility for child nutrition programs," and he noted that President Richard M. Nixon expressed the same view in 1969.
Officials of two groups that advocate Government assistance for needy people, Edward M. Cooney, deputy director of the Food Research and Action Center, and Isaac Shapiro, acting co-director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said the Republican proposal would hamper the Government's ability to respond to urgent need.
"In the event of a recession," Mr. Shapiro said, "the need for food assistance increases sharply, but the food stamp program would not be able to expand to meet the need," because of the Republican plan's spending limits. In late 1991 and early 1992, food stamp rolls sometimes grew by more than 300,000 people a month, and the number of recipients soared to more than 24 million.
In a further effort to control spending on social welfare programs, the House Republican plan would deny most forms of assistance to people who were not citizens, including many legal aliens.
State welfare officials would have to provide the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service with "the name, address and other identifying information" on illegal aliens whose children were United States citizens.
The Republican bill, the Personal Responsibility Act, lists 60 programs for which illegal aliens and many legal aliens would be ineligible. These include Medicaid, maternal and child health care, community health centers, migrant health centers, the school lunch and breakfast programs, the WIC. program, public housing, child immunizations, job training, aid to homeless people and the screening of youngsters to detect lead poisoning.
This proposed ban is similar to one approved this month by the voters of California, in Proposition 187. Civil liberties groups and some Hispanic organizations are challenging the California measure in court, saying it violates the constitutional guarantee of equal protection of the laws.
Under current law, illegal aliens are ineligible for most major Federal and state benefit programs, but they may get emergency medical care under Medicaid, and mothers with small children can get supplemental food assistance. In addition, the Supreme Court has said children who are illegal aliens may not be denied a free public education. Presumably, some of these children get school lunches, because there is no test of citizenship or alien status.
Legal aliens, especially permanent residents of the United States, are currently eligible for most Government benefits available to citizens, like education and housing assistance. The Republican proposal would make aliens ineligible for many of these.
But the restrictions would not apply to refugees, to emergency medical services or to permanent resident aliens who are over 75 and have lived in the United States for at least five years.
The Republicans' bill would also, for the first time, set a limit on the growth of Federal spending for welfare programs, including Aid to Families with Dependent Children; Supplemental Security Income, for elderly, blind and disabled people, and on 15 types of housing assistance for low-income people.
In general, the bill says, the states would not be allowed to pay welfare benefits for a child whose paternity had not been established, nor could the states provide welfare benefits for children born out of wedlock to women under the age of 18.
Money saved from these restrictions would be returned to the states as block grants to provide services, but not cash payments, to help young mothers with illegitimate children. The money could be used "to establish and operate orphanages," to operate group homes for unwed mothers, to promote adoption and to reduce out-of-wedlock births, the bill says.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Republican Party may have swept to power in Congress, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia may be in line to be the House Speaker and to propose the "Contrast With America" plan to overhaulo welfare, but that does not mean everything is perfect for the Republicans. Mr. Gingrich waited, vainly, for a missing bag at an airline luggage carousel in the Atlanta airport yesterday. (Michael A. Schwarz for The New York Times) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Ukraine Leader, Dogged by Economic Woes, to Meet Clinton

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 21

 BODY:
When the Ukrainian leader, Leonid Kuchma, meets with President Clinton at the White House on Tuesday, he will very likely be praised for moving in the last month to reform the economy and to persuade his truculent Parliament to rid the nation of nuclear weapons.
The Parliament's ratification last week of the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear arms means that the long-sought goal of eliminating those weapons is a done deal. But living up to tough economic conditions set by the International Monetary Fund last month is hitting road blocks. 
 Already, the leftist Parliament, led by the powerful Olexandre O. Morov, the chairman of Ukraine's Socialist Party, is threatening to overturn President Kuchma's decrees and oppose the elements of his package of economic reforms.
And in the countryside, where managers of collective farms and factories have watched inflation soar, energy become scarce and their prices plummet, there are severe doubts about I.M.F. reforms.
With 52 million people in an area about the size of France, Ukraine is the second most populous country from the former Soviet Union and now one of the most economically depressed. Despite a potentially rich agricultural sector and a technologically advanced industrial base, the economy has been badly mismanaged since independence in 1991.
Last week, a Ukrainian toilet paper plant announced that it was recycling the local currency, known as coupons, to make its product.
Earlier this year, the United States doubled its foreign aid to Ukraine to $700 million for 1994, making it the fourth largest recipient, after Israel, Egypt and Russia. As little as 10 percent of the aid is actually being spent, however, an American official said.
[In Washington, Administration officials speaking on condition of anonimity said President Clinton would offer Mr. Kuchma a total of $900 million in aid in their meeting, an increase of $200 million beyond amounts already in the pipeline.]
In return for Ukraine's first I.M.F. loan, for $371 million, Mr. Kuchma and the president of the National Bank, Viktor Yuschenko, moved in recent weeks toward liberalizing prices, freeing trade restrictions, reducing the budget deficit and stabilizing the exchange rate of the almost worthless coupon.
Bread, milk and meat prices as much as tripled in recent weeks. Mass transit and electricity prices have gone up dramatically, too.
But in other areas, there appeared to be some early back-tracking. The Government lifted export licenses but in their place the foreign trade ministry introduced new registration requirements, which exporters say are another form of bureauracy intended to stall legal export.
In an indication of how rocky the reform path would be, Mr. Morov said in an interview today that he opposed Mr. Kuchma's decree on land reform. He said a decree last week authorizing farmers to buy and sell land on collectivized farms violated the constitution.
Mr. Morov charged further that the reforms were turning land "into a commodity," and that such a step was "unreasonable, to put it mildly."
In contrast, Mr. Kuchma's chief economic strategist, First Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Pynzenyk, said last week that the private ownership of land was the most important step toward market reform and "if such an initiative is not undertaken, nothing can go forward."
Mr. Pynzenyk was referring in part to World Bank import rehabilitation loans of more than $300 million that have strict privatization requirements tied to them.

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
It's Time, Again, to Talk of Cabbages, Not Kings

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 21

 BODY:
"How much do you charge for delivery?" a customer asked, leaning on the handlebars of his bicycle in front of a truck- sized heap of cabbage on the side of the street in western Beijing.
"Charge for delivery?" Wang Zhenping fired back in a mocking tone that turned a few heads in the Horse Tail Gully vegetable market. "Did you just crawl out of a cave or something? It's free!" 
 The great cabbage migration has begun, and it's a buyer's market.
Mountains of Chinese cabbage -- 396 million pounds by the reckoning of the Beijing authorities -- began advancing on the capital this month, as one of old Beijing's agricultural rhythms persists against the onslaught of modern supermarkets and glitzy shopping centers that have sprouted here.
Rough-hewn peasants who have been sleeping with their crops for weeks in a 100-mile arc of farmland outside Beijing have converged for the annual ritual of selling what was once a survival crop for many Chinese.
They come in trucks, horse-drawn carts and pedal-powered three-wheelers, all straining under billowing loads of cabbage that within the space of a week fill acres of sidewalks and alleyway space.
Ten thousand city workers help the farmers with a fleet of 1,400 trucks, which haul cabbage to 500 city-run markets.
From these and from hundreds of freelance cabbage heaps, the hawking begins.
"People will always buy cabbage," Mr. Wang said. "That's the food you get through the winter on."
Lan Wei, a 26-year-old worker in a state factory who was out marketing the other day, said, "In the past, there used to be nothing else to eat."
Smiling, she repeated a ditty of the Communist era, "When you've got your winter cabbage, in your heart you feel secure."
Buying winter cabbage is no simple chore. Volume is the key, as is buying early to get the best price, as little as a penny per pound.
"It used to be that people would get in long lines and really stock up on the stuff -- 400 to 500 pounds," Ms. Lan said. It was stacked on balconies and in stairwells and hung outside windows as a strategic food reserve for every family.
By December it freezes and turns black from the coal soot that makes China's wintertime air famous for its density, but Beijingers just peel away the outside leaves and plop it in boiling water.
"You can fry it, you can make it into dumplings, you can put it into soup," said Wang Yanhong, a young woman who works for an American company in Beijing. She defended it against the disdain of today's youth in China.
"It's not that all young people don't like it," she said, "It's the same as any vegetable. If you eat it every day, you'll get sick of it."
Ms. Lan said that "in recent years, a lot of cabbage hasn't been sold."
The reason is that prosperity, greenhouse farming and year-round vegetable crops shipped from southern China have cut into the northern custom of stocking up on baicai, which in Chinese literally means "white vegetable." (Chinese cabbage is not the soccer-ball-shaped stuff familiar in the West. The Chinese version is cylindrical, with broad white leaves that trend toward a green crown.)
But there seems to be a larger cultural shift afoot.
"Of course, young people don't like cabbage as much as the older generation does," said Hu Bei, 23, another shopper in western Beijing, "but it's also that lots of young people are too lazy to cook, especially the ones who are earning high salaries or working for foreign enterprises."
Many newly well-off Chinese simply identify the annual cabbage haul as a relic of past privation. And to the young, it seems downright unfashionable.
But if anything has spurred the sales of this year's crop of cabbage, it has been soaring urban inflation, which has pushed up vegetable prices 50 percent in the last year. Even households with new income are watching their food budgets.
"In the past few years people haven't bought so much cabbage," Ms. Hu said. "Now, though, they're worried about the prices going up on vegetables, so they're buying more."
It may seem hard to imagine that while millions of Chinese are getting rich, millions of other Chinese seem to be slavishly following the habits of an earlier era.
"The farther north you go, the more people rely on it," Ms. Lan said.
Back at the Horse Tail Gully market, Mr. Wang, his brother and sister-in-law, Gao Aijun, 27, had been selling for three straight days and it looked like it might take two more days to reduce their cabbage heap to the dregs.
"This year it's been a pretty good harvest," Ms. Gao said, "and we'll do a lot better this year than last," perhaps with a total profit of more than $1,200 on 55,000 pounds of cabbage.
That is, Mr. Wang added with a note of caution and a sideways glance up and down the street, "depending on whether any competition arrives."
In the cabbage business, a competing heap could come around the corner at any moment, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Every November, farmers descend on Beijing with mountains of cabbages for sale to families stocking up for the winter. But prosperity, greenhouse gardening and vegetable shipments from the south have cut into sales. (Mark Leong for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
An oil company tries to enliven one of the basic purchases -- gasoline -- with a light touch.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
IT has been decades since the enthusiastic uniformed Men from Texaco sang their way through hard-charging sales pitches and Esso insistently promised it would "put a tiger in your tank." Today's gasoline advertising tries selling in a far softer, more low-key manner, as demonstrated by a humorous, at times even winsome, campaign for the Sun Company.
Broadcast commercials and print advertisements by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge in New York focus on products like Sunoco gasoline and a new "co-branded" credit card linking Sunoco and Mastercard. The campaign for Sun, which spends $13 million to $14 million annually on promoting its Sunoco brand and service stations in the East and Midwest, is intended to put gasoline in its proper place, so to speak. 
 A big mistake made in traditional "chest pounding" ads by oil companies was "the idea that gasoline was more important to people than it actually was," Rochelle Klein, executive creative director at Angott, Thomas, said. "They never took into account that it's a purchase people have to make, not want to make."
By comparison, she added, the tenor of the agency's Sunoco advertising is that "we're something you have to do on the way to do something you want to do."
That attitude is evinced in the campaign, which began running last week. One television commercial pays tribute to cars as the song "Bless 'Em All," a paean to the troops during World War II, plays on the soundtrack. "After all," an announcer asks puckishly, "without cars, where would we be?"
In a second spot, for the Sunoco Mastercard, which offers rebates on gasoline purchases, the announcer asserts: "For years, your credit card purchases have fueled the economy. It's time they fueled your car."
And a final spot, also for the Sunoco Mastercard, spoofs a familiar animated commercial for the co-branded credit card of a Sunoco rival, Shell. "Unlike our competitors' cards, our new Sunoco Mastercard doesn't fox trot, cha-cha or lambada," the announcer wryly declares, referring to the Shell commercial in which special effects give the impression that the credit cards can dance.
"And for those who have to have a card that dances," he says, as a hand picks up a Sunoco Mastercard and moves it from side to side, "arriba!"
Norm Vincoff, manager for marketing services at Sun in Philadelphia, said: "In any business, you can get tied up in the belief people out there have a deep interest in your product and it's one of the most important things in their lives. But you have to be realistic about the role gasoline plays."
"We don't want to insult the level of intelligence of consumers," he added.
The campaign carries a theme, "On the driver's side," that was introduced in the spring of 1993 by Sunoco's previous agency, the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners. Angotti, Thomas absorbed Riney's New York office, and its accounts, in September of that year.
"Angotti has done a great job positioning Sunoco the way we want to be," Mr. Vincoff said, "in terms of value and high-quality product."
In addition to the Angotti, Thomas ads for the Sunoco Mastercard, 13 million to 14 million households -- including about 1.8 million that hold Sunoco credit cards -- will receive mail solicitations created by Cohn & Wells, a San Francisco shop specializing in direct-response advertising. The Sunoco Mastercard is issued by Bank of America.
The Angotti, Thomas campaign will appear in three phases, Mr. Vincoff said. The first runs through early December, the second begins after the new year and the third is scheduled for mid- to late 1995. There will be television and radio commercials in local markets, he said, as well as ads in newspapers in Boston, New York and Philadelphia.

HEADLINE: Amid Midwest Roar, Inflation Sleeps

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
Business is booming all across the major industrial centers of the Midwest. In a region that only a decade ago was dubbed the Rust Belt, companies are running at top speed, hiring temporary workers, demanding overtime of employees and straining to meet deliveries.
These are some of the signs that worry the Federal Reserve, which raised interest rates last week for the sixth time this year out of fear that a fast-paced economy points to a re-emergence of rising wages and prices. But amid this outbreak of inflation's symptoms in the nation's heartland is a curious phenomenon: so far, there is no disease. 
 The main reason that inflation remains benign, business executives and analysts in the region said, is that greater domestic and overseas competition helps keep prices in check. Moreover, now that American industry is again in fighting trim, both business and labor seem to recognize that the United States has a much better chance of seizing a larger share of expanding foreign markets if prices remain attractive.
"Business is hot and heavy right now," said David Carlson, sales vice president for the Adron Tool Corporation, an advanced tool and die shop here. "But it's truly a world market and we're under the gun constantly to improve productivity. Basically, we can't raise prices or we might not get the job."
If inflation is coming, this is the first place it should show up. But in contrast to the inflation rate during many previous periods of surging business, price increases remain quite tame. Consumer prices even fell in the North Central states in October, the only region where this occurred, according to the Government.
"It's amazing that in the Midwest, where manufacturing activity is leading the nation, that inflation pressures are as well contained as they are," said Robert H. Schnorbus, senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
Indeed, it is possible that price pressures are building under the surface so that they will eventually break loose of the Fed's monetary restraint. But it is more likely, to judge by recent interviews with business executives and other analysts in the Midwest, that intensified market forces and new attitudes are reinforcing Fed policy so strongly that inflation should remain restrained.
Even after more than three and a half years of economic growth, "one doesn't see any upward pressure at all on labor costs," said Norman Robertson, an economic consultant in Pittsburgh. "The competitive pressures seem to be more intense now than in previous upswings."
The Midwest labor market is the tightest in the nation. A sharp rebound in the region's automotive and machine tool industries has driven the unemployment rate down to 5 percent, eight-tenths of a point below the nation as a whole. As recently as May 1993, the Midwest unemployment rate was 6.4 percent.
If current levels of unemployment persist in the region, said Mark M. Zandi, an analyst at Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa., "we should begin to see some more pronounced wage pressure." In contrast to the warmer South or to the Rocky Mountain West, with its wide open spaces and recreational features, the Midwest is not as likely to import many workers from other areas. "You don't see the big migration flows into the Midwest," Mr. Zandi said.
But that pressure toward higher prices has so far been held in check by forces working in the other direction.
Jeffery T. Grade, chairman of Harnischfeger Industries, a large company here that produces cranes and other heavy industrial equipment, points to what he calls a new "self-imposed discipline" that is creating a partnership among producers, suppliers and customers.
"If you take unfair advantage," Mr. Grade said, "in the short run you'll be a hero but in the long run you'll wish you were not so stentorian. That, to me, is what's regulating inflation."
One important way that American companies are keeping costs under control is by using more temporary workers for blue-collar production. The pattern, which is long established in many clerical and technical jobs, is even spreading to managerial work.
Workers supplied by Manpower Inc., the largest temporary-help company in the nation, generally cost companies just as much in the short term as full-time workers. But they help keep costs under control by giving management a high degree of flexibility, according to Mitchell S. Fromstein, president of Manpower, which is based in Milwaukee.
"Strategically, companies face both a need to find people and the fear of adding costs because buyers aren't willing to pay increased prices," he said. "That is a total change in everybody's psychology."
Conditions are similar elsewhere in the factory-heavy Midwest. Even in the auto industry, manufacturers and their suppliers are relying on large numbers of temporary workers in Indiana, Michigan and other states.
"We're opening offices in places I'd never even heard of" a year ago, said Warren Rosenow, Manpower's regional vice president in Chicago.
Still, some signs of potential inflation are cropping up here that policy makers in Washington cannot risk ignoring. There was the man who turned up on a radio call-in show the other day complaining that his "totally burned out" brother-in-law has had only seven days off since July. Meanwhile, some manufacturers say they can no longer count on prompt delivery from suppliers. That points to production bottlenecks that lay the foundation for prices to be bid higher.
The Milwaukee Metal Products Company, for instance, used to be able to obtain steel blanks in a week or so, said Betty Jane Parrott, the company's vice president, but now "they're moving out to two or three weeks."
And in Wisconsin's Sheboygan County, where the unemployment rate is 3.6 percent, companies are contracting out work they no longer can get done locally. Many are even putting expansion plans on hold. Finding workers, especially for blue-collar jobs, "is a huge problem right now," acknowledged Barbara N. Lillesand, executive director of the Sheboygan County Chamber of Commerce.
The squeeze is finally forcing companies to start offering more money to attract new workers. "We're bumping up against our capacity to be able to fill all the orders," said Kenneth Krueger, financial vice president of the Allen-Bradley Company, a Milwaukee-based unit of the Rockwell International Corporation that is a leading producer of automation controls. In early summer, it hired its first new workers since 1978 after exhausting an employee-recall list that once included thousands of names.
But companies are also gaining flexibility by investing heavily in advanced, highly productive equipment that expands capacity and thereby tends to relieve inflation pressure. Indeed, much of this equipment is produced in the Midwest, a big reason the region's economy is so strong.
It is possible, of course, that "we're just sort of waiting for the dam to break," said Mr. Schnorbus, the Federal Reserve economist in Chicago. "But I'm more inclined to believe that we're in a different pricing environment than has existed in the past."
