HEADLINE: Where's 42d St. Grit? Around the Corner;
Slow Change Along Eighth Ave. Strip

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Come midnight, Eighth Avenue in midtown is a street of neon thrills, lurking dangers and impossible expectation, a Felliniesque montage where a group of giggling theatergoers crowds into a peep booth to have something to talk about on the ride home.
But there is pain in the face of the old man jiggling two quarters in a paper cup, and an odd frenzy in the voice of a man passing out handbills for a topless bar. Doris Brown, a 41-year-old prostitute looking for business across from the Port Authority Bus Terminal recently, said life wasn't getting any easier. 
 "There's money out here, but some nights it takes so long to get it," she said.
Except for the part near Eighth Avenue, 42d Street is now largely a surreal ghost town awaiting a new life. It is Eighth Avenue itself that has become the most sex-saturated street in the city, the police, business people and leaders of community groups said. In the last five years, sex shops and adult theaters have tripled to 15 from 40th to 48th Street, and the corridor south to Penn Station is peppered with about a half dozen more. In addition, many stores are situated on side streets just around the corner from Eighth Avenue.
Although crime statistics are not broken down by street, the police believe the crime rate is the highest in the Times Square area.
This is the avenue that seems never to improve, even as Broadway and Seventh Avenue to the east have taken on a new sparkle, and the Clinton neighborhood immediately to the west more or less succeeds in burying its Hell's Kitchen past. "Eighth Avenue is like the same jungle it was I don't know how many years ago," said a businessman running for a late bus. "It just swallows people up."
Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, fears the street's continuing blight threatens the revitalized theater district. "It is a street people try to avoid," he said.
But there are gathering whisps of change. Several weeks ago, the state Urban Development Corporation took title to all of the east side of Eighth Avenue between 42d Street and 43d Street to build a hotel as part of its redevelopment project; Disney is among the bidders. The businesses there now include peep shows, video shops and adult book stores. The condemnation process is expected to start soon.
William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement, said that, in terms of square footage, this one step will eliminate nearly 30 percent of sex businesses on Eighth Avenue between 40th and 53d streets. Even more important, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is pushing for a yearlong moratorium on the opening of sex businesses in the city. During that period, zoning changes would be formulated to push the sex shops to the city's industrial periphery. Current shops would likely be allowed to recover at least some of their investment before having to move, although details have not been determined.
Last week, the City Planning Commission approved the moratorium. It next has to go the the City Council, and the city Planning Department is drafting zoning regulations.
Although the rules will apply equally to sex shops from the Bronx to Staten Island, perhaps its greatest impact will be felt on Eighth Avenue. "The initiative is generic and citywide, but would certainly change Eighth Avenue," said Andrew Lynn, executive director of the Planning Commission.
For the Times Square Business Improvement District, which is now focusing on Eighth Avenue, such action is crucial to stemming the street's slide. "We absolutely need government intervention," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the group.
According to a recent study by her group, there is economic incentive for landlords to rent to owners of sex shops. The study found that rents from 40th Street to 53d Street for sex businesses range from $90 to $125 per square foot per year. Rents for nonpornographic uses along Eighth Avenue are $40 to $50 a square foot north of 48th Street and $50 to $80 south of it. Still, the study found, there's money to be made on the avenue: average rent for nonpornographic uses elsewhere in western Manhattan was $35.
The study also found a lower commercial vacancy rate than for the city as a whole -- 9.6 percent, compared with 15 percent citywide -- a figure that attests to the strong commercial interest in the area. "Eighth Avenue could become a far more vibrant retail strip," the report declared.
There is some evidence this is already happening. Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream says the company's store at the northeast corner of 43d Street is one of its highest-volume sellers. Partly as a result, Green Mountain Coffee said it is planning to open an upscale coffee bar next door. Between 46th and 47th Streets, bright new awnings outside bustling establishments indicate a new retail energy.
The once-grubby Port Authority Bus Terminal, at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street, bristles with new upscale fast-food outlets and, after years of trying, the Port Authority finally convinced a bank to install automated teller machines earlier this year. It quickly became one of the city's busiest A.T.M. centers.
Worldwide Plaza, the five-year-old complex between 49th and 50th Streets, has no vacancies for either commercial or residential space.
As a result, real-estate executives and property owners voice much optimism about the avenue's future. "Eighth Avenue is going to have a fantastic decade," said Arthur Zeckendorf, whose family built Worldwide Plaza and is scouting for other opportunities on the street.
But it is premature to say any corners have been turned. The street still has a dangerous edge, and considerable low-level drug dealing continues, despite beefed-up police efforts.
"There are about 30 junkies on the corner every morning when I walk my dog," said the Rev. Dale D. Hansen, pastor of St. Luke's Lutheran Church on 46th Street, just around the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue.
But things are still better than they used to be, neighborhood people say. Child pornography, a staple of the old 42d Street a decade ago, is seldom seen on Eighth Avenue, the managers of the video stores say. And the dozens of massage parlors, more dens of violence than sex, were chased from Eighth Avenue in the early 1980's. "This was a meaner street back then," said Mr. Daly, of the midtown enforcement office.
A backhanded compliment comes from Ernest Schroeder, who runs the Full Moon bar at 46th Street. "They've eliminated the low-lifes up and down the street," he growled. "Those were my customers."
The sex shop business has changed, too. Mr. Daly says that organized crime's hold on pornography has been loosened, largely, he said, because of aggressive Federal prosecutions. Smaller entrepreneurs, many from India or Pakistan, have taken over, he said. With little capital, they tend not to offer live entertainment, but pirated, often crudely reproduced videos at $5 each or three for $12.
"There are too many video stores, and all of us hurt each other," said a worker at XXX Video at 778 Eighth Avenue. "It is a bad sign."
Rick Travis, owner of the Pleasure Palace at 733 Eighth Avenue, said that he voted for Mr. Giuliani and would do so again, but that the Mayor was wrong in trying to control sex establishments. "We pay millions of dollars in taxes and give jobs to a lot of people who normally would otherwise be unemployed," he said.
He also contended that sex shops were a benefit to property owners. The Oriental gift shop that preceded him in his space did not generate enough business to pay the rent, he said, whereas he is prompt with his.
"My landlady wanted somebody who could pay the rent," he said. "It doesn't make her a porn queen. It makes her a businessperson."
Even so, there are property owners who are declining to rent to pornographers. Reasons vary from moral considerations to concern that the value of upper floors will be lowered by renting to an objectionable tenant on the ground floor.
"We want to upgrade our property, not downgrade it," said Richard Barth, vice president of corporate properties for Chemical Bank. He said he has passed up many opportunities to get high rents from pornographers for the bank's property on the northwest corner of 43d Street.
Robert Cohen, a developer who just bought four buildings, including the defunct Covenant House social service agency between 43d and 44th streets, said he would never rent to a sex shop, despite the "crazy numbers" he said he has been offered. "You end up cannibalizing the value of your investment," he said.
Peer pressure is also a factor. Carvel Moore, executive director of the Fashion Center Business Improvement District, which includes Eighth Avenue from 35th to 41st Streets, says more than 80 percent of the landlords there have signed agreements not to rent to sex shops.
Among them is Mark Orbach, whose commercial space at 585 Eighth Avenue was vacant for almost a year. He heard generous offers from sex merchants, but owners of neighboring buildings begged him not to accept them. They even enlisted his rabbi to lobby him.
The result was that Mr. Orbach rented his space to a clothing store for 60 percent of what he could have taken in from a pornographer; his neighbors gave him money to help him make up for the loss. "I would like to clean up Eighth Avenue," he explained.

HEADLINE: Pataki Asks Cuomo's Help In Holding Down Spending

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Showing increasing concern about the state's fiscal condition, Governor-elect George E. Pataki asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today to freeze state hiring, delay signing new contracts and impose a moratorium on other major spending commitments until he takes office on Jan. 1.
Mr. Pataki's request came on a day he said New York's deepening fiscal problems would make it "more difficult" to fulfill his campaign promise to cut taxes deeply without noticeably reducing government services. 
 But he said he remained committed to his tax-cut plan, though he provided few details about how he might cut spending.
"Obviously, when you're facing a multibillion-dollar deficit that we did not anticipate, it's going to be more difficult and going to require a harder look at programs and personnel," Mr. Pataki told reporters in Williamsburg, Va., where he was attending a meeting of the Republican Governors Association. "And that's just a fact of life."
Mr. Pataki, who left Williamsburg for a weeklong working vacation with his family in Florida, spoke to Mr. Cuomo this afternoon about his requests and followed up the conversation with a letter that he released.
Because the Cuomo administration projects a gap in next year's state budget of at least $4 billion, Mr. Pataki wrote, "I would request certain discretionary actions that might occur in the normal course of business be delayed until my administration has had the opportunity to review them next year, particularly those that would result in potentially exacerbating this deficit problem."
Mr. Pataki said that he made the request "with clear understanding and utmost respect that you as Governor and your administration must and should be responsible for the state government, its policies and actions throughout the remainder of your term."
Mr. Cuomo responded in a letter of his own that he would keep state costs low, but he did not explicitly agree to Mr. Pataki's requests. "We intend to manage our budget situation so as to keep costs as low as possible while still meeting our obligations," Mr. Cuomo wrote. "In addition, my budget director will work to limit the filling of vacant positions in the state general fund work force."
Mr. Pataki asked for a freeze on hiring, promotions and reclassifications of state workers in all but essential areas, a delay in signing new state contract awards, including construction contracts, and a "moratorium on any other major commitments that can be reasonably delayed until after Jan. 1, 1995." Spokesmen for the Cuomo administration and the State Comptroller's office said early this evening that they could not determine how many state employees had been hired since the Nov. 8 election.
Mr. Pataki said in Williamsburg today that at the time he proposed his plan to cut income taxes by 25 percent over four years, he expected next year's budget gap to be between $1 billion and $1.5 billion. The Cuomo administration disclosed after the election that the gap could be as much as $4 billion, and perhaps more, in a general fund budget that is $34 billion this year.
Mr. Cuomo's top aides have said that it was clear when this year's state budget was passed in June that the gap in next year's budget would be at least $3 billion. And Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Columbia County Republican whom Mr. Pataki has appointed to lead his budget task force during the transition, said today that he thought at the time that the gap would be between $2.5 billion and $3 billion.
During the campaign, Mr. Pataki said he could pay for his income tax cut through growth in state revenues, which he projected at 6 percent a year, and by keeping growth in state spending to the rate of inflation. "I believe we can do it without cutting services in a way that people are going to look and say, 'My God, I've lost this service,' " Mr. Pataki said in an Oct. 7 interview with The New York Times.
Today Mr. Pataki said that in light of the increased gap, "We are going to have to look very carefully at all the different options as to how we can cut costs. We talked during the campaign about a targeted hiring freeze, and we're certainly going to have to do that. We talked about cutting political patronage jobs. We're going to have to do that."
At the governors conference, Mr. Pataki received advice from those of his counterparts who also came into office facing large budget gaps, and most said he should prepare to make deep cuts.
Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who said he and his Legislature cut about a third of his state's projected spending over four years, recalled that he "left a lot of jobs vacant" and imposed a 5 percent pay cut for state workers. And Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, who said he cut $1.8 billion out of a $13.7 billion budget by eliminating one out of every nine state jobs, said he advised Mr. Pataki, "If you're going to step on toes, kick over the milk boxes and gore sacred oxen, it's better to do it all at once."

But there are few signs of such price pressures in the Rust Belt, largely because increased domestic and overseas competition is helping to keep prices in check. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Ameritech Forcefully Stays Home

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Richard C. Notebaert, the chairman of the Ameritech Corporation, opened a newspaper here last May to find a startling full-page advertisement by AT&T.
"Check your phone bill -- you may be surprised at what you're paying," the ad said, offering a 10 percent discount from Ameritech prices for calls to points farther than 15 miles. 
 AT&T was muscling in on the market for calls between places as close to one another as downtown Chicago and the suburb of Winnetka -- a market dominated by Ameritech, the regional Bell company that provides local phone service in Illinois and four other Midwestern states.
Mr. Notebaert ordered an immediate counterattack -- radio, television and print ads. "DO NOTHING," urged one set of ads. "Trick or treat indeed," snarled another, arguing that AT&T's savings were largely illusory and that customers would have to dial an extra five digits to complete calls through AT&T.
Such competition for the local telephone market is developing in New York, Maryland and other states, and on a more narrow basis in most big cities. But nowhere is the fight more ferocious than in Chicago, because Ameritech has been girding for competition -- and even banking on it -- far more than any of the other Bell companies.
"They almost have a biker mentality about defending their territory," said Jack Grubman, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
While many other regional Bells have been seeking nationwide opportunities in video services and wireless communications, Ameritech has decided to focus on its own five-state Great Lakes region and its core telecommunications network. It was conspicuously absent from the merger frenzy last year among telephone and cable television companies, and this fall it spurned invitations to join long-distance carriers or other Bell companies in a national alliance to develop wireless communications networks.
"Ameritech has really stuck to its knitting," William Vogel, an analyst with NatWest Securities, said. "They think the telephone business is a great business and see no need to de-emphasize it."
But defending its franchise will not be easy. Because of recent decisions by Illinois regulators intent on ending monopoly control of local telephone service, and thanks to the sheer size of the Chicago market, this city has in recent months become a magnet for new telephone ventures. In the process, it has become a laboratory for changes sweeping telecommunications.
Ameritech has been aggressively promoting a sort of grand bargain with Federal regulators. The company would agree to open its network fully to all rivals, giving up any preferences it now enjoys in exchange for being allowed to enter the long-distance and cable television markets. Such a trade-off is the core principle of legislation, applying to all phone companies, that almost passed Congress last month and will be debated again next year. The general principle is supported by all Bell companies, but they objected sharply to many crucial details and blocked the bill's passage.
Ameritech has also waged a successful campaign to persuade regulators to give it more flexibility on profits and pricing. The new regulatory policies allow Ameritech to keep almost all the profits it can squeeze out from improved efficiency, typically in exchange for a commitment to freeze or lower the price of basic phone service.
In its own house, Ameritech has slashed jobs and other costs to become the most efficient of the Bells, and it is cutting crucial prices aggressively. As a result, analysts say, Ameritech may be the phone company best positioned for the new competitive era.
"Competition will be good for everyone, including us," said Mr. Notebaert, 47, who assumed the post when William L. Weiss retired in May. "Look at AT&T. Their market share in long distance has dropped from 100 percent to 60 percent, but they are stronger than ever."
The list of Ameritech's current and aspiring rivals is a long one. MFS Communications has built a fiber optic network in downtown Chicago and some outlying suburbs that stretches several hundred miles. So has Teleport Communications Group, based in New York.
MCI Communications, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, has announced plans to offer both residential and business service in Illinois -- as well as New York and four other states -- as early as next year. Time Warner Inc., the nation's second-largest cable television company, plans to compete against Ameritech in much of Ohio. Sprint, the third-largest long-distance company, has just formed an alliance with three cable television companies and plans to offer both wired and wireless services.
Chicago will be one of the Sprint team's first targets. Helping lead the way is Teleport Communications, which operates fiber optic networks in 19 cities and is owned by Sprint's three cable partners: Tele-Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and Cox Enterprises.
Teleport, which occupies almost a full floor in the Sears Tower building, plus switching centers around the area, has already announced that it will start residential phone service in January in the Chicago suburb of Arlington Heights.
The list of rivals does not stop there. AT&T, the world's biggest long-distance carrier, is pursuing its attack on Ameritech's lucrative business in "toll calls." These are calls that cover distances of more than eight miles but stop short of the true long-distance calls that Federal rules bar Bell companies like Ameritech from carrying.
These toll calls, between places like downtown Chicago and suburbs like Schaumberg, are billed by time and distance. Because customers must dial extra digits if they use a long-distance carrier for such calls, Ameritech has been able to keep toll calls almost exclusively to itself. Toll calls represent a $1.4 billion business for the company in its five-state region. But AT&T, despite the extra-digit drawback, has made a target of this business, promoting discounts it says can be as much as 30 percent.
Ameritech is countering in a number of ways. In Washington, it has proposed what it calls its Customer First plan: opening its network totally to competition in exchange for being allowed to enter the long-distance and cable television markets. The Justice Department's antitrust division has been negotiating with Ameritech, and a decision could come early next year.
Richard H. Brown, vice chairman of Ameritech, said his company would prosper amid competition if it was allowed to enter the long-distance business. "Forty percent of our business is already subject to active competition," he said in a recent interview, referring to areas like cellular telephones and Yellow Pages listings.
If the Customer First plan is accepted, Mr. Brown said, it will expose about $1 billion of Ameritech's $12 billion in revenues to new competition while allowing it to compete for $8 billion in long-distance service that originates within its region.
Ameritech is eager for full competitive freedom because customers are already beginning to pursue the fruits of competition. In Chicago, Chrysler Systems, a computer leasing subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, leases high-speed lines from Teleport and has cut the cost of long-distance calls within Illinois by more than 15 percent.
The Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest commodity futures exchange, uses several companies to provide the high-speed lines that relay transaction data. And Frank Romer, the exchange's director of telecommunications, has thought of using Ameritech's rivals for the thousands of telephone lines used by trading firms on the exchange floor. "We've been offered options on dial-tone service that are cheaper than what we pay now," he said.
To be sure, competition for ordinary local phone service is still limited. Mr. Romer said he was reluctant to switch carriers for ordinary voice service because thousands of people would have to change their phone numbers, a big disruption. Ameritech has agreed in principle to install technology that would let customers take their phone numbers with them when they switch -- but not until Ameritech wins more freedom for itself.
For all of Ameritech's free-market talk, rivals complain that the company has been balking about negotiating on several important issues. Last month, MFS Communications complained to Illinois regulators that Ameritech was refusing to discuss terms on which it and rivals would compensate one another when each completed calls for the other's customers. For now, MFS must pay Ameritech when an MFS customer calls an Ameritech customer -- but also when an Ameritech customer calls one served by MFS.
"They talk the talk, but they don't walk the walk," complained Royce M. Holland, president of MFS Communications. "To us, the Customer First plan sounds more like the Me First plan."
Even as the regulatory battles grind on, the economics of competition are inciting Ameritech's rivals to become more aggressive.
Robert Anunziata, chief executive of Teleport Communications, said his company would have to expand beyond business services and into serving residential customers. "Our business users will be using our switches very heavily during the day, but at night the usage is very limited," he said. "That's when residential usage picks up. Business and residential service complement each other."
Ameritech makes a similar argument on why it needs to enter long-distance business, saying that it must be a "full service" provider. Slowly but surely, state and Federal regulators are heading toward such full competition from all sides. When that happens, consumers will learn which of the rivals can fulfill its promise.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Brazil Supply Report Pushes Orange Juice Prices Lower

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Orange juice prices plunged yesterday after an estimate of Brazil's orange production showed much less drought damage than traders expected.
Coffee prices extended a recent decline to five-month lows, as additional rainfall in Brazil lifted prospects for coffee production there as well. Since late September, coffee prices have dropped by one-third. 
 Steep declines in soybean and pork prices pushed the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities down 1.22 points, to 231.50, the inflation index's lowest level since Oct. 14.
On the New York Cotton Exchange, orange juice for January delivery fell 10 cents, to 107.55 cents a pound, and subsequent contracts dropped the maximum 5-cent limit.
The Brazilian Citrus Exporters Association estimated this year's supply in the state of Sao Paulo at 277 million 90-pound boxes, compared with 292 million boxes estimated at the end of September. The state accounts for nearly 90 percent of Brazil's orange production.
"The market was looking for a 10 percent drop in the Brazilian crop estimate due to effects of a prolonged drought," said Warren Seeley, a trader with Arcal Brokerage. "But it appears they only lost about 5 percent of their crop."
Orange juice prices have risen 31 percent since Oct. 7, largely on the basis of drought damage in Brazil.
Florida's orange crop was not affected by the recent pass of Tropical Storm Gordon, which destroyed millions of dollars worth of other crops.
Coffee prices extended a recent selloff. Coffee for December delivery fell 8.75 cents, to $1.5865 a pound, while coffee for March delivery lost 8.65 cents, to $1.6370, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.
A sharp decline in soybean oil prices and reports of stepped-up farmer selling of soybeans weighed on soybean prices at the Chicago Board of Trade. January soybeans fell 7 cents, to $5.635 a bushel.
Crude oil prices were little changed as traders anticipated the chance that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would decide to maintain current production quotas.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Early Dollar Rally vs. Mark Fades in New York Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the German mark in European trading early yesterday before retreating in New York as traders tried to determine whether the dollar's recent gains were justified.
"There is still a bullish mentality toward the dollar," said Frank Pusateri, vice president of foreign exchange sales at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. 
 The dollar has been stronger against the mark and Japanese yen in recent weeks. Traders have attributed the gains to higher interest rates in the United States, which make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive and to the possibility of another large round of dollar-buying by the United States to prop up the value of the dollar.
The dollar has also gained, some traders say, on expectations that Republican control of Congress will lead to spending cuts, lower taxes and a reduced Federal deficit.
The dollar rose to 1.5640 marks in intraday trading yesterday, its highest level since Sept. 2. In late New York trading, the dollar fell back to 1.5562 marks, barely up from 1.5548 marks on Friday. The dollar slipped to 98.34 yen, from 98.56 on Friday.
The dollar continues to be weighed down by a number of concerns, including a weak American bond market and the United States deficit. Some traders say that the Federal Reserve's increases in short-term interest rates this year have not been sufficient to quell worries about inflation, which erodes the value of bonds and holds down the demand for dollars by foreign investors.
Investment fund managers and corporations that hold currency positions for months "haven't gotten into the fray" of buying dollars, said Amy Smith, senior currency strategist at the IDEA consulting firm.
Dealers are looking ahead to a meeting of the Bundesbank's Central Bank Council on Thursday.
Stephen Axilrod, a former top official at the Fed who is now an economic consultant in New York, said there was a 50 percent chance that the German central bank would ease rates again. A strong mark and decelerating German money-supply growth would seem to give the Bundesbank room to ease its credit stance, he said.
In other currency trading in New York, the British pound edged up to $1.5678, from $1.5655 on Friday. The dollar, firming Friday's gains against the Swiss franc, rose to 1.3190 Swiss francs, from 1.3185 francs on Friday.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
The Future Lies Ahead, Perhaps Far, Far Ahead

BYLINE: By STEPHEN MANES 

 BODY:
LAS VEGAS is the perfect spot for the country's biggest computer convention. Like the enormous marquees for shows like "Sooper Dogs," computer ballyhoo greatly exceeds reality. A city literally built on silicon and chockablock with hotels masquerading as tropical islands, showboats and pirate dens seems a particularly fitting place to promote boxes once devoted to staid scientific calculations but now decked out in hardware and software trappings that can simulate even aerobatics so realistically that airsickness bags may become useful peripherals.
Year after year, fall Comdex charmingly demolishes the myth of the universality and importance of the information highway. No matter how wired they might be, more than 190,000 hardcore infomaniacs and salespeople insist on abandoning virtuality and transport their physical persons to the desert to press buttons and the flesh. 
 This year's most obvious novelty was multimedia pornography, largely traditional stuff transferred to CD-ROM. Aisle upon aisle of it attracted some of the conference's biggest crowds in a vast multimedia hall occupying what was once a parking garage.
On display elsewhere was fantasy of a similar variety, the corporate propaganda that we might call technography, something first popularized at World's Fairs, where carmakers extolled the benefits of paving the universe. What the two genres have in common (aside from their music and acting) is a dream world where pure pleasure has no unintended consequences and, most incredibly, everything always works.
The purest recent example of technography was presented by the Microsoft Corporation in a film that accompanied the Comdex keynote address of the company's chairman, William H. Gates 3d.
Set in Seattle in 2005, the production revisits the "Information at Your Fingertips" theme Mr. Gates introduced in 1990. It offers a vision of homes controlled by smart digital devices, police officers equipped with screens that can transcribe speech instantly, ambulances with videophones and telemetry and schools with lots of high-tech goodies. Exactly where the money for these items might come from in a city whose citizens recently rejected bond issues for rebuilding aging school, police and library buildings is not discussed.
While the world of science fiction tends to present dystopias of unrelenting gloom, technography invariably sees technology as a virtually unmitigated good. In a scene that has become obligatory in the genre, the young hero of Microsoft's melodrama researches his class assignment with the help of a home computer linked to vast storehouses of information. Then, as in Apple Computer Inc.'s "Knowledge Navigator" demonstration (one of the great early landmarks of this form of propaganda), he delivers a flashy presentation containing approximately half a shred of information.
This triumph of production values over content utterly dazzles his teacher and peers, perhaps because he has demonstrated such an aptitude for politics or software marketing. But Microsoft's n otion that a schoolchild of 2005 will have $58.89 of discretionary digital cash to spend on a reproduction of a pre-Columbian artifact for a school project suggests that what the future really holds is rampant inflation.
In Comdex's real world, much of the future was postponed. The greatest expectations revolved around projects that are not yet products, like the operating system Microsoft originally expected to have shipped by now, recently christened Windows 95 and still unavailable. The company also announced a new on-line service, but it will not be available before the middle of next year either. The new line of PowerPC computers from I.B.M., expected since early 1994, may now arrive after next year's crocuses. What you can buy now, however, is a videotape of Microsoft's technographic extravaganza, for $9.95; no E-mail address is listed, but would-be visionaries can call (800) 369-5718.
As always, interesting technologies were on display, but their potential for success remains unclear. High-speed infrared links may give portable computers the ability to transfer data without a cable, but only if compatible devices turn up on printers and desktop machines. High-resolution flat-panel screens, shown by the NEC Corporation and the Sharp Electronics Corporation, offer improved lightweight displays that come with annoying real-world tradeoffs. As always, it is safe to predict that the unrelenting improvement of electronic hardware will bring faster, cheaper products packing more information into each inch and ounce.
But though products conforming to the new "Plug and Play" standards were much in evidence, there is little reason to expect that computers will soon be significantly easier to use or understand. A simple question to a software engineer about a CD-ROM drive elicited a disquisition about standards, drivers and BIOS'es that left my head spinning and the poor CD-ROM drive more misunderstood than ever.
In the year 2005, despite the manifold glories of the information highway, we will still be traveling to conventions like Comdex and having these conversations face to face. Our computers will understand them only in our dreams.

HEADLINE: Top International Trade Official Urges U.S. to Approve Accord

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Failure by the United States Senate to ratify the proposed new global trade agreement, the world's top trade official said yesterday, would destroy the existing world trading order, return international commerce to "the law of the jungle" and deprive the world of an estimated $500 billion in economic gains by the year 2005.
 Addressing a press conference at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, the official, Peter Sutherland, who heads the Geneva organization that regulates international commerce, said it was inconceivable to him that the Senate could reject an accord that has been supported by both Republican and Democratic administrations. 
 But with the Senate preparing to vote on the agreement, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, amid signs of resistance from Republicans, Mr. Sutherland warned that failure to ratify it would "destroy the credibility of the existing trading system" and create a growing risk of trade wars as countries retreated into beggar-thy-neighbor policies.
"It would be the law of the jungle," Mr. Sutherland said, adding that if the United States failed to ratify the agreement from the Uruguay round of negotiations then other partners to the accord would also renege on reducing trade barriers and extending international trade law into new fields, like the protection of intellectual property rights.
In recent days Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is likely to become chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, has called for the vote to be postponed into next year. And Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said over the weekend that he wanted passage of the trade measure linked to a cut in the capital gains tax.
Other conservative senators have expressed fears that the agreement requires the United States to give up too much sovereignty to the proposed new World Trade Organization.
Such indications of weakening support for the agreement have caused dismay among America's trading partners in Europe and elsewhere, raising the possibility of a trans-Atlantic economic clash.
Mr. Sutherland focused on the economic gains all countries are expected to make under the new agreement. He said a new study predicts that the world's total annual income gain from freer trade in goods alone would be $510 billion by the year 2005, against an earlier estimate of $235 billion. In practice the gain would be greater because freer trade in services is not included in this calculation.
On the most optimistic assumptions in the study, the United States stands to gain $122 billion in additional income from the growth of its exports and imports. The study says the comparable figures for the 12 European Union members is $164 billion, for Japan $27 billion and for the developing world together and the countries in transition between Communism and capitalism, $116 billion.
The study also estimates that America's exports and imports would both increase by as much as 21.7 percent and those of the European Union by up to 19.4 percent.

HEADLINE: The Right Thinkers: Some Voices in the New Political Conversation

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
It was only two years ago that the hottest think tanks, the most sought-after strategists and the most visible political organizations were the ones devoted to charting bold new directions for the "New Democrats." They talked about "third ways" and "reinventing government." They talked about spending government money -- "strategically," of course.
No more. 
 The hot strategists in Washington today are those who helped think the conservative movement back to power and are now happily meeting, planning and networking over how to use that power in the next two years. They are consumed with the grand task of building an enduring conservative majority: by reclaiming the tax issue, using the energy of conservative Christians, capitalizing on the politics of values and, perhaps most of all, stoking the public's anger toward big government and the appetite for rolling it back.
Since Election Day, the nation's capital has been utterly in thrall to this new conservative ascendancy, or Reagan II, as some conservatives call it. The Heritage Foundation has reclaimed its 1980's glow. The world view of Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the likely House Speaker, always available to loyal viewers of C-Span, is now parsed and pored over by a city of political professionals. Sales of his 20-hour videotaped course, "Renewing American Civilization," are soaring.
William Kristol, the conservative strategist who long predicted that health care plans would be the Democrats' Afghanistan ("not a threat but an opportunity for us"), has acquired the status of all-purpose seer. And the Contract With America, the House Republicans' list of campaign promises from tax cuts to term limits, is now considered a Baedeker to the 104th Congress.
"What's caught this city, the political class and the media class by surprise is that the political conversation has totally changed its terms," said Terry Eastland, a top official in the Justice Department during Ronald Reagan's Administration. "So that the entire conversation is, 'How do we limit and downsize government?' "
In the House, which has become ground zero for the revolution, Mr. Gingrich, Representative Dick Armey, the incoming majority leader, and a handful of other members are scrambling to prepare for the first 100 days; away from Capitol Hill, several strategists are thinking further with the new political calculus. For those seeking to adjust to the transition -- or, as some Republicans put it, the "transformation" -- what follows is a sampling of conservative strategists to watch:
 
William Kristol
Head of political group who resisted compromise
At 41, Mr. Kristol already has a long conservative pedigree, as the son of the commentator Irving Kristol and a former top aide to William Bennett, Secretary of Education, and Vice President Dan Quayle. But Mr. Kristol rose to new prominence over the last two years by writing a series of widely circulated memorandums that challenged the conventional wisdom on health.
These days, with the advantage of hindsight, the risks to the Democrats in advancing a big overhaul of the health care system seem obvious. But in early 1993, the Republicans were the ones who seemed in danger -- of being outmaneuvered on domestic policy as they were in the 1992 campaign, of being latecomers and foot-draggers for a vast new benefit program for the middle class.
Mr. Kristol played heretic, arguing against the idea that there was, in fact, a health care crisis; he also urged Republicans to resist any effort at making a grand compromise with the Democrats on the issue. "I never thought we faced an inevitably dominant resurgence of liberalism," he said, then and now. "I always thought '92 was a rejection of Bush, not an endorsement of activist government."
A Ph.D. in government from Harvard who left a career in academia, Mr. Kristol is chairman of a political group known as the Project for the Republican Future and is a longtime believer in "limited government." He sees the next two years as crucial to laying the groundwork for a Republican return to the White House. At the risk, he says, of offending more pure-minded conservatives, he argues that the party needs to "build for the long haul" on Capitol Hill and "shed the minority mind-set of let's do everything we can all at once."
 
Grover Norquist
An ally of Gingrich and foe of new taxes
If there was one issue that tormented conservatives in their 1992 electoral debacle, it was taxes; specifically, watching their party lose its image as the anti-tax party after President George Bush broke his "read my lips" pledge and signed on to the 1990 budget agreement. To Grover Norquist, this was simple heresy -- then, now and in time to come.
Mr. Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, is part of the Gingrich/Armey network on Capitol Hill and is considered an expert on populist anti-tax movements. Since the late 1980's, his organization has been circulating pledges among candidates, asking them to forswear new taxes; 185 in the new House and 28 in the Senate have now signed them.
"The tax issue is the central divide between the two parties," Mr. Norquist said. "That's the centerpiece: The Republican Party is saying, 'No more money and power to Washington; turn off the spigot.' And the Democratic Party is saying, 'No, no, more money and more power.' "
The 38-year-old Mr. Norquist, a former executive director of the National Taxpayers Union, says the American public now sees the connection very clearly between smaller government and lower taxes. He can envision no tax increase that he could ever support, and sees the next two years as a time to begin to "radically restructure Washington."
 
Ralph Reed
Christian Coalition leader and family advocate
Tony Blankley, spokesman for Mr. Gingrich, said this week: "The organized Christian vote is roughly to the Republican Party today what organized labor was to the Democrats. It brings similar resources: people, money and ideological conviction." Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, is widely credited with bringing a new political sophistication to this crucial segment of the party.
Mr. Reed says he saw the challenge of the past two years as bridging the gap between the Republican Party's economic conservatives and those more oriented to the social and moral issues, like many of his constituents. Both welfare reform and tax relief for middle-class families were issues that connected "the great divide," he said. In surveys of Christian Coalition members, "We've found these voters are hungering for a broader agenda that addresses the financial strain on the family as well as moral pressures."
Looking ahead, Mr. Reed says he is keenly aware of the dangers of over-reaching, especially on issues like prayer in the school. "Social change proceeds in America with deliberate and slow steps," he said. "Our desire to restore the centrality of the family will take place over decades, not years. The mistake that frankly the religious conservative movement made in the early 1980's with Reagan, and the gay rights movement made with Clinton, was: 'O. K., we won. Now we want, in turn, our entire agenda legislated immediately.' "
Mr. Blankley says: "Newt has said that they have a seat at the table. We want them at the table."
 
William Bennett
Former Education chief who writes on values
Mr. Bennett, the former Education Secretary who took to the campaign trail this year for an array of candidates, said he was utterly clear on the meaning of this election. "It was about limited government, about the end of the nanny state," he says. It was about beginning to reverse "the discharge of responsibilities from families and communities and local governments onto the Federal Government," and reviving personal responsibility.
After the 1992 Republican National Convention, many analysts believed that the campaign for traditional values had proven too divisive, too dangerous to inject into mainstream politics. Mr. Bennett said that all that was proven was this, "Using the values issues as a club and stick, that's not right." With his best-selling book, "A Book of Virtues," and his writing and speaking, Mr. Bennett did much to revive these issues in the past few years.
"Why did it come back? Because that's what it's all about," Mr. Bennett said. "The question I'd get asked was: 'What's going on with America? Are our wheels coming off? Are we losing this great republic? Is it getting nasty and mean and brutal and coarse, and can we get it back?' " Every major policy proposal should be viewed through these concerns, he says.
Mr. Bennett added that this new conservative ascendancy "won't work" if lawmakers simply cut programs for the poor, "but middle-class subsidies remain the same." Asked for examples, he suggests lawmakers start looking at financing for the arts and humanities, the Department of Education and agriculture programs.
Mr. Bennett is a co-director of Empower America, a conservative political group.
 
Vin Weber
A former lawmaker and friend of Gingrich
Another co-director of Empower America, Vin Weber is also a longtime friend and former House colleague of Mr. Gingrich's. After serving six terms as a representative from Minnesota, including a stint in the Republican leadership, Mr. Weber announced his retirement in 1992. Since then, he has made himself felt from his perch at Empower America.
Mr. Weber, who was chairman of Jack Kemp's Presidential campaign in 1988, describes the challenge of the next two years as nothing short of "replacing a 60-year-old framework for problem solving with a new framework for problem solving" -- one less centralized, less bureaucratic. Look to the new farm bill, he suggests, as an early proving ground for these new approaches.
Mr. Weber argues that people are ready for a different kind of government -- not a passive one.
 
Kate O'Beirne
A leader in Heritage and specialist in marketing
As vice president for government relations at Heritage, Mrs. O'Beirne describes herself as immersed in the "marketing" of conservative proposals. Among them is a $500-per-child tax credit for American families, which was embraced by the Contract With America.
The Heritage analyst says that the promise of such tax cuts helps build the constituency for reducing the size of the government, "actually getting rid of the programs that we learned in the '80s are darned tough to cut."
She describes the challenge for Republicans over the next two years as "Be not afraid." Mrs. O'Beirne, who first came to Washington in the 1970's with Senator James Buckley of New York, and later served as a deputy assistant secretary at Health and Human Services under President Ronald Reagan, added that this new conservative insurgency has an edge over the last.
"We have resources that we didn't have in 1980," she said. "We had no infrastructure in 1980. Now, there's a network; there's Reagan alums and Bush alums all over town, and they have substantive expertise. You want to reform H.H.S.? We have people who know the department intimately."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Splits on Dole Threat on Trade Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Republicans split today over the decision of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to hold a worldwide trade agreement hostage to tax concessions from the White House. While a prominent Republican strategist warned against the move, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, a supporter of the pact, said he would not interfere with Mr. Dole's effort.
Meanwhile, Democrats worried that the uncertainty over whether the Senate would ultimately approve the pact could erode support for the agreement in the House, where it previously seemed headed for an easy victory. 
 Mr. Dole, the likely Senate majority leader, said again today that he would be more inclined to vote for the accord if the White House dropped its objections to a cut in the capital gains tax. The accord reduces tariffs and greatly extends the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, and is the result of more than a decade of negotiations that spanned three Administrations. Until Sunday, Mr. Dole had not linked the passage of the agreement to the tax cut, long a Republican objective.
Mr. Gingrich, who is expected to become Speaker of the House in January, today reaffirmed his commitment to trying to pass the agreement in a lame-duck session that begins next week. But he declined to criticize Mr. Dole.
"The Senator is negotiating a situation in the Senate which is different from the House," he told reporters at a news conference in Atlanta. "He's a very smart negotiator, and I wouldn't attempt to critique what he's doing."
But today some other members of his own party warned that Mr. Dole was playing a dangerous game, with the possible consequence that Republicans could be blamed for the loss of one of the biggest international tax cuts in history and the failure of an important issue for the business constituents of Republicans.
"We need to get GATT ratified and out of the way," William Kristol, the Republican strategist, said in a memorandum that was widely distributed today. "From a strategic point of view, we don't want a GATT fracas to be the nation's first taste of the new Republican dispensation."
If the bill is delayed beyond the special session of Congress that will begin after Thanksgiving, Mr. Kristol said, it could overwhelm the first weeks or months of the new Republican-controlled Congress.
"The last thing we need at the start," he wrote, "is a complicated and divisive debate on GATT."
This afternoon Mr. Kristol said he had written the memorandum because "I was trying to help the Republicans walk back off this limb."
"Given the opposition out there for GATT," he said, it would not be in the best interest of Republicans "to appear to be part of a back room deal for some financial interests." He added: "If we were still a minority party, it would be reasonable to use this as a weapon. But we're not."
Mr. Kristol's memorandum underscored how divided the Republicans, traditionally the party of free trade, have become over the issue of the 124-nation trade agreement.
A growing number of Republicans have joined an odd alliance of Democratic conservatives, some Southern Republicans like Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and consumer advocates like Ralph Nader in criticizing the accord.
The conservative Democrats and Southerners like Senator Helms from textile-producing states fear that the agreement will speed the importation of low-cost goods. The consumer groups argue that the new World Trade Organization, an institution created under the agreement to arbitrate trade disputes between nations, would have the power to override American environmental or consumer-protection laws that other nations view as barriers to selling goods in the American market.
The result is that the accord has become the subject of three simultaneous struggles. One is among Republicans vying for position as they prepare to take over majority control of Congress. A second is between Republicans and the Democratic White House, as Mr. Dole and others attempt to exercise their new-found powers to negotiate. And a third is a revival of the many economic interests who opposed the pact, but had given up the fight.
Mr. Dole's continued refusal to support the agreement is also beginning to erode support in the House, where passage of the agreement had not been in doubt.
Many House members who planned to vote for the agreement when passage seemed certain are now questioning whether it is wise to go on record in favor of an pact that may ultimately die in the Senate. The House is scheduled to vote on Nov. 29, and the Senate two days later.
"People don't want to be put on the line," Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader in the current Democratically controlled Congress and a supporter of the trade accord, said in an interview today. "There needs to be a sense of confidence in the Senate, or we will begin wondering in the House if we want to even bring it up."
In recent days, some Democratic leaders have been critical of the White House for failing to get President Clinton more publicly involved in the debate. "The President has probably been thinking that this is getting done, and now it is just down to the details," Mr. Gephardt said. "That was correct before, when there was an expectation of general support for GATT. But it may not be true now."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Overtime Is Money, but G.M. Assembly Workers Say They've Had Enough

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JANESVILLE, Wis., Nov. 16

 BODY:
If for many workers the American dream is drifting out of reach, the 4,800 General Motors workers here have nailed it down. They own homes, cars, big-screen televisions, sometimes boats. They have the assurance of secure pensions and good medical care. Many of these men -- and most are men -- earn enough that they can comfortably support their families; their wives don't have to work.
But these workers, whether young and building families or older and planning for retirement, say they cannot enjoy what their labors have bought. G.M., they say, asks them to put in extraordinary stretches of overtime. 
 The company requires them to work 10 hours beyond the conventional 40, about twice the average overtime for American factory workers. And the company strongly encourages them to work even more hours voluntarily, so that it can sell more of the Chevrolet Suburbans and GMC medium duty trucks made here.
Products of a labor union culture that promised a good day's work for a good day's pay, these workers can afford to say that there's such a thing as too much work and more than enough pay. And that is precisely what they are doing. Indeed, they are so fed up with overtime that 92 percent voted early this month to strike if their union, the United Automobile Workers, agrees to authorize one.
Anger with overtime has erupted at other G.M. plants; the union went on strike in Flint, Mich., for four days last September. There, the company bowed to the union's demands, and agreed to hire more workers.
People here like Jack Courtney, 50, who fills in for people on breaks, want the same deal. "People don't just want the money," he said. "They want time with their families."
Like most assembly line workers in this city of 52,133 about 75 miles southwest of Milwaukee, Mr. Courtney is paid about $18.50 an hour before overtime kicks in; $27.75 with it. He said that his U.A.W. Local 95 here thought it had made a sweet deal in 1986 when it agreed to four 10's -- a four-day work week of 10-hour days, with three days off. But the contract also provided for a fifth 10-hour day if the company felt it was needed. Such days were rare at first, but became routine about four years ago.
"Then they went to eight hours on Saturdays," Mr. Courtney said as he drank beer at the G.M. workers' watering hole, Zachow's, on the edge of the plant's grounds. "A lot work Sundays, too. After two or three years of it people are tired."
No one is forced to work beyond the mandatory 50 hours, but the company can make it hard to say no. G.M. has been losing money in its North American business this year, despite strong sales. Workers do not have to look far beyond Janesville to see the rubble of G.M. factories that died after other bouts of losses.
Michael Marcks, president of Local 95, explained: "They'll say: 'You know, we've got customers and they need our product. They could go buy product somewhere else.' You can lean on people that way."
Many other companies have moved to heavy overtime. In September and October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says factory workers put in an average of 4 hours 42 minutes of overtime a week, the most ever registered in the 38 years during which the agency has kept track.
Joe Valdez, 29, would promptly settle for a regular work week. A floater, like Mr. Courtney, he said: "I live a comfortable life. I have my house. I have my car. I have my wife. I got my kids. I got a 2-year-old and a 6-year-old.
"I got my toys, a lot of garage toys. We're saving up to go to Mexico. Forty hours a week is fine for me. If once in a while you get a 50-hour week, that's not bad. But we've got people working double shifts. We need more help in that place."
Mr. Marcks said more workers were being injured at the plant because the overtime leaves them tired, and that makes them accident-prone. But James W. Crellin, a G.M. spokesman in Detroit, said, "We have seen no statistics that would indicate an increase in the severity or frequency of accidents due to increased overtime at out facilities."
General Motors asks people at the busier of its 150 North American plants to work overtime because it is loath to take on permanent new workers. Mr. Marcks said that with the exception of temporary employees, no new workers have been hired in Janesville since 1986.
To stop periodic losses and to streamline the business, General Motors, like thousands of American manufacturers, has been restructuring and cutting its work force even as the economy grows. Almost three years ago, the company said it would eliminate 74,000 jobs; with 244,000 blue- and white-collar workers now, it is just 14,000 short of the goal.
Charles Licari, a company spokesman, said new workers cost about $42 to $43 in hourly wages and benefits, plus time and production lost to hiring and training, so that asking people to work overtime is still less expensive. The typical worker here, who earns $18.50 an hour for 40 hours, earns the standard 50 percent premium, or $27.75 for Saturday and weekday overtime, and double pay, or $37 an hour on Sundays and holidays.
For some busy executives and professional workers, 50-, 60- and even 70-hour weeks are not unusual. But there is a dimension of assembly line overtime that middle-class, white-collar workers seldom face: Management that has to ask people to work longer so that it can produce more goods often asks them to work harder and faster.
On the Suburban line here, G.M. has been stepping up production from 44 vehicles an hour to a goal of 49. Management says that robots, computers and new work methods should permit the higher production speed. But workers say any productivity increases are hurting them and the quality of their work. "We have so many seconds to do a job," said Jim Silbaugh, 44, who puts roofs on trucks. "I've got a moving table. I put the roof on the table. Then a robot picks it up and puts it on the truck."
Then, Mr. Silbaugh said, "They speed the line up. Everybody's got to hurry, hurry, hurry. Sooner or later, somebody's going to be screwing up."
Indeed, more and more finished vehicles are being sent to the plant's repair section, the workers say. A man who does paint repairs, for example, and who declined to be identified, said he works 11 1/2 hours five days a week, 12 hours on Saturday and 8 to 12 hours most Sundays. For his 80 or so hours, he earns more than $2,000. "But if they would give these people more help to do their job better," he said, "then I would think that would take care of some of the repair."
Idolina Garcia, a 40-year-old worker who installs airbags, said she feared that too much work would lead to a recurrence of the repetitive motion injury she sustained to her wrists. Last week, she says she worked only three days, more than 50 hours: Monday and Tuesday from 5:48 A.M. to 10 P.M., and Wednesday from 5:48 A.M. to 1:30 A.M.
Fred Peper, 55, works as a janitor, lifting and breaking up cardboard cartons, for the standard $18.50 an hour. Sometimes he works as much as 66 hours a week over seven days. He doesn't need the money, he said, but his grown children do. In their jobs, they don't have health insurance, so he pays his grandchildren's medical bills.
"I like my job," he said. "I feel good. I hurt, of course. My arms are numb. They're still pushing me pretty hard, but I'm used to it."
Edward Mackay, 36, said high pay could become a habit, and with it, high debt. Mr. Mackay, who tightens bolts that hold gas tanks on trucks, said he kept to the mandatory 50 hours and insisted on two days off a week.
He said he could manage easily on his $750 a week, or $38,000 a year, without the overtime that brings him to $1,000 a week. Married, with a year-and-a-half-old daughter, he has a 1985 Ford truck, a 1990 Harley-Davidson motorcycle and a two-bedroom house he bought four years ago for $23,000.
But he said some co-workers seem ill-prepared for the 40-hour week, or worse, that will reappear when the economy eventually stalls. "These guys are getting in so far over their heads," he said. "They have $200,000 homes. They've just got to have something new in that driveway so people driving by can say, 'That guy must work at G.M.' "

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
A Renewed Modern: More of a Museum Or More Modern?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
Gertrude Stein is supposed to have said, "A museum can either be a museum or it can be modern, but it cannot be both." That has been the Museum of Modern Art's dilemma for all of its 65 years, and it is truer today than it ever was.
How is the archetypal museum of the 20th century to survive into the 21st? Or to put it as Stein might have, how can the Modern remain modern after modernism? 
 As Stein knew, a collection is what makes a museum a museum, and the Modern keeps collecting. Among the first tasks assigned to Glenn D. Lowry, its recently appointed director, when he takes over full-time in July will surely be to ponder the expansion that everyone at the museum has been talking about almost since the last one 10 years ago. The Modern outgrew its new building on 53d Street even before it opened in 1984, and a decade of art since, including lots of big paintings, photographs, sculptures and installations, has only added to the museum's sense that it has a space crunch.
The Modern has been not-so-secretly looking at places to annex around town, including the Dorset Hotel next door, thus far without announcing any results. One explanation of why the museum took so long to find a new director may be that candidates didn't relish the prospect of a tenure spent dealing with real estate, not art.
Even in these straitened economic times for cultural institutions, museums accept the idea that bigger is better. Is it? There are reasons that places like the Frick, the Kimbell, the Gardner and the Freer are many people's favorites. Those museums are intimate, meaning visitors can get to know every work on view in them. The Louvre and the Metropolitan may be indispensible, but they also seem unfathomable.
The Modern is far bigger than the Frick and much smaller than the Metropolitan. Yet if it grows indefinitely, its galleries expanding to accommodate an ever-more-numerous collection, what will distinguish it, eventually, from the Met, except that it has no art from before 1880?
The question isn't quite as crazy as it may seem. Expansion at the Modern is probably unavoidable -- considering bequests that continue to come in, like the Rockefeller and Paley collections -- and not necessarily bad. But there are reasons to fret about it. Some are practical: the last expansion was a disappointment, even if it gave the museum more room and higher revenues. The Modern replaced intimacy with the ambiance of an office building. Its galleries for temporary shows have turned out to be inadequate, even grim, while the best spaces are given over to restaurants.
Most important, the galleries for the permanent collection of painting and sculpture are designed like an endless hallway. Not only must visitors wend their way from one end to the other to get in or out, but the curators must also make the history of modern art, as told through the collection, conform to the architecture. In reality, that history may be multi-layered and contradictory, but in the Modern it must look seamless, as if marching forward in an orderly manner.
The museum has long seen 20th-century art as seamless. The old Modern building had something of the same architectural arrangement, only smaller. The idea of seamlessness stemmed from the museum's founding director, Alfred H. Barr Jr. One of his most extraordinary achievements was literally to draw a chart, like the branches of a family tree, showing how everything in modernism (everything he deemed relevant, at least) grew from the same French roots -- Cezanne, Gauguin, Seurat and van Gogh. Barr's approach influenced the physical layout of the museum, and his legacy was still alive in 1984 for the last expansion.
But times have changed. Barr's vision clearly needs to be reconsidered and broadened, and if the Modern is going to expand successfully, it must think not just of more square footage but also of a revised vision. At the heart of the expansion issue, in other words, is a philosophical question about the way the museum conceives of modern art.
It helps to recall something of the Modern's evolution. The museum opened in 1929 as a place devoted to the new in art. Barr and the museum's founders, aware of the dilemma that Stein described, thought at first that the Modern should possess representative works by Cezanne, van Gogh and others to put new art on view in context, but that it shouldn't be a traditional collecting institution. Barr used a torpedo metaphor. He said the permanent collection was like "a torpedo moving through time, its nose the ever advancing present, its tail the ever receding past of 50 to 100 years ago." Thus the bulk of the collection would remain in the near past and taper off as it went back in time. To remain modern, the Modern would have to avoid becoming a repository of old art.
For a while it was decided that the Modern would periodically turn over older art to the Metropolitan. But that changed after World War II. Rising prices for modern art made it imprudent for the Modern simply to give away what it owned.
At the same time, just as the United States gained hegemony in political and economic spheres, the Modern not coincidentally rose to a position of international pre-eminence in the art world. This meant not only that its exhibitions carried more weight but also that its collection assumed canonical stature. The Modern was transformed, in a sense, by its own success from a spunky and quick-footed place to an august and slow-moving one.
The museum became less spontaneous, more self-conscious about its influence, more focused on history and more reluctant to throw its authority behind young artists. Artists, meanwhile, began to react against modernism, which meant they were reacting against the museum that was synonymous with it. The Modern was increasingly attacked for being out of touch with the new, and by the late 1960's other institutions arose in New York to fill the gaps it had supposedly left. Those attacks persisted through the 80's, when the museum took conspicuously long to recognize post-modernism, and they continue to this day.
But a new generation of curators has lately come to power at the Modern. One sign of change is the rearrangement of the permanent collection by Kirk Varnedoe, the chief curator of painting and sculpture, to reflect more of the rough-and-tumble reality of history, although Mr. Varnedoe can still do only so much within the constraints of the Modern's galleries and its collection. Another sign is the variety of shows of new art, which is a little more extensive than before.
And yet another is the apparent willingness of curators from many departments in the museum, like photography, drawings, prints, architecture and design, to work together, thus breaking down the barriers between media that were also a holdover from the old days. Since so much contemporary art is multi-media, departmental cooperation is crucial if the museum is to dedicate itself to the new.
But should it? The Modern could just declare itself a museum specializing in the 20th century, as the Musee d'Orsay in Paris specializes in the 19th. It's a perfectly plausible goal: to elaborate on and refine the vision of 20th-century art that Barr and his colleagues developed, leaving the 21st century to someplace else.
It's plausible. But museums tend to think of themselves as sharks (not just torpedoes): they've got to keep moving to stay afloat. And at the Modern, movement has always meant expansion.
One can only hope that plans for more of it will not go forward until the museum and its incoming director have first done some hard thinking about how the new space will be used, as well as who will design it. Will it unlock the Modern from its old vision of art history and allow it more flexibility? Will it make sense of a museum in the 21st century whose collection begins in the 19th? Or will it just mean bigger rooms, more art, more restaurants, shops and bookstores? One hopes not. The Modern will have to prove Stein wrong, without simply doing more of the same, to succeed. Real estate, in some ways, will be the least of Mr. Lowry's concerns.

HEADLINE: Appellate Ruling Called a Threat to Endangered Species Act

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
IF the United States Supreme Court does not overturn a ruling from a Federal appeals panel, the Endangered Species Act might itself be threatened with de facto extinction, conservation groups, biologists and the Justice Department argue.
The department filed a petition with the Supreme Court this month asking it to reject a ruling from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia that the act does not prevent the destruction of the habitat of an endangered species, even if destroying the habitat means exterminating the animal. The lower court ruling, called Sweet Home Chapter of Communities for a Greater Oregon v. Babbitt, shocked conservationists and made them run for legal ammunition to protect the teeth of an act that is considered one of the most effective pieces of environmental legislation ever passed. 
 If the act cannot be used to protect the habitat of an endangered organism, the opponents of the new ruling insist, then it cannot protect the species and becomes an impotent husk of legislation.
The act states that it is illegal to take, kill, capture, harass or "harm" an endangered species. For the 20 years of the act's existence, the word "harm" has been interpreted to mean that the foraging, nesting or living sites on which an animal depends cannot be substantially modified. It certainly means that it cannot be destroyed altogether, said Tim Eichenberg, a lawyer with the Center for Marine Conservation in Washington, which opposes the appellate ruling.
Based on that interpretation, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has devised regulations to protect the habitat of species living on either government or private lands and to encourage property owners to take the needs of any threatened species living on their lands into account when planning development projects.
But the appeals court ruled that the word harm did not mean habitat must be protected, and that the act merely prevented an animal from being bagged or shot at outright.
"I find it totally absurd to conclude legalistically that the endangered species act did not mean to include habitat," said Dr. Thomas Eisner, an evolutionary biologist at Cornell University who has been extremely active in conservation work. "This says that you can build on either side of an eagle's nest as long as you don't build right on top of the eagle." And if the eagle happens to be out hunting, he added, "then the nest also becomes fair game."
For now, the ruling only applies to the District of Columbia, but should it be upheld by the Supreme Court it would doubtless have nationwide reverberations, casting into doubt 150 habitat conservation plans proposed by Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt that are in various stages of development. If there is no longer any legal incentive to protect habitat for endangered species, said Mr. Eichenberg, "then I don't think many companies or individuals now engaged in conservation planning efforts are going to bother continuing."
He said tens of thousands of acres of non-Federal lands could be affected by the ruling, and about half the 230 species listed on the roster of endangered animals and plants -- those living largely or exclusively on non-government territory -- would find their living quarters suddenly in jeopardy.
The act is thought to be responsible for rescuing a number of famously endangered beasts, among them the bald eagle, alligator, gray whale, black-footed ferret and red wolf. Many surveys show that the act enjoys vast support among the general public, though lately the act has been depicted as a drag on economic development and an example of Government obstructionism.
The case started about four years ago when a loose coalition of timberland holders, logging companies and community groups in the Oregon region used the debate over the fate of the northern spotted owl as an opportunity to begin challenging Federal rules intended to protect endangered animals.
Last year, a panel of the appeals court in the District of Columbia voted 2 to 1 to reject the group's arguments that habitat preservation was not specified by the endangered species act and instead upheld Fish and Wildlife's definition of the word harm. The Sweet Home group asked the court to reconsider, and in March the same three judges reversed their previous ruling and agreed, 2 to 1, that the act strictly referred to the immediate and direct destruction of species, not to their habitat.
The Justice Department has asked the full Court of Appeals to reconsider that decision, but it has also called on the Supreme Court to issue a ruling that would become the law of the land. Should the High Court choose to take up the case -- and many predict that it will -- the ruling is likely to be handed down by summer.
The judge who reversed himself in March was Judge Stephen F. Williams. Voting both times to protect the habitat was Chief Judge Abner J. Mikva, while Judge David B. Sentelle voted against extending such protection.

HEADLINE: Bob Dole, Trade Bully

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, the next majority leader, is exploiting his new political power by withholding approval of a world trade agreement that has taken seven years to negotiate. One reason, he says, is that the accord will threaten American sovereignty. That at least sounds noble, though Mr. Dole is wrong. His other reason is narrow and crass. As he told ABC on Sunday, he may block the trade accord unless the Administration swallows a cut in the tax on capital gains -- the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other investments.
Mr. Dole's behavior mirrors what the electorate decisively rejected two weeks ago: politicians who say they stand for one set of principles but act according to another. The Republican Party has proudly put the U.S. in the forefront of nations negotiating for open trade and investment. Mr. Dole supported past free-trade pacts because he recognized that they contributed mightily to world growth. The new accord would give the U.S. economy alone a boost of between $70 billion and $200 billion a year. 
 Now, however, he threatens to dishonor this tradition by sacrificing an agreement that, on average, could enrich American families by $1,000 per year -- for the sake of a proposal designed to line the pockets of already-wealthy investors. The Republican version of a capital gains tax cut would do little for the economy. But it would provide a nifty and undeserved gift for investors whose assets have appreciated over time.
Time, alas, is on Mr. Dole's side. When Congress takes up the accord next week the legislation comes under "fast track" rules, which require Congress to vote immediately and without amendments. If Mr. Dole stops approval, the legislation will carry over into next year when it may no longer be protected by fast track. Protectionist forces could add crippling amendments, which the 123 other signatory nations would surely reject. Delay, then, almost surely means defeat.
Also adding to Mr. Dole's leverage is the fact that the Government estimates that the accord, by cutting tariffs, would initially reduce government revenue. To adopt it, the Senate will need 60 votes to suspend budget rules -- a total that would appear out of reach unless Mr. Dole signs on.
The Senator apparently wants the Administration to enter a Faustian bargain. It would agree to warp estimates of future tariff revenues so that the trade pact would no longer appear to raise the deficit. But the Administration would thereby set a precedent of using optimistic revenue estimates, providing safe haven for Mr. Dole's proposals for cuts in taxes on capital gains and retirement savings. At risk is the credibility of budget estimates upon which Congress bases decisions.
Mr. Dole is apparently close to negotiating at least a cosmetic victory on sovereignty. The threat he and others have raised is mostly imaginary, but it goes like this: The World Trade Organization, which the accord would set up to adjudicate trade disputes, might capriciously rule that U.S. environmental, labor and safety laws amount to unfair trade barriers that should be struck down or answered with sanctions against U.S. exports.
Mr. Dole exaggerates the threat. Trade panels under existing international rules can already authorize sanctions against the U.S.; the new treaty does not invent new threats. The U.S. would be ultimately protected in the future, as it is now, by the unwillingness of countries to engage the U.S. in a trade war.
Besides, the U.S. has the right to pull out of the Trade Organization on six months' notice. Whatever deal Mr. Dole might strike with the Administration is likely to clarify procedures for withdrawal but is unlikely to enhance U.S. sovereignty.
Tearing apart the trade accord for the sake of a tax cut on capital gains is reckless. Few believe the tax cut can have a powerful impact on the economy. But free trade helps, enormously.
