LENGTH: 690 words

HEADLINE: Observer;
Adam Smith, Please Call

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Reading an article on popular music the other day, I was halfway through before realizing I was asleep. This was not the article's fault.
A primitive conviction that anything can be learned if you have the patience to read about it remains with me despite long experience to the contrary. Another primitive impulse, however, has lately been sending me into dreamland whenever I delve into difficult subjects. As a result, I now spend a lot of time sleeping in prose which I have entered in search of knowledge. 
Computer manuals, for example. I will never need sleeping pills as long as there's a computer manual. A page or two on RAM and ROM and I'm the sandman's most peaceful baby. A recent tract on what caused the First World War gave me the best night's sleep in a month, and on a straight-back kitchen chair too.
Only last week while writing one of these columns I had reached just about this point when I paused to read it from the top, hoping to discover what I was talking about. I might have slept past the deadline but for a panicked editor's telephoned reminder that an uncertain America awaited my guidance.
What anesthetized me in the pop-music article was a reference to punk rock and macho rock. Mere tots are totally knowledgeable on these subjects, but to me they are as remote as the moons of Uranus. To me there is only one kind of rock; namely, loud rock.
It's wonderful that anybody has ears subtle enough to tell punk rock from macho rock, nerd rock or rock-'em-sock-'em rock. I am ashamed that I can't do it, and would like to learn, but an ancient inner voice whispers, "Nobody can master everything, pal, so why not settle for a little nap?"
"Well," you may ask if you are Alan Greenspan, "if you're not qualified to dilate on simple rocks, how can you dare talk about economics, as you obviously intend to do?"
The answer is I'm not going to talk about economics, but merely ask a few simpleton's questions. These have occurred to me over the past few weeks just before falling into deep slumber from opening paragraphs of economics news stories.
For instance, about the Federal Reserve people constantly raising interest rates: I know they do it for our own good. To prevent inflation. And I understand that inflation would be a terrible disaster.
I also understand that whether we're hit by the inflation catastrophe depends on people who buy and sell bonds. If they think we are inflation bound, it's "So long, sweetheart!"
They start buying or maybe selling bonds -- I'm not sure which -- at a prodigious rate, and the whole country is kaput. So obviously, having us at their mercy, they must be kept happy. Meaning, assured that inflation is not in the cards.
That's why Mr. Greenspan and company have to keep raising rates. And bless them in this good work, say I. There's a drawback though. Raising rates keeps the economy hissing and knocking like a car with a missing cylinder.
With each rate rise, businesses that are about to boom slow down instead. Out-of-work people with good job prospects remain out of work instead.
This unhappiness -- misery for some -- is all for the greater good of the whole country. Hence, commendable. Failing businessmen and jobless people are doing heroic service. By going down the drain, by not working, they are keeping the bond people from dropping the inflation bomb.
My question is this: Shouldn't the country treat these people at least as well as it treats its military people? They get uniforms, decent salaries, early-retirement pension plans.
Why not the same for the businessmen ducking the bankers' artillery, the unemployed working stiffs living on pasta and beans? They're on the front line every day sacrificing to keep a terrifying bond market at bay.
This leads to a second economics question; to wit, why are politicians suddenly so eager to make welfare people take jobs? Here is the Federal Reserve doing its best to keep unemployment high so as to pacify bond people, while politicians insist that these already unemployed welfare people become dis-unemployed.
Does this make economic sense? Wake me if you find out.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Gets Shortchanged on Subway Station Renovation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 15 news article on renewal of subway work in Flushing, Queens, raises great concerns for the residents and commuters of Brooklyn. For the New York City administration to target a single renovation project in one borough is an oversight that needs correction. 
 A look at the last decade of Metropolitan Transportation Authority use of capital funds shows that though Brooklyn has 36 percent of the stations in the city transit system, only 17 percent of M.T.A. station renovations between 1982 through 1991 were done in Brooklyn.
That is why Brooklyn's elected officials and transit riders fought to insure that Brooklyn would have the largest share of station renovations in the current five-year capital improvement plan. Of 93 stations scheduled for rehabilitation before 1997, 41 are in Brooklyn.
This week we learned that 13 of these projects have been canceled. These include two, the Franklin Shuttle and Atlantic Terminal, that are vital to the thousands of people who live, work and go to school in Brooklyn. These are grave omissions, and they need to be restored.
The condition of stations on the Franklin Avenue Shuttle line may be the system's worst. Further delay in making repairs to the line may mean the loss of an entire transportation system for Crown Heights and central Brooklyn.
Additionally, by any measure, Atlantic Terminal must remain on the M.T.A.'s list for immediate rehabilitation. Conditions at this busy transportation complex in downtown Brooklyn are also among the worst in the city.
This complex, which serves 10 subway lines and connects the system with the Long Island Rail Road, is Brooklyn's Grand Central Terminal, serving 140,000 commuters daily. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's own staff survey has urgently recommended this much-needed rehabilitation.
The M.T.A.'s failure to finance rehabilitation of the Atlantic Terminal complex will be a serious setback to the economic resurgence under way in the commercial center of Brooklyn, which is generating new jobs, new housing and new commercial activity.
 
HOWARD GOLDEN
Borough President
Brooklyn, Nov. 16, 1994

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY PLANS TO CUT PAYMENTS FOR MEDICAID 20%

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
New Jersey officials said today that they planned to cut the amount of money hospitals receive to care for Medicaid patients by 20 percent starting in March. William Waldman, the State Human Services Commissioner, said he expected a court challenge, but is confident the move, which would reduce hospital reimbursements by $135 million annually, would be upheld.
"We cannot be in the business of subsidizing hospitals," Mr. Waldman told reporters at a meeting in his office. "We must become the purchasers of services that are delivered efficiently and economically." 
 New Jersey now pays the third highest Medicaid rates in the country, behind Rhode Island and New York, Mr. Waldman said, and the proposed rate changes would place the state closer to the national average. The cuts would simply be made across the board, based on the amounts of the previous year's reimbursements, regardless of the number of patients served. Under state law, no one may be refused medical care.
Medicaid is one of the largest and fastest-growing costs for state governments, in many cases the second biggest outlay after education. In recent years, state officials across the country have taken a variety of approaches to lower expenses, limiting prescription drug use as well as coverage for certain procedures considered optional, like fertility operations.
One approach is to lower compensation to providers: hospitals and doctors. For example, Kentucky has recently proposed a $50 million reduction in Medicaid payments to physicians.
Although Mr. Waldman said the cutback is not intended to be a budget-saving device, he said it was inspired in part by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's philosophy of making government "smarter, leaner and more effective." But he also called Medicaid "the Pac-Man" of government, eating up the state budget, and said program costs were increasing at a rate of 18 percent a year, threatening possible service cuts in the future.
The announcement was a surprise and shock to hospital administrators. Gary S. Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, said, "Slashing payment rates to hospitals by 20 percent at a time when demand for services is increasing and proposed alternatives like managed care for Medicaid is still on the drawing board is wrong.
"In the long run, these cuts will hurt the most vulnerable hospitals and most vulnerable people in the state," Mr. Carter said, in a written statement released through his office. "Hospitals are not in favor of any cuts that would undermine the mission and integrity of the entire Medicaid payment system."
Administrators of many of the association's 100 member hospitals will meet on Monday to come up with a more complete response to the announcement, he said.
Ron Jones, the chief financial officer of United Hospitals Medical Center and Children's Hospital in Newark, learned that his hospital's Medicaid reimbursements will drop to $32.5 million from $40.6 million if the changes are finally approved.
"I can't imagine setting a budget with $8 million less," he said. "We might have to curtail services at some point." Mr. Jones said half of the 10,000 patients the hospital admits each year are Medicaid recipients. The medical center has 345 beds and a $140 million annual budget.
"I hope we can at least convince the state to phase in these cuts so we don't have to deal with them all at once," he said. "We'll have to think about increasing the number of insured patients we serve, but that would take several months and probably wouldn't make up for all the loss."
Michael Sparer, an assistant professor of health in the School of Public Health at Columbia University, said there are frequent challenges across the country over hospital reimbursement rates by state-run Medicaid programs. "The states win some contests and some they don't," he said.
The test for the courts is whether the reimbursement is "reasonable" and whether the hospitals are providing "efficient and economic" services, he said.
"I think New Jersey has a better chance of winning because it has always paid hospitals above cost," Professor Sparer said. The national reimbursement rate is about 80 percent, he said, but in a report released last year by the Congressional Research Service, New Jersey was reported to have paid hospitals 105 percent of costs in 1990, the last year covered by the report.
The Medicaid cuts are one of several financial pressures on the hospital industry. In recent years Congress has regularly limited its increases in compensation for the Medicare program for the elderly, and private insurers have used their managed-care programs to negotiate lower compensation rates.
In New York, Governor-elect George E. Pataki has appointed a task force headed by Elizabeth P. McCaughey, the Lieutenant Governor-elect, to examine the state's $20 billion Medicaid program for possible economies.
James R. Tallon, the president of the United Hospitals Fund of New York, said, "There is also pressure to cut Medicaid spending in other states, and if it disproportionately affects urban hospitals it could make it difficult for them to survive."
John Holahan, director of the health policy research center at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research group in Washington, said, "There are lots of ways cut back on Medicaid, but not many pain-free ways." The same hospitals that care for most of the Medicaid patients are those that have a lot of charity care, he said.
"You can probably find some fat in administrative costs but at some point you're going to get into the muscle," he said. Mr. Holahan said the search for economies comes as Congress is preparing to look at Medicare next year. "You could see hospitals scrambling to remain competitive," he said.
New York, New Jersey and most other states are moving to managed-care systems, aimed at getting patients out of emergency rooms and into health centers where they can get preventive and primary care. So far, 420,000 of the New York's 2.5 million Medicaid patients are in managed care, but the goal is to enroll half by the year 2000.
New Jersey has enrolled 46,000 of about 400,000 people who receive welfare through the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program and hopes to have most receiving their health care through health maintenance organizations in another two years.
Indiana trimmed its Medicaid program by $100 million in 1993 and is looking to make $400 million more in cuts this year. Critics there have charged that the service reductions are too severe and say the two-year Medicaid reduction program should be stopped.
In Massachusetts, Gov. William Weld, a Republican, recently stopped paying for fertility treatments for women on Medicaid. In 1993, his administration, with support from the Democratic Legislature, negotiated lower rates with nursing homes and hospitals and moved 250,000 Medicaid recipients into managed care.
Until two years ago, New Jersey, like many other states, paid for charity care by adding a 19 percent surcharge to the hospital bills of paying patients or those with insurance. That system also covered bad debts, which could conceivably been used to pay for any shortfall in Medicaid reimbursement.
But under the new system, which runs through the end of the next year, charity care is being financed by borrowing $1.6 billion from the Unemployment Insurance Fund, and bad debts are not covered.
Hospital administrators say that if they can't find the economies in their operations the state is seeking, then they will have no choice but to cut services. Ron Napiorski, chief financial officer for University Hospital, a teaching hospital at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, said the $14 million cut the hospital is scheduled to experience could force a reduction in its training program for interns and residents.
Mr. Waldman said the cutback in Medicaid payments would not be so severe that it would affect access to health care. He said as a result of deregulation, "Market forces in the health care industry are changing very rapidly, and we believe our new rates will be competitive with what other purchasers of health care are paying next year."
Federal law requires that states make Medicaid reimbursements that are "reasonable and adequate." In the last several years hospitals and nursing homes in several states, including New York, Indiana and Washington, have won legal challenges to have reimbursement increased.
Velvet Miller, New Jersey's director of the Division of Medical Assistance and Health Services, said Medicaid pays $1 billion for inpatient services for 132,000 people annually. Of that total, $676 million is paid to the state's 84 acute care hospitals that would be affected by the rate change.
The Federal and state governments each pay half of New Jersey's Medicaid costs, so the $135 million in projected savings will mean a $67.5 million spending cut for the state.
Al Drake, the chief spokesman for the Public Defender's Office, said the proposed cutback was the type of government action the Public Advocate's office "would have looked at and expressed concern about, but there is no longer a Public Advocate." As part of a cost savings effort, Mrs. Whitman eliminated the Public Advocate's Department during her first few months in office.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 91.52 As High Rates Lure Investors to Bonds

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In one of the most turbulent market sessions this year, stock prices fell further yesterday than on any other day in the last 10 months.
Almost all the 91.52-point, or 2.4 percent, selloff in the Dow Jones industrial average came in late afternoon trading and left traders puzzling about the reasons. But many said the heavy sales were a result of the belief that investors, both large companies and average Americans, would now sell stocks to buy bonds because they were becoming a more attractive investment. 
 The attraction of bonds is tied to the fact that interest rates are at their highest level in more than two years. Such higher rates are offering investors yields in the bond market that many feel outweigh the near-term gains in stocks. Indeed, bonds rallied yesterday. [Page D15].
Don Fishback, president of Fishback Management and Research in Cincinnati, likened the current situation to "reverse sticker shock," the mirror image of the time that consumers soured on low yields for bank certificates of deposit and Treasury bills a few years ago and bought stocks instead.
"People are finally understanding that it's better to get 7.5 percent guaranteed by the Government than a 3 percent dividend" from a stock, he said.
Yesterday, the Dow fell 91.52 points, to 3,677.99, in one of the heaviest trading days of the year, with 385.3 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange. That level is 33 percent higher than the year's daily average of 290 million shares.
The two other big stock indexes also fell, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks down 1.8 percent and the Nasdaq down 2.2 percent.
The Federal Reserve's six short-term rate increases this year have pushed the interest rate on 30-year Government bonds to more than 8 percent and two-year Treasury notes to more than 7 percent. The last increase, a jump of three-quarters of a percentage point, came last week, as the Fed continued to try to slow growth and restrain inflation in the year ahead.
Analysts worry that if the rate increases prompt a shift in investors' sentiment to bonds, the outlook for the stock market could be for further sharp declines. At the least, the stock market, which set highs in January, would settle around its lows for the year.
Selling in expectation of an event is normal in financial markets, as traders and investors try to get ahead of the tide, which can increase their gains and cut their losses.
On Monday Byron Wien, United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, reduced his recommended allocation of stocks to 85 percent, from 97 percent, with the difference going to securities with maturities less than one year.
"I think I'm late in recommending this change," Mr. Wien said. "The thing that has been driving the stock market is mutual funds, and there is increased probability that cash inflows into mutual funds may slow or even reverse."
"It's not happening yet," he added. "I'm just saying the risk is higher."
Spokeswomen at Fidelity Magellan and T. Rowe Price, two of the nation's biggest mutual funds, said there was little transfering out of stock funds into bond or money-market funds yesterday.
In the last two days, the Dow has fallen 137 points, or 3.6 percent, the biggest two-day drop since late March, about three weeks after the Federal Reserve raised short term interest rates on Feb. 4 for the first time this year.
Moreover, stock prices may drop again this week if two Government reports -- durable-goods orders today and jobless claims on Friday -- signal the kind of economic strength that the Federal Reserve's policy makers and the financial markets regard as inflationary. Such inflation signals often prompt the Fed to further push up interest rates.
Because of the Fed's six increases in key interest rates, Treasury notes with maturities as short as one year now yield more than twice as much as the 30 blue-chip stocks of the Dow, even with their dividends reinvested into the stocks. On price alone, the Dow has lost more than 2 cents for every dollar invested in it since the beginning of the year.
"We're talking negative territory as far as stocks, and everybody is noticing," said Gregory A. Nie, vice president for technical analysis atKemper Securities in Chicago. "Even cash -- and I mean 30-day or 90-day notes -- is outperforming bonds, and bonds are certainly beating stocks."
On any given day, there are any number of explanations for market movements, such as worries about the passage of the global free trade agreement or speculation about large institutional investors or mutual funds selling large blocks of shares in key stocks.
But like Monday's decline, in which the Dow tumbled 45.75 points, yesterday's fall came out of a cloudless sky. The dollar had been stable for much of the session, bond prices were up and no significant Government reports were released to rattle traders.
A normally favorable portent for the markets may have stampeded the stock traders. The Treasury Department sold $11 billion in five-year notes at a yield of 7.81 percent, one-hundredth of a percentage point less than bond traders had expected to pay.
That tiny gap signaled to many stock and bond traders that the floodgates of potential bond buyers might open soon. Those buyers had been sitting on their hands for more than a month since long-term bond yields passed 8 percent.
If those buyers sold stocks to buy bonds, that meant a downdraft for stocks. The rush for the exits began around 2:45 P.M., not long after the results of the Treasury auction were announced, and accelerated in the last 15 minutes of trading.
Mr. Nie, the technical analyst at Kemper, said that much like they did on Monday, traders watched a key price indicator all day and then sold stocks in a rush. But instead of watching the 200-day moving average for the S.& P. 500, they watched the Dow, whose level of 3,750 had held at critical points in the March and June quarters.
When, at 3 P.M., the Dow fell past that level, traders pushed the button on their high-speed computer programs to sell stocks, mainly those in the Dow and S.& P. 500 indexes. At 3:35 P.M., the New York Stock Exchange invoked its "circuit breaker" rules to slow computer-guided trading.
In addition, a third key stock index, the Nasdaq composite index was signaling trouble. The Nasdaq index, generally reflecting smaller companies like high-technology firms, fell 16.53 points to 741.21 yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 4.26 points, to 246.32, and the American Stock Exchange market value index declined 5.14 points, to 436.14. The S.& P. 500 fell 8.21 points, to 450.08.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 565 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Markets
 Stocks plunged in tumultuous late afternoon trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 91.52 points, or 2.4 percent. Although the steep selloff left many traders puzzling, others saw it as a result of a growing awareness that higher interest rates have made bonds a more attractive investment. [Page A1.] 
 Treasury securities staged a broad rally, benefiting from a flight by investors out of stocks and a strong five-year auction. [D15.]
 The dollar was weaker after the head of the Bundesbank said he favored a strong mark and American stocks plunged. [D16.]
 Sugar prices jumped on a forecast that consumption would outpace production. Crude oil prices rose modestly. [D16.]
 
Companies
 Continental Cablevision will acquire the cable systems of the Providence Journal Company in a $1.4 billion deal. [D1.]
 The S.E.C. is investigating the sales of limited partnerships by Paine Webber, Merrill Lynch, Dean Witter, Lehman Brothers and other brokerage firms. The broad inquiry comes after almost four years of investigating Prudential Securities. [D1.]
 Union Bank of Switzerland won a shareholder vote to keep the institution out of the hands of a Swiss financier. [D2.]
 The $2 billion tender offer for Borden began. [D4.]
 Santa Fe Pacific urged shareholders to back a proposed merger with Burlington Northern but hinted that it might change its mind if Union Pacific sweetened its rival offer. [D4.]
 The California Insurance Commissioner ordered 28 auto insurers to pay premium rollbacks totaling $1.25 billion. [D4.]
 SNET will buy cellular properties for $450 million. [D4.]
 The president of Karl Lagerfeld left the company. [D4.]
 Microsoft and Intuit received a second request from the Justice Department for information on their proposed merger. [D5.]
 
Business Technology
 Cost-cutting in health care is changing the use of medical devices. Hospital administrators are pressing doctors to use cheaper artificial joints, pacemakers and other implants. And many doctors are also being urged to channel more business to manufacturers that offer hospitals the deepest discounts. [D1.]
 
International
 A deal with Senator Bob Dole for his support of GATT is expected by the Clinton Administration. [A18.]
 Oil traders are not worried about OPEC's decision to freeze current production levels through 1995. High world inventories and past OPEC failures to enforce production agreements cast doubts on the latest effort to drive up oil prices. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Dole and Gingrich Embrace Before Republican Governors

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 22

 BODY:
Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich today displayed a bonhomie seldom, if ever, seen between the two Republicans.
In their first joint appearance since the election two weeks ago, Mr. Gingrich of Georgia, the House Speaker-in-waiting, and Mr. Dole, who is likely to become the Senate majority leader, appeared at the close of the Republican Governors Association conference here to emphasize how well they will work together. 
 When they were not flattering each other, they were flattering the 30 governors and governors-to-be whose party dominates the governorships for the first time in a quarter-century.
As might be expected on this day of mutual admiration, the governors responded with standing ovations after Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich vowed that they would restore power to the states. Seeking to reassure the governors, they said that while the states would get less Federal money, they would not be unduly burdened by efforts in Washington to balance the budget and streamline Government.
Even for politicians, who have a penchant for saying nice things about people they despise, the cordiality between Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole was noteworthy. The two have never been close. It was Mr. Gingrich who once called Mr. Dole "the tax collector for the welfare state." And in recent years Mr. Dole has made it clear that he prefers working within the system and had little patience, or respect, for Mr. Gingrich or his attacks on the political establishment.
During the campaign, Mr. Dole declined to endorse Mr. Gingrich's "Contract With America," a manifesto of proposals signed by more than 300 Republican House candidates.
But today Mr. Dole said, "I'm excited about the Contract With America." And he pledged to work with Mr. Gingrich, even as he acknowledged, "We're not going to agree on every issue."
Mr. Dole playfully teased Mr. Gingrich for getting more attention now that he is in line to be the first Republican Speaker in 40 years, which would put him second in succession to the President.
"I generally follow Newt these days on these TV shows; he's in line to be President but I'm not sure what I'm in line to be," Mr. Dole, who is preparing for a possible bid for President in 1996, said to roars of laughter from the audience.
Mr. Gingrich, 51, who spoke first, was just as complimentary of Mr. Dole, describing the 71-year-old Senator as far more experienced in Government. "The press is going to make a big effort to try to get a wedge between the Republicans in the Senate and the Republicans in the House," he said, perhaps foreseeing inevitable strains between the two chambers -- and the two leaders. "We lead two different institutions, and Senator Dole is clearly the senior Republican leader in Washington, has been a Presidential candidate, has been a majority leader. I mean, he actually has been in charge.
"I stand here, in a sense, as the student of the governors."
Mr. Dole drew cheers from the chief executives by telling them that the first Senate bill introduced in the new session will deal with limiting the Government's practice of imposing requirements, or mandates, for the states without providing the money to meet them.
But Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, who is expected to become chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, warned the governors that it would not be painless. "We will get out of the mandate business," Mr. Packwood said, "but we will also get out of the money business."
The appeals for unity clearly pleased the governors, many of whom praised Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich. Several governors also said they were no longer as concerned as they had been on Sunday, when the conference opened and some were warning the new leadership not to impose themselves on the states and not to emphasize social programs at the expense of economic ones.
After a closed-door breakfast meeting between the governors and the new Congressional leaders, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey said, "The most important thing is that we are all together."
Gov. John Engler of Michigan said it was an exciting time because "the doors are open and we're sitting at the table." And Gov.-elect George W. Bush of Texas spoke of the "positive spirit of addressing difficult problems."
Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole called it a historic meeting, and it certainly was unusual. For the first time in decades, the Republicans who will dominate both chambers of Congress and the governorships sat together, with all parties seemingly eager to use their new power to make major changes.
"This is the meeting which crystallized the process of getting power out of Washington," Mr. Gingrich said.
As high as their spirits were, both Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich acknowledged that they were well aware that the era of good feeling and harmony on the issues among Republicans would probably not last.
Mr. Dole declined to embrace a welfare overhaul plan supported by Mr. Gingrich that would replace poverty and food plans with lump sum payments to the states. "I don't know how many welfare ideas we have -- probably as many as we have people up here," the Senator, flanked by several governors, said at a news conference.
At one session with the governors, Mr. Dole said it was too early to debate specifics. "Don't get sucked into the details," he told them. "Give us a little time."
In the meantime, he was savoring the moment. "It's never going to get any better than it is right now because we don't have the responsibility yet," Mr. Dole said. "So it's great."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Bob Dole, right, and Representative Newt Gingrich, left, told the Republican governors yesterday that they would return power to the states. At Mr. Gingrich's left was Haley Barbour, Republican National Committee chairman, and at his right, Gov. Mike Leavitt of Utah. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Administration Says Deal With Dole on Trade Is Near

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Administration officials said tonight that they expected by Wednesday to reach a deal with Senator Bob Dole that would pave the way for his support of a world trade agreement scheduled for a vote in a lame-duck session of Congress next week.
After a day of negotiations with Mr. Dole over his objections to a crucial part of the pact, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said, "We're making great progress and I think we'll have it." 
 At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Clinton contended that the expansion of the 124-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, would "raise incomes of American workers, and I think that is our most urgent economic job."
Moreover, he rejected Mr. Dole's effort to win a concession from the White House. Over the weekend, Mr. Dole suggested that his support for the trade pact would be linked to White House support for a cut in the capital gains tax rate, long a Republican objective.
But Mr. Clinton gingerly steered clear of criticizing Mr. Dole today, saying he had shown a "very constructive attitude." The President said he was "encouraged by the progress that we have made in working with Senator Dole on the substantive issues surrounding GATT."
Mr. Dole was more cautious than Mr. Kantor this evening and made no predictions of an imminent agreement. "It is my hope that the differences with the Administration over the GATT accord can be resolved soon," he said. "We are trying to fix GATT, and if we can, we should act on it this year." But he did make his support for the trade accord conditional on White House concessions on the capital gains tax cut, which Mr. Clinton has repeatedly rejected as a tax break for the rich.
"My objective is to make certain that the capital gains issue gets a fair hearing from this Administration," Mr. Dole said.
Without the support of Mr. Dole, who is likely to be the next majority leader, passage of the agreement seems difficult, and perhaps impossible, in the Senate. Over the past two days Mr. Dole has come under tremendous pressure from all sides of his party, with major business interests -- including potential financial supporters if Mr. Dole seeks the Presidency in 1996 -- urging him to support the complex trade accord, and conservatives warning him that the bill would surrender American sovereignty to a newly created organization, the World Trade Organization.
Critics of the accord, including many conservatives in both parties, have complained that foreign judges reviewing trade complaints for the World Trade Organization could rule against American environmental or labor laws, or state regulations, declaring them impediments to the importing of foreign goods into the United States. If Congress or the states refused to change the law, trade sanctions could be imposed against American goods.
Mr. Kantor said today that the Administration had been negotiating with Mr. Dole over the creation of a commission that would review World Trade Organization decisions to determine that the proceedings were fair. "The issue is not whether we win or lose," he said, "as long as the process is proper."
Though Mr. Kantor declined to go into the details of the commission's workings, other Administration officials said that it would be able to recommend, if necessary, that Congress pull out of the trade accord. Under the terms of GATT, any member can leave the organization with six months' notice.
"It's very, very unlikely this would ever happen," a senior Administration official said earlier this week. "But we want to give Dole the cover he needs to support this thing."
But the review panel idea is fraught with its own political perils, both for the Administration and for Mr. Dole. Foreign nations that were pressured by the United States to agree to the extension of GATT and to the creation of the organization, may view the accord with Mr. Dole as a sign that the United States is not committed to obeying the World Trade Organization's mandates. "It weakens the authority of the institution if the United States is threatening to pull away if they don't like the outcomes," a Japanese diplomat said this week.
Nor is the accord likely to satisfy critics of the trade accord, who have seized upon the World Trade Organization issue in their efforts to torpedo the entire accord.
Today a prominent Democrat, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, declared that he would vote against "this misguided agreement."
"I heard the message from the voters two weeks ago, and they want their Federal government to change the way business is conducted in Washington," he said. "I believe it would be a mistake to ignore this political sea change by ramming the GATT through Congress next week without much debate and with no opportunity to amend." Under the rules guiding GATT's passage, debate is limited and the bill itself cannot be amended. Mr. Dole's concerns would be addressed in subsequent legislation, probably next year.
The right wing of the Republican party, whose support Mr. Dole must also seek in any presidential bid, is also urging Mr. Dole to hold out against GATT, no matter what assurances are provided by the Administration. Patrick J. Buchanan, who led the "America First" trade campaigns, calls the agreement "a wholesale surrender of American sovereignty and states rights."
Paul Weyrich, president of the conservative Free Congress Foundation and president of National Empowerment Television, said today, "I believe the implementing legislation is flawed, that the World Trade Organization is suspect and that a lame-duck session of Congress has no business taking up a measure as important as GATT, in as much as this session of Congress has been repudiated by the American people."

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Board Votes Plan Calling for 10 Fare Rise

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Brushing aside the objections of New York City officials, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a long-range strategy yesterday that calls for a 10-cent fare increase next year to help pay for monthly passes with unlimited rides and free transfers between subways and buses.
But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's two representatives on the M.T.A. board said the plan was unrealistic because it did not take into account the city's decision to cut $113 million from its contribution to the M.T.A. 
 "There are a lot of holes in this plan -- you could drive an M.T.A. train through some of them," said Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, one of the Giuliani administration's representatives on the board.
Several other board members said they had voted for the plan with deep reservations and now expected a lengthy public debate over whether to raise the fare. But after decades of charging a single fare for each ride, the board for the first time has proposed raising the basic fare -- now $1.25 -- to reduce the costs for some riders, members said.
"This town has never been through a debate like this," said Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A. chairman.
Every year, the M.T.A. must submit a five-year financial plan to the Legislature. But each of the main elements of the plan voted on yesterday must still face public hearings and a separate vote by the board.
The business plan's approval, by a 9-to-3 vote, came at a stormy meeting in which the board also approved giving a $17 million contract to a data processing company, Lockheed Information Management Services, that the Giuliani administration has banned from doing business with the city. Again the Mayor's representatives objected but lost the vote.
The board also voted to delay until at least 1997 the rehabilitation of the decrepit Franklin Avenue shuttle in Brooklyn. The work was put off along with 20 other projects to make up for $500 million the city has cut from the M.T.A. capital budget. While the Brooklyn project was shelved, the board voted to put back into its plan the reconstruction of a busy stop in Flushing, Queens, that Mayor Giuliani wanted protected.
Transit officials acknowledged that plans to revamp fares faced several hurdles before they can become reality. The plan ignores Mr. Giuliani's proposed cut for M.T.A.'s operations this year and counts on the state's replacing that money in the future, an unlikely prospect given the state's own budget problems.
The M.T.A.'s plan also assumes Federal aid will remain steady despite signs in Washington that the new Republican-controlled Congress may again reduce mass-transit financing. It also banks on the board's winning public support for fare rises both next summer and in early 1997 in return for the fare changes.
The Governor-elect and the Assembly Speaker have already voiced opposition to raising the fare. Mr. Giuliani's aides say the Mayor would prefer to pay for the new fare plan through cuts elsewhere in the M.T.A.
Mr. Stangl said the proposals were intended to break with the past practice of keeping the fare as low as possible and raising it only in economic crises. The monthly passes and free transfers were crafted to attract more riders, he said.
"What we're trying to do is to establish a policy that will increase ridership," he said. "I just don't buy that this is giving discounts to some on the backs of others."
But some board members, like Barry Feinstein, a labor leader, said the proposed fare rise seemed intended to pay for changes that would benefit commuters in outlying suburbs and well-off riders who can buy in bulk rather than working-class people living in the inner city. "I think it's discriminatory," he said. "Those who can least afford the ride are the ones who will pay the greatest amount for the ride," he said.
The plan approved yesterday would establish unlimited monthly passes priced at the cost of 55 rides and give people a 5 percent discount on each $20 purchase of rides. It would also provide free transfers between buses and subways, cutting in half the fares paid by nearly 525,000 commuters who take both trains and buses to work. The plan also gives riders of commuter rail lines a slight discount on subway rides, 46 rides for the price of 40, and would let mass-transit riders travel free on the Staten Island ferry.
Those changes are estimated to cost $32 million next year in lost revenues, $200 million in 1996 and $273 million in 1997, transit officials said. To help make up the revenues, the plan calls for the fare to rise to $1.35 in July and to $1.50 in January 1997. Even with those increases, the M.T.A. will have to seek an additional $149 million in state aid in 1997 to balance its books, officials said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Cost-Cutters Reviewing Implants

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 22

 BODY:
On a recent trip to a New Jersey hospital, Kevin Weeks was appalled to witness an operation he considers a waste of money.
"I saw them putting a $3,000 hip that will last more than 20 years in a 100-year-old woman," said Mr. Weeks, director of operating room programs for Premier Health Alliance of Westchester, Ill., a purchasing cooperative owned by 53 large hospitals around the country. "They should have used a $300 unit that will last five years." 
 Goaded by the need to control spending, hospital administrators backed by experts like Mr. Weeks are pressing doctors to use cheaper artificial joints, pacemakers and other implants. And many physicians, who long chose whatever medical device they wanted, are also being urged to channel more business to manufacturers that offer hospitals the deepest discounts.
The drive for economy in a realm where hospitals traditionally have given doctors complete freedom of choice is one of the most dramatic signs yet of how powerful market-driven forces are reshaping health care. Hospitals say hundreds of millions of dollars can be saved by providers without harming patients.
But some doctors worry that this assault on their once-sacrosanct reign over implants could compromise health care. At the very least, they warn, the first patients operated on by a doctor who switches to a new device may suffer more pain and a higher rate of failure until the surgeon becomes intimately familiar with the new implant. And some manufacturers and research-oriented physicians warn that the pressure threatens to slow the pace of innovation that produces better equipment.
"It's difficult to control cost in a rigorous fashion without sacrificing quality of care," said Dr. Richard Frieberg, head of orthopedic surgery at the Jewish Hospital of Cincinnati. Dr. Frieberg has played a central role in developing a plan to reduce the variety of implants used at his hospital. But his cautious approach to negotiations with colleagues underscores the difficulties in getting doctors to agree on money-saving measures.
"I disagree with what some colleagues have done," Dr. Frieberg said, "but I can't say it's wrong."
Many hospitals are enlisting doctors and nurses in an effort to develop plans that among other things would sort out which patients should get which implants. A 30-year-old fitness instructor, for example, might receive the latest high-performance knee replacement; his sedentary grandfather might receive a standard model like those used in the 1970's.
The pressure to pay more attention to cost is most intense in orthopedics -- which has more manufacturers to play against each other -- and where lives are rarely at stake. But even heart surgeons are feeling growing pressure to contain costs.
"We found some folks who hadn't looked at the alternatives in pacemakers for years," said Samuel A. Greco, senior vice president for financial operations at the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation, the hospital chain based in Louisville, Ky., that has grown rapidly through mergers.
To cut costs on orthopedic devices, Columbia has been telling its doctors that if they agree to narrow their options, the chain could win more contracts from health maintenance groups, thus attracting more patients and giving the company the clout to negotiate still deeper discounts from suppliers. Mr. Greco said a number of orthopedic implant contracts had been renegotiated in the last few months, driving costs down by 25 percent to 30 percent.
Medical devices account for 4 percent of total health care spending, but orthopedic implants typically account for 35 to 40 percent of the bill for an operation and often run much higher. The Medicare reimbursement for a total hip replacement -- and 85 percent are on patients covered by Medicare -- is $9,500 for the entire operation. But with prices for equipment averaging $2,500 to $3,000 in simple cases and ranging up to $7,000 in more difficult surgeries, many hospitals contend they are losing money on orthopedics. The Premier hospitals, for example, say they now lose an average of $1,300 per case. Doctors are reimbursed separately by Medicare.
Costs can vary widely, even for the same device. Within New York alone, one hospital paid $2,000 for the same hip replacement from the same manufacturer that another hospital purchased for $4,500, said Kerry Hicks, senior vice president at LBA Health Care Management of Englewood, Colo.
The economy drive is riding on the conviction that in most applications there is much less than what is claimed to distinguish new designs from old ones or the products of different equipment makers.
"The bottom line is that the materials and designs have evolved to the point where they are very similar, almost commodities," said Dr. William Healy, chairman of the orthopedic surgery group at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass.
Hospitals still have to overcome the reluctance of many doctors to abandon equipment they are familiar with. Loyalties also rest on relationships with sales representatives who frequently assist doctors in surgery, provide educational tips and support doctors who are interested in developing new implants. And many surgeons find company-supplied data showing a performance edge for their products convincing.
Even doctors who believe there is little to distinguish the competing product lines fear the legal risks they run if they get poor results during a switch-over.
Experts like Dr. Charles Engh, who runs a teaching practice at Mount Vernon Hospital in Virginia, say that even the most experienced surgeons may need 40 operations to regain their former success rate after switching to a new line of implants.
"It's something we will ultimately do but it's not our preference," said Dr. Sheehan, an orthopedic surgeon since 1968 who works at three suburban hospitals here. "How would you like to go to a patient," Dr. Sheehan added, "and say, 'I've never used one of these before but I'm sure it will be O.K.'?"
The economy drive is clearly eroding profits for medical manufacturers. The number of hospitals receiving discounts from at least one orthopedic implant vendor jumped from 11 percent in 1992 to 75 percent last year, according to a survey of its readers by Orthopedic Network News, an industry newsletter.
Equipment makers say that the profit-sapping trend could slow the pace of innovation in several key segments of the $45 billion medical device industry. They also contend that it could lead to higher costs in the long run if the cheaper implants need to be replaced sooner.
But some patients' rights advocates challenge those claims. "The power of the device companies to oversell should not be underestimated," said Dr. Sidney Wolfe, who heads a health issues group for Public Citizen, a consumer lobbying organization in Washington. Over long periods, more expensive devices may not necessarily perform any better than those they supplanted, he said. And because it is much harder to compare implants that stay in the body for years than it is to judge prescription drugs, Dr. Wolfe said, nobody really knows.
The major manufacturers are granting discounts to hospitals that prove they can deliver high volumes of orders. Occasionally, the price retreat is cloaked by rebates or by offering additional services to save money elsewhere. DePuy Inc., for example, offers its Orthopace program advising doctors on how to prepare patients for rehabilitation ahead of time, leading to faster releases from hospitals.
Medtronic Inc., a leading device company in the cardiovascular field, is trying to counter pressure to cut pacemaker prices by offering discounts to hospitals that will buy more of its other products. "Having broad product lines allows us to come up with counteroffers," said Richard Reid, a spokesman for the Minneapolis-based company.
Still, the competition is taking its toll. Three smaller orthopedics companies have sold themselves to competitors in the last year.
And the uphill battle manufacturers face in proving their products are superior is expected to lead to ever tougher demands for discounts from individual hospitals and buying groups. Premier, the nationwide buying group based outside Chicago, recently introduced a new program offering its hospitals discounts of up to 40 percent on orthopedic implants if they steer most of their business to participating suppliers.
The suppliers that signed on to the three-year arrangement included the orthopedics division of Johnson & Johnson, Intermedics Orthopedics Inc. (a division of Switzerland's Sulzer), the Osteonics Corporation (a subsidiary of the Stryker Corporation), Smith & Nephew Richards Inc., and Wright Medical Technologies Inc.
Perhaps the most notable thing about the supplier group is the absence of the market leaders, including the Zimmer Corporation (a division of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company), Howmedica Inc. (a division of Pfizer Inc.), and DePuy (a division of Germany's Boehringer Mannheim G.m.b.H.). These companies currently account for well over half the orthopedic implants used at Premier hospitals.
What the established leaders are gambling on is that enough doctors will remain loyal, despite encouragement from hospital managers to switch, that they will do better by not giving in to the demand for big discounts.
That is just fine by Gary Sabins, vice president in charge of sales at Intermedics. The company, based in Austin, Tex., has 70 percent of the business at St. Francis Hospital in Tulsa, Okla., but much less in other Premier hospitals. "It's our hope the doctors will reward those who came to the party," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Thanks Ukraine With $200 Million

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton offered $200 million in additional economic aid to Ukraine today to thank that country's new President, Leonid Kuchma, for taking politically difficult steps sought by Washington toward free-market reforms and the elimination of nuclear weapons.
Promising a new relationship with Ukraine, which the Administration expects to become a major power in Europe in years to come, Mr. Clinton also provided Mr. Kuchma with security assurances in return for having persuaded his Parliament last week to vote to eliminate Ukraine's 1,800 nuclear warheads. 
 Those assurances included a promise never to use nuclear weapons against Ukraine, to talk with its Government if the country is ever threatened militarily and, if necessary, to present Ukraine's case to the United Nations Security Council.
To demonstrate the Administration's new bonds with Ukraine, Mr. Clinton announced that Washington would provide a $100 million emergency grant to Ukraine -- with no strings -- for importing food and fuel. No other country receives such a grant from the United States.
Administration officials say that after years of delaying economic reforms, Ukraine sorely needs money to pay for imports because its citizens are being squeezed by a series of reform initiatives, like removing price controls on many products.
Another $100 million in assistance for student exchanges, privatization and small business will raise aid to Ukraine to a total of $900 million for 1994 and 1995, making the former Soviet republic Washington's fourth-largest aid recipient after Israel, Egypt and Russia.
Mr. Clinton welcomed Mr. Kuchma with a full state visit and a 21-gun salute on the White House South Lawn, a greeting that seemed likely to bolster the Ukrainian leader's status among his own people.
"Your boldness in the face of daunting problems reminds us of one of our greatest leaders, Franklin Roosevelt, who provided leadership in a time of great hardship," Mr. Clinton said. "You have blazed a path ahead on the two most critical issues for the future: economic reform and nuclear weapons."
When Mr. Kuchma was elected last July, American officials warned him that unless he took drastic and painful steps to fix his economy, Ukraine risked disintegration.
Administration officials said they were delighted that Mr. Kuchma was able to push through a far-reaching economic reform program even though former Communists still have a strong hold on Parliament. Among the moves that he has taken are large-scale privatization of state companies, cuts in Ukraine's budget deficit and the removal of price controls on many goods.
"He has made the tough decisions that eluded his predecessor," a senior Administration official said.
President Clinton has written to European and Japanese leaders to urge them to contribute funds to Ukraine so it can buy imports of basic necessities. Several American officials criticized the European Union for moving slowly on furnishing the $100 million in emergency aid that Washington has suggested.
For the Clinton Administration, the Ukrainian Parliament's vote, after months of delay, to eliminate its arsenal of nuclear arms, the world's third-largest, was crucial because it cleared the way for two other arms reduction treaties.
American officials said that vote required extensive arm-twisting by Mr. Kuchma because many Ukrainian lawmakers wanted to hold onto the nuclear weapons so Ukraine would retain its clout.
The United States has already committed $350 million to speed the dismantling of Ukraine's warheads.

HEADLINE: London Journal;
A Tipsy Big Ben Leans Over Bedlam-on-Thames

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Westminster Bridge is falling down, or would be if engineers had not just embarked on a project to shore it up. Across town, near Sloane Square, one of the Victorian-era iron beams supporting the roof of the Underground station is cracked, forcing trains to crawl through at 15 miles an hour.
Even Big Ben isn't standing as tall as it used to. Last month, engineers reported the 135-year-old clock tower was listing just over a tenth of an inch, a slight tilt that some experts believe is related to nearby tunneling for a rail line extension. 
 It was Dr. Samuel Johnson who said that when a man is tired of London, he is tired of life. But these days, as the Sunday newspaper The Observer noted recently, when a man is tired of London, he may have a good reason. The capital itself seems to be sagging, gridlocked and constantly under repair.
"London is like a piece of Gruyere cheese," grumbled Gerry Brennan as his taxicab crept past Buckingham Palace, where workers closed lanes to tear up sidewalks. "There are holes everywhere. If hole digging were an Olympic sport, I can tell you this: Britain would win the gold medal every time."
Anyone who has lived within commuting distance of New York or Tokyo or Paris knows that grousing about traffic and detours is just part of the usual background static, a kind of urban white noise.
But in London's salons and boardrooms, in the letter columns and front pages of its newspapers, the grumbling has built to a kind of crescendo. "London is crumbling under the strain of modern living, and trouble-shooters are failing to keep it from falling apart," declared a special report broadcast this month on London's Capital Radio. "Roads are collapsing, bridges are bending and buildings subsiding."
For many tourists, London is still the most agreeable of foreign capitals: safer, cleaner, more intimate than most. Yet the same things that charm tourists -- narrow streets, ancient buildings and quaint plumbing -- frustrate Londoners since so much of the city, at any one moment, seems to be either broken or under repair.
Movement for London, a public interest group that campaigns on behalf of transportation issues, estimated recently that more than two million holes are dug each year in London roads by any one of 17 different utilities and public agencies, which -- to make matters worse -- do not always coordinate their construction schedules.
As a result, these critics complain, the city's traffic pattern has increasingly been turned into an ever-changing labyrinth of detours, roadblocks and one-lane roads.
There are other holes too, appearing entirely on their own. At Heathrow Airport, a parking lot and office building alongside one of the main passenger terminals suddenly began to disappear last month, when nearby tunneling for a new high-speed rail line caused them to sink.
Some critics argue that the problem is complicated because London, alone among the major cities of the world, does not have its own central, elected government to oversee and coordinate activities.
Since the Greater London Council was abolished in 1982 by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who saw it as a redoubt of profligate socialism, the administration of the metropolitan area has been balkanized among 33 different boroughs and local governments, 5 departments of the national government and 60 separate boards and committees.
Stephen O'Brien, the chief executive of London First, which seeks to lure investors and businesses to London, says the disruptions and repairs are the price that comes with building new rail links, or installing a citywide system of underground wiring for cable television.
"As a result of the recession, key parts of London's infrastructure have suffered from under-investment," Mr. O'Brien said. "But in time you will see fabulous things; we are just all going to have put up with the misery until they are finished."
But Roy Porter, a historian and the author of "London, A Social History," published this month by Hamish Hamilton Ltd., says he believes the jury is still out. For all its myriad charms, its thriving neighborhoods, its open spaces, London is suffering from its lack of governance and central planning, Mr. Porter concludes.
"It's true that London is an old city, and that its sewage system is crumbling and its road system out-of-date," he said. "But it is not to be excused. We need a central government."
Without those kinds of improvements, Mr. Porter says, he is not hopeful. "The projections are that London road traffic will double in the next 15 years," he said. "What that will mean to levels of traffic, to pollution, to quality of life in this city, you and I can both guess."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Even London's mighty heart is crumbling under the strain of modern life: Big Ben is listing a bit, Westminster Bridge nearby has to be propped up and the subway station there is under restoration. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Region News Briefs;
Brink's Robbery Case Goes to Rochester Jury

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Nov. 22

 BODY:
After a seven-week trial, a Federal jury today began deliberating the fate of four men linked to the $7.4 million robbery of a Brink's armored-car depot.
The theft, on Jan. 5, 1993, was the nation's fifth-biggest armored-car robbery. 
 A year ago, $2 million was recovered in a New York City apartment used by the Rev. Patrick Moloney, 62, a Melkite Catholic priest who runs a youth shelter, and Samuel Millar, 39, a former rebel from Northern Ireland.
Before deliberations began, Judge David Larimer of Federal District Court told jurors not to infer anything from his decision two weeks ago to throw out two of the three charges against Mr. Millar and the Father Moloney.
They and the fourth defendant, Charles McCormick, 30, an unemployed teacher who subleased the Manhattan apartment to the priest four months before the money was found in a bedroom closet, each face a sole remaining charge of conspiring to possess money from the robbery.
The judge said the prosecution had failed to show that they ever possessed stolen money in western New York, or that the money ever left the state and became an "interstate shipment," as two counts of the indictment allege.
The judge also dropped an interstate shipment possession charge against Thomas O'Connor, a retired Rochester police officer who smuggled Mr. Millar into the United States in 1984. He was working as a guard at Brink's on the night gunmen raided the depot.
Mr. O'Connor, 55, is the only one accused of taking part in the holdup and faces up to 25 years if found guilty. Mr. Millar, Father Moloney and Mr. McCormick, face up to five years each.

HEADLINE: Labor Secretary Urges Cuts For 'Corporate Welfare' Too

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Firing back at conservatives who have vowed to trim welfare costs, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich today issued a broad but vague call to choke off as much as $200 billion in "corporate welfare" as a way of finding money for jobs programs.
But he stopped short of identifying any corporate tax break or subsidy as unreasonable or counterproductive. And though he referred to a study by a Democratic research organization that identifies $111 billion in preferential programs for specific industries, the Labor Secretary said he was not endorsing that report or the suggestions in it. 
 Instead, in the third speech in which he has laid out a theory of America on the decline -- with a crimped middle class and a growing divide between the rich and poor -- he blamed social divisions and lingering pocketbook issues for the Democrats' defeat in the Nov. 8 elections and reiterated his vow to streamline and reinvigorate his department's approach to job training and job creation.
Convulsive political change will continue, he warned, until the middle class sees an end to a spiral of downward mobility that started 15 years ago.
In the Administration's soul-searching since Election Day, Mr. Reich has been the most consistent advocate for sticking to President Clinton's original agenda for using the Government to promote social change, arguing against a wholesale shift to the political center.
"We are re-examining every special benefit that the poor receive," Mr. Reich said in an interview after his midday speech before the Democratic Leadership Council. "It seems only fair that we should also target tax breaks and subsidies that simply don't make sense. All of that needs to be on the table."
Mr. Reich's comments were not immediately echoed at the White House, where, at a news conference this afternoon, President Clinton said he needed time to review the details of the study and assess any possible action.
"Conceptually, it's an attractive idea," he said. "I have to have time to review the details in the context of our budget." He added, however, that he had made no decision about any of the specifics of the Labor Secretary's proposal.
Mr. Reich, this morning, called for bipartisan support. He vowed to "streamline and consolidate the current clutter of adult education and job-training programs" overseen by his department and to "pull the plug on programs that don't work." But he also called on Republicans, who have been readying proposals for budget cuts and tough changes in welfare, to consider the fates of workers who have not been able to take advantage of a steadily growing economy because of slow wage growth and flat job opportunities.
"Nearly one out of five who lost a full-time job since the start of 1991 is still without work," he said. "Among those who have landed new jobs, almost half, 47 percent, are now earning less than they did before."
At the center of Mr. Reich's prescription for change was an 11-month-old report written by the Democratic Leadership Committee's Progressive Policy Institute. The institute's report identifies specific subsidies in the oil and gas industry, private utilities, agriculture and those industries that make tax-free investments in the United States-linked lands like Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Guam as drains on the economy and areas of unproductive tax policy.
Robert J. Shapiro, the author of the report, said the timing of Mr. Reich's remarks was apt, though the report had been in circulation for nearly a year. "We are coming up to the new budget season," he said. "The fact is, if you want to find a little tax relief, you have to find somewhere to save. I'm pleased that they are using market logic" to diagram potential tax cuts.
Tax experts today responded cautiously to Mr. Reich's remarks, pointing out that ever since President Ronald Reagan started assailing welfare benefits, liberals had threatened corporate benefits.
"There has always been this talk that if you don't like welfare, then don't give it to corporations," said Eugene L. Vogel, chairman of the tax department at the New York law firm of Rosenman & Colin.
Mr. Vogel said he generally approved of Mr. Reich's comments but hoped that the Clinton Administration would not move to make a flurry of changes in the tax code. "We just shouldn't keep jiggling it," he said. And in the current political environment, with Republicans dominating Congress, Mr. Vogel added, "I'm not sure how cooperative Congress is going to be, anyway."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
More Scrutiny of a Microsoft Merger

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation and Intuit Inc. said today that they had received a second request from the Justice Department for information on their proposed merger. Both said the request had been anticipated and that they were cooperating with the Government.
"We were by no means surprised to get a second request," said William H. Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for law and corporate affairs, adding that second requests were not uncommon in mergers of companies with overlapping products. 
 Microsoft, of Redmond, Wash., agreed last month to acquire Intuit, a Menlo Park, Calif., producer of Quicken, the market-leading personal finance software program, in a stock swap valued at about $1.5 billion. Microsoft also agreed to divest itself of its competing product, Money, to Novell Inc. for an undisclosed amount, to avoid antitrust action.
In what is the largest software industry acquisition ever, Microsoft paid more than 7 times revenues and more than 60 times earnings for Intuit, an indication of just how far it is willing to go to capture a market.
The deal also signaled the intention of Microsoft to dominate electronic banking as thoroughly as it does desktop computing, as was underscored by a subsequent deal with Visa International to provide software for electronic shopping.
Last week the Silicon Valley law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosetti filed a brief with the Justice Department, arguing that while Microsoft's acquisition of Intuit was anticompetitive in the present market for personal finance software, its future implications were even more troubling.
Relying on an economics concept called "increasing returns" theory, the paper suggested that Microsoft could use its dominance of desktop computing today to achieve dominance of nascent markets it deems strategic.
"Notwithstanding that in certain places their market share is small, the economics would predict they're going to dominate," said Gary Reback, the lawyer who wrote the brief. He said the Justice Department had requested the brief, submitted on behalf of the firm's clients, which declined to be named for fear of retaliation from Microsoft. The brief "argues that the Government should take action," he said.
Justice Department officials declined to comment. But Esther Roditti, editor of the Computer Law & Tax Report, said that the argument made by the law firm was not likely to sway the Justice Department. "I've never heard anything so speculative as that argument in an antitrust case," she said. "They've always been based on current conditions."
Still, analysts say that Microsoft has made a series of moves that could let it dominate the market for on-line commerce, banking and information. Windows 95, the next release of the company's popular operating system software, will contain the software needed to dial up Microsoft Network, an on-line service the company plans to introduce. With six million users, Quicken, which permits electronic bill-paying, already has more users than the three largest on-line services combined. And Visa has hundreds of millions of users, many of whom might shop on line.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Mexican Attitudes Shift In Flood of U.S. Goods

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The Marlboro Man rode off American television years ago, but in Mexico he is still galloping hard, part of a stampede for products from across the border that is changing and challenging Mexico's modest advertising industry.
The elimination of tariffs by the North American Free Trade Agreement has brought hundreds of American products, from Kellogg's Pop-Tarts to the new Ford Mystique, to join standbys like Marlboro cigarettes on Mexican shelves and in showrooms. 
 The newcomers are extensively advertised in ways that try to reflect Mexican culture. In response, the established Mexican products must be more heavily marketed to keep from losing ground.
As they bid for attention, the new advertisements are testing accepted conventions that until now have excluded nearly all humor and sarcasm -- or even indigenous Mexican faces -- from television commercials.
When American competitors were kept out and consumers had few choices, Mexican manufacturers considered advertising to be a nuisance. Now that the border is largely open, that attitude is changing.
"The whole market here is in a state of flux right now," said John E. Holmes, regional president for J. Walter Thompson, which has been in Mexico for 50 years. "The big question now is, 'Are we a part of Latin America or are we a part of North America?' The answer is unclear."
This might seem to be a good time for Mexican ad agencies or the local branches of big international companies to flourish. But the comparatively small size of the Mexican consumer market and the traditional aversion of Mexican businesses to spending on advertising have made this a shakeout year for the country's advertising industry.
"An open economy is going to open up creativity, but it's going to pulverize the market itself," said Cecilia Bouleau, editor of the advertising magazine Adcebra. She said big agencies had been forced to lower commissions and reduce staff to be more competitive.
The five largest agencies in Mexico, as measured by billings, are foreign, beginning with McCann-Erickson. Many Mexican agencies have survived by allying with international companies, which tends to obscure the smaller agency's identity.
Still, advertising interest in Mexico remains high. "Latin America is double the size of the population of the U.S., and Mexico is the second- largest country in Latin America," said Angel Collado-Schwartz, chairman of Nazca, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi.
While Mexico ranks second in population behind Brazil, its advertising expenditures of nearly $2 billion last year were third behind those of Brazil and Argentina. More than half the 90 million Mexicans are 25 years old or younger, making them a prime consumer market, at least in theory.
Advertising experts in Mexico say that almost anything American sells, but finding the right approach is not always as simple as translating "yes" into "si."
American Express learned that lesson a few years ago, when it tried to transplant its successful "Membership has its privileges" campaign into Mexico.
American Express told its agency, Panamericana Ogilvy & Mather, to use the same advertisement in Mexico that ran in Argentina. But while Mexicans and Argentines both speak Spanish, some words have quite different meanings.
An account executive on the campaign said the slogan in Argentina had been translated: "Ser miembro tiene su privilegio," or "To be a member has its privileges." In Mexico, the slogan caused snickers, because miembro is commonly used to refer to male genitals. The ads were pulled, and the offending phrase changed to "membresia," the word that Mexicans use for membership.
Sergio Armando Lopez Zepeda, director of the Mexican Association of Advertising Agencies, said advertising in Mexico still lacked a degree of sophistication and its own brand of creativity. Many television commercials, like those by the Leo Burnett Company for Marlboro, copy commercials in the United States. The earthy humor that Mexicans love is rare, because many companies fear it would reflect badly on their products.
But a cross-cultural style is emerging that acknowledges the proximity of the United States, but adds a uniquely Mexican flavor.
The commercials done for the Mexican Yellow Pages by the Mexican agency Alazraki & Associates, are among the first designed around Mexican humor. They feature working-class Mexicans who almost never appear in advertisements, which are dominated by people who look like upper-class Anglos.
In one new commercial, two men parking cars complain in Mexican street slang as they rush from car to car. They feel overworked, it turns out, because their boss is attracting so many customers.
"I thought he didn't advertise in the Yellow Pages," one disgruntled employee says. "What do you mean?" the other says. "He put it in there, in red."
Television advertising is the most effective medium in Mexico. Ads for cigarettes and hard liquor are shown, but only after 10 P.M, as are commercials for condoms.
Slightly more than 65 percent of the advertising peso is spent on television, with more than 80 percent of that going to Televisa, a communications giant that operates three nationwide networks. But the cost of television commercials -- up to $150,000 a minute -- is too expensive for most Mexican businesses. A newly privatized network, Television Azteca, is competing by offering lower rates and more attractive time packages.
While Mexico's population of 90 million is relatively young, advertisers point out that it is also quite poor. Only about 12 million Mexicans have enough money to be considered active consumers.
As a result, only 8,000 of Mexico's 55,000 medium-sized businesses mount advertising campaigns, Mr. Lopez Zepeda said. The products most heavily advertised are aimed at the broadest potential market, like Coca-Cola, Frito-Lay's Sabritas brand chips and Bimbo bread and baked goods.
With some of the sheen starting to wear off the new American imports, advertisers must try harder to make Mexicans buy their products.
"We Mexicans are realizing that not everything that comes from outside is better than what we make here," Mr. Lopez Zepeda said. "For the first time, the Mexican consumer is learning how to buy."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Sugar Surges on Prediction Supply Won't Meet Demand

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Sugar prices surged to a four-and-a-half-year high yesterday after the International Sugar Organization predicted consumption would outpace production in 1994-95 by 1.9 million metric tons.
The deficit forecast for the September-August marketing year reflects declining production, particularly in Europe, and rising world demand. 
 On other commodity markets, crude oil futures rose modestly after OPEC members agreed to freeze production levels for a year, and copper prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.35 point, to 231.15.
World sugar for March delivery rose 0.61 cent on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to 14.59 cents a pound, the highest daily settlement for near-term deliveries since May 25, 1990.
The International Sugar Organization, representing major sugar-producing countries, increased its deficit forecast by 46 percent from the September estimate of 1.3 million tons. This would be the third consecutive year of deficit production and declining world stockpiles.
"You've had some major production problems in Russia and Europe and you're seeing some continued erosion in Cuban production," said Stephen Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter, Discover & Company in Chicago.
At the same time, developing nations are becoming bigger sugar consumers, said William Byers, director of futures research at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. "Consumption increases as people have more money and their diets change with the increase in their disposable income," he said.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil prices rose after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said it would maintain its output ceiling of 24.52 million barrels a day for another year. Demand for OPEC crude is expected to average 25 million barrels a day in the first half of 1995, and 25.6 million in the second half.
Even with OPEC cheating, which currently increases production to about 25.1 million barrels a day, demand could outstrip production late next year, forcing prices higher.
January deliveries of crude oil rose 26 cents, to $17.82 a barrel.
Profit taking ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday tomorrow brought copper prices down from near five-year highs on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The December copper contract fell 4.1 cents, to $1.3225 a pound.
