HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hurt by Stock Drop And View on Strong Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was weaker against most leading currencies yesterday, hurt by a late stock plunge on Wall Street and comments from Germany's top central banker.
The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said he favored a strong German mark. In addition, he said there was no pressure on the central bank to alter its monetary policy. 
 "You should not prepare yourselves for too great a change," Mr. Tietmeyer said. The Bundesbank's policy-making Central Bank Council meets tomorrow . Lower German interest rates would bolster the value of the dollar against the mark, but the Bundesbank last cut interest rates in May, and most European economists expect no change in interest rate policy.
"The statement in itself is probably nothing new, but given the fact that the dollar was slightly vulnerable, the market was able to push it lower," said Ian Spence, a managing director at the Chemical Bank.
Traders said the dollar was also pulled down in late trading by a selloff in American stocks, which dampened demand among foreign investors for the dollars needed to buy the securities. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 91.52 points.
Despite the weakness in stocks, currency dealers said investor sentiment toward the dollar remained relatively upbeat.
"What we've seen in the bigger picture is four straight weeks of new highs in the dollar," said Paul Farrell, a vice president at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "I think this trend will probably stay in place."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5527 marks from 1.5562 marks on Monday. The dollar slipped to 98.23 yen from 98.34 yen.
Currency trading is expected to be quiet today on the eve of Thanksgiving. Japanese banks will be closed today for a national holiday.
Separately, the Italian lira came under attack after news that magistrates had told Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi that he was being investigated on corruption charges.
The lira fell to a record low of 1,035.60 against the German mark. The dollar rose to 1,609 lire, from 1,594.50 on Monday.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar fell to 1.3180 Swiss francs, from 1.390 francs on Monday. The British pound rose to $1.5695 from $1.5678.

HEADLINE: Resisting O.J.-itis

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
EARLY next year, when the O. J. Simpson trial kicks off in earnest and full-time coverage returns to television, J. W. Johnson vows that the Cottonwood Cafe will be an O. J.-free zone. He will not tune the cafe's television to Court TV, nor will he lend an ear to barflies who wish to dissect the latest about Cato Kaylin or Marcia Clark's skirt lengths.
"I just can't take it anymore," said Mr. Johnson, an owner of the cafe, on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. "This morning when I was eating breakfast, watching CNN, they came on with jury selection and I flipped it to another channel." 
 Mr. Johnson is one of a growing number of Americans who feel that the never-ending rain of news, analysis and water-cooler chitchat about the O. J. Simpson story, which continues even now, during a lull in the case, has become too much, crowding out the stuff of daily life.
"This is November," Mara Manus, a Los Angeles film producer, said in exasperation. "When did it happen, last June? It's insane we're still talking about this."
She and others -- you could call them O. J. avoiders -- want to be covered under Judge Lance A. Ito's recent order requiring that jury members get morning papers with references to the case snipped out. Barring that, they have devised ways to sequester themselves from the barrage of news, recently estimated by the judge's clerk at 27,000 newspaper and magazine stories, with broadcast reports heard as far away as Tibet.
Their strategies range from banning mention of Mr. Simpson at social gatherings to packing away television sets for the duration to seeking alternative news sources in cyberspace.
Deborah Rosen, the founder of Rosen & Company, a marketing firm in Santa Monica, Calif., told of eating recently at a Manhattan restaurant where everyone at the table agreed to avoid mention of the trial.
"Every day and everywhere you go, people are talking about it," Ms. Rosen complained. "Everyone's got to weigh in with their views."
Penn Jillette, the illusionist, said he lost interest in the case "about a minute into the car chase" in June.
"I live in a rarefied non-O. J. environment," he added. To black out further information, he gets most of his news from the Economist, the British newsweekly that has scarcely mentioned the story. And he hangs out with computer scientists, many from Bell Labs in New York, a set famous for its tunnel vision. "In that particular social circle, I don't think it was ever mentioned, not so much as a joke," Mr. Jillette said proudly.
David Zinsser, who owns the Cottonwood with Mr. Johnson, said that when he and two friends rented a beach house in Montauk, L.I., this summer, they made a simple rule: not one word was to be uttered about the Simpson case. In the interest of a restful vacation, Mr. Zinsser said, "we refused to listen to, watch or read anything about it."
To be sure, most Americans seem eager to devour each new bit of O. J. trivia. "Nicole Brown Simpson: The Private Diary of a Life Interrupted," the biography by Faye D. Resnick, is holding strong on the New York Times best-seller list at No. 4.
But there is some evidence that outbreaks of O. J. Simpson fatigue are not isolated cases. Television magazine shows like ABC's "Prime Time Live" and CBS's "Eye to Eye With Connie Chung" have suffered sharp ratings declines this fall. Several television executives have said the drop-off could be traced in part to viewers' satiation with the Simpson story.
"There has been an O. J. overload, there's no question in my mind," said Joe Peyronnin, a vice president of CBS News. "Everybody is doing the jury story. Everybody is doing the DNA story. People have gotten too much of that."
Several experts pointed to the surprisingly low rating for Ms. Chung's Oct. 20 interview with Ms. Resnick on "Eye to Eye," despite the huge publicity the show inadvertantly received when Judge Ito ordered prospective jurors not to watch it. The broadcast got a 9.8 rating, compared with 19.4 for NBC's drama "E.R." in the same time period (each rating point represents 952,000 households).
But other television news insiders cautioned that the Simpson story is in a temporary lull as jury selection drags out and that once the trial begins, probably in mid-January, viewer interest will bounce back. Frank Magid, a consultant to about 130 television news departments around the country, said he recently surveyed 1,000 people about their appetite for the story and advised his clients, in effect, to keep it coming.
That is bad news for folks determined to carve out an O. J.-free zone. For them the world can be a daunting place. News of the trial makes the papers every morning, the television news almost nightly and the covers of supermarket tabloids week after week.
"It's so clear there is no new information," said Paul Rudnick, the playwright. "I would like to avoid the whole subject. But I feel simply by passing the newsstand, it clings to me. It's become a form of asbestos. It's in the air and impossible to avoid."
Even some of those whose business it is to keep the information flowing admit to feeling tuckered out. "Frankly, I'm drowning in it," said Tom Leykis, a talk-radio host on Los Angeles station KMPC-AM. "Unless you've been here, you have no perception of how ever-present this story is on television."
Los Angeles has seven television channels with local news broadcasts, and judging by their blow-by-blow coverage, most seem to agree with Geraldo Rivera, who said earlier this month that the trial is "the most extraordinary criminal case in our lifetimes, maybe in this century, maybe in history, maybe ever."
Faced with hyperventilating of this kind, some people have taken the drastic, almost un-American step of seceding from the great republic of television watchers. Mr. Leykis said he had heard from callers who said they don't watch the news anymore, and several who've unplugged their television sets because of the O. J. tsunami.
But Ken Minyard, another Los Angeles talk-radio host, wondered whether such O. J. avoiders were really closet O. J. watchers.
"From the beginning we've had calls from people who say this is terrible and people are obsessed with it," said Mr. Minyard, whose morning-drive show on KABC-AM is top-rated in Los Angeles. "I think they're the first ones watching 'Hard Copy' that night."
Mr. Peyronnin of CBS News predicted that if and when Mr. Simpson takes the stand or grants an interview to a network news division, it will be "a national television moment" that rivets Americans to their sets.
In that event, however, there are many O. J.-phobes who say that they will skip the appointment. One is Kevin Kelly, the executive editor of the computer magazine Wired, whose October cover promised "Absolutely nothing about O. J. Simpson in this issue!"
On the Internet and on-line services, where Mr. Kelly goes for much news and information, one can pick and choose topics of interest, rather than submit to the barrage that comes across the airwaves.
"It's much more of a hunting, browsing thing, where the reader or customer is in control," Mr. Kelly said. "It is easier to avoid stuff you're tired of. My little roamings are pretty O. J.-free."
He has one other strategy for avoiding the topic: getting rid of reporters who ask about it. Ten minutes into a telephone interview, Mr. Kelly said: "I've just talked more about O. J. than I ever have in my life, and I'm finding I'm tired of it. So maybe I should go on to something else."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: A Natural at Filling the Seats;
Weak Bat Adds Skepticism to Jordan's Future in Majors

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
Michael Jordan swung at the first pitch and dumped a double next to the left-field line. The fans at Scottsdale Stadium cheered lustily, but a group of more dispassionate observers reacted differently.
"That soft line drive was on an 81-mile-an-hour fastball that was right there," a major league scout said a couple of innings after Jordan's hit in a recent game. "He just got out too early with a soft swing." 
 The scout was not putting down Jordan for the way he got his third Arizona Fall League extra-base hit in 93 times at bat; he was assessing the Scorpions' outfielder critically, the way scouts are paid to do. And when scouts assess Jordan, the first aspect they address is his weak way of hitting, which they cite as the greatest obstacle to him playing in the major leagues.
Like many others in baseball, the scouts talk candidly about Jordan's ability only if they are not identified. Bashing Jordan is not a game that is readily accepted by people who admire him for the effort he has made the last 10 months and appreciate him for the economic benefit his presence has brought to the Southern League and the Arizona Fall League.
The Birmingham Barons drew a franchise record 467,867 fans this year, the sixth-highest attendance in Class AA history. Scorpions games attract far more fans than other games in the Arizona league. Two of the three Saturday night games drew 161 and 476 fans; Jordan's game attracted 1,937.
Even the scout who harshly assessed Jordan's double said: "You can't get rid of him because he's quadrupled the attendance of every game down here and it's the same way everywhere he goes. He's great for baseball. It's great to see somebody who fulfills a dream, and it would translate to the younger kids if they stuck with it."
After a season with Birmingham on the Class AA level of the minor leagues, the National Basketball Association legend has spent several more weeks playing in a league that is a minor league mixture, but with pitchers who are considered Class AAA quality.
The Chicago White Sox, whose operating owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, has the same position with the Bulls, have pegged Jordan for Class AAA Nashville next season. Class AAA is the last stop for players before the major leagues. Sometimes young players slip backward from that level. More often than not, players of many ages become stuck there, unable to cross the gulf that is much larger than any jump in the minors.
At the age of 31, Jordan is not a typical minor leaguer. His teammates here are mostly 24 or younger. They have time to develop into major leaguers, if they have the talent. Jordan does not have much time, and it's highly questionable that he has the talent.
Scouts and other baseball people differ in their assessment of his defensive and base-running skills, but they are unanimous in their view of his hitting.
"He has a pretty weak stroke," said the head of one major league scouting department.
A general manager who saw Jordan play last week said: "He doesn't have a good swing. The ball doesn't jump off his bat." Another concluded: "I don't think he's going to hit the ball. He doesn't have a lot of wrist in the ball."
Syd Thrift is a veteran baseball man who has worked for several clubs. Currently the director of player development for the Baltimore Orioles, he knows about the process of turning good athletes into baseball players from the days he ran the Kansas City Royals' Baseball Academy.
"He's going through the process of where his hands should be, his starting position, where you take the ball, what do you do with your body," said Thrift, who watched Jordan play from a scout's seat behind home plate. "He's in a pretty good position to take the pitch. He's learning how to identify breaking pitches. That's his problem. He hasn't hit them. You have to learn how to hit. You learn by seeing and feeling."
Jordan batted .202 for Birmingham, needing a late-season splurge to get there. He hit only 3 home runs and struck out 114 times in 436 times at bat. In Arizona, he has maintained his strikeout ratio while raising his batting average (.239 after yesterday's game) but hitting no home runs.
He has not been a factor in producing runs. His ratio of 6 runs batted in for 109 at-bats would translate to 33 r.b.i. for a 600 at-bat season. His inability to generate power, his penchant for hitting soft singles instead, has kept him from being a productive hitter.
"His hands are not back far enough," Thrift said, dissecting Jordan's stance. "If he moved his hands straight back six inches, he'd be in a strong hand position. The difference between here and here gives you more power. He's right here. I think that comes from being defensive, protecting you against the breaking ball."
Gordon Goldsberry, an Orioles' scout, echoed Thrift's assessment.
"I talked to people who saw him take batting practice in Chicago two, three years ago when he was playing basketball," the former major league first baseman said. "They said he hit balls into the seats. It looks like maybe he manufactured his swing just to try to hit the ball instead of trying to hit the ball hard. As big as he is, with his arms and legs, it seems to me he could turn the bat loose."
Instead, Goldsberry said, the 6-foot-6-inch Jordan hits defensively. "It looks like he's trying to avoid striking out," he said. "He sort of feels for the ball instead of hitting it. I'd like to see him take a hack at it and see what happens. I think he could hit some home runs. I think it would be better suited for him to be that kind of a hitter than a straight Punch and Judy type of hitter."
Another scout said he thought Jordan's defensive style of hitting stems from a lack of recognition of pitches.
"There's nothing that can be done or cured or helped in the space of a year or two," he said. "It's going to take awhile. You have to have a feel for how hard the guy's throwing, how the ball moves, what pitch it might be. He gets caught out in front. He gets fooled quite a bit."
An executive of a National League club said if he were in charge of Jordan's baseball future, he would put him back in Class AA next season, not that he had flunked that grade but that he just needed to repeat it.
Jim Beattie, a former pitcher and now the Seattle Mariners' minor league director, said Jordan needed to face a lot of different pitching and learn to adjust to pitches inside.
"When I saw him, it looked like his swing was a little long," Beattie said. "It looked like he was trying to sweep a little bit, just trying to get his hands through. If I was a pitcher pitching to him, I'd try to hit him hard in, then throw breaking balls away."
That's precisely what pitchers try to do with Jordan, with success more often than not. But inside pitches, at least, don't intimidate him.
"He has no fear of the ball," a general manager said. "One time I saw where a ball went up under his chin. He went right back in and took a good swing at the next pitch."
Can Jordan make it to the majors? That is, after all, what he's trying to do. None of the general managers, other executives and scouts answered the question with an unqualified yes.
"If he gets there," an assistant general manager said, "it'll be on a promotional basis, I believe. From what little I've seen, he's so far behind at 31 years old, he doesn't seem to have real good instincts for the game. He was on base twice the game I saw, was picked off once and was damn near picked off the second time. He seems to be slow reacting. In the outfield, he's a little tentative."
Another assistant general manager said he thought Jordan would make it "but only because of a very unique situation with ownership." This executive, too, pointed to something Jordan lacks.
"It's not just the physical and mechanical adjustment but also a mental approach to this game he still has to overcome," he said. "I don't think he can overcome that. That's the whole thing. You get to that point by playing when you're a youngster. This game is difficult enough playing it all your life."
Gary Hughes, the Florida Marlins' scouting director, was one of those who cited Jordan's improvement from the time he started last February.
"It's not as goofy as I thought it was," Hughes said of the idea of Jordan's playing major league baseball. "It's still within the realm of possibility."
But time is against Jordan. "If you looked at him as an 18- or 19-year-old, you might think you could improve his skills a little bit, but at his age, it looks like it will be difficult," a general manager said, then offered a scouting report: "arm below average, power below average, ball doesn't jump off his bat, good runner, plays the game hard, instincts lacking."
The scout who watched Jordan hit an 81-mile-an-hour fastball for a soft double did not rule out an eventual visit to the majors.
"If I had to bet on him making it, I'd probably take the Fifth because I have no way of determining how long he'll stick with it," he said. "If he sticks with it a couple more years, he may be able to play. If he ever gets to the point where he can do some of these things naturally, he'd be worth his weight in gold. But as far as being a major league player, the chances are astronomical against it. But I wouldn't bet against him. If I had him, I wouldn't release him."

HEADLINE: In America;
At Last, A Truce

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The cold war has ended. Governor-elect George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani are going to sit down and talk. The blood feud, provoked by Mayor Giuliani's decision to cross party lines and endorse Mario Cuomo for re-election, is being put aside -- at least for the time being.
Political egos being what they are, it took nearly a week to negotiate the cease-fire. The word began to filter out early yesterday: 
 "Something may happen soon," said a Pataki aide.
"We may have it resolved," said a voice from the Giuliani camp.
You might have thought they were talking about Grant and Lee at Appomattox.
However it was arranged, the agreement comes not a moment too soon. Mr. Pataki is on a working vacation in Florida, no doubt trying to figure out how to keep his promise to cut income taxes by 25 percent now that he knows the state will face a $4 billion shortfall next year.
Mr. Giuliani is in City Hall, trying to close a billion-dollar budget gap right now. The Mayor's cuts are no longer surgical in nature. Most fat has already been removed. Each new cut is a ghastly gouging of services needed by New Yorkers -- in some cases, desperately needed.
With both the city and the state in deep financial trouble, there was no time for a feud between the Mayor and the Governor-elect.
Ramon Cortines, the city's Schools Chancellor, was on the verge of tears Monday as he testified before the City Council about the latest cuts to hit the school system. "We are standing at the edge of an abyss," he said. "With each new round of cuts our footing grows more precarious."
Council leaders are fighting drastic budget cuts on a wide front. They are trying to prevent the elimination of city funding for mental retardation and substance abuse programs. They are trying to block the dismissal of civilians from the police force and prevent further cuts to the overburdened Department of Corrections.
Youth programs are hemorrhaging. Programs that feed the hungry are hurting. And Comptroller Alan Hevesi contends that the city could face another shortfall, of $400 million, before the end of the fiscal year.
The feud between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani had gone far beyond the usual antipathy between governors and mayors. Mr. Giuliani took an enormous gamble with his endorsement and he lost. It was inevitable that he would be punished. But there were other elements to the feud -- big slights and little slights, some public, some private. And there was always the specter of U.S. Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's patron, hovering in the background. The feud was threatening to seriously interfere with the work of running the city and the state.
I once asked Dizzy Gillespie how close he had been to Charlie Parker. He replied, "How close are two coats of paint?" The same can be said about the interests of New York City and New York State. Each is dependent upon the other.
Mr. Giuliani's continuing budget problems cannot be worked out without the help of the state. Mr. Pataki's effort to cut taxes and streamline government haven't a prayer without the cooperation of the city.
The mutual interests go far beyond issues of budget and taxation. Mayors and governors have no choice but to work together in good faith on economic development, on transportation issues, on law and order.
(One example: As soon as a convict in New York City is sentenced to a year or more in jail, he goes into the state prison system.)
The links are endless. The city's health and social welfare systems are monitored and regulated by the state. And while there are many who are reluctant to admit it, the city is the dynamic force that gives the entire state its national and international stature.
"You can't separate the two," said a former state official. "Without a hand-in-glove kind of interaction, neither jurisdiction can be effective in achieving its objectives."
New York City is particularly vulnerable now because of the tax-cutting, anti-urban, anti-social welfare policies of the national Republican Party. Although Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani are Republicans, they have an obligation to fight for the legitimate interests of city residents.
That can begin to happen when they finally sit down next week. It could have begun sooner, if either man's ego had allowed him to just pick up the telephone.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Out of the Hands of Babes

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
Would you buy a rug if you knew that it had been woven in India by 10-year-olds beaten if they didn't work fast enough? Would you wear a shirt if it had been sewn by a 9-year-old locked into a factory in Bangladesh until production quotas for the day had been met? Would you eat sardines if the cans had been filled by 12-year-old Filipino children sold into bonded servitude?
The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as GATT, is the most sweeping free-trade pact in history. But like many agreements among different nations with different agendas, much has been lost in the translation. One of the losses in the GATT negotiations was the right of children not to be exploited, overworked and underpaid as a source of cheap and compliant labor around the world. 
 From the children who make carpets in India, sometimes 16 hours a day, seven days a week, to those who sew in Bangladesh for as little as five cents an hour, the International Labor Organization estimates that there may be as many as 200 million child laborers worldwide. Some are working in sweatshops that contract to make American goods. In testimony before the Senate earlier this year, a 15-year-old from Honduras told of girls working up to 80 hours a week at a factory manufacturing Liz Claiborne sweaters.
Child labor is the dirty little secret of foreign imports. Senator Tom Harkin, who wants to outlaw U.S. imports of all products made by children under age 15, says the problem is that Americans don't know that some of what they buy, including toys for their own kids, has been manufactured by children working the kind of hours, under the kind of conditions, that many still associate with the darkest days of the Industrial Revolution.
"You give me any cross-section of 100 Americans," says the Senator, "people from any income level, any area of the country, and I think the reaction would be overwhelmingly against buying the products."
Mr. Harkin is a voice crying in the wilderness, and the wilderness is the gilded thicket of free trade, thorny with U.S. concessions. Mr. Harkin's bill to keep products made with child labor out of the United States would probably be a violation of GATT, which provides only for those restrictions spelled out in the trade pact.
During various GATT negotiations, developing countries successfully argued against child labor provisions, insisting that children have always worked in their cultures, that to try to interfere with child labor is protectionist and punitive when a child may be the only wage-earner in a desperately poor family.
But the tradition of children helping on small farms and the innovation of locking them into a hotbox of a factory for 14 hours a day are worlds apart. The reason they may be the only wage-earner in some areas is because adult workers have been laid off in favor of children, who are infinitely more exploitable and provide bigger profits for prosperous factory owners. And nations that really want to compete in a global economy will educate their kids, not work them half to death before they've even reached puberty.
After the bad publicity of the Senate hearings, Liz Claiborne announced that it was ditching the Honduran contractor, then decided instead it would "work with the facility" to "meet our human rights standards." A few American companies have been ahead of the curve; Levi Strauss and Reebok, for instance, had already demanded that their contractors overseas hire only workers over age 14. In India a consortium of carpet makers has started an industry campaign that tags those products made without child labor. That's the least Americans deserve, some assurance that what they buy has not been manufactured by kids.
Amid attempts to protect elephants from ivory poachers and dolphins from tuna nets, the rights of children go remarkably unremarked. "This is the last vestige of slavery sanctioned in the world today," said Senator Harkin. If GATT passes, an opportunity to end these children's servitude will have been shunted aside for the alleged bonanza of free trade. But consumers can vote with their credit cards only if products are labeled. At the very least the slogan "Not Manufactured with Child Labor" should shame those companies not in a position to affix it to their products.

HEADLINE: The Cheering Over, Haitians Face New Trials

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having lived in and reported on Haiti on and off for five years, I've found your coverage reflects an exclusively Northern perspective. 
 On Oct. 15, Jean-Bertrand Aristide returned to Haiti's presidential palace, where, flanked by Northern diplomats and standing behind a bulletproof-glass encasement, he released a dove. Less than a month later, President Clinton has announced the withdrawal, by Dec. 1, of the first 6,000 American troops. The crisis, it seems, is over.
But for the Haitian people, a new trial is at hand. President Aristide's term is nearly elapsed. The grass-roots organizations that elected him have been coerced, co-opted and killed off. The military leaders have been legitimized by golden exile and even honored by Jimmy Carter, who invited Gen. Raoul Cedras to teach his Sunday school class; their underlings remain at large.
The international lending agencies have already taken command of Haiti's economic future with a program allowing the Haitian elite along with foreign businesses to continue exploiting Haiti's "price-competitive" labor force (the lowest paid of the region).
Many of the Haitian poor have welcomed the United States troops, who they believe will rescue them from the military's thugs. Haitians were asked to bring known criminals to the Americans, who in turn are supposed to escort them to local jails. So far, the faith of the Haitian poor has been misplaced. Those arrested at the front gate are released out the back.
On Oct. 30, more than 100 prisoners "broke out" of the national penitentiary when guards opened their cells. The problem is that the jailers are good friends with the jailed, having worked side by side with them during the military rule.
Haiti's remaining grass-roots leaders have been more wary of the occupation. Chavannes Jean-Baptiste, a cabinet member in President Aristide's Government and leader of Haiti's largest peasant movement, returned to his base in the town of Hinche after three years in exile and hiding. He warned the cheering crowd not to count on the United States Army. "Only Haitians can free Haiti," he proclaimed.
Three years ago the United States responded to Haiti's bloody coup with overt indignation and covert support. Secretary of State James Baker declared to the Organization of American States in October 1991, "Until President Aristide's Government is restored, this junta will be treated as a pariah, without support, and without a future."
But the military and their sponsors in the Haitian elite were given no reason to believe that the United States would interfere.
President Bush delayed a month in joining the O.A.S. embargo adopted just after the coup. By February 1992 Mr. Bush actually lifted the embargo for United States companies with factories in Haiti. Sears, Wal-Mart and American baseball manufacturers continued to profit from the junta -- and indirectly insure its future.
President Aristide, meanwhile, became the victim of a Central Intelligence Agency propaganda campaign that questioned his human rights record and leaked false documents that diagnosed him as a psychopath. C.I.A. complicity did not end there. Last winter Toto Constant, head of the violent paramilitary group Fraph, handed me a thick binder, complete with color copies, documenting Mr. Aristide's maniacal tendencies.
As I interviewed Mr. Constant in his sitting room, he looked me straight in the eye and began every sentence with the phrase "The C.I.A. has found that . . ." You finally reported last month that Toto Constant was on the C.I.A. payroll.
The generals retire to honorable exile, earned at the cost of thousands of Haitian lives, while Mr. Aristide stands in a glass box, caged by his American saviors. The Haitian people have lost all that they won in their first free elections. Though the crisis seems to be over from America's perspective, it is no victory for Haiti.
 
CATHERINE ORENSTEIN
 New York, Nov. 18, 1994

HEADLINE: Personal Health;
Making it work when opposites attract.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
LAST summer one of my sons, the product of a Swedish-American father from a Lutheran Minnesota family and a mother of Russian-Jewish descent from New York, married a Filipino-born Presbyterian woman from California. Next spring his twin brother will marry a Korean-born woman who grew up in a Methodist family in Ohio and New York.
But according to the findings of the newest and best survey of sexuality in America, my family's melting-pot mix of ethnic, religious and racial heritages is relatively rare. Despite the fascination many claim to have with the exotic and the popular belief that opposites attract, this survey found that the overwhelming majority of Americans choose their sexual partners and their lifetime mates from a pool of people very much like themselves. 
 The survey, published by the University of Chicago Press, found that choices of sexual partners seem to follow the same rules of social behavior that friendships do: "Birds of a feather flock together." Although you may think you can choose from among an endless variety of potential partners, or that your choice will be determined by some irresistible spark ignited without regard for social background, the survey findings and the way the researchers have interpreted them indicate otherwise. Few of us are as free as we might like to think we are, ready to pursue an unfettered sex life and mate and marry at random.
Indirectly, the findings also suggest that couples like those in my family who break out of cultural confines do so at more than the usual risk to a harmonious relationship.
 
Limited Choices
 The authors, an economist, Dr. Robert T. Michael, two sociologists, Dr. John H. Gagnon and Dr. Edward O. Laumann, and a graduate student in sociology, Stuart Michaels, point to strong incentives that prompt people to date others who are like themselves. In a companion volume, "Sex in America (Little, Brown $22.95) written with Gina Kolata, a science writer for The New York Times, they explain: "Not only do the man and woman in a partnership have sex together, but they share conversations and meals, they decide which movie to see on a Saturday night and which radio station to listen to when they drive there. The more alike the individuals are -- the more they have similar intellects and interests, for example -- the easier it is to share their lives. If a man and a woman also have similar levels of education, are of similar ages and similar social and religious backgrounds, it may be even easier for them to share their lives."
If only from a logistic perspective, people with similar backgrounds are most likely to meet one another -- at school, work, parties, clubs or social organizations or through introductions made by family members or friends. Sixty-three percent of the couples in the survey met through people who knew them both, and 60 percent met at places where people who are alike tend to congregate.
Many outsiders exert their influence. Those who feel they have a stake in a match pass judgment on its suitability and thus affect the stability of the relationship. How well will the partner you choose fit into your social, professional and family milieu? Will the partner get along with your friends? Will he or she be accepted -- or better yet, welcomed -- into the family fold? A professional woman with a graduate degree is not likely to choose a mechanic who never finished high school. Nor is a white man from a politically and religiously conservative family likely to bring home a woman who is a Black Muslim.
Personal issues enter in as well. The researchers say, for example, that people with similar ethnic, racial and religious backgrounds are more likely to be sexually compatible. "Some sexual preferences, like oral sex, are closely related to a person's race and social class," they point out. Partners with similar backgrounds are also more likely to agree on how to bring up children, sharing views on discipline, guidance and nurturing.
The bottom line, according to the survey authors, is that "likes attract each other because the partnerships between similar people work best."
 
Solving Problems
 Although my husband and I are thrilled with our expanding international family, our own experience in reconciling differences in our backgrounds should serve as a warning to our sons that they may face more than the usual challenges involved in making a marriage work. While open communication is essential to the success of any close relationship, "mixed" couples especially need to be certain that their messages are not only spoken and heard but understood and dealt with.
A reticent Garrison Keillor type who is a master of indirection speaks a different language from that spoken by an aggressive New Yorker who always says what is on her mind. The Keillor type may take the voluble woman too seriously, whereas the woman may not even hear, let alone appreciate, the significance of what the man is saying.
Also important is to try to avoid behaviors -- social, sexual and relational -- that, as a result of the partners' disparate backgrounds, are embarrassing or distasteful to either of them. Rather than ignoring such sensitivities or constantly trying to change one another, the couple must acknowledge and accept differences or else equitably resolve them in ways that preserve the individuality and self-esteem of each partner without undermining the integrity of the relationship.
Molly Haskell, a film critic who describes herself as "a Southern WASP, repressed, poised" and "totally committed" to her marriage to a man of Greek heritage who is "rumpled, swarthy, explosive," concluded that "the success -- or failure -- of these seemingly odd couples depends to a great extent on the success of both partners in establishing their viable independence. At the first sign of weakness or failure, the difference in background can become more exasperating than exotic."
For some mixed couples, the societal obstacles are especially difficult to surmount. The survey authors note that "some of the most vehement proscriptions are against homosexual couples; almost as forbidden is interracial dating." The adjustments required of such couples can be made even more challenging if, as in the case of Romeo and Juliet or Abie and his Irish Rose, families oppose the match or disapproving friends desert the couple. Love does not always conquer all.

HEADLINE: One Nation, One Vote? That's Not Fair

SERIES: CLINTON & CONGRESS -- An occasional series.

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is a senior editor at Harper's Magazine.

 BODY:
When Congress takes up the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade next week, it should focus on diplomacy, not economics. It should give particular scrutiny to the treaty's proposed offspring, the World Trade Organization, which could cause immeasurable damage to American diplomacy for years to come.
Contrary to the claims of Vice President Al Gore and other Administration spokesmen, the future of world trade does not depend on GATT. Whether the treaty is ratified or not, world trade will continue to grow as it has for half a century. Nor, despite the claims of right-wing isolationists and left-wing consumer advocates, is sovereignty -- ours or anyone else's -- at stake. By definition, a treaty requires signers to forgo certain exercises of authority or "sovereignty." 
 The most important thing at stake in the debate over GATT is American power. Can America still convert its military and economic power into preponderance in international organizations? Apparently not, on the evidence of the treaty that the Bush Administration negotiated and that President Clinton is pushing.
For four decades, the United States has protected its interests and made the most of its influence in trade negotiations under GATT. In effect, the U.S. has always had a veto in GATT, which has operated by consensus since 1959 (the last time a formal vote was taken). But that veto is about to be taken away.
If Congress ratifies the new treaty, GATT's loose working arrangement will be replaced by the World Trade Organization, which has frequently been described as a United Nations for world trade. That analogy is off the mark.
When negotiating the U.N. Charter, American diplomats were careful to balance the General Assembly, in which every country has one vote, with the Security Council, whose permanent members -- the great powers -- are able to protect their interests with a veto over any collective action. The World Trade Organization would give the great powers no such advantage; it would be nothing more than a General Assembly of world trade.
The U.S., despite its enormous importance in the world economy, would have neither a veto nor a weighted vote (as it has in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank). The treaty provides that in most cases decisions "shall be taken by a majority of the votes cast" and that "each member of the W.T.O. shall have one vote."
Cuba would have as much voting power as the U.S. Eighteen members would have populations of less than a million; the votes of many of these tiny countries might be up for sale in return for investment or arms.
Japan might round up enough ministate votes to bar U.S. trade laws intended to pry open its markets. The European Community has already published lists of U.S. trade measures it would like to see struck down. It could use the trade organization to do so, perhaps with the help of Eastern European and African proxies.
The consequences for American diplomacy may be even more serious. If the U.S. endorses the rule of one nation one vote in the World Trade Organization, other countries may insist on that principle in the design of other international bodies.
Suppose that the U.S. decided to support the creation of a new Pacific security forum. The best institutional arrangement for the U.S. would give weighted votes or vetoes to the great powers -- America, China and Japan, and perhaps India, Russia and Indonesia. But tiny countries like Singapore, grown accustomed to having as much pull as the U.S. in the World Trade Organization, might insist on the right to outvote the U.S. in Pacific security matters.
GATT's proponents argue that the U.S. will be protected by a clause allowing members to quit the World Trade Organization on six months' notice. But if we join, the same voices will be heard stridently denouncing the very idea of withdrawal as a threat to the world economy and an abandonment of U.S. leadership. Countries hostile to our economic interests will correctly dismiss the threat of American withdrawal as a bluff.
Yes, GATT contains minor market-opening measures that would benefit us. But these can be obtained by future negotiations. In fact, we don't really need global consensus on trade matters. Most world trade takes place among the U.S., Europe and Japan. Other countries have little choice but to go along with the arrangements they agree upon.
The potential benefits of the treaty are not worth the endorsement of the one nation one vote principle as the basis for the first major international organization to be established after the cold war. By torpedoing the World Trade Organization, Congress would not damage America's prestige, as the Administration claims. Rather, it would demonstrate that the U.S. is still a great power that insists on its prerogatives in international organizations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed: Series

HEADLINE: Dole and Clinton Strike a Deal on World Trade Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton today struck a deal with the prospective Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, that appeared to rescue a world trade agreement scheduled for a vote at a special session of Congress next week.
The compromise with Mr. Dole raised the hope of a measure of bipartisanship in foreign policy between the White House and the new Republican-controlled Congress. 
 After weeks of haggling with Administration officials, Mr. Dole received many of the concessions he had demanded. At noon today he appeared in the Rose Garden, shook Mr. Clinton's hand and declared that his reservations about the 124-nation accord, an expansion of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, had been resolved.
The major concession by the Administration, he said, was to give Congress a "trigger mechanism" that would enable it to vote to withdraw from the agreement if it felt the United States was subject to unfair rulings by a newly created court of international trade. "I think we've fixed it," said Mr. Dole, who had come under tremendous and conflicting pressures in recent days from businesses that declared the pact vital to American competitiveness and from conservatives who said it would give panels of foreign judges the right to override American laws. "It may not be perfect, but it answers a lot of the concerns."
To reach today's compromise, Mr. Dole backed away from an effort he began last weekend to get the Administration to go along with a cut in the capital gains tax, long a Republican objective, in exchange for his support for the trade pact. In the end, he settled for a letter from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen to consider the issue next year.
The agreement accomplished two goals for Mr. Dole: he appeared to have toughened the agreement -- though not enough for his conservative critics -- while satisfying corporations that would be his most vital source of support if he decided to seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996.
By making concessions to Mr. Dole, Mr. Clinton is sidestepping what Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a floor manager of the bill, termed near-certain defeat in the Senate, where 60 votes will be required to approve the agreement.
"We did not have the votes," Mr. Moynihan said today. "We weren't going to get them. The problem was, there were 35 Republicans who were Senator Dole's supporters." Without Mr. Dole's support, he said, "it can't be done."
The House is scheduled to vote on the trade agreement next Tuesday. Passage there, by a simple majority, seems nearly assured. The Senate vote is set for Thursday.
Both White House officials and Mr. Dole's aides, while differing somewhat on the nuances and effects of the agreement they struck, declared that the trade accord had demonstrated that the President and the future majority leader could work together and that paralysis was not the destiny of the 104th Congress.
"We have moved one step closer toward gaining broad bipartisan support for GATT," Mr. Clinton said today, clearly relieved that passage of his Administration's largest international economic initiative now seemed assured. "This agreement requires all trading nations to play by the same rules, and since the United States has the most productive and competitive economy in the world, that is good news for our workers and our future."
But the Administration paid a price for Mr. Dole's support. It agreed to create a commission next year that will ultimately give Congress a far greater voice in the question of whether the United States should remain a member of the newly created World Trade Organization, the institution that will act as a rule-setter and a judge in the disputes over international trade.
The commission, consisting of five Federal appellate judges, will review all the organization's rulings against the United States and determine whether they were fairly reached. Under what Mr. Dole termed today a "three strikes and we're out" rule, if the commission finds three unreasonable rulings, Congress can initiate moves to withdraw from the World Trade Organization. Under the rules of the agreement, any country can withdraw with six months' notice. Before the Administration's concession to Mr. Dole, that was assumed to be solely the decision of the President.
Mr. Dole is hoping that the change he extracted will be enough to silence opponents of the agreement. That is a disparate group that includes consumer advocates like Ralph Nader, trade hawks like Ross Perot and conservatives like Senators Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina.
All of the pact's critics have contended that the new trade organization will effectively have the power to rule against any American laws -- from environmental protections to laws against the purchase of goods made by child labor -- that it judges to be a barrier to imported goods. The result, they argue, is a loss of sovereignty for the United States.
The Administration responded that the concerns were vastly overblown, because the World Trade Organization would have the power not to force a change in American law, only to impose trade penalties if the United States refused to go along with its rulings.
Still, the complaints about the loss of American sovereignty left the Administration in a quandary. It could not open up the trade agreement and change provisions without renegotiating its terms with all 123 other member nations, a step that would have undoubtedly killed an agreement that took a dozen years to negotiate.
On the other hand, defeat of the treaty in Congress would have killed any hopes of expanding GATT, an agreement that began in 1948 and has expanded in fits and starts since. It would have wiped out the broad tariff cuts that would aid American exports, and killed provisions providing new protections for intellectual property -- whether computer software or music -- and services in which American industry is most competitive.
But Mr. Dole clearly was not able to satisfy the right wing of his party, which has abandoned its traditional commitment to free trade and begun to describe agreements like the GATT as a sell-out of American economic interests. Today, Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who sought the Republican Presidential nomination in 1992 on a platform of "America First" in trade, said that the message of Mr. Dole's decision was that "money talks."
"All the big money in the Republican Party is pro-GATT, and all the populists are against it," Mr. Buchanan said today. "The party went with the big money, and stiffed the populists, to pay its campaign debts."

HEADLINE: Durable Orders Off 1.5% In First Drop Since July

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Orders for long-lived manufactured products, a closely watched predictor of economic activity, fell last month for the first time since July in what some economists regarded as a sign the business expansion might be slowing.
"This does perhaps indicate that the economic boomlet may be subsiding," said Lynn Reaser, senior vice president at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, as the Commerce Department reported a 1.5 percent decline in orders for durable goods, which range from camcorders to tanks. 
 But other economists disputed the idea that the report, though somewhat weaker on its face than expected, pointed to diminished activity in the nation's factories.
"There's an awful lot of orders in the pipeline," said Mark P. Vitner, economist at the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C., noting that orders for capital goods were 14.7 percent above those of October 1993. "I just don't see the slowdown out there."
Another skeptic was Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. Factories are "very much alive and well," he said, noting that durables figures are highly erratic and that main sectors that fell in October -- transportation and the military -- had surged in preceding months.
Separately, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment benefits were unchanged at 326,000 in the week ended last Saturday, with the four-week average edging up 500, to 326,750.
And the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence eased to 91.6 in November from 92.7 last month, according to subscribers to its survey.
The report on durable goods, products made to last at least three years, was dominated by a 9.4 percent drop for transportation orders. But analysts said this was not a sign of real weakness because of various production problems in the auto industry, where, because vehicles can be turned out virtually on demand, there is no distinction between orders and shipments.
Transportation equipment was about unchanged in September but had soared 20.1 percent in August. Excluding transportation, orders for durables climbed 1.1 percent in October.
Similarly, military orders slumped 16.9 percent in October, the first month of the new fiscal year, after gains of 11.6 percent and 10.8 percent, respectively, in September and August.
Not counting this sector, durable goods would have fallen eight-tenths of 1 percent, the report showed.
But the other major categories all posted gains, albeit fractional ones -- industrial machinery eight-tenths of 1 percent, electronic equipment five-tenths of 1 percent and primary metals three-tenths of 1 percent.
For capital goods alone, new orders fell 5 percent but this drop was pared to 2.9 percent, mainly reflecting communications equipment, when the military is excluded and to four-tenths of 1 percent when both the military and the aircraft and parts categories are excluded.
Shipments of durables last month fell 1.2 percent, the second straight decline and the third in four months, but this also reflected the big decline in auto production.
Unfilled orders edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, to $424.8 billion, the report also showed, with industrial machinery up 2 percent and primary metals up 3.4 percent.
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, pointing to a 1.7 percent advance in unfilled orders for nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft, said this indicated "growing backlog problems in the manufacturing sector of the economy and continued momentum going forward."
On the other hand, Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, said the decline in orders "clearly indicates the economy is slowing down."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Ukraine has a good chance of winning its dash for capitalism.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
LEONID KUCHMA, the President of Ukraine since July, made the rounds this week to convince Americans to come to the aid of his country. To no one's surprise, the blunt, poised politician -- once the manager of the Soviet Union's premier nuclear missile factory -- argued that Ukrainians were finally ready to take the plunge to free markets.
"We have no other choice," Mr. Kuchma said. 
 What may be surprising is that a lot of analysts jaded by the unfulfilled promises of post-Soviet reformers take his words seriously. Indeed, among Western advocates of a rapid conversion to a market economy in the ex-Soviet nations, enthusiasm for President Kuchma's plan borders on the unbridled.
"Ukraine," says John Mroz, director of the Institute for East-West Studies in New York, "could be the economic success story of 1995."
Before 1991 all lines of authority ran directly from Ukraine's bloated state enterprises to ministries in Moscow. That left the newly independent country of 52 million people without experience in managing the government budget or the economy. Even worse, says David Snelbacker, associate director of the Project on Economic Reform in Ukraine at the Kennedy School at Harvard, the long-Sovietized nation could not draw on the "collective memory of capitalism" enjoyed by Poles and Czechs.
Still, when the empire collapsed, Ukraine seemed to have a reasonable shot at economic success. Like Russia, the country was well endowed with natural resources and an educated work force. Unlike Russia, it had a decent transportation system and did not need to resort to police-state tactics to maintain ethnic peace.
Anything that could have gone wrong, though, did. The first nationalist government, led by Leonid Kravchuk, "was more interested in politics than policy," Mr. Snelbacker says. President Kravchuk refused to make unpleasant choices. He propped up obsolete industries, ran gigantic budget deficits to support social spending and financed imports -- notably, natural gas -- with loans from the other former Soviet republics.
The result was hyperinflation and a collapse in production. The World Bank estimates that prices doubled in 1991, rose fifteenfold in 1992 and another 41-fold in 1993. Anders Aslund, a Swedish economist at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington and an adviser to the new Government, says he believes national output is down by half since 1991.
As Mr. Mroz baldly puts it: "Ukraine was desperate for change, on the verge of economic and political collapse."
And change is what it is about to get. At first, Mr. Kuchma hardly seemed the sort to break the crucible. He was, after all, a man, in Mr. Mroz's words, from "the pinnacle of the military-industrial complex." But Westerners underestimated his pragmatism and political skill.
Apparently with little direct knowledge of economics, Mr. Kuchma surrounded himself with competent technocrats. Equally important, he alternately bullied and flattered the parliamentary opposition into submission.
President Kuchma's economic policies look like an amalgam of the shock therapy imposed in Poland in 1990 and the rapid privatization under way in Russia. Prices have been decontrolled. And thanks to the quiet resistance of the central bank in the waning months of the Kravchek administration, inflation is down to a level that is almost tolerable.
The next steps are more ambitious. One goal is to curb industrial credit, allowing nonmonopoly enterprises to profit from deregulation so that markets are used to determine the survivors. Another is to phase out the budget deficit, largely by eliminating subsidies. Still another is to raise domestic energy prices and eliminate barriers to exports. All these measures are to be buttressed by privatization financed by vouchers.
Mr. Aslund, who has seen equally grand plans scaled back in Russia, is nonetheless optimistic about Ukraine's dash for capitalism. For one thing, he argues, the collapse of obsolete industry has virtually run its course. For another, Ukraine's "social fabric is pretty much intact."
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank -- chastened by criticism of their bureaucratic inertia elsewhere in the former Soviet empire -- stand prepared to finance a good portion of the stabilization effort. What is unclear, however, is whether the rich industrialized countries will do their part: Neither the United States nor the European Union seems inclined to lend more than token sums for the effort.
Mr. Kuchma, who recently rammed through legislation confirming a promise to dismantle strategic nuclear weapons, makes no secret of his frustration. This may be the last chance for a long time, he suggests, to create a prosperous Ukraine to anchor stability in eastern Europe.
"It is a lot better to have visits from President Kuchma," explains the ex-missile maker, "than from the products he formerly produced."

HEADLINE: A Day to Give Thanks for Balloons;
A 'Balloonatic' Makes Air Sculptures for Macy's Parade

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
For 30 years, Manfred G. Bass has dreamed up and guided the creation of the balloons and floats of Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade. It is the only job Mr. Bass, a 59-year-old artist, has ever held, and the only one he ever really wanted.
"It's a work of love," he said, as he matter-of-factly fastened his official metal parade badge to his canvas overalls with industrial rivets, as always. "It's what makes the world go round. They're all giant toys, you know?" 
 So it was that Mr. Bass was at work yesterday, checking to make sure his beloved balloons were properly packed in their huge boxes for today's parade, handling all manner of last-minute transportation planning. He was far from alone in the former Tootsie Roll factory in Hoboken where what he calls his "air sculptures" are born. Volunteers, some from as far away as Michigan and Australia, were helping his staff of 20 pack boxes and load trucks with such wonders as his grinning new Cat in the Hat balloon.
"This is my favorite place in the whole world," said George Behn, who was there to escort the convoy through the Lincoln Tunnel and today will drive the emergency repair truck. He began doing this as a Macy's employee, then kept on volunteering after getting a job as a salesman for a competitor. "This is like Santa's workshop and I feel like a little kid in the middle of it."
It was part of a long tradition that appears likely to continue. Mr. Bass said that despite the recent purchase of Macy's by Federated Department Stores, he has neither seen nor heard of any change in Macy's commitment to the parade. In Cleveland, Dixie Barker, a Federated spokeswoman, confirmed his observation. "You can't mess with tradition like this," she said.
The actual event is the culmination of a long process. Already, he and his 20 self-described "balloonatics," including artists, sculptors, draftsmen, welders and animators, are thinking of ideas for the 1995 parade. In January, the serious brainstorming will begin, escalating through the months to this week's frenzied, sleepless pace.
Design, Mr. Bass said, can take many months. An important question is whether a figure is best presented vertically, like Bart Simpson, or horizontally, like Spiderman. Some like Big Bird are in between: the Sesame Street hero is about three-quarters vertical.
The presentation of the Cat in the Hat, the Dr. Seuss character making his premiere appearance in the parade this year, presented certain opportunities and definite challenges. His large, striped stovepipe hat provided a lot of volume to fill up with helium, helping to support him. But the cat as drawn in the book was woefully skinny.
This was solved by placing the cat on the vacuum-cleaner-like contraption he uses to clean up his extensive mess in the last part of the book. This provided valuable volume to be filled with buoyant helium gas.
By contrast, this year's other new character, Barney, the saccharine purple dinosaur, needed no such calculations. "Barney is a full-bodied character," Mr. Bass said.
Mr. Bass, the oldest of seven siblings, has always lived in New Jersey, except for a stint at the New York Phoenix School of Design in Manhattan, where he studied storybook illustration. In the Army, he worked as an artist and sculptured a 12-foot-high statue of an infantryman for Fort Benning, Ga., that was dedicated by President Eisenhower. Then in 1960, he became an assistant to the Thanksgiving Day parade designer, then an outside contractor.
Several years later, Macy's took over the parade as an in-house production, and named Mr. Bass chief designer. He attributes much of the success of the parade to the nearly 3,000 Macy's employees who volunteer their lunch hours to be drilled in how to handle the big balloons. A dozen or so others sit inside the turkey float, moving eyes and wings as internal puppeteers. Others help dismantle floats at Macy's even as others are just getting started from the American Museum of Natural History at 77th Street and Central Park West.
Leaders are also anointed. Some are trained in the intricacies of balloon flight and are called pilots. Others are captains, and taught to bark orders in the event of sudden wind shifts. "Move right, fast!" they scream, as crowds ooh and ahh.
"This is something you can't capture on TV," Mr. Bass said. "The effect is that of a huge sailing ship coming down the parade route."
The parade begins at 9 A.M. at the Museum of Natural History, follows Central Park West to Columbus Circle, then goes south on Broadway to Herald Square and east on 34th Street to Seventh Avenue.
Yesterday, the chief balloonatic was constantly on the phone, handling last-minute strategy. "Oh, brother," he muttered when informed of a windy weather forecast. Ahead was the task of getting some of the biggest floats, particularly the 40-foot-high Swan Princess through the 12 1/2-foot-high Lincoln Tunnel. Balloons, which travel in eight-foot-long boxes, are easier.
But the journey was made, and the inflation of the balloons began just after 3 P.M. at the staging area outside the museum.
"Just don't use the word blow up," Mr. Bass cautioned. "We get a little nervous when we hear that word."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The only job Manfred G. Bass, a "balloonatic," has ever had in his life is designing and building Macy's balloons for the annual Thanksgiving Day parade. Here he is with the Macy's star balloon, the first one to be inflated last night in preparation for today's big event. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)(pg. B4)
 
Chart: "AT A GALNCE: The Birth of a Balloon"
The balloons feature each year in the Macy's Thankgiving Day parade are complex undertakings. Making his debut this year will be the Cat in the Hat, the Dr. Seuss character. When the Cat in the Hat, along with 17 other balloons, heads down Central Park West this morning, it will mark the culmination of a long process.
 
THE BEGINNING
Workers begin brainstorming in January. First, a drawing is made, followed by a clay model from which is made a plastic mold. This is used to make a working model. Small patches are plces on the model's surface and used to create larger pieces for the actual balloon.
 
THE CONSTRUCTION
Volunteers, working in a loft on Hoboken, take about three months to construct a balloon. Each balloon takes 320 to 450 pounds of nylon, which is coated on both side with urethane. The seams are heat sealed.
 
THE DESIGN
This balloon has 14 chambers, which help in stabilization. Helium is used in the upper chambers, and a mixture of Helium and air is used in the lower chambers.
To allow for additional volume, the balloon's creators places the cat on a simplified version of the contraption he rides in the book. (Source: Macy's)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 
A flaw in the Pentium, the top chip made by Intel, can cause inaccurate calculations in certain rare cases. Intel said the chip would not have to be recalled. But many scientists and engineers who depend on precise calculations are concerned. [Page D1.]
 
Gibson Greetings and Bankers Trust settled a lawsuit over derivatives. Gibson agreed to pay Bankers Trust nearly $6.2 million, or about 30 percent of the $20.7 million that Bankers claimed it was owed in the trades between the two. [D1.] 

Sorry, Charlie: H. J. Heinz and Leo Burnett are parting ways after 27 years. The Burnett agency created familiar advertising characters like Morris the finicky cat and Charlie the tuna. [D1.]
 
Pfizer will buy SmithKline Beecham's animal health business for $1.45 billion in cash. The deal would make Pfizer the world's largest maker of animal drugs, topping Merck. [D4.]
 
Kmart is seeking ways to save as much as $800 million in two years in addition to store closings and job cuts. [D4.]
 
A Federal judge froze a New York brokerage account of a British businessman accused of illegal insider trading. [D4.]
 
The F.T.C. is seeking data on alliances with Caremark International, in a broadening of an investigation of relations between drug makers and managed health-care drug distributors. [D4.]
 
Metallgesellschaft of Germany plans to write down the paper value of its shares by half in an effort to rescue itself. [D4.]
 
I.B.M., AT&T, Apple Computer and Siemens plan to create a universal communication language for computers. [D5.]

Markets
 
After a roller-coaster session, stocks ended slightly lower. The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell just 0.16 point, easing investors' concerns that stocks were in for a long, hard descent. [D1.]
 
A stock slide is not likely to change Federal Reserve policy. Indeed, stocks' strength until now surprised Fed officials. [D6.]
 
Stock markets fell sharply across Europe as investors took their cue from Wall Street and sought refuge in bonds. [D6.]
 
Treasury prices climbed for a second day, continuing to attract investors fleeing the stock market. [D15.]
 
The dollar was stronger against most currencies. [D16.]
 
Crude oil and heating oil prices surged, lifted by colder weather and a strike by Brazilian oil workers. Copper prices fell. [D16.]
 
The Economy
 
PC-based services may play a big role in holiday shopping, but not this year. Two efforts are coming to market too late. [D1.]
 
Orders for durable goods fell 1.5 percent in October, suggesting that the business expansion might be slowing. [D2.]
 
Oil prices could rise by $2 to $3 a barrel in a year, industry analysts said, because of OPEC's plan to freeze production. [D7.]
 
A record number of Americans are expected to travel this week, spurred by bargain air fares and stable gasoline prices. [B24.]

HEADLINE: Many Turn Holiday Into Mini-Vacation

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Spurred by bargain air fares and stable gasoline prices, a record number of Americans were expected to travel over Thanksgiving week, traditionally the busiest travel time of the year.
And although many people have long taken off the Friday after Thanksgiving, this year, travel experts say, more are viewing their long weekend as a time for both holiday visits with families and friends as well as a chance to sightsee, shop or ski. 
 "Instead of journeying to Grandma's house near home, many families will spend Thanksgiving a good distance from home, treating the holiday as a mini-vacation," said Jerry Cheske, who monitors travel patterns for the Automobile Association of America.
Henry Blinder, a spokesman for Thomas Cook Travel/American Express, said, "We're noticing that more people than usual are also taking off Friday this year, in addition to Thanksgiving Day, and using it for vacation travel."
A record 30.4 million Americans will travel at least 100 miles this holiday, one million more than last Thanksgiving, according to the automobile association's estimates, and 66 percent say they will stay with friends or relatives.
But the actual number of Americans traveling is likely to exceed even those heady estimates, since the survey, prepared for the automobile association by the U.S. Travel Data Center, the research arm of the Travel Industry Association of America, was taken before a recent spate of discount airfares -- most notably United Airlines fares as low as $9.97 between San Francisco and Los Angeles.
All 5,600 seats offered at that fare, valid for travel from noon today to noon Saturday, sold out in just over 24 hours. The airline originally planned to charge $9.99, said Joe Hopkins, a United spokesman, but it settled on the even lower fare when its obdurate computer insisted on rounding off $9.99 to $10. The revenue from those fares, about $40,000 after taxes, is going to homeless groups in San Francisco and Los Angeles.
Other airlines have also offered Thanksgiving bargains, most of them aimed at leisure travelers, said Chris Chiames, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association. As a result, Mr. Chiames said, the discounts should enable the airlines to fly with planes fuller than even the early predictions. The association estimates that the percentage of seats filled on Sunday, the day most travelers will head home, will average a whopping 80.3 percent, or almost 1.7 million passengers, compared with a usual percentage on other days of roughly 65 percent.
While neither the Air Transport Association nor the A.A.A. necessarily recommend it, both organizations agreed that Thanksgiving Day is the least hectic day during this holiday for travelers to get where they are going and back.
Even before the latest holiday discounts, average domestic air fares were down 3.3 percent from last year. And the 2.6 percent rise in the cost of travel for the 12 months through September 1994 lagged behind the 3 percent rise in consumer prices, according to the U.S. Travel Data Center.
Moreover, most travelers will journey by car this holiday, and while gasoline will cost almost a nickel a gallon more than last Thanksgiving, averaging $1.17 for self-service regular unleaded, the price of gas adjusted for inflation remains a travel bargain. And the two-thirds of travelers who will stay with family and friends presumably will save enough on hotel bills to help offset other expenses.
One such traveler is Rick Putro, 34, a Portland, Ore., hairdresser, who flew last night to a friend's house near Santa Fe, N.M., to enjoy what he described as "some fun, sun and snow." Four other friends were coming from Dallas, Los Angeles and San Louis Obispo, Calif.
Yet the change in traditional travel patterns is also spurred by the increasing attractiveness of shorter and more frequent getaways among families that have to juggle conflicting home and work schedules.
This is true for Clement G. Motten's family. A widower, he has two daughters in suburban Philadelphia, a daughter in Seattle and a son, daughter-in-law and two grandsons in Durham, N.C. All will gather today for a reunion in Williamsburg, Va., the restored colonial city that served as the British capital and the capital of Virginia.
"When the kids were growing up we used to go there once a year for a winter weekend," said Dr. Motten, a retired professor of history at Temple University and a resident of Haverford, Pa. Williamsburg not only remains steeped in history and tradition, but, Dr. Motten said, it was most convenient place to get together.
Kim Rawlings, 25, a paralegal in Houston, has things other than football on her mind once she arrives at her parents' home in Baton Rouge, La. -- things like eating a big dinner, watching a parade on television and doing lots of talking with her parents, maternal grandparents and two older brothers. "Most of the time my grandmother grills me on my personal life," she said. On this holiday, many hotels will be relatively empty, but Manhattan hotels expect to do well. "All 805 of our rooms are sold out and our four restaurants are already booked solid," said Tom Civitano, executive vice president of marketing at the Plaza hotel. The guest list, he said, is top-heavy with families.
The occupancy rate at Manhattan hotels has already risen to 74.8 percent through September, from 69.6 percent during the same period last year, according to Coopers & Lybrand, but many hoteliers expect a further increase because of the recent repeal of the 5 percent state tax on hotel rooms costing $100 or more.
Even visitors who do not check into Manhattan hotels were expected to swell city streets for Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade and for visits to museums and shops.
Partly to offset the drop in their restaurant business, hotels from Niagara Falls, N.Y., to Newport Beach, Calif., were advertising Thanksgiving Day dinners and buffets. The Hyatt Regency Hotel in Phoenix has added a twist -- turkey dinners to go, aimed mainly at households with people who do not have time to cook for their Thanksgiving visitors.
One of the most unusual Thanksgiving treats was be offered yesterday at the 20-room Morenci Motel in the tiny mining town of Morenci, Ariz., which served a free turkey dinner that was offered to all elderly people in the area.
"We usually serve about 400 people from all over the area," said Jackie Lindhorst, the motel manager. For the motel and the community, she added, "It's one of the most special days of the year."

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Hint the U.S. Could Use Port Again

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Fearing China, Vietnam has begun to signal an interest in inviting American naval forces back to Cam Ranh Bay, the large port installation built by the United States during the Vietnam War.
The United States Navy seems interested in returning. Adm. Richard C. Macke, the commander of American forces in the Pacific, said on his recent trip to Vietnam that Washington and Hanoi could begin talking about military cooperation after settling their final differences over accounting for missing American servicemen from the Vietnam War. 
 On Cam Ranh Bay, he said, "I'm a naval officer and naval officers are always looking for good ports." He was responding to reporters' questions at a news conference in Hanoi on Oct. 26 after meeting with the Vietnamese Prime Minister, Vo Van Kiet.
After the fall of South Vietnam in 1975, Hanoi made Cam Ranh Bay's deep-water harbor and port installation available to the Soviet Pacific Fleet, whose submarines and surface warships were regularly stationed there for more than a decade.
But China has expressed its opposition to a renewed American presence at the base.
"We are opposed to any foreign country establishing a military base or stationing troops on foreign soil," said Shen Guofang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman.
The United States has been without a major naval base in the region since 1992, when the Philippines decided not to renew the American lease on the base at Subic Bay. The importance of finding forward bases in the Pacific for American forces and their equipment was underscored in discussions last week between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Southeast Asian leaders.
Mr. Christopher tried to persuade Thailand to reconsider its opposition to accepting "equipment afloat ships" in its coastal waters as a means of positioning tanks, artillery and ammunition that could support an American military expedition to the region.
For Vietnam, which fears that China will one day use military power to enforce its claim over the entire South China Sea and its potentially rich oil reserves, the desirability of inviting American forces back into the disputed neighborhood is a form of insurance against what is seen as Chinese hegemonism.
At the time of Admiral Macke's visit to Hanoi, Vietnamese Foreign Ministry officials expressed a keen interest in opening talks with the United States on an "access agreement" on Cam Ranh Bay.
In Beijing, Mr. Shen, the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said that China welcomed the normalization of relations between Washington and Hanoi, but he admonished the two former belligerents to focus on economic development and not military cooperation.
"We believe that all countries in Asia are committed to their own economic development and that all countries in this region will benefit from regional peace and prosperity," Mr. Shen said.
Some American diplomats in the region cautioned that the United States, which takes no position on the disputed islands and oil leases of the South China Sea, should try to avoid being pulled into a territorial dispute.
"Of course the Vietnamese would love to have us back in Cam Ranh Bay," one Western diplomat said, indicating that Washington would have to take care not to be manipulated by the parties in the dispute.
China, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, Taiwan and the Philippines all assert territorial claims to islands in the South China Sea.
But in 1992 China asserted sovereignty over virtually all of the South China Sea and its islands. It has twice clashed with Vietnamese naval forces, ejecting them from one set of islands in 1974 and from another set in 1988.
China, Vietnam and Taiwan have been the most aggressive in patrolling the area and in establishing a continuous presence on some of the larger islands.
