HEADLINE: OPEC Move May Spur Sharp Rise in Oil Prices

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Oil prices could rise by $2 to $3 a barrel within a year because of the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to freeze production at current levels while world consumption rises, industry analysts said yesterday.
The decision to hold the group's total production at 24.5 million barrels for another year was announced on Tuesday, at the conclusion of a meeting of OPEC's oil ministers on the Indonesian resort island of Bali. 
 "Taken all together, it seems to mean higher prices," said Cyrus H. Tahmassebi, chief economist for Ashland Oil.
Oil prices rose yesterday for the second day, with crude for January delivery gaining 33 cents a barrel, to $18.15, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Higher prices for oil and products like gasoline seem likely, the analysts said, because all the requisite trends are running in OPEC's favor.
World demand outside the former Soviet Union is expected to climb by 3 percent this year, a rise of 1.8 million barrels a day, to 63.3 million barrels of oil consumed daily.
Next year, the demand is projected to increase by another 1.6 million barrels, or 2.5 percent, unless the economies of some large countries like the United States experience sharp declines.
But some experts and analysts say prices will begin to rise significantly in the latter half of 1995.
If the United Nations lifts the embargo imposed on Iraqi oil exports because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the increased production could undercut the OPEC freeze. But some analysts said that scenario might not be realistic.
Mr. Tahmassebi said OPEC's strategy would be to have each member of the group cut back on production so the flow of new Iraqi oil could be absorbed and the overall production level maintained.
Analysts also doubted that Iraq could revive its production so fast.
"It will take years for them to get to three-million-barrels-a-day production," said John H. Lichtblau,chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a private consulting firm based in New York. In the early stages, he estimated, Iraq may be able to export only 500,000 to 600,000 barrels a day.
"That's a level that would not be difficult to absorb," he added.
In general, OPEC hopes to tighten supplies as demand increases. In the past, that has forced consuming nations to find alternate sources of oil like those in the North Sea, an area that developed rapidly after the oil embargo in 1973.
Higher recovery rates from existing North Sea fields have led to more oil being produced than was anticipated. In the last two years, that helped hold down oil prices. The extra North Sea production is now expected to level off.
Analysts agreed that there were no other significant new sources that could disrupt OPEC's strategy.
Adam E. Sieminski, an oil analyst with NatWest Securities in Washington, said Russia was the only country outside OPEC with a big reserve production capacity.
But, he said, Russian oil exports have dropped to about 2.2 million barrels a day this year. That is down from the 3.5 million barrels a day that Russia used to sell abroad. Production has been disrupted by the turmoil in Russia's move toward a free-market economy.
But the poor maintenance of the Russian pipelines and terminals that are needed to ship oil overseas also makes it unlikely that Russia can increase its exports if the world price goes up.
At the same time, Mr. Sieminski said, Saudi Arabia, which has taken the lead in advocating OPEC's present course, will have to be careful not to let oil prices escalate too much, because they could disrupt the robust growth of some economies and ease demand.
"It's a delicate balance," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
For Giuliani, a Checklist; For Pataki, Opportunities

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
WHEN the big day finally comes next week, and the pending power of Albany finally meets the reigning regent of New York City, what will they say to each other? The imagination roars.
Maybe they will exchange home phone numbers so they can reach each other before 9 A.M. and after 5 P.M. Maybe they will thank each other: Governor-elect George E. Pataki could thank Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for boosting his chances, maybe even for electing him, by endorsing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and campaigning upstate for him. And the Mayor could thank the Governor-elect for giving him even more acceptance with New York City Democrats than he already had. 
 But since such expressions of gratitude are not too likely at this ice-breaking session, it is more realistic to assume that the two men will discuss at least some substantive issues, the kind Mr. Giuliani said he considered when he endorsed Mr. Cuomo. New York City's problems are still there. Mr. Pataki has, as a peace offering, already agreed to veto two bills that Mr. Giuliani opposes -- one that would prevent the Mayor from using state school aid to help close his budget gap, the other that would increase public employee pensions.
WHAT else could be on the Mayor's wish list?
The budget: A fifth of the city budget comes from the state, not counting separate payments for Medicaid. Any reduction in state aid, or even a failure to keep pace with inflation, would hurt.
Education: Mayors have long argued that the city doesn't get its fair share of state money for education. With 37.4 percent of the state's students, it gets 34.5 percent of the state aid, because of opposition from the Republican-dominated State Senate, of which Mr. Pataki has been a member since 1992. Perhaps being Governor will change his perspective.
Two other huge costs are special education, with 139,500 students at an annual cost of more than $1.5 billion, and language education for 147,531 students with limited English proficiency, at a cost of $167 million. Any effort the Mayor and Governor made together to push the Board of Education to cut expenses and improve the programs would have to help.
The next Governor could also help the Mayor get more control over the Board of Education.
Mass transit: Will Mr. Pataki help the city avoid a fare increase and renovate its subway stations?
Medicaid: It is, after education, the second largest city expense -- $2.5 billion out of the $32 billion budget. That's why Mr. Giuliani wants a state takeover of Medicaid.
Mr. Pataki has said he would support a takeover only if the state can pay for it in Medicaid savings -- a highly unlikely prospect. The Governor could also try getting the Legislature to restrict Medicaid spending, like putting time limits on the very expensive personal care program for the elderly and disabled.
Pensions: A Pataki veto of the pension bill would help, but the new Governor could do more. The exorbitant pension system allows police officers and firefighters to qualify for generous, tax-free disability pensions if they say they injured themselves on the job, even if the injury was slight and they continued to work. The infamous "heart bill" is a controversial state law qualifying officers and firefighters with heart ailments for higher disability pensions on the presumption that the condition is work-related.
The watershed: If the state fails to protect land surrounding the upstate reservoirs from development, the city will have to build an expensive filtration plant. The plant might have to be built anyway, but it surely will if the reservoirs are despoiled. Mr. Pataki's ambiguity on this figured heavily in the Mayor's decision not to endorse him.
The homeless: The next Governor could lift a state rule requiring the city to house its homeless immediately. Because New York often fails to comply, a judge has cited the city for contempt.
Welfare: The Mayor might ask Mr. Pataki to pick up more of the city's Home Relief bill. Home Relief is a welfare program for adults without children that gets no Federal money; the state and local governments share the cost.
Secession: Mr. Pataki supports the secession of Mr. Giuliani's stronghold, Staten Island, from New York City. Perhaps the Mayor can get the Governor-elect to reverse himself.
Appointments: The Governor makes appointments to a number of boards and agencies that wield considerable influence over the city's finances. Mr. Giuliani might ask the Governor-elect to consider that when he names members of the Financial Control Board, the Urban Development Corporation, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and other panels.
Relations with Congress: If they get along well enough, Mr. Pataki could volunteer to act as a liaison between Mr. Giuliani and the man in line to be the next chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

HEADLINE: NEEDIEST CASES;
A Family Comes Back From a Slow Descent Into Poverty

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Twice a day she leaves the half-light of her apartment and gingerly circles the block, savoring the sharp air and grasping at normalcy after months of illness and loss.
Life as Mary Wolfe knew it ended last October, when the security-guard company she ran with her three sons failed for lack of business. As they searched fruitlessly for new jobs, hope turned to panic, and Mrs. Wolfe, 57, developed a heart condition. 
 By March, her family owed $12,000 in rent on its home in Bayside, Queens. Mrs. Wolfe had lost 40 pounds, and her fine dark hair was streaked with white. One morning she had a seizure, ending up in the emergency room. It was the first of five hospital visits.
"All of the sudden, everything was coming to a end," she said. "Some people see these problems coming for years, but they hit us out of the blue."
Too sick to fight her impending eviction, Mrs. Wolfe called the Community Service Society of New York. It won her a two-week extension in housing court, then helped her negotiate the welfare bureaucracy. With the extra time, Mrs. Wolfe and her sons found a small apartment near their old home. Her former landlord forgave most of her debt, and the Community Service Society paid the arrears on her phone and electricity bills.
In this city of extremes, Mrs. Wolfe is among thousands of poor and sick people who received help this year from the Community Service Society and six other charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund is to begin its 83d annual appeal on Sunday and, as in past years, thousands are expected to contribute. The Times pays for the overhead of the campaign, giving donations directly to the charities.
This year, as state and city budget cuts threaten social-service programs and the percentage of poor New Yorkers receiving public assistance is falling, charity officials say the need for private donations is urgent. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget cuts would phase out money for soup kitchens, cut 1,900 openings in day-care centers and reduce financing for substance-abuse programs, among other things.
"For the first time in our history, we will have to use private donations to supplement public funds," said Philip Coltoff, executive director of The Children's Aid Society, which receives Neediest Cases money. "Individual contributions will be crucial to keep our programs functioning."
New York City is finally recovering from a long recession, but the going has been painfully slow. Although jobs are gradually returning to the metropolitan region, many of them pay minimum wage, and increasing numbers of employed people have incomes below the poverty level. Most charities supported by Neediest Cases say donations have remained flat or decreased this year.
That points to another problem: many New Yorkers, charity officials say, are nonchalant about and even resentful of the ever-growing ranks of the poor.
"There's a lot of free-floating anger toward people who can't defend themselves," said Megan E. McLaughlin, executive director of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, another of the seven organizations helped by Neediest Cases. "More than ever before, we have made the poor into pariahs."
The Neediest Cases Fund dates to 1911. Even then, poverty in New York City was as obvious as homeless families huddled on the sidewalk, and as hidden as elderly couples who survived for months on soup and bread. In 1912, 117 contributors gave $3,630.88. Last year, nearly 13,500 people donated $4,590,568.69, the second-highest amount in the campaign's history.
The campaign will have to be at least as successful this year to keep pace with charities' growing needs, said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Foundation, which administers the fund.
"Field caseworkers trying to restore wasting lives, especially those of children, need our support more than ever," Mr. Gelb said. "Our goal is to make this a banner year so we can help fill the harsh void created by the cutbacks."
Neediest Cases money supports programs as various as day care for the elderly, job training for immigrants and pregnancy prevention. It has supplied shelter for victims of domestic violence and birthday parties for homeless children. And it has provided emergency money for people who, like Mrs. Wolfe, plummet unexpectedly into poverty.
Last week, Mrs. Wolfe sat in her sparsely furnished living room and wept as she recounted her recent good fortune. Her 27- and 24-year-old sons have found steady jobs, and her heart condition has improved thanks to medication and daily walks. When Mrs. Wolfe was hospitalized this summer, social workers at the Community Service Society offered emotional support and helped her apply for Medicaid and other benefits. When her 22-year-old son was injured in a car accident, the charity paid his portion of the rent for a month.
There are still obstacles to stability. Mrs. Wolfe's youngest son is still recovering from the accident, and the others work long hours to make the $1,100 monthly rent. Food stamps don't provide enough groceries, so the family often turns to a local church for necessities. And an ungentle reminder of bad luck -- instructions for cardiopulmonary resuscitation -- hangs on the refrigerator.
But hope has returned, and Mrs. Wolfe said she does not look back.
"They gave me my life back," she said, leaning over a vase of artificial flowers as if their smell had a sweetness only she could detect. "If you've got someone promising that you're going to get through, I tell you, it means a lot."

HEADLINE: Late Season's Greetings From PC Shopping Plans

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Everyone knows Santa can deliver his gifts in a twinkle, and overnight delivery services are only hours slower. The real bottleneck in the holiday shopping season is the time it takes to go shopping.
Two new companies are trying to solve the problem, turning to a combination of computer-based on-line information services and interactive CD-ROM disks that can store dozens of product catalogues. 
 If all goes as planned -- and the history of home shopping technology suggests that it will not -- shoppers may become cyber-Santas, soaring through virtual malls where the only creature stirring is the computer mouse. But most experts predict the new services' impact will not be felt until holiday season 1995, rather than this year.
There is little likelihood, of course, that CD-ROM and on-line service sales will do away with printed catalogues any time soon. The nation's 100 million households are pelted by an estimated 15 billion catalogues in the course of the year, according to Jupiter Communications Inc., a research firm in New York. Some companies send glossy catalogues as frequently as 13 times a year, while others send them only before the holidays.
Computer-based shopping systems are more efficient than home shopping by cable television or even by printed catalogues, advocates say, because consumers can search quickly for specific items of interest. One system even uses automated assistants to help select the perfect gift for a hard-to-buy-for relative, and even remind the shopper of birthdays and holidays ahead of time.
"People don't have enough time," said Thomas C. Burt, chief operating officer of 2Market, a computer-based shopping service announced this week by Apple Computer Inc., America Online Inc. and Medior Inc. "Convenience was the key word in the '80's, but we've got to go a step past convenience in the '90's."
The 2Market system stores more than two dozen product catalogues on a single CD-ROM disk, which can be viewed on a personal computer screen. The company has begun to send out 275,000 CD-ROM catalogues that are linked to America Online's information network. America Online currently has 1.2 million subscribers.
The system also provides a software helper that can recommend a list of gifts if the shopper provides criteria like a cost range for the gift, the age and sex of the recipient and the recipient's special interests.
Another new company, Contentware Inc. of New York, has persuaded J. C. Penney, Spiegel, Marshall Field and other retailers to place their catalogues on 400,000 CD-ROM disks and on the Internet's World Wide Web, as well.
"2Market and the others are basically coming to market too late," said Lisa Johnson, a research analyst with Link Resources Inc. of New York. "Christmas catalogues start arriving in August and these guys are coming after Thanksgiving." She did predict that interactive shopping's impact on gift sales will be felt next year.
Ms. Johnson noted that the promise of PC-based, push-button shopping has been touted for several years without noticeable results. But several developments could give the technology the legitimacy it now lacks, she and other analysts said:
*The installation of millions of multimedia computers with CD-ROM players in the home, expected to reach 15 million households in 1995.
*The rapid growth of consumer on-line information systems, which now have nearly six million subscribers in the United States, not counting the Internet.
*The entrance into the on-line information and Internet businesses of giants including Apple, AT&T, I.B.M., MCI Communications and Microsoft.
*The rising cost of producing and delivering billions of glossy paper catalogues to millions of households year-round.
*The emergence of more secure methods for transacting business over computer networks.
But if the technical framework is coming into place, the psychological and behavioral foundation of consumers may prove more intractable. Many consumers have balked at on-line shopping, in part because the mechanisms for ordering and paying for products are clumsy and insecure, even in the newest systems.
"People have varied needs when it comes to shopping," said Mr. Burt of 2Market. "Some are mission-oriented and practical, while others are browsers who love to shop. By using CD-ROM and on line, we can deliver advertising in ways that meet the needs of both those who love it and hate it."
Kathey Hale, senior analyst for Dataquest in San Jose, Calif., said the market research company recently convened a focus group of several dozen "big-income people with limited amounts of time" and discovered, to her surprise, that "their biggest hot button was being able to shop at home by themselves with their computer."
Yet because the 2Market and Contentware systems are making their debuts so late in the year, they are unlikely to have a significant impact on this year's holiday sales.
"But next Christmas should be very merry indeed for on-line providers if these early adopters are any indication," Ms. Hale said.
The Dataquest findings would seem to contradict a nationwide survey of 1,000 adults reported last month, in which computer-based shopping ranked last among 14 possible services when Americans were asked to rank their interest in interactive services. The ability to "shop for and buy goods and services you called up on the TV or computer screen" elicited a "very interested" response from just 6 percent of the people surveyed. Only 32 percent cited any interest at all.
The survey, sponsored by the newsletter Privacy & American Business and conducted by Louis Harris & Associates, found 64 percent of respondents had made a purchase from a catalogue or brochure sent to their home or office.
Companies like 2Market and Contentware, as well as some analysts, say the national survey was misleading because it asked people to comment on technologies many of them had never heard of. Surveys of people who already use computers at home reveal a marketer's dream, these parties said.
"The demographics of catalogue shoppers are higher than those who do home shopping by cable," said Gene DeRose, editor in chief of the New York-based newsletter Consumer Information Appliance. "Computer users tend to have higher education and income levels than the average consumer and are more prone to do this kind of shopping from home because it is more efficient, it saves time and in many cases gives greater value."
Given those factors, Mr. DeRose said: "We expect to see significant displacement directly from catalogue to CD-ROM. Cataloguers are definitely aware of this and are going with the flow."
While the initial round of CD-ROM disks will be distributed next week without charge, both 2Market and Contentware plan to release updated CD-ROM disks quarterly and to sell them to consumers for the cost of postage and handling, typically $5 a disk.
CD-ROM offers several advantages over the on-line services, including ease of use, high-resolution color images, stereo soundtracks and the ability to search quickly through large amounts of information. The on-line services offer the advantage of nearly instant updates, allowing sellers to offer sale prices and special promotions that are not possible on a CD-ROM disk updated quarterly.
Also, the global reach of the Internet allows shoppers to peruse the contents of stores in New Zealand as easily as they would stores in New York.
There is no standard currently for secure financial transactions over the Internet or on on-line services, although several shopping services have proprietary data-encryption methods to safeguard credit-card numbers and other sensitive information.
MCI reported Monday that it planned to offer Internet-based shopping services using what it said would be a secure data system, and Microsoft has indicated it, too, will use some form of data security on its forthcoming Microsoft Network.

HEADLINE: Lower Stocks Aren't a Worry for the Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The steep fall in stock prices this week is not expected to prompt any policy review at the Federal Reserve, where officials have been surprised at the stock market's resilience until now.
While the Fed did not set out last week to bring down the stock market when it raised short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, its officials have not worried about such a prospect. 
 Fed officials are aware that falling stock prices hurt consumer confidence and make people feel poorer. Both effects can help the central bank in its goal of preventing the economy from growing so fast that shortages of raw materials and skilled workers develop, feeding inflation.
"To the extent people have been buying cars and houses with gusto, this cools things off," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said, "For many at the Fed, it's probably a not surprising byproduct of rising interest rates."
The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 4.4 percent in the last five days of trading while broader market indexes have dropped almost as much. Many market analysts have attributed the drop to a decision by money managers to shift assets from the stock market to the bond market. As the yields on bonds increase, 2 or 3 percent dividends on stocks become less attractive.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, warned in Senate testimony in May that stock and bond prices might have risen to unsustainably high levels by the beginning of this year because of the long drop in interest rates from 1989 through 1993.
"The resulting attractiveness of holding stocks and bonds was further enhanced by a nearly unbroken stream of capital gains as long-term rates fell, which imparted the false impression that not only were returns on long-term investments quite high, but consistently so," he said on May 27. "The recovery of the stock market after the October 1987 crash, along with the successful fending off of any significant adverse consequences from that event, may also have contributed to investor complacency."
The Fed did not change interest rates at the beginning of April, when long-term interest rates were soaring, stock and bond prices were tumbling and Wall Street traders were clamoring for another increase in short-term interest rates to reassure investors that the central bank would hold inflation under control.
"I don't think that we should be in the business of trying to, in effect, speculate ourselves on what long-term interest rates should be," Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Fed governor, said on April 4.
Mr. Greenspan waited until April 18, when financial markets had settled down, before raising rates by another quarter-percentage point.
Even if the Fed wanted to help the stock market, it might not be able to do so, said David C. Munro, an economist at High-Frequency Economics, a New York consulting company.
Further increases in short-term interest rates would worsen investor fears of a possible recession, while any reversal of last week's increase might so create an air of such uncertainty in policy that stocks and bonds might both fall, he said.
"It isn't obvious what if anything they could do that would be a help," Mr. Munro said.
Preston Martin, who was the Fed's vice chairman from 1982 to 1986, said the central bank would not worry about the stock market unless the recent downturn accelerated into a rout that threatened to disrupt the nation's financial system.
"I think they should be reasonably content, as long as you don't have 70 points, 90 points, 200 points, then 300 points," he said.
The Fed was sufficiently concerned about the possibility of market turmoil earlier this year that its first three rate increases, beginning on Feb. 4, were limited to a quarter of a percentage point each. "Many of us were concerned that a large immediate move in rates would create too high a dose of uncertainty, which could destabilize the financial system, indirectly affecting the real economy," Mr. Greenspan said on May 27.
The Fed stepped up its pace of raising interest rates with half-percentage-point increases on May 17 and Aug. 16. And on Nov. 15, it raised rates three-quarters of a point.
